html:
Overview

Raná is a very popular and historic paragliding site in the Czech Republic, located near Louny in the České Středohoří mountain range. Characterized by a bare ridge with three peaks reaching approximately 457 meters, it offers excellent soaring and thermaling opportunities. The site is used by multiple paragliding schools and attracts both local and international pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Ideal wind directions are from Southeast (SE) or Northwest (NW), but flying is possible with winds from East (E) to South (S), or from West (W) to North (N).
  • Wind Speed: Soaring is possible with winds over 4 m/s, but takeoffs are not recommended above 8 m/s. Stronger winds can cause turbulence.
  • Soaring Opportunities: There is a possibility of soaring in calm laminar air one or two hours before sunset, especially if XCmeteo forecasts soarable wind (around 5 m/s) between 500-1000 meters AMSL.

Who Should Fly Here?

Raná is suitable for both paragliding (PG) and hang gliding (HG) and is used by multiple paragliding schools. Caution is advised in stronger wind conditions, particularly in the saddle area and on the sides of the hill.

Pilots need a valid pilot license, a valid technical inspection of their wing, and insurance covering damages to third parties. An IPPI card is recommended but not required.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the site involves a 15-minute walk uphill.
  • Fees: Flying itself is free, but there is a parking fee on the SE side (approximately 2€, cash only, payable at the "Sklenik"). Parking on the NW side is free.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Stronger winds can cause stronger turbulence in the saddle area and on the sides of the hill.
  • Lee Turbulence: Lee turbulence can occur behind the main hilltop, especially with E to NE wind conditions.
  • Quarry Turbulence: A small, old quarry is located on the SE slope below the main hilltop. The area above this quarry, closer to the hill, can experience turbulence. It's safer to fly above the quarry than close to the slope.
  • Airfield Proximity: Raná airfield is located on the NW side. Pilots should not stay in the runway axis for thermaling or any other reason. Crossing the runway axis is allowed if no aircraft is landing or preparing for takeoff, especially gliders.
  • Airspace: Raná is under the edge of TMA (Terminal Control Area) Praha. The bottom of the TMA is at FL065 (approximately 1980 meters AMSL).
  • Landing Restrictions: Landing in fields on the NW side is prohibited, except after harvest and before winter sowing.
  • Zlatník Takeoff Restrictions: For the Zlatník takeoff there are specific restrictions and procedures: The time limit for flying from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. is in place. Zlatník belongs to ATZ Most, and planned traffic on the hill must be reported to the airport in advance.
  • "Dělící vrstva" (Dividing Layer): In the evening, a calm layer of air with no wind can form and rise from the ground, creating a turbulent dividing layer.
  • Operational Rules: Flying on Raná is permitted for anyone meeting the requirements set by Czech Republic's legal regulations. Local operation is specifically addressed in the "Provozní řád areálu Raná" (Operating Regulations of the Raná Area), approved by the main paragliding inspector of LAA ČR. The "Provozní řád" is available for review at the "Skleník" building.
  • Protected Area: Ranská hora is located in the first zone of CHKO České středohoří (Protected Landscape Area České středohoří). All movement in this area is governed by the operating regulations. All vehicle entry is prohibited. Ascending the southeastern slope along the fall line is prohibited. Dog owners must clean up after their dogs.

html:
Overview

Javorový vrch (Maple Mountain) is a popular paragliding site located in the northeastern part of the Beskydy Mountains, near the town of Třinec in the Czech Republic. Rising to 1032 meters above sea level, Javorový offers stunning views of the Polish side of the Beskydy Mountains and, on clear days, the Slovakian Tatras. As a recreation center with a tourist chalet and a funicular, it provides a convenient and scenic location for paragliding enthusiasts.

Flying Conditions

Javorový is known for its thermal and ridge soaring opportunities, making it a good site for cross-country (XC) flights. The site record stands at an impressive 112.6 km.

  • Takeoff Areas: Two launch areas are available on a ski slope below the Javorový Chata (Chalet): one facing north and one facing west.
  • Suitable Winds: The site is suitable for take-offs towards the north, west, or north-northwest. Winds from the north, northeast, east, west, and northwest are generally suitable. Be cautious of rotor effects during strong westerly winds and thermal north-western winds.
  • Flying Season: The typical flying season runs from March/April (after the snow melts) to October/November. Flights are possible year-round, weather permitting, but winter flying is infrequent.

Who Should Fly Here?

Javorový is a versatile site suitable for a wide range of pilots.

  • Experience Levels: Suitable for basic and advanced pilot training, recreational flying, and thermal performance flying.
  • Tandem Flights: Tandem flights are also a popular activity at this site.

Access & Facilities

Getting to the launch area is relatively straightforward, with convenient facilities available.

  • Funicular Access: Access to the take-off area is via a ski lift (funicular) that operates hourly. In summer, it typically runs from 8:00 to 17:00, and in winter from 9:00 to 16:00.
  • Ticket Costs: A one-way ticket costs 100 CZK, and a return ticket costs 150 CZK. Tickets can be purchased directly from the operator (cash or credit cards accepted).
  • Accessing the Launch: From the top of the lift, follow the footpath to the right towards the Javorový Chata.
  • Road Access: The road to the top of Javorový Vrch is generally restricted; access by car requires permission from Lesy ČR (Forests of the Czech Republic).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

Pilots should be aware of potential hazards and restrictions to ensure a safe flying experience.

  • North-westerly wind: Thermal north-westerly airflow on the northern launch can often be the reason for injuries.
  • Wind Direction and Strength: Launching in a north-westerly wind stronger than 6 m/s (above the trees) at the northern start is a hazard, even for experienced pilots.
  • Turbulence: Approaching the slope for landing can have turbulence because it is bordered by high voltage wires on two sides.
  • Northern Launch Hazards: The shape of the hill and growing spruces complicate airflow on the northern launch. Assess wind conditions from the western launch if you suspect a north-westerly wind.
  • Airspace: Paragliders and hang gliders are generally expected to stay outside of controlled airspace.
  • Regulations: Paragliding activity must comply with the laws of the Czech Republic.

html:
Overview

Kozákov is a popular paragliding site situated on the northern edge of the Bohemian Paradise (Český Ráj) in the Czech Republic, nestled between the towns of Turnov and Semily. Known for its thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying potential, Kozákov Hill offers a well-maintained grassy launch area and stunning views of the surrounding rolling hills and forests.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions:
    • South Takeoff (190°): Ideal with a southern flow.
    • West Takeoff (260°): Best suited for a western flow.
    • Northern Takeoff: A less frequently used option located near the ski lift.
  • Wind Speeds: Optimal wind speeds are between 2-5 m/s.
  • Thermals: Kozákov is well-known for its thermal activity, making it a popular site for cross-country flights.
  • Landing Areas: Landing areas are conveniently located next to the road on the way to the top of Kozákov and are marked with windsocks.

Who Should Fly Here?

Kozákov is rated as a medium difficulty site, attracting pilots of varying experience levels. The large, well-maintained launch area can accommodate at least 20 paragliders. However, southwest winds can cause turbulence, making conditions more suitable for experienced pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Take the road from Turnov to Semily, then turn off at Lestkov towards Kozákov. Continue past the "U Coufalů" restaurant, following signs for Riegrova chata and Kozákov.
  • Parking: Available near the Riegrova chata at the summit, a short walk from the launch area.
  • Permits: Required to fly at Kozákov.
    • Annual Permits (LAA Members): 200 CZK
    • Annual Permits (Non-LAA Members): 400 CZK
    • Daily Permits: 30 CZK
    • Available at the Paragliding Centrum Kozákov in Komárov.
  • Official Information: Obtainable at the Paragliding Centrum Kozákov in Komárov. Website: http://www.kozakov.cz

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • West Takeoff Turbulence: Turbulence can occur behind trees with a southwest flow; more suitable for experienced pilots.
  • South Takeoff Difficulty: Slightly more challenging due to the mild slope of the starting area.
  • Southeast Flow from South Takeoff: Possibility of turbulence; recommended for experienced pilots only.
  • Southern Side near Ski-tow: Not recommended due to adult trees and small space for forced landings.
  • Landing Hazards: Be aware of electric cables and trees along the field way when approaching the landing areas.
  • Turbulence: Be aware of potential turbulence, especially with certain wind directions and near the trees.

html:
Overview

Černá hora, meaning Black Mountain, is a popular paragliding site located in the Krkonoše (Giant Mountains) range of the Czech Republic. Known for its thermal activity and cross-country (XC) potential, it attracts pilots seeking varied flying conditions amidst stunning mountain and forest landscapes. Operated by Scelet Klub, the site offers well-maintained facilities and clear guidelines for safe and enjoyable flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Flying: Černá hora is renowned as a thermal flying site with good XC potential. The site is thermal active, offering varied flying conditions throughout the flying season.
  • Wind Direction: The recommended wind direction for takeoff is 160°-210° (South to West).
  • Best Flying Months: Spring, summer, and autumn offer the most favorable flying conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Černá hora is considered an easy site, suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including tandem flights. However, pilots should have good handling experience, especially for the schneisen start. The site can get very busy, particularly on weekends. School groups must contact the site authority at +420 777666747 prior to flying.

Access & Facilities

  • Access to Takeoff:
    • Via cable car from Jánské Lázně, followed by a 15-minute walk.
    • Alternatively, by foot from the landing area, following the yellow marked tourist trail (approximately 1 hour).
  • Fees: A launch fee is required to fly at Černá hora. Members of LAA (Aeronautical Amateur Association) receive a discount upon presentation of their membership card. Annual passes are available for purchase.
  • Vehicle Access: Vehicles with permits are allowed for transportation.
  • Landing Zone: The designated landing zone is a mown section of the meadow near road no. 297 Černý Důl – Janské Lázně.
  • Official Information: Official information, operating rules, webcams, and weather stations can be found at pgcernahora.cz.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Vrchlabí Airport (LKVR): The site is located near Vrchlabí airport. Pilots must strictly adhere to airspace regulations to avoid conflicts with air traffic.
  • Gliding Sector LKTRA50 Vrchlabí: Černá hora is on the border of gliding sector LKTRA50 Vrchlabí (lower limit: 1500 m AMSL, upper limit 7351 m FL). Exercise extreme caution when this sector is active.
  • Krkonoše National Park: The site is located within the Krkonoše National Park (KRNAP). Pilots must comply with the park's regulations, which include staying within designated flying corridors and landing areas. Landing outside of official landing areas may be considered trespassing.
  • Trees near launch: Be aware of trees approximately 20m high located 300m below the launch area and also on both sides of the launch site.

Flight Restrictions

  • Launch Site: Paragliding and hang gliding launches are only permitted from the designated launch site on Černá hora (50.6494N; 15.7399E; 1240 m. n. m.).
  • Landing Area: Only paragliders are allowed to land on the designated, mown area of the meadow next to road no. 297 Černý Důl – Janské Lázně (50.6339N; 15.7267E; 680 m. n. m.). This area is not for hang gliders.
  • Wind Limits:
    • Direction: 160°-220°.
    • Paragliding: 0-8 m/s.
    • Hang gliding: 3 - 10 m/s.
  • Instruction Restriction: Giving lessons is prohibited in this flying area.

html:
Overview

Krupka is a popular paragliding site located in the Ústí nad Labem region of the Czech Republic, high on the foothills of the Krušné hory (Ore Mountains). Offering a significant 400m height difference, this site is known for its thermal flying and ridge soaring potential. Open year-round, Krupka attracts both local and international pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Usable wind directions are from southeast to south.
  • Soaring/Thermal Flying: The site is known for thermal flying and ridge soaring, with a height difference of approximately 400m between take-off and landing.
  • Rotors: Be aware of potential rotors in strong east or southwest winds.
  • Landing Approach: It's recommended to start the landing approach when the pilot descends to 150m below the take-off.

Who Should Fly Here?

Krupka attracts pilots of various skill levels, but given the potential for rotors and the need to manage the landing approach, some experience is advisable. It is crucial to respect right of way rules and be aware of crowded launch sites.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easily accessible by car, public transport, or cable car (Lanovka z Krupky).
  • Public Transport: Buses run from Krupka square with specific weekday and weekend schedules to the Horní Krupka stop.
  • Fees:
    • Annual "helmet sticker": 500 CZK (approximately 20 EUR).
    • Daily allowance: 150 CZK (approximately 6 EUR).
    • Members of the Paragliding Association pay reduced fees: 300 CZK for the annual sticker and 100 CZK for the daily allowance.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Rotors: Unpleasant rotors can form above the launch site during strong easterly or southwesterly winds.
  • Overcrowding: Be aware of crowded sites, and respect priority rules.
  • Landing Restrictions: Landing on the football field is tolerated, but is not desirable, especially during sports activities.

For more information, visit the Paragliding klub Krupka LAA ČR z.s. website: pgkrupka.cz or paragliding-mapa.cz.

html:
Overview

Svatobor is a popular paragliding site nestled in the scenic Šumava region of the Czech Republic. Located on the Svatobor mountain in the Šumavské podhůří range, it offers significant altitude and stunning views. Officially recognized and maintained, Svatobor is known for its thermaling and soaring opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Takeoff Locations:
    • Svatobor SV: Suitable for wind directions from 45° to 90°.
    • Svatobor JZ: Suitable for wind directions from 210° to 250°.
    • Svatobor II. Jihozápad: Best for wind directions between 170° and 230°. This takeoff is at an altitude of 825m AMSL with a height difference of 300m.
  • Type of Flying: Thermaling and soaring.
  • Weather Considerations: Pilots should carefully assess wind speed, thermal currents, and visibility before launching.

Who Should Fly Here?

Svatobor is a popular site attracting pilots. While specific experience level recommendations aren't available, pilots are expected to have the necessary training, certification, and skills to assess conditions and safely manage their gliders.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The primary access to "Svatobor II. Jihozápad" is via a parking lot located below the observation tower. From there, a marked trail leads to the takeoff point.
  • Fees:
    • Daily Launch Fee: 50 Kč for members of the Svaz PG (Paragliding Association), 100 Kč for non-members.
    • Yearly Fee: 200 Kč.
    • Payment can be made via a QR code at the information board on the takeoff or on the website pgsumava.cz.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Tree Landing Hazard: Be aware of the risk of landing in trees, requiring potential rescue.
  • Svatobor SV Takeoff: There is currently no reported information regarding risks associated with the Svatobor SV Takeoff.
  • Airspace: Always check current airspace regulations before flying and be aware of controlled and uncontrolled airspace.
  • Operational Rules: As an officially designated flying site, flights are subject to launch fees and likely insurance requirements.
  • Protected Areas: Respect protected landscape areas (CHKO) surrounding the site.

html:
Overview

Skalka is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Moravskoslezské Beskydy region of the Czech Republic. Known for thermal soaring and cross-country (XC) flying opportunities, it is also a frequently used competition take-off site. Managed by the Beskydský letecký klub (BLK), Skalka offers a rewarding flying experience for pilots with some experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Optimal wind direction for take-off is from the Southwest to West (220°-280°).
  • Seasonal Operation: The site is generally operational year-round. There is a seasonal closure in place from September 15th to September 30th.
  • Thermal Soaring: Skalka is known for its thermal soaring potential.
  • Wind Considerations: Strong southern winds can create dangerous conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Skalka caters to a range of skill levels, from schools to competition pilots. While the terrain is used for practice flights, the launch area is relatively short and narrow. The site is not recommended for complete beginners, especially in strong southern winds. Sufficient airspeed is essential for a safe take-off due to the uneven terrain. Training flights are common at this site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Variable Winds: Strong southern winds can create dangerous conditions, including the risk of downdrafts (Úplav).
  • Turbulence: Expect turbulence when exiting the clearing if the wind is at limit angles, especially with stronger winds.
  • Short Launch Area: The launch area is relatively short and narrow and should not be underestimated.
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • Located near TMA II Ostrava, which begins at 4000 ft (1200m) AMSL, 1.2 km in the Northwest direction.
    • TMA VI. Ostrava is located 2.3 km NW and is always active, with a lower limit of 3500 ft / 1070 m AMSL.
  • National Nature Reserve: The launch is located within the Skalka National Nature Reserve; pilots are asked to respect the operating rules of the area.
  • Pilot Qualifications and Insurance: Pilots must have a valid pilot's license for the glider type, a valid glider technical certificate, and liability insurance.

Important Note: Always check with the Beskydský letecký klub (BLK) for the most up-to-date information, operating rules, and safety guidelines before flying at Skalka.

html:
Overview

Doubrava is a paragliding site located near the village of Poleňka in the Klatovy district of the Czech Republic. The site sits atop Velká Doubrava hill, offering a 280-meter elevation difference. Managed by PG Plzeň, it's an established site popular with experienced recreational pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Suitable for winds from 270° to 360°.
  • Turbulence: Be aware of potential turbulence at takeoff, especially with winds exceeding 310°.
  • Thermal Activity: Information on thermal activity is not specified in the provided reports.
  • Time Restrictions: Flying is permitted between 11:00 and 19:00 from April to October, and between 11:00 and 16:00 from November to March.

Who Should Fly Here?

Doubrava is best suited for experienced pilots. According to the operating rules, the site is not intended for training. The takeoff is considered moderately difficult ("středně obtížný") for both paragliders and hang gliders, especially in north-westerly flow, due to strong turbulence along the forest clearing.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the take-off is either by car or on foot. Vehicle access to the forest is restricted to members of PG Plzeň.
  • Parking: Parking is available near the landing area, with limited parking (max 3 cars for PG Plzeň members) near the take-off.
  • Coordination: Coordination for transport is done via the club's WhatsApp group.
  • Fees: There are fees associated with using the site: 120 CZK per day for members of the Czech Paragliding Association, and 180 CZK per day for non-members. An annual fee of 600 CZK covers all sites managed by the club (Doubrava, Švihov, Koterov).
  • Official Information: Official information, including the operating rules ("Provozní řád"), can be found on the PG Plzeň website: https://pgplzen.cz.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Strong turbulence can occur at the launch site when the wind is greater than 310 degrees, especially along the forest clearing with northwest wind.
  • Takeoff Hazards: The takeoff is a forest clearing near a transmitter. There are tall trees on both sides of the launch area and approximately 120 meters in front of the launch.
  • Airspace: Pilots flying XC should coordinate with LKKT airport operations (+420 376 570 757).
  • Klatovy Airport (LKKT): Doubrava is located close to the flight path of Klatovy Airport. Pilots must monitor the area east of Doubrava due to possible flight and parachute operations from Klatovy Airport. Minimize flights over this area. Check www.lkkt.cz/kalendar-akci.php for para operations at LKKT.
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • Approximately 26 km east is the D6 Stražovice boundary: GND-1000 AGL.
    • Approximately 32 km east is TRA68 Písek Boundary FL70-FL240, with information available from Praha Teren.
  • Forest Regulations: Adherence to Czech Forest Law No. 289/1995 Sb. is required, including prohibitions against:
    • Smoking, open fires, and camping outside designated areas. Open fires are prohibited within 50m of the forest edge.
    • Disturbing the peace and quiet.
    • Collecting forest fruits in a way that damages the forest.
    • Damaging or felling trees and shrubs.
    • Removing seedlings and saplings.

html:
Overview

Uhřínov is a paragliding and hang gliding site located near Milenov in the Czech Republic. Characterized by rolling hills and forests, the site offers a scenic flying experience with a launch altitude of approximately 420m above sea level and a height difference of 70-80m to the landing area.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Optimal wind direction for takeoff is between 160°-190°.
  • Wind Speed:
    • For paragliding, the recommended wind speed is 3-7 m/s.
    • For hang gliding, the recommended wind speed is 3-8 m/s.
  • Airspace: Pilots must be aware of restricted airspaces, including the edge of ATZ airport LKHN and the Libavá military area. A new restricted area to protect nesting eagles is in effect annually from December 1st to August 31st; check www.paragliding-uhrinov.cz, airspace.xcontest.org, aisview.rlp.cz and aup.rlp.cz for up-to-date information.

Who Should Fly Here?

While Uhřínov is a popular site, it may not be suitable for beginners, especially in weak wind conditions. The launch area is small and requires pilots to be proficient in launching.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the launch site is by foot.
  • Parking: Parking is allowed only in designated areas. Ensure you do not block access to the landing field for agricultural machinery.
  • Fees: There are no fees to use the site, but voluntary contributions for site maintenance are welcomed.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Launch Area: The small launch area can accommodate only one paraglider at a time, requiring confident launches with an immediate need to fly after takeoff.
  • Fire Hazard: Strict no-smoking policy at the launch site due to a high risk of fire in the dry area.
  • License & Documentation: Valid pilot license, necessary documents (technical certificate), and insurance for damages caused by the operation of Sporting Flying Equipment are required.
  • Activity Restrictions: The launch site may not be used for organizing races or paragliding schools.
  • Airspace Awareness:
    • Proximity to the edge of the LKHN airport's ATZ (Aerodrome Traffic Zone), where skydivers operate.
    • Activation of the Libavá military area (LKTSA3, LKTSA3A, LKTSA3B, LKD 13). Check NOTAMs before flight.
    • TMA IV Ostrava 1370m AMSL - 2900m (FL95).
    • TMA V Ostrava 1980m (FL65) - 2900m (FL95).
  • Eagle Nesting Area: A restricted area is effective annually from December 1st to August 31st to protect the nesting grounds of the Golden Eagle. Flying is permitted on the ridge south of the connecting line between Slavkovský vrch, Obírka, Kopánky, and the "Pod Drahotušem" blue trail crossing, allowing soaring up to the tunnels. Check current information at www.paragliding-uhrinov.cz, airspace.xcontest.org, aisview.rlp.cz, aup.rlp.cz, and www.laacr.cz.
  • Podhoří Restriction: There is a restriction when flying beyond Podhoří, implemented in February 2019.

Important Note: The legalisation of the launch site was stated to be valid from 2017 to 2026. Please verify its current validity.

html:
Overview

Jeviněves is a paragliding site situated in the Central Bohemian Region of the Czech Republic, specifically in the Mělník District. Known for its flat landscape typical of the Polabí lowlands, Jeviněves offers a suitable environment for both training and soaring. It accommodates both paragliding and hang gliding, including single and two-seater flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Optimal wind direction is between 90° and 160°.
  • Wind Speed: Ideal wind strength is between 4 and 7 m/s. Flying outside this range can be risky.
  • Soaring: The site is well-suited for soaring due to the terrain.
  • Suitability: Suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding.

Who Should Fly Here?

<

Jeviněves is particularly well-suited for beginners.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Accessible by car.
  • Parking: Parking is available near the windsock.
  • Fees: A fee of 40 CZK is required to fly, payable via a QR code located at the windsock.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Flying outside the ideal wind speed range of 4-7 m/s can be risky. Strong gusts can cause sudden altitude drops or canopy collapse.
  • Spring Conditions: Be aware that spring conditions can be stronger than autumn conditions.
  • Crowded Site: Exercise caution and be aware of priority rules when the site is crowded.
  • Takeoff Direction: Ensure the wind direction is within the optimal range of 90° - 160° for takeoff.
  • Minimum Wind Speed: Minimum wind speed 4m/s.

html:
Overview

Dolní Morava, nestled between the Orlické hory (Eagle Mountains) and Jeseníky Mountains in the Czech Republic, offers a unique paragliding experience integrated into a mountain resort environment. Characterized by its ski slopes and forested landscapes, Dolní Morava is a popular site known for its thermal activity and the potential for scenic flights towards Králický Sněžník mountain.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal & Ridge Soaring: The site is known for thermal activity, especially during spring and summer. Ridge soaring is also possible.
  • Wind Direction: Launching is recommended with wind directions from South to Northwest (270° to 330°).
  • Wind Speed: Suitable for wind speeds up to 6 m/s.

Who Should Fly Here?

Dolní Morava caters to a range of pilot skill levels. Its popularity and use for tandem flights suggest it's accessible to many, but pilots should be comfortable handling thermal conditions. A pilot qualification equivalent to APPI 3 or higher may be recommended.

Access & Facilities

  • Takeoff Location: The take-off is situated at the top of a black ski slope.
  • Winter Access: Access via the four-seater chairlift in the Sněžník ski area.
  • Summer Access: Access is by foot from the U Slona ski slope through the forest and up the black ski slope.
  • Fees: Expect lift fees to access the launch. Parking is available near the lower chairlift station, consult www.dolnimorava.cz/en/parking for up-to-date parking fee information.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Thermal Turbulence: Be aware of strong thermals and associated turbulence, especially during spring and summer.
  • Takeoff Challenges: The takeoff location on a black ski slope might present challenges depending on the season and ground conditions.
  • Wind Direction: Launching with winds outside the 270° to 330° range may be dangerous.
  • Airspace Regulations: Pilots should be aware of and adhere to general airspace regulations in the Czech Republic.

html:
Overview

Čerťák is a paragliding site located in the Ústí nad Labem Region of the Czech Republic, known for its opportunities for both ridge soaring and cross-country (XC) flying. Managed by the Paragliding club Krupka LAA ČR z.s., the site offers a unique flying experience with a maintained grassy launch area on a steep, rocky slope providing views of the Elbe River valley.

Please note that this site requires fees to fly. Detailed information can be found on Paragliding Mapa and the club's website (PGkrupka.com).

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: The prevailing wind direction is 340°-40°.
  • Flying Style: Suitable for ridge soaring and cross-country (XC) flying. The site sees an average of 17.5 XC days per year, with about 41 flights exceeding 50 km.
  • Best Time to Fly: Spring (April-May) is considered a good time for flying at Čerťák.
  • Landing Options:
    • Top Landing: Near the road behind the launch, requiring active piloting due to potential rotor. Fly past the power lines to reach the field beyond the road.
    • Bottom Landing (Precise Skills Required):
      • A small football field close to the site but surrounded by hazards (houses, river, road, electrified railway).
      • A sand pit (pískovna) near the Elbe River, offering more space but is further away.

Who Should Fly Here?

Čerťák is recommended for pilots who are skilled in active piloting and can manage landings in restricted spaces. Due to the potential for rotor and challenging landing areas, it is not suitable for beginners. Proficiency in handling rotor and executing precise landings is crucial.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: An official parking lot is available near the road, followed by a flat walk to the launch area. Public transportation is possible via bus to Podlešín, followed by a walk.
  • Shuttle: Shuttle options may be available through local pilots.
  • Fees:
    • Yearly sticker for the helmet: 500 CZK (20 EUR)
    • Daily fee: 150 CZK (6 EUR)
    • For members of the Paragliding Association: Daily fee is reduced to 100 CZK, and the membership fee is 300 CZK.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Pilot Skill: Only suitable for pilots who are proficient in active piloting and landing in confined spaces.
  • Rotor: Strong rotor in the area of the main launch, especially when landing on the hill behind the launch. AVOID landing in the launch area itself due to rotor; pilots have sustained serious injuries in this area.
  • Power Lines: Power lines exist near the upper landing area; pilots need to be aware of these when approaching to land on the hill. Fly far out to the field at least 300m past the road when attempting a top landing.
  • Landing Restrictions: Landing on the football field at the bottom is tolerated but not desired, especially during sports activities. The football field has nets around its perimeter.
  • Protected Area: Čerťák is located within the CHKO (Protected Landscape Area) České Středohoří.
  • Flight Restrictions: Potential flight restrictions in Průčelská rokle due to nesting of the protected falcon.
  • Airspace: Flights must comply with Czech Republic airspace regulations. Paragliding is generally permitted in Class E, F, or G airspace.
  • Takeoff Conditions: The launch is from a large, maintained meadow into a wide gap between trees, beyond which there is a steep, rocky slope.

html:
Overview

Zvičina, located in the Královéhradecký region of the Czech Republic, is a popular paragliding site renowned for its stunning hilltop scenery and excellent soaring conditions. With a 5-star rating on Paragliding Map, it attracts pilots seeking both ridge soaring and thermal flights, with potential for cross-country adventures.

Flying Conditions

  • Launch Altitude: Take-off points are situated around 640m above sea level, with a maximum height difference of approximately 195m.
  • Suitable Winds: Take-off is possible with winds from North (N), Northeast (NE), and East (E).
  • Soaring & Thermals: The site is known for both ridge soaring and thermal activity.

Who Should Fly Here?

Zvičina is best suited for pilots with good handling experience. If a school is using the site, they should contact the head authority by phone. Tandem flights are also possible here.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The site is accessible via a road leading to a parking area near the Raisova chata (mountain hut) at the summit.
  • Parking: Free parking is available.
  • Fees: There is a yearly fee of 50 CZK for using the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Rotor (South Takeoff): Be aware of rotor forming above the small structure near the upper ski lift in Northwest (NW) wind conditions.
  • Rotor (East Takeoff): Avoid flying over the ski slope in easterly wind conditions due to potential rotor.
  • LK TRA 50 Airspace (East Takeoff): The East takeoff is located within the LK TRA 50 airspace. Note: *It is crucial to confirm the current status of LKTRA 50 before flying, as some sources indicate it may have been cancelled at the end of 2018.*

html:
Overview

Řevničov is a paragliding site located in the Central Bohemian Region of the Czech Republic. It features a gently sloping hill suitable for ridge soaring, attracting local pilots looking for accessible flying opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Requirements: A minimum headwind of 4 m/s is necessary for takeoff to clear the trees.
  • Soaring: Primarily suited for ridge soaring, leveraging the slope for lift.
  • Weather Data: Pilots can reference the weather station at Raná (PgSonda) for conditions, and Windguru has a dedicated weather station.

Who Should Fly Here?

Řevničov is best suited for pilots with some experience due to the need for a good headwind and the presence of trees near the takeoff area. It's popular among local pilots, indicating a community atmosphere.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Takeoff is accessible via municipal land, with a 10-minute walk from the village where parking is available. Parking is limited near the takeoff.
  • Fees: The existence of fees is uncertain; further clarification may be needed from local authorities (paragliding-mapa site says "Tolerated. Flying? Fees.").

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Nesting Season: Avoid landing in fields during May and June due to the nesting season for game animals.
  • Wind Conditions: Ensure a minimum of 4 m/s headwind to clear trees on takeoff.
  • Traffic: Be aware of other vehicles using the access roads, estimated at 40 vehicles per day.
search_recs: Řevničov paragliding site information paragliding Řevničov CZ Řevničov paragliding club Řevničov takeoff paragliding

html:
Overview

Velký Javorník, located near Frenštát pod Radhoštěm in the Czech Republic's Beskydy Mountains, offers a popular paragliding experience. Managed by the Beskydský letecký klub, the site provides ridge soaring and thermaling opportunities with a north-east facing takeoff. The summit features a lookout tower with views of the Beskydy and Hostýnské mountains.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Suitable for winds between 340° and 050°. Western winds can make reaching the landing area difficult and can cause turbulence.
  • Soaring & Thermaling: Known for both ridge soaring and thermaling. The site complements the nearby Skalka site, providing alternative flying options.
  • Altitude Limit: Flights are possible up to a maximum altitude of 1200m AMSL due to the TMA 2 Ostrava Mošnov airport overhead.

Who Should Fly Here?

Velký Javorník is suitable for pilots of all experience levels. It's a popular training ground for paragliding schools and tandem flights. While the site itself is not very demanding, the narrow and short takeoff area requires sufficient airspeed.

Access & Facilities

  • Parking: The official parking lot is at the football field in Veřovice, a 5-minute walk to the landing area.
  • Takeoff Access: Driving to the takeoff is restricted to vehicles with permits. Commercial transport to the top is available for a fee (200 CZK per person).
  • Fees: Check http://obchod.blk-pg.cz/ and http://www.blk-pg.cz/startoviste/velky-javornik/#provozni-rad for potential fees and operational rules.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Expect turbulence with greater force if the wind is at its limit angles. Stronger western flows at takeoff can cause turbulence.
  • Uneven Terrain: The launch area has uneven terrain, requiring constant correction during takeoff.
  • Terrain Wave: The starting surface contains a terrain wave that can cause a short-term relief of the canopy.
  • Ravine: Under the start is a ravine several meters deep.
  • Narrow Launch Area: The launch area is narrow and relatively short, requiring sufficient airspeed for a safe takeoff.
  • Airspace: Flights are possible up to a maximum altitude of 1200m AMSL due to TMA 2 Ostrava Mošnov airport above the takeoff area and TMA VI Ostrava nearby.
  • TRAMTVJ: Pilots must be familiar with and adhere to the current vertical limits of TRAMTVJ and the boundaries of neighboring TMA Ostrava spaces before each start. Check the BLK website, Whatsapp group, or on-site for TRAMTVJ activation status.
  • Operating Rules: Pilots must respect the operating rules of the flying site.

html:
Overview

Zásada is a paragliding site nestled in the Liberec region of the Czech Republic, within the rolling hills of the Jizera Mountains. The takeoff point sits at 670m altitude. It is used for both paragliding and hang gliding.

Flying Conditions

Zásada is known for its slope soaring opportunities. The most favorable wind direction is between 120° and 150°.

Who Should Fly Here?

The site is moderately popular among local paragliding enthusiasts. While the specific skill level isn't defined, some experience is recommended due to potential hazards.

Access & Facilities

Parking is available along the road. Please note that driving onto the meadow or parking at the take-off area is prohibited. No information regarding fees for using the site is available.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Power Lines: Electric power lines are located on the LEFT side of the landing zone, requiring extra caution during landing approaches.
  • Airspace: Be aware that Class G airspace extends up to 300m AGL, and Class E extends from 300m AGL to FL95 (2900m).
  • General Czech Republic Restrictions: Ensure you possess a valid pilot license, necessary documents (technical certificate), and insurance. Respect restricted airspaces unless you have explicit permission to enter.

html:
Overview

Srbce is a paragliding site located in the Pardubice Region of the Czech Republic. Described as a "small soaring hill" ("Svahovací kopeček") directly at the landing field, it offers slope soaring opportunities. The takeoff is at 369 meters above mean sea level (MAMSL), with a 50-meter superelevation.

Flying Conditions

  • Takeoff Direction: Primarily suitable for winds from 260° to 280°.
  • Soaring: Ideal for slope soaring.
  • Altitude Restriction: Due to the TMA (Terminal Control Area) of Pardubice airport, flights are limited to a maximum of 300 meters AGL (Above Ground Level).
  • Weather: Check the weather station at http://maldaweather.aspfree.cz for current conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

While the description as a small hill suggests it could be suitable for less experienced pilots, it's crucial to assess conditions carefully. Caution and good judgment are necessary, considering a past accident due to a strong gust of wind. Pilots of all levels are welcome here.

Access & Facilities

  • Takeoff Location: 49.917N 16.0566E.
  • Access Road: When the ground is wet, avoid driving all the way to the landing area to prevent damaging the road.
  • Fees: The presence of formal fees is unclear ("? Poplatky" - "fees?").

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • TMA Pardubice Airspace: The maximum flight altitude is strictly limited to 300 meters AGL due to the Pardubice airport's TMA.
  • Local Sensitivities: Avoid flying over the village buildings, as locals are not pleased with gliders near their gardens. Fly above the edge and the forest around the village instead.
  • Site Rules: Consult the official flying rules ("Provozní řád") available at https://www.paragliding-srbce.cz/.
  • Wind Conditions: Be aware of potential strong gusts; a past accident occurred due to such conditions.

html:
Overview

Švihov is a paragliding site situated in the Plzeň Region of the Czech Republic, approximately 9 km north of Klatovy and 28 km south of Plzeň. Located in the Švihov Highlands, the site offers a scenic landscape of rolling hills and the Úhlava River.

Flying Conditions

  • Takeoff Orientation: Suitable for Northeast (NE), East (E), and Southeast (SE) wind directions (60°-145°).
  • Suitability: Appropriate for both paragliding and hang gliding, including tandem flights.
  • The flight terrain is located at the foot of a hill. Pilots should be aware of terrain features that could affect wind conditions and landing options.
  • Real-time Weather Data: Pilots can monitor wind and temperature conditions via a nearby weather station.

Who Should Fly Here?

Švihov is rated with 1 star on Paragliding Mapa. Consult local forums and the managing club for up-to-date recommendations on skill levels and current conditions to ensure a safe and enjoyable flight.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Takeoff is accessible by foot, a short walking distance from the parking area.
  • Parking: Parking is available in the lower part of the meadow. Parking is restricted to the right side of the meadow's edge, in a single row. Driving onto the meadow is prohibited.
  • The site is managed by Západočeský paragliding klub Plzeň z.s.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Fees: Flying at Švihov requires payment.
    • Members of the Czech Paragliding Association: 120 Kč/day
    • Non-members: 180 Kč/day
    An annual fee of 600 Kč covers all launch sites managed by the club (Doubrava, Švihov, Koterov).
  • Operational Rules: Familiarize yourself with the official operational rules for the Švihov - Tuhošť area, available online.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Always check the current NOTAM (Notice to Airmen) for any temporary restrictions or changes to the airspace.

html:
Overview

Suchomasty is a paragliding site located in the Central Bohemia region of the Czech Republic, within the scenic Český kras (Bohemian Karst) area. The Klonk takeoff point is situated near the village of Suchomasty and offers opportunities for ridge soaring.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: The ideal wind direction for the takeoff is between 200° and 260°.
  • Soaring: The site is known for ridge soaring, utilizing the steep slope/ridge.
  • Launch Characteristics: The takeoff is described as a steep edge. Although suitable for soaring, pilots should be aware that the laminar flow may not always be perfect due to the launch being slightly recessed.
  • Best Conditions: Typically found in spring.

Who Should Fly Here?

The launch difficulty is considered moderate. It is recommended that pilots be proficient enough to abort a launch if necessary. The site has a low popularity rating (1 out of 5 stars), so less frequented, but is still used.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the takeoff is by foot.
  • Parking: Parking is available at the bottom of the hill.
  • Trail: The trail to the takeoff requires pilots to cross a stream (via a log or stones) before walking uphill.
  • Fees: No information is available regarding any fees for using the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wires: Be aware of wires in the middle of the landing zone.
  • Non-Laminar Flow: The launch is slightly recessed, so laminar flow may not always be perfect.
  • Airspace: Flying is restricted to 1000 ft AGL (300 m) above the launch due to the TMA 1 Mošnov airspace.
  • Czech Republic Rules: It is essential to check the current rules and regulations for paragliding in the Czech Republic before flying.
search_recs: Suchomasty takeoff paragliding Suchomasty paragliding site information Czech paragliding Suchomasty (CZ) paragliding club Suchomasty

html:
Overview

Kalovy is a paragliding site nestled in the scenic Šumava region of the Czech Republic, offering pilots a chance to experience the beauty of its rolling hills and forests. Managed by the PARA DELTA CLUB Sušice and PARAGLIDING KLUB ŠUMAVA, this site provides a rewarding flying experience with ridge soaring and potential thermal activity.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: The site is best suited for northwest winds, specifically between 285° and 330°.
  • Soaring & Thermalling: Ridge soaring is a primary activity here. Thermalling opportunities may be present depending on the day's conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Launch Site Elevation: Kalovy I. Severozápad is situated at 710 meters above sea level, with a height difference of 200 meters.
  • Parking: Available near the landing area along the road or at the Rok village intersection.
  • Access to Launch:
    • By Foot: Directly behind the car service (autoservis).
    • By Car & Foot: Drive to the village of Rok, then follow a forest path on foot. Note: A permit from Městské lesy Sušice is required to drive to the launch area.
  • Fees: A daily launch fee is applicable:
    • 50 Kč for members of Svaz PG (Czech Paragliding Association).
    • 100 Kč for non-members.
    • Payment can be made via QR code found on the information board at the take-off or on the website.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Electrical Wires: Be aware of electrical wires bordering the landing area. Use caution during approach and landing.
  • Permit Required: Driving to the takeoff requires a permit from Městské lesy Sušice (Sušice Municipal Forests).

For more detailed and up-to-date information, including operating rules, please visit www.pgsumava.cz.

html:
Overview

Rašovka is a popular paragliding site located in the Liberec region of the Czech Republic, south of the mountain range that peaks above the city of Liberec. Nestled at 785m MSL with a 410m height difference, the launch sits on a clearing ("mýtina") within a forest. The site is an official (unpaid) flying site, well-regarded for thermaling and cross-country (XC) flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction:
    • Optimal wind directions range from 160° to 250° (SE, S, SW).
    • Avoid flying with easterly (E) winds due to potential turbulence.
  • Turbulence:
    • Be cautious of turbulence after launch, especially with southeasterly (SE) winds when flying through the trees.
    • Stronger winds can cause stronger turbulence in the saddle area and on the sides of the hill.
  • Wind Speed:
    • Recommended maximum wind speed: 8 m/s of homogeneous flow at the top of the hill for paragliding wings.
  • Seasonality:
    • Flights have been recorded throughout the year, but conditions may vary depending on the season.

Who Should Fly Here?

Rašovka is suitable for both 1 and 2-seater paragliders. However, caution is advised for less experienced pilots due to potential turbulence after launch. Ensure you are comfortable with thermaling and handling your glider in potentially turbulent conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access:
    • You can reach the launch by walking up the ski lift path or driving to the summit, followed by a walk along a forest path to the clearing.
    • The path from the parking spot involves walking on a paved road, then through a meadow that can get overgrown in the summer, and finally through a forest.
  • Car Access Restrictions:
    • Car access to the top requires a permit from the Obecní úřad (Municipal Office) in Proseč. Unauthorized vehicle entry is prohibited.
  • Fees:
    • The site is listed as "official (unpaid)," suggesting no fees are required for flying itself.
    • However, you need to acquire a permit for car access.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence After Launch: Be particularly mindful of turbulence, especially with southeasterly winds, as you fly through the clearing and the trees.
  • Wind Conditions: Avoid flying with East winds and be aware that stronger winds can cause stronger turbulence in the saddle area and on the sides of the hill.
  • Launch Area: The launch is a forest clearing into a cut/clearing, so plan your takeoff accordingly.
  • Car Access Restrictions: Vehicle access to the launch is prohibited without a permit from the Proseč Municipal Office.

html:
Overview

Cukrák is a popular paragliding site located near Prague in the Central Bohemia region of the Czech Republic, close to Černošice. The launch altitude ranges from 337 to 370 meters, with a height difference of 136 to 160 meters. While the site is tolerated, it is not officially certified, offering soaring conditions and potential for cross-country (XC) flights, especially in the spring.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Optimal wind directions are N, W, WNW, and NW. Takeoff directions range from 280° to 330°.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • Avoid flying behind the curve to the left of the launch in northerly winds.
    • Do not fly to the right of the launch in westerly winds.
    • Westerly directions with stronger winds are not recommended due to the Berounka valley creating a nozzle effect and turbulent thermals.
  • Wind Speed Limits: The maximum wind speed allowed is 8 m/s for paragliding and 10 m/s for hang gliding.
  • Soaring and XC: Known for providing excellent soaring conditions and good potential for cross-country (XC) flights.
  • Thermals: Westerly winds can bring strong and unpredictable thermals, especially in summer.

Who Should Fly Here?

Cukrák is suitable for pilots with some experience, particularly due to potential turbulence and wind conditions. Caution is advised when top landing in soaring conditions due to turbulence.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Park near the cottages and walk the last 300 meters.
  • Parking: During logging operations, park at least 10 meters away from any woodpiles.
  • Fees: It is considered tolerated, but payment requirements are unclear.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Landing: Landing is typically done in large meadows to the left of the launch, where horses often graze.
  • Turbulence: Landing on the upper field can be risky in soaring winds due to turbulence.
  • Berounka River Valley Effect: With stronger westerly winds, the Berounka valley creates a nozzle effect, potentially making it difficult to reach the landing field. Some pilots have reportedly ended up in the river due to this effect.
  • Rotor Risk: When starting with almost pure North wind there is a rotor behind the bulge to the right of the start.
search_recs: Cukrák paragliding regulations paragliding Cukrák Czech Republic Cukrák paragliding site information Cukrák paragliding access Cukrák paragliding club

html:
Overview

Brná is a paragliding site nestled in the Ústecký kraj region of the Czech Republic, within the Bohemian Uplands (České středohoří). The takeoff point boasts a 300m superelevation and a 180-210° aspect, making it suitable for slope soaring over the scenic Elbe river valley. Managed by the Paragliding klub Krupka LAA ČR z.s., Brná offers a rewarding flying experience for pilots familiar with dynamic conditions.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Best suited for southerly winds.
  • Soaring: Ideal for slope soaring.
  • Weather Resources: Monitor the "Krupka (PgSonda)" weather station, Windfinder, and Windguru for real-time meteorological data and forecasts.

Who Should Fly Here?

Given the potential for turbulence near the takeoff, Brná is best suited for pilots with intermediate skill levels. While specific popularity data is unavailable, logged flights and videos indicate that the site is regularly used by experienced pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Reach the takeoff point by car followed by a short walk across a meadow. Alternatively, use a taxi from Ústí nad Labem or take bus 9 to Nová Ves.
  • Fees: Flying at Brná requires a fee. A yearly "sticker" for the helmet costs 500 CZK (20 EUR), while a daily fee is 150 CZK (6 EUR). Members of the Czech Paragliding Association (Svaz paraglidingu) enjoy reduced rates of 100 CZK for a daily fee and 300 CZK for the yearly sticker.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Exercise caution due to potential turbulence, especially near the edge of the hill during takeoff.
  • Takeoff Risks: Be precise during takeoff. The launch area leads to a steep, rocky slope beyond the trees.
  • Nature Reserve: Be aware that Brná is situated within the CHKO České středohoří (Protected Landscape Area of the Czech Uplands). The slope immediately below the takeoff is part of the Sluneční stráň Nature Reserve. Respect the area and adhere to any guidelines provided by the flying club and landowner.
  • Nesting Falcons: Be aware of potential flight restrictions in Průčelská rokle (Průčely Gorge) due to nesting protected falcons.

Please be mindful of the natural environment and help maintain the site's good standing by following established guidelines and showing respect for the surroundings.

html:
Overview

Straník is a popular paragliding site located near Žilina in Slovakia, nestled within the Malá Fatra region. This accessible hill, reaching 769m, offers stunning panoramic views of the Little Fatra, Žilina Basin, Terchová Valley, and the Kysuce region. Known for its thermaling and ridge soaring opportunities, Straník attracts paragliders from Slovakia, the Czech Republic, and Poland, offering flights practically year-round.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Suitable for SE, S, SW, W, and NW winds. Take-off is possible in all directions except east.
  • Soaring & Thermals: Straník is well-regarded for both thermaling and ridge soaring, offering excellent conditions for distance flights.
  • Year-Round Flying: Flights are possible practically all year round.

Who Should Fly Here?

Straník is considered an easy site, making it suitable for a wide range of pilots. Basic paragliding courses often utilize Straník for flights from the large hill (400m elevation), so even relatively new pilots can enjoy the site. More experienced pilots will appreciate the excellent thermaling and soaring conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Accessible by car to a parking lot in the village of Zastranie, near the church. From there, it's a 15-20 minute walk to the take-off sites.
  • Landing: A landing site is conveniently located near the parking lot.
  • Fees:
    • 2,5€/day or 35€/year.
    • For members of LAA SR (Aeronautical Amateur Association of the Slovak Republic): 2,0€/day or 30€/year.
    • A lift to take-off costs 5€/ride or a pass for 5 rides costs 20€.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • Straník is located within the TMA (Terminal Control Area) of Žilina Airport and very close to its CTR (Control Zone).
    • Since 2013, a Free Fly Zone has been established as part of a TMA exclusion, but pilots must be aware of the specific boundaries and altitude limits.
    • Flights within airspace classes C and D are forbidden without two-way radio contact with ATC.
  • Free Fly Zone: Pilots must be aware of the Free Fly Zone's boundaries and altitude restrictions. This zone was created in cooperation with LAA SR (Aero Amateur Association of the Slovak Republic) and LÚ SR (Air Transport Authority of the Slovak Republic).
  • VFR Only: Only VFR (Visual Flight Rules) flights are permitted.
  • Terrain: While the site is described as having good landing options, the surrounding terrain can be rocky or rough, which could limit emergency landing options.
  • Weather Conditions: Pilots need to be aware of current and forecasted weather conditions and avoid flying in dangerous conditions.
  • Launch Permits: Use of the Straník takeoff area requires a seasonal, three-month, or daily permit purchased from X-air paragliding. A valid permit is indicated by a sticker on the pilot's helmet or a receipt.

Important Note: Pilots are recommended to fly at least 1 NM outside the published paragliding area. Operation of the takeoff area is only possible in accordance with the regulations of LAA SR and at the pilot's own risk and responsibility. Consult the X-air paragliding club website or contact them at vrabec@x-air.sk for the most up-to-date information.

html:
Overview

Donovaly is a popular paragliding site in Slovakia, situated between the Low Tatra Mountains and the Veľká Fatra National Park. With the takeoff point at Nová Hoľa (1343m), it offers scenic views and opportunities for both ridge soaring and thermaling.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Flyable wind directions include SE, S, SW, and W from the main takeoff. Other takeoffs allow for N, NE, and E winds.
  • Year-Round Flying: Flying is possible throughout the year, depending on weather conditions and the operation of the Nová hoľa cable car.
  • Flight Types: Tandem paragliding flights are common, with flight times of 10-15 minutes and altitudes between 200-500 meters. Longer thermal flights are also available.

Who Should Fly Here?

Donovaly is a popular site suitable for a range of pilots. The main takeoff at Nová Hoľa is considered easy. Tandem flights are a common activity, requiring no previous paragliding experience for passengers.

Access & Facilities

  • Access Options: Access to the Nová Hoľa takeoff is available by car, public transport, cable car, or walking.
  • Cable Car: The cable car operates during the winter ski season and every half hour in the summer.
  • Hiking: Hiking takes about an hour in spring and autumn.
  • Fees: The price of a tandem flight varies depending on the operator and flight type, ranging from approximately 60 EUR to 150 EUR, generally including equipment rental, insurance, and pre-flight instructions. A multi-ticket for paragliders/cyclists is also available for the chairlift.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Landing areas can have turbulent conditions. Avoid flying over buildings and parking areas near the chairlift. The preferred landing area is to the west, behind the lift, in the middle of the landing area.
  • Landing Difficulty: The landing is considered medium difficulty.
  • Airspace: Paragliding in the Slovak Republic is governed by the Directive LZ 1 issued by the Flight Amateur Association of the Slovak Republic.
  • Designated Area: The area around Donovaly is marked with a paragliding and hang gliding symbol on aeronautical charts, designating a circular area with a 1.5 NM (nautical mile) radius centered on the takeoff area, extending vertically from the ground (GND) to the upper limit of Class G airspace. Pilots are advised to fly at least 1 NM outside the published paragliding area for increased safety.
  • Nová Hoľa Takeoff Risks:
    • NW Winds: Rotor from Zvolen peak (higher peak to the NW) is possible in strong NW winds.
    • Ski Season: When using the E, SE takeoff, make sure you are off the ski slope during the ski season.

html:
Overview

Horná Súča is a paragliding site located in the Trenčín Region of Slovakia. With rolling hills and small ridges, the area offers scenic views for pilots. The takeoff is situated at 551m above sea level, providing a height difference of approximately 150m.

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable Activities: Paragliding, hang gliding, and tandem flights are all permitted.
  • Wind Directions: The site is best suited for wind directions from North, West, and Northwest (270°-359°).
  • Wind Speed: A minimum wind speed of 2 m/s is required.
  • Soaring: Known for ridge soaring.

Who Should Fly Here?

While the popularity and recommended experience level aren't explicitly stated, the availability of tandem flights indicates that less experienced pilots can enjoy the site under the guidance of certified instructors.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The site can be accessed by car and on foot.
  • Fees: There is a fee of 2€ per day or 10€ per year to fly at the site. More information is available at paraglidingnm.sk.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Terrain: The launch site is on Holý Vrch, a ridge approximately 1.5 km long with a South-Southeast orientation.
  • Turbulence: The terrain is not prone to strong turbulence.
  • Airspace: The takeoff is located near Trenčín airport, approximately 10 km to the south. Pilots must contact the Trenčín airport tower (tel. number 032/6565255) during flight operations, particularly LOT flights, to report activity or flight paths.
  • Certification: Note that the site is not certified.
search_recs: Horná Súča paragliding club Horná Súča paragliding site information paragliding Horná Súča Slovakia Paragliding Slovakia official sites

html:
Overview

Sľubica is a well-regarded paragliding site in the Košický kraj region of Slovakia. Located on a mountain ridge with a takeoff altitude of 1113m, it offers a substantial 420m elevation above the landing zone. The landscape features meadows, fields, and small villages in a 10km wide valley, sheltered by the Levoča Mountains to the north and the Slovak Ore Mountains to the south. The peak of Sľubica (1129 m. n. m.) is the third highest peak of the Branisko mountain range.

Flying Conditions

Sľubica is known for its excellent cross-country (XC) flying potential, with popular closed circuits and triangle routes. The site is best suited for winds from SW, W, and NW, with optimal wind speeds up to 4 m/s. Pilots can expect predictable thermic activity both on the ridge and in front of Sľubica. The flying season here typically offers good XC weather conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Sľubica is a popular site, with tandem flights and courses frequently organized. Given its XC potential, this site is best suited for intermediate to experienced pilots looking to log some distance. Be prepared for potentially weak wind at launch.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The takeoff is reached via a 3km hike on a macadam road. Driving to the top is prohibited, except for the local club.
  • Fees: A fee of 2€ per day or 20€ for the whole year is required to fly here.
  • Contact for transport/access: 0915918406 or 0918477180
  • Parking: Available in Dubrava.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Strong Thermals: Exercise caution, as strong thermals can develop approximately 300 meters south or west of the takeoff.
  • Weak Wind at Launch: Be aware that the wind can often be weak at the launch point.
  • Airspace:
    • To the West of the takeoff, the Class G airspace extends to a maximum altitude of 2450m AMSL towards Jablonov.
    • From Jablonov towards Levoča, the maximum height is 300m AGL.
    • TMA Poprad (Terminal Control Area) is located approximately 10 km to the west, behind Spiš Castle, about 3 km to the West of the Jablonov border.
    • The takeoff Sľubica is near TMA Poprad.
  • General Slovakian Airspace Regulations:
    • Paragliding and hang gliding in Slovakia are governed by Directive LZ 1 issued by the Flight Amateur Association of the Slovak Republic.
    • The paragliding area is defined as a circle with a 1.5 NM radius centered on the takeoff, extending vertically from the ground to the upper limit of Class G airspace.
    • Pilots are advised to fly at least 1 NM outside the published paragliding area for increased safety.
search_recs: Sľubica paragliding site official information Sľubica paragliding site Paragliding Sľubica SK Sľubica paragliding club Sľubica flying conditions

html:
Overview

Martinské hole is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Malá Fatra mountain range, near the city of Martin in the Turiec region of Slovakia. Known for its thermalling and cross-country (XC) flying potential, this site offers a significant elevation difference of approximately 1000 meters. The wide, gently sloping highland meadows on the crest of the ridge provide excellent conditions for experienced pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Suitable for East (E), Northeast (NE), and Southeast (SE) winds.
  • Wind Speed: Maximum recommended wind speed for launching is 6 m/s.
  • Thermals: The long, south-facing ridge and the vast Turiec valley create conditions for strong and consistent thermals.
  • Cross-Country (XC): Known as a good XC area in the region, with FAI triangles flown over 200km.
  • Ideal Season: Typically from April to October.

Who Should Fly Here?

Martinské hole is well-suited for intermediate to experienced pilots (IPPI 4 or higher) due to the potential for strong thermals and XC flights. The site is suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including tandem flights.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Possible by car, public transport, cable car, or on foot. An asphalt road leads to the ski resort area and chalets.
  • Launch Area: Veľká lúka, located near the upper station of a six-seat chairlift. Managed by the X-air paragliding club.
  • Landing Area: Spacious meadow near Autocamping Turiec. Inspect the landing area for power lines before flight.
  • Fees: No fees to use the launch site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Maximum Wind Speed: Do not launch if wind speed exceeds 6 m/s.
  • Thunderstorms: Monitor weather conditions and land immediately if dark clouds appear.
  • Vegetation: After takeoff, the grassy launch area transitions into forest vegetation.
  • Turbulence: Be aware of potential turbulence from strong gusts of wind and unexpected downdrafts.
  • Airspace: Located within an uncontrolled airspace.
  • Paragliding/Hang Gliding Areas: Fly at least 1 NM outside the published paragliding and hang gliding areas.
  • Radio Contact: Mandatory two-way radio contact.

html:
Overview

Orešany, situated in the Trnava region of Slovakia near the villages of Horné and Dolné Orešany, offers a fantastic paragliding experience at the foothills of the Little Carpathians (Malé Karpaty) mountains. The launch site, Slepý vrch (Blind Peak), stands at approximately 543 meters and provides a dominant ridge for launching and soaring.

Flying Conditions

  • Launch Direction: The recommended launch direction is southeast (wind azimuth 110°-170°).
  • Soaring: Known for thermal soaring, which facilitates relatively easy cross-country (XC) flights. The recorded XC distance is 56.7 km.
  • Wind Considerations: Pilots should be aware of potential rotor caused by surrounding trees, especially when the wind is not directly aligned with the launch direction. Strong winds can occur throughout the year. It's crucial to check wind direction and speed before flying.
  • Altitude Limit: Flying is permitted up to 300 meters above the terrain.

Who Should Fly Here?

Orešany is frequently used and is considered suitable for intermediate pilots. Beginners should exercise caution due to the potential for rotor and the thermal activity that makes XC flying possible.

Access & Facilities

The site is accessible by car, followed by a short walk to the take-off area. It is advisable to contact the local club PGOrešany to confirm about possible fees for flying at Orešany.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Rotor Risk: When planning flights, especially with a southeast start direction, pilots should be aware of potential rotor effects caused by surrounding trees.
  • Wind Conditions: The site experiences strong winds throughout the year, and the surrounding trees can create significant rotor effects if the wind isn't straight in.
  • Landing: There is no officially designated landing zone, so pilots need to carefully assess landing options.
  • Airspace: The paragliding area is defined as a circle with a 1.5 NM (2.78 km) radius centered on the takeoff area, extending vertically to the upper limit of Class G airspace. When this area overlaps with controlled airspace or restricted areas, those airspace restrictions apply.
  • Radio Contact: Mandatory two-way radio contact is required in areas listed in ENR 5.5.1.4 when activated.
  • Directive LZ 1: Paragliding activities are governed by Directive LZ 1, issued by the Flight Amateur Association of the Slovak Republic.
  • Safety Recommendation: Pilots are advised to fly at least 1 nautical mile outside the published paragliding area to enhance safety.

html:
Overview

Velký Lopeník is a well-known paragliding site situated on the Czech-Slovak border, specifically on the fourth highest peak of the White Carpathians (Bílé Karpaty), reaching an altitude of 911 meters. Surrounded by the villages of Lopeník, Březová, and Nová Bošáca, this site offers unique thermal flying opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Flying: Known for excellent thermal flying due to its south-facing bowl shape.
  • Launch Directions: Offers launch sites facing between 135° and 225°.
  • Northwest Takeoff: Another launch site on the northwest side above Horná Súča, suitable for both slope soaring and cross-country flights.
  • Cross-Country Potential: Cross-country flights exceeding 130 km are possible, potentially reaching the Hungarian border.
  • Wind Conditions: Best flown with south to southeast winds.

Who Should Fly Here?

Velký Lopeník is not suitable for beginners. This site is popular among experienced pilots who are comfortable with thermal flying and challenging conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Requires a 35-minute uphill hike to the main launch site.
  • Directions:
    1. From Bošáca, continue to Nová Bošáca.
    2. Pass the turnoff to Predpoloma and at the next turn, turn right steeply uphill (blue hiking sign on the tree).
    3. Follow this road to the village of Grúň.
    4. Leave the car at the end of the asphalt road and follow the blue mark just below the summit (about 50m).
    5. Turn to the left, which leads over the forest clearings. The take-off point is on the second of these.
    6. Leave the path onto a footpath, which leads to the take-off point (through raspberry bushes).
  • Fees: There may be potential fees related to flying at the site, but this is unconfirmed.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Beginner Unsuitable: The site is generally considered unsuitable for beginner paragliding pilots.
  • Valley Influence: The valley can influence the wind, making it stronger than indicated by nearby weather stations and straighten the wind direction, often to the south.
  • Turbulent Spring Air: Can experience turbulent spring air with bumps, especially during thermal activity.
  • Tailwind Risk: Risk of getting blown to the trees in case of start in tailwind.
  • Takeoff Complexity: The takeoff is from a forest clearing and only suitable for one paraglider at a time, potentially creating rotors. It is not recommended to fly alone for this reason.
  • Potential Permission Required: Launching may require permission from the landowner because the launch area is a grassland for domestic animals. Contact Petr Doležal: +420 777 215 471 (verify current status).
  • Airspace: General airspace rules for Slovakia will apply. Specific flight restrictions are not readily available but should be checked before flight.
search_recs: Velky Lopenik paragliding site details Velky Lopenik paragliding Velky Lopenik paragliding take off coordinates Velky Lopenik paragliding restrictions Paragliding in Slovakia official sites

html:
Overview

Slopovo is a popular paragliding site in Slovakia, located near the villages of Klenovec and Kokava nad Rimavicou in the Banská Bystrica Region. Situated in the picturesque Slovenské rudohorie (Slovak Ore Mountains), the takeoff offers stunning views from a deforested hill near a wooden lookout tower. This site is known for its thermal activity and cross-country (XC) flying potential.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Suitable wind directions range from 1° to 230°.
  • Altitude: The takeoff is located between 823 and 851 meters, with a height difference of 450-469 meters.
  • Type of Flying: Primarily known for thermal flying and cross-country (XC) flights. Pilots have achieved distances of up to 81 km from this site.

Who Should Fly Here?

Slopovo attracts pilots from all over Slovakia. While specific skill level recommendations aren't provided, its cross-country flying potential suggests it's best suited for intermediate to experienced pilots looking to explore the Slovakian skies.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The takeoff can be reached via a 3.5 km walking trail from Kokava nad Rimavicou or Klenovec, taking approximately 25 minutes from the main road. Follow the yellow marked tourist route from the Chorepa saddle on the road from Klenovec to Kokava nad Rimavicou. Cyclists can also access the site via a forest path.
  • Accommodation: Available in Kokava nad Rimavicou.
  • Fees: Flying at Slopovo takeoff is officially free (neplacené).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wires: Be aware of wires located at the end of the landing zone. Avoid landing too close to them to prevent being lifted by the wind.
  • LZ-1 Directive: Paragliding and hang gliding activities are governed by Directive LZ-1 issued by the Flight Amateur Association of the Slovak Republic (Letecká Amatérska Asociácia SR).
  • Airspace: Understand and respect the airspace regulations, which generally allow paragliding only in Class G airspace, with varying altitude limits. Further investigation of the airspace around Slopovo is necessary.
  • Proximity to Airfields: Comply with regulations regarding airspaces around airfields to prevent endangering air traffic.
  • 1 NM Rule: Adhere to the recommendation of flying at least 1 nautical mile outside published paragliding and hang gliding areas for increased safety.
  • Parachute Descent Areas: Avoid flying within 1 NM of airports in uncontrolled airspace where parachute descents are taking place, unless intending to land at the airport.
  • Maximum Height: The maximum height for flying in Slovakia is 2,450 m above sea level.

Disclaimer: Always check with local flying clubs and the Slovakian National Aviation Authority for the most up-to-date information on regulations and site conditions.
