html:
Overview

Kubínska hoľa is a popular paragliding site located in the Orava region of Slovakia, near Dolný Kubín. This site, situated on the ridge of the Orava Magura mountain range, offers stunning panoramic views of the Western, High, and Low Tatras, Choč Mountains, and Veľká Fatra. Known for its thermaling conditions and accessible launch, Kubínska hoľa attracts moderately experienced pilots seeking scenic cross-country opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Suitable for Southeast (SE), South (S), and Southwest (SW) winds. Takeoff possible from 120° to 220°.
  • Wind Speed: Maximum wind speed of 6 m/s recommended for paragliders and 8 m/s for hang gliders. The flat summit facilitates launch even in stronger winds.
  • Thermals: The site is well-known for its good thermal conditions due to the mountain's shape and open terrain. Expect strong thermals.
  • Flight Potential: Pilots can fly along the ridge of Kubínska hoľa, with potential to connect to Malá Fatra, Martinské hole ranges, Choč Mountains, or Western Tatras.
  • VFR Only: Flights are restricted to Visual Flight Rules (VFR).
  • Maximum Altitude: Maximum flight altitude of 2450 meters MSL (FL 80).

Who Should Fly Here?

Kubínska hoľa is best suited for moderately experienced pilots who are comfortable with thermaling conditions. Beginner pilots are advised to fly along the southern ridge towards Oravská Magura and the Orava dam.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the takeoff area is via a chairlift at the SKI PARK Kubínska hoľa ski resort. The takeoff area is near the upper chairlift station.
  • Parking & Transport: Parking is available at the chairlift station. Public transport (bus from Dolný Kubín) is also an option.
  • Landing Areas: Landing areas include the parking lot near the lower chairlift station and Repiská.
  • Tandem Flights: Tandem paragliding flights are available with certified pilots. Booking in advance is recommended. Fees apply for tandem flights, and payment is usually in cash. Lift ticket not included.
  • Operating Rules: Site operating rules and regulations ("Prevádzkový poriadok") are managed by the X-air paragliding club Žilina (Contact: +421 903 103 839).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Strong Winds & Thermals: Be aware of your limits and the potential dangers of flying in strong winds and strong thermals. Turbulence can cause wing collapses.
  • Cables: Be aware of the risk of injury caused by snow cannon cables and slope-grooming machines, especially winch machines with extended cables (primarily during winter operations, if applicable).
  • LZTRA 04 Airspace: Be mindful of nearby Čičmany - Javorinka launch site located near LZTRA 04 Žilina airport (lower limit of 2450 AMSL).
  • Maximum Flight Level: Ensure adherence to the maximum flight level restriction of 2450m MSL (FL80).
  • Hang Glider Landings: Landing on the uneven terrain can be difficult for hang gliders.
search_recs: Kubínska hoľa paragliding official site paragliding Kubínska hoľa Slovakia Kubínska hoľa paragliding site guide Kubínska hoľa paragliding restrictions

html:
Overview

Podkonické Pleše is a popular paragliding site located above the village of Podkonice, at the edge of the Low Tatras mountains in Slovakia. The site is known for its thermaling opportunities and easy access, making it a favorite among pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Known for good thermaling conditions. Thermals can be moderate to strong and accompanied by moderate to strong turbulence, particularly near the ridge.
  • Wind Direction: Optimal take-off wind direction is between 150° and 220°.
  • Seasonal Restriction: Take-off is prohibited from May 15 until the meadows are mowed, typically in early August.

Who Should Fly Here?

Podkonické Pleše is considered an easy site, capable of accommodating a large number of gliders (around 150). It is suitable for pilots of varying experience levels.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Drive to a parking lot near a cottage, followed by a 10-15 minute walk to the take-off area. Alternatively, a marked hiking trail from the village takes approximately 50-60 minutes.
  • Vehicle Restriction: Driving to the takeoff is forbidden.
  • Fees: It is advised to check locally for any potential usage fees.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Landing Area Hazard: Be aware of a thin wire fence on the eastern side of the cemetery landing area. It is supported by inconspicuous posts.
  • Airspace: Pilots should always be aware of current NOTAMs (Notice to Airmen) that may be in effect, potentially influencing available flying levels. While no significant limitations within the intended airspace were noted during the 2007 World Hang Gliding Championship, be mindful of the airspace.
  • Weather Conditions: Paragliding activities should only be conducted during daylight hours and in visual meteorological conditions. Paraglider pilots must remain clear of clouds and in sight of the ground at all times.
  • Airspace Zones: Paragliders can only operate in category E, F, or G zones.
search_recs: Podkonické Pleše paragliding official site Podkonické Pleše paragliding paragliding Podkonické Pleše site information Podkonické Pleše flying conditions

html:
Overview

Emberger Alm, nestled in Greifenburg, Carinthia, Austria, near the Italian border, is a renowned paragliding destination in the Alps. With its southeast-facing mountain meadows extending up to the Nassfeldriegel summit, this site offers reliable thermal conditions and breathtaking views of the Drau Valley.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Emberger Alm is celebrated for its excellent thermal conditions, ridge soaring, and cross-country (XC) potential. The Drautal valley is particularly suited for beginner long-distance flights.
  • Seasonality: The flying season typically runs from March through November.
  • Weather Considerations: Expect reliable thermals before noon due to the southeast-facing terrain. Spring can bring very strong thermals. Be aware of potential turbulence, especially with west wind conditions, and lee-wave rotors in north- and west-wind conditions. Valley winds can reach the take-off site with east-wind conditions, causing turbulent thermals. The area is generally exposed to thunderstorms.

Who Should Fly Here?

Emberger Alm is a popular site, attracting a wide range of pilots. While the area offers beginner-friendly XC opportunities, strong thermal activity during peak season necessitates expert support (such as from a flight instructor) for less experienced pilots. Expert pilots will enjoy the long XC potential.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The main take-off site is accessible via private vehicle or a collective taxi service. A higher take-off site is a 15-minute walk from the main site, accessible on foot or via the collective cabs. The Dünhofer family provides a reliable shuttle service from the landing site to the Emberger Alm launch site with an altitude difference of 1100 m.
  • Fees: A day ticket for the shuttle service costs €6, and a season ticket costs €60 (as of 2021). A start/landing fee of €4.50 is payable at the take-off or landing site. A one-way trip to the launch site is around 9€.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Thermal Activity: The area is known for strong thermals, especially during spring. Flying during the thermal high season is not recommended for beginners or casual pilots without expert support. The area is also prone to thunderstorms.
  • Wind Conditions: Be cautious of lee-wave rotors in north and west wind conditions. East wind can bring turbulent valley winds up to the takeoff site.
  • Turbulence: Low relief can cause turbulence at the southeast takeoff, especially with west wind. West wind can also cause turbulence at the main takeoff.
  • Wildlife Reserve: Respect the wildlife reserve east of Emberger Alm.
  • South-East Takeoff: This launch has a flat grass slope. Low relief with turbulence for paragliders, especially when there is west wind.
  • South-West Takeoff: Steep grass-slope straight into the thermal. With west-wind conditions there is a risk of lee vortexes occurring.
  • Designated Launch Sites: Launching is only permitted at designated sites.
  • Landing Area Power Lines: The landing site near the Fliegercamp Oberes Drautal has high-voltage power lines. Observe the landing pattern (Landevolte) carefully.
  • Downwind Takeoffs: Takeoffs should only be done with downwind.

html:
Overview

Bischling is one of the most popular paragliding destinations in Salzburger Land, Austria. Located in Werfenweng, this site offers a unique blend of soaring and cross-country (XC) opportunities, set against the stunning backdrop of the Tennengebirge mountain range and panoramic views of the surrounding Alps, including the Gosaukamm, Bischofsmütze, Großglockner, Hochkönigmassiv, and Hagengebirge. The site is known for being flyable even when other areas are too windy due to its sheltered location.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Excellent for both thermaling and cross-country flights.
  • Seasonality: Flyable from mid-May to the end of October, and from December to the end of the ski season. Thermal activity is common even in winter due to favorable sun exposure.
  • Weather Considerations: While sheltered, pilots should be aware that afternoon thermals can strengthen in the ridge area, especially with West-Northwest winds. Be aware of the risk of strong storms. Strong regional North winds are to be strictly avoided.

Who Should Fly Here?

Bischling is suitable for pilots of all skill levels, from beginners to experienced XC pilots. Launch sites are relatively easy, and aborted takeoffs can be performed without difficulty.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The primary access is via the IKARUS cable car from Werfenweng. The cable car operates from mid-May to late October and from December to the end of the ski season.
  • Launch Site: The Bischlinghöhe launch site is located a short distance from the mountain station, next to the Alpengasthaus Bischlinghöhe.
  • Fees: There are fees associated with using the cable car. Special ticket options may be available for paragliders. Check the Bergbahnen Werfenweng website for current operating times and prices.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Variable Wind Conditions: Bischling can be flown even with strong regional West-Northwest winds. However, these winds can strengthen thermally in the afternoon, especially in the ridge area.
  • Turbulence: While thermals are typically not turbulent, pilots should be aware of the potential for changing conditions, especially in spring.
  • Takeoff Hazards: Be aware of trees at the launch area; pilots should trim their glider appropriately to clear the tree line during launch.
  • Airspace: The Bischling flying zone is located within CTA C (Controlled Trans-Airspace C), with a lower limit at FL 125 (approximately 12,500 feet).
  • Launch Site Requirement: For flights to be valid for XContest, the launch must be from an official Bischling launch site.
  • FlyPark Dachstein Card: Only Sky Club Austria members or holders of the FlyPark Dachstein Card are permitted to use the paragliding take-off and landing areas in the FlyPark Dachstein. Pilots without membership or the FlyPark Dachstein Card must register online or at the flight school office (Flugschule Sky Club Austria).
  • Commercial Tandem Flights: Tandem passenger flights are only permitted by pilots instructed by the Sky Club Austria flight school from Hauser Kaibling, Michaelerberg, Krippenstein, Stoderzinken and Dachstein flying areas (Flugschule Sky Club Austria).
  • XContest Rules: Flights with airspace infringements will not be counted for the XContest.

html:
Overview

The Schöckl, standing at 1,445 meters, is a prominent mountain near Graz, Austria, marking the eastern end of the Alps in the region. As a highly popular and well-established paragliding site, the Schöckl attracts pilots and hang gliders internationally, drawn by its excellent thermic conditions and stunning views of the Passailer Kessel and the Graz Bergland. The mountain features steep slopes and an extended plateau, offering a diverse flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • The Schöckl is renowned for its excellent thermaling opportunities.
  • Cross-country flights are possible, although pilots should be mindful of the nearby Graz control zone.
  • Take-off sites cater to both north-westerly and southerly wind directions.
  • Flights are restricted to between two hours after sunrise and two hours before sunset due to game protection regulations.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Schöckl is a popular site, especially on weekends, attracting both paragliders and hang gliders. The site is suitable for training. However, it's recommended to visit the landing site before heading up to familiarize yourself with the area.

Access & Facilities

  • Access to the take-off area is conveniently provided by a cable car operating year-round (except for maintenance periods). A special ticket is needed to transport sports equipment, such as paragliders.
  • A daily membership fee may be required, payable at the local club or the restaurant at the Schöcklbahn valley station.
  • Alternatively, pilots can hike to the summit using one of the numerous trails, with the hike from the landing area in St. Radegund taking approximately 40 minutes.
  • Parking is available at the "Schöcklkreuz," subject to parking fees.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • The main landing area slopes downwards to the south, which can be challenging, especially in thermal conditions. Prior assessment of the landing area is strongly advised.
  • Pilots must be aware of and avoid obstacles such as cable cars, roads, car parks, and power lines.
  • The Schöckl is known for being susceptible to strong wind conditions, so pilots should assess wind direction and speed carefully.
  • Turbulence can occur when flying through thermals, potentially leading to collapses.
  • Schöckl Nord (North Launch): Can be in the wind shadow of the edge when the wind is stronger. With stronger northerly or northeasterly winds, the launch area is in the lee of the side basin. Caution is advised for beginners due to its short length and steep drop-off.
  • The maximum altitude is limited by the proximity of the Graz control zone (CTR Graz). The maximum altitude over the Schöckl is 2134m (7000ft).
  • Launches are prohibited for game protection reasons earlier than 2 hours after sunrise and later than 2 hours before sunset.

It is highly recommended to seek an introduction from local pilots or a flight school before flying at the Schöckl.

html:
Overview

Hohe Wand, a karst plateau reaching 1,132 meters, is located approximately 30 minutes southwest of Vienna in Lower Austria. Part of the Viennese Alps, the landscape features impressive rock faces, making it a visually stunning and popular paragliding destination.

Flying Conditions

  • Ridge Soaring: Hohe Wand is renowned for its excellent ridge soaring conditions, particularly with east and southeast winds.
  • Cross-Country Potential: The site offers good opportunities for cross-country (XC) flying.
  • Thermals: Strong thermals are common during the spring and summer months. However beginners should avoid midday hours during these seasons. Area around Almfrieden and "Rote Felsen" (Red Rock) are known for strong thermals, potentially with climb rates of up to 10 m/s.
  • Optimal Wind Directions: Best takeoff conditions are generally found with east and south winds.
  • Launch Specifics:
    • Südstart (South Launch): A cliff launch used for SE-S winds; pilots using this launch should have sufficient experience. It's a short meadow launch on a rocky promontory and is preferred for hang gliders.
    • Oststartplatz (East Launch): Used for NE-SE winds, but can be turbulent if the wind comes over the trees.

Who Should Fly Here?

Hohe Wand is a popular airfield suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including tandem flights. The site caters to a range of experience levels, but certain launches require more advanced skills. Pilots should be considerate of student pilots as the area is also used for training.

Access & Facilities

  • Accessibility: The site is easily accessible by car via the panorama mountain road (Hohe Wand Straße).
  • Parking: Multiple starting points with parking are available.
  • Fees:
    • The Hohe Wand Straße is subject to a toll on Sundays and public holidays.
    • A launch fee of approximately €6 may be required.
    • An entrance fee to the Hohe Wand Nature Park is required: Adults €4.50, Children €2.
  • Day Flight Entitlement: A day flight entitlement may be obtained at the Gasthof Postl.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Strong thermals, especially in spring and summer, can create turbulent conditions.
  • Crowded Airspace: High pilot volume, especially on weekends, increases the risk of collision.
  • Strong Winds: Caution is advised in strong south winds due to rotors.
  • Changing Conditions: Special wind and weather situations can lead to demanding flying conditions.
  • Loss of Altitude/Downwind Conditions: Be aware of potentially strong headwinds that can make returning to the launch difficult. There is a risk of "Absaufgefahr" (sinking out) when crossing the valley where the Hohe Wand road is located. Stay close to the ridge to utilize any available lift.
  • Rotor Danger: Be aware of dangerous rotors with East, Northeast, and East-Northeast winds.
  • Airspace Restrictions: There is a height restriction above Hohe Wand up to the Hochkogelhaus (SRA Wien V 6500 FT/MSL or 1980m). Southwest of that is the SRA Wien VIII with a maximum altitude of 8500 FT/MSL (2590m). These restrictions must be observed.

html:
Overview

Kössen, located in the Kaiserwinkl region of Tyrol, Austria, is known as the "cradle of alpine paragliding". Nestled near the German border, the site offers stunning views of the Tyrolean Alpine landscape, including the Kaiserwinkl, the Kitzbühel Alps and neighboring Bavaria. With consistent flyable days and favorable microclimate, it's a popular destination for paragliding enthusiasts of all skill levels.

Flying Conditions

Kössen is renowned for its excellent thermal conditions, making it ideal for both ridge soaring and thermaling. The Unterberghorn mountain provides take-off locations facing east, north, and west, offering flexibility based on the wind direction. Spring, summer, and autumn offer the best flying conditions, with potential for XC flights ranging from 20 km to over 200 km. The area is also used by flight schools for high-altitude flight training.

Who Should Fly Here?

Kössen is a very popular site, attracting a wide range of pilots. It is suitable for beginners (with instruction) to experienced XC pilots. Several flight schools operate in the area, offering tandem flights and courses. Weekends can be busy, so flying during the week is recommended to avoid crowds.

Access & Facilities

Access to the take-off sites on the Unterberg is via the Unterberghorn cable car, which also accommodates hang gliders. The main landing area is near the Fliegerbar, close to the valley station. The Fliegerbar is a popular gathering place for pilots, offering valuable local information. There are no takeoff or landing fees in Kössen, but cable car tickets are required to access the take-off sites.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • "Bermuda Triangle": Be aware of the north/south valley to the west of the Unterberg, where landing is impossible at the bottom. This is a significant flight planning hazard.
  • Flight School Operations: The airspace above the Unterberg is frequently used for flight school training. Pilots should be considerate of these activities.
  • Turbulence at Stocking Landing: The Stocking landing place can experience turbulence due to upstream backdraft, houses, and strong valley winds. Land only in calm wind conditions and carefully assess the landing area.
  • Takeoff Hazards: Pay attention to announcements over the cable car loudspeakers regarding specific hazards.
  • Landing Restrictions (Stocking): Only pilots with at least an "A-License" are permitted to land at the Stocking landing site.
  • Cable Car Clearance: Maintain a safety distance of at least 70 meters from the cable cars at all times.
  • Guest Pilot Regulations: Non-Austrian licensed pilots must comply with Austrian regulations. Ensure you meet the requirements for flying legally in Austria, potentially including a "Guest-License" from an Austrian flying school. Always carry your license and third-party liability insurance.
  • Groundhandling Restrictions: Groundhandling is not permitted at the Stocking landing site.
search_recs: Thermik Kössen Kössen paragliding site regulations paragliding Kössen Austria site information paragliding Kössen official site paragliding Kössen fees

html:
Overview

The Gaisberg, near Salzburg, Austria, is a popular alpine paragliding site known for its potential for thermal and cross-country flights. With meadow launch sites on the summit plateau offering scenic views, and a landing area at the foot of the mountain in Guggenthal, the Gaisberg presents a challenging yet rewarding flying experience. Flights are possible year-round, with spring and early summer offering particularly good climb values.

Flying Conditions

  • The Gaisberg is suitable for thermal and cross-country flying, especially in spring and early summer.
  • Longer flights are best attempted early in the day (before noon).
  • The best soaring conditions occur when the mountain is approached from the north to the east.
  • Expect strong turbulence, especially in the afternoons when the wind shifts to the east. This site is not suitable for beginners under such conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Gaisberg is considered a challenging alpine flying area suitable for experienced pilots. Disciplined flight behavior and knowledge of airspaces are essential due to airspace restrictions and the potential for strong conditions. Be aware of Foehn winds, which can be dangerous.

Access & Facilities

  • The summit plateau is easily accessible by car via the Gaisbergstraße or by bus (line 151 from Salzburg) year-round.
  • A daily membership of €5 is required to fly here and can be purchased at the 'Gaisbergwirt'.
  • Parking directly on the road at the landing site is prohibited.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Restrictions: The Gaisberg is located within the control zone (CTR) of Salzburg Airport (LOWS).
  • TRA Activation Required: Flying is only permitted when one of the two Temporary Reserved Airspaces (TRA) is active: TRA Gaisberg and TRA Schwarzenberg.
  • TRA Activation Procedure: Check the airspace status daily and activate the TRA by telephone with air traffic control each flying day.
  • Wind Conditions: Be aware of weather hazards, particularly the Foehn winds, which can be dangerous.
  • Turbulence: Expect strong turbulence, especially in the afternoons when the wind shifts to the east.
  • Launch Site Risks: The launch sites are mostly narrow and require competent launch technique.
  • West Launch Restriction: It is forbidden to fly below the transmitter height above the Gaisberg plateau and to top-land northwest of the road to the transmitter.
  • Protection Zone Nockstein: Respect distance rules in the Nockstein protection zone.
  • Notification of Airport: It is mandatory to notify the airport when flying in the Gaisberg or Schwarzenberg areas.

For the most up-to-date information and regulations, please check the 1st Hang Gliding and Paragliding Club Salzburg (FLY FOR FUN) website.
search_recs: Gaisberg paragliding site access fees paragliding Gaisberg (AT) Gaisberg paragliding site official information

html:
Overview

Gerlitzen, nestled in Carinthia, Austria, is a renowned paragliding site that rises dramatically from the northern shores of Lake Ossiacher See. With its summit reaching 1,911 meters (6,270 feet), pilots can enjoy a substantial altitude difference of approximately 1,400 meters (4,593 feet) down to the landing areas. Its stunning landscape, combining mountainous terrain with the scenic beauty of the lake, makes Gerlitzen a "paraglider's paradise".

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Gerlitzen is famous for both thermaling and acro flying. The unique conditions over Lake Ossiacher See also make it ideal for safety training.
  • Seasonality: Flying is possible year-round due to relatively stable weather in all seasons.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • Be cautious of strong westerly or northerly winds as they can make reaching the designated landing areas difficult.
    • Strong North, West or East wind will make a takeoff very difficult.
    • South wind, rising thermals, or calm conditions provide the best flying opportunities.

Who Should Fly Here?

Gerlitzen caters to a wide range of pilots, from beginners to advanced acro experts. Multiple takeoff options at different altitudes accommodate varying skill levels. However, visiting pilots should be aware of the Austrian licensing requirements (see below).

Access & Facilities

  • Access:
    • The main takeoff (1,900m) is easily accessible via the Kanzelbahn gondola to the middle station, followed by a chairlift to the top.
    • A toll road also provides access to the launch site.
    • Ossiachberg "500" takeoff is often used for hike and fly (prior permission required from the flight school, or purchase of the "Hike and Fly - Sommerpass").
  • Fees: Fees apply for the gondola/chairlift (day tickets and season passes available). The toll road also requires a fee.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Strong westerly or northerly winds pose a risk, making it difficult to reach the landing area. It is advisable not to fly in such conditions due to the possibility of dangerous rotor from trees.
  • Turbulence: Thermic activity, wind gusts, and general turbulence can lead to accidents.
  • Hikers: Be mindful of hikers, especially around the main takeoff area.
  • Landing Restrictions:
    • Landing is strictly prohibited on the Ossiachersee campsite and beach areas. Violators will be fined by the police.
    • Pilots must land at least 50 meters away from the road.
  • Airspace:
    • Be aware of the Klagenfurt airport entry corridor at 2,100 meters, which can impact cross-country flying.
    • Pay attention to TRA (Temporary Reserved Area) Gerlitzen airspace restrictions.
    • Normally, pilots are limited to 1,981m (FL65/6500ft MSL) or 300m above ground within the Gerlitzen area.
    • The maximum altitude at the summit area is 2,200m.
    • When the TRA is activated (requires permission via Flugplatz Feldkirchen), the allowed altitude increases to 2,896m (FL95/9500ft).
    • Outside the TRA Gerlitzen (South and West), the allowed flight altitude is always 2,896m (FL95/9500ft MSL).
  • Licensing: Austrian law requires a valid Austrian, German, or Swiss license and a flight book. Foreign licenses might not be accepted, and pilots have faced fines. Check with the Austrian Aeroclub for the most up-to-date regulations.

Important Note: First-time pilots are strongly advised to get a briefing from the local flight school.
search_recs: Gerlitzen paragliding access Gerlitzen paragliding official information Gerlitzen paragliding site Austria Gerlitzen Gleitschirmfliegen Gerlitzen paragliding pilot skill level Gerlitzen paragliding flying characteristics

html:
Overview

Bezau, nestled in the scenic Bregenzerwald region of Vorarlberg, Austria, is renowned as one of Europe's premier paragliding destinations. With its stunning Alpine landscape, characterized by grassy mountains and valleys, Bezau offers pilots breathtaking views of the Bregenzerwald and Lake Constance area. The site's favorable flying conditions and multiple launch options cater to both beginners and experienced pilots alike.

Flying Conditions

  • Laminar Upslope Winds & Thermals: Bezau benefits from laminar upslope winds and pleasant thermal conditions, making it suitable for year-round flying.
  • Multiple Launch Sites:
    • Niedere Mountain: Offers take-offs towards the south (Bezau side) and northeast (Andelsbuch side).
    • Bezau Side: Particularly suitable for winter flying or during southerly conditions and early mornings in summer (September to April, start direction South).
    • Hintere Niedere: Located east of the mountain station, requires a 15-minute walk following the ridge towards the ski lift support (windsock). A relatively large launch area.
    • Baumgarten: Offers a large, simple launch site at the summit and another good launch site next to the old mountain station. Launching to the north is also possible directly at the summit. A smaller, steeper launch is located right by the mountain station. (Note: One source indicates that the Baumgarten launch site might be temporarily unavailable due to construction of the new cable car).

Who Should Fly Here?

The Bregenzerwald, including Bezau, is popular with pilots of all skill levels. Its excellent conditions and paragliding schools make it ideal for both beginners and seasoned experts. The site is frequently used for paragliding training.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Primary access to the launch sites is via the Seilbahn Bezau cable car.
  • Landing Area: The designated landing site is conveniently located near the valley station of the cable car.
  • Tandem Flights: Contact Flugschule Bregenzerwald for tandem flight pricing (approximately €170 for a 15-minute flight, discounts available with the Guest Card Bregenzerwald & Großes Walsertal).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Lee Situations with North Wind: The entire south face of the Niedere becomes a lee area (turbulent downwind) with north wind (Talwind). Avoid flying on the Bezau side of the mountain with north or northwest wind at the ridgeline.
  • Turbulence in Bezau Valley Basin: Expect treacherous, very turbulent gusts from the north in the Bezau valley basin, especially on the mountain side of the paragliding landing site.
  • Wind Increase Awareness: Pilots should be attentive to increasing wind speeds.
  • Föhn Wind Potential: The area is susceptible to Föhn winds. Flying becomes difficult with a significant south-to-north pressure gradient.
  • Landing Regulations: Strictly adhere to the landing regulations posted on the information board at the landing site, particularly when flight training is in progress.
  • Landing Field Conditions: The landing field is a narrow, marked meadow requiring precision.
  • Evening Launch Ban (Andelsbuch nearby): No launching is permitted from 7 PM onwards in the nearby Andelsbuch area.

html:
Overview

The Kulm is a popular paragliding site located near Weiz and Stubenberg See in Styria, Austria. Characterized by rolling hills south of the Fischbacher Alpen and Wechsel mountains, the Kulm offers a height difference of 523 meters, with a takeoff point at 910 meters and a landing area at 397 meters.

Flying Conditions

  • The Kulm is known as an easy site, suitable for beginners.
  • Excellent thermalling conditions, with southeast-facing launch sites enabling early access to thermals.
  • While not primarily a cross-country (XC) site, pilots occasionally fly distances of several kilometers.
  • Due to its lower altitude and regional microclimate, the site is often flyable even when other sites are not.
  • Ridge soaring is also possible.
  • Thermals are generally not very demanding, with lift mostly under 5 m/s.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Kulm is generally considered suitable for beginner to intermediate pilots. The site is also used as a training ground by the Fun2Fly flying school. However, it is crucial to note that as of August 2023, access and launch permission may be restricted to club members only due to issues with guest pilots. Check current access rules with the Seegeier Para- & Hängegleiter Club.

Access & Facilities

  • Access to the Kulm is typically by car, followed by a walk to the launch.
  • It is advisable to coordinate with the local flying school or club (Seegeier) to form carpools before ascending to the launch.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Access Restrictions: As of August 10, 2023, access and launch permission are *only* for club members of the "Sea Vulture Paragliding & Hang-glider Club".
  • Top Landing: Top landing is strictly prohibited.
  • Soaring Restrictions: Soaring in the launch corridor is forbidden.
  • Tandem Flights: Commercial tandem flights are prohibited.
  • General Austrian Regulations: Pilots flying in Austria must hold third-party liability insurance and carry their license and insurance card. Non-Austrian license holders from specific countries may fly legally; others may need a special 'Guest-License' from a local Austrian flying school.
  • Terrain Awareness: Be aware of the surrounding terrain and limited emergency landing areas, especially in rocky or rough terrain.
search_recs: Fluggebiet Kulm Österreich paragliding Kulm Austria Kulm Austria paragliding site information Paragliding club Kulm Austria

html:
Overview

Schlick 2000, also known as Kreuzjoch, is a popular paragliding site located in the Stubaital valley in Tyrol, Austria, near Fulpmes, approximately 20 minutes by car from Innsbruck. Nestled within the Stubai Alps, this site offers impressive mountain scenery and excellent potential for cross-country (XC) flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Altitude: Take-off at Kreuzjoch is at 2,094m, with a landing area in Fulpmes at 911m, giving a height difference of 1,183m.
  • Thermals: The south-easterly orientation helps generate strong thermals early in the day, making it ideal for XC flying.
  • Season: Flying is possible in summer and winter, with the south-facing slopes offering sun-kissed conditions on clear winter days.
  • Wind: Be aware of potential foehn wind breakthroughs despite the Stubaital generally being shielded from strong winds.
  • Glide Ratio: Good glide ratio for long flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

This site is recommended for intermediate to experienced pilots due to the altitude and potential for strong conditions. The site is not considered suitable for complete beginners, and pilots should be able to assess the tailwind strength. The site is also used by hang gliders.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the take-off is via the Kreuzjochbahn cable car.
  • Fees: A one-way ticket on the Kreuzjochbahn cable car costs €20.10 for adults (with guest card), €17.10 for youth, and €10.70 for children.
  • Hiking: It is possible to hike to the take-off, meeting at the Bergstation (summit station).
  • Landing: Landing is in Fulpmes, a 10-15 minute walk from the Talstation (valley station).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: The area is known to experience turbulence, especially shortly after takeoff. A strong gust of wind can cause mid-flight pitching.
  • Lee Side Danger (Leegefahr): Strong valley winds can create a lee-side situation, especially when landing near the parking lot.
  • Mountain Weather: Be prepared for sudden changes in weather, which can affect flight safety.
  • Spring Conditions: Spring conditions may be stronger than autumn.
  • Flight Restrictions: The "Flugbetriebsordnung der Schlick 2000" (Schlick 2000 flight regulations) applies.
  • Area Introduction: Pilots unfamiliar with the area should get an introduction from the Parafly flying school to ensure safe flight operations.
  • Takeoff/Landing Ban: Schlick 2000 Schizentrum AG can issue takeoff and landing bans if pilots do not adhere to the flight regulations.
  • Tandem Flights: Private tandem flights are allowed only for members of the Stubaier Jochdohlen. Commercial tandem flights and cost-covering tandem flights are only allowed after consultation with Schlick 2000.
  • Landing Site Fulpmes:
    • Ground handling is not permitted at the landing site.
    • Pilots should not fly over the marked red area (farm) near the landing site.
    • Landing is prohibited below the valley station.
  • Speedflying: Speedflying has been officially forbidden at Schlick 2000.
  • Orange cross: Pilots already in the air will see a large orange cross at the landing site to indicate an upcoming danger when there is a flight ban on the landing site.

Recommendations: Check the weather forecast before flying, use an anemometer to estimate wind strength and direction, and be aware of wind indicators. Consider completing an area introduction to the flying area.

html:
Overview

Hinterstoder, nestled in the scenic Pyhrn-Priel region of Upper Austria and shadowed by the Totes Gebirge mountains, is a popular paragliding destination offering varied flying experiences. From gentle slopes to high-alpine environments, the site is known for its thermaling potential and opportunities for cross-country (XC) flights. Soaring is also a common activity, especially during the winter months.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals & Soaring: Known for good thermaling conditions with XC potential. Soaring is common, especially in winter.
  • Varied Terrain: The diverse landscape provides varied flying conditions, from gentle slopes to high alpine environments.
  • Wind Considerations: Be cautious of potential lee conditions with East or Southeast winds. Flying is not permitted in highly turbulent wind conditions.
  • No-Fly Zone: The Weißenbachtal valley/southwest edge is a strict no-fly zone for wildlife protection.

Who Should Fly Here?

Hinterstoder is suitable for pilots of varying skill levels. Designated training areas are available for beginners, and the site is generally considered to be of easy to medium difficulty. Experienced pilots can take advantage of the thermaling conditions and XC potential.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Access to the primary launch sites on the Hutterer Höß is via cable car (Hössbahn and Höss-Express).
  • Paragliding Tickets: Paragliding tickets are required, and they include start and landing fees. A day ticket costs €39.50.
  • Registration: Tandem pilots and holders of a training certificate must register with the Flugschule Hinterstoder before flying.
  • Designated Landing Areas: Landing is only permitted in designated areas.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Lee Conditions: Be aware of potentially dangerous lee conditions during East or South/East winds.
  • Turbulence: Flying is prohibited in highly turbulent wind conditions.
  • Winter Ski Piste Closures: During winter, be aware of ski piste closures from 5 PM to 9 AM. No skiing or loitering is allowed on the pistes during this time.
  • Landing Restrictions: Landing is expressly prohibited at the Hutterer Böden middle station and on all ski slopes.
  • No-Fly Zone: The Weißenbachtal valley/southwest edge is an absolute no-fly zone due to wildlife protection. If thermals are weak, pilots must fly towards the landing site above the edge of this area.
  • VFR Compliance: Any violation of Visual Flight Rules (VFR) will result in a flying ban.
  • Wind Speed Limits: Takeoff is not allowed if the wind speed at the launch site exceeds 2/3 of the glider's trim speed.
  • Commercial Flight Permission: Written permission is required for commercial flights and training courses.
search_recs: Thermikflug Hinterstoder Hinterstoder paragliding site guide paragliding Hinterstoder Austria Hinterstoder Gleitschirmfliegen Gleitschirmclub Hinterstoder Hinterstoder paragliding official site

html:
Overview

Radsberg is a popular paragliding site located on the Sattnitz ridge, south of Klagenfurt, in Carinthia, Austria. This relatively low-altitude ridge (approximately 800m at launch) offers stunning views of the Drau valley, Rosental valley, and the Karawanken mountains. It is a well-known recreation spot with hiking and cycling trails, and a favorite among local pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Radsberg is known for being suitable for both beginners and experienced pilots. It's often used for after-work flights and ridge soaring, but also serves as a starting point for cross-country (XC) flights.
  • XC Potential: The site offers XC potential towards Klopeinersee to the east, the Karawanken mountains and Slovenia to the south, and Gerlitzen and Tschiernock to the west.
  • Seasonality: Radsberg is most popular in spring due to its "microclimate," where thermals can be strong even at lower altitudes, allowing pilots to reach 2500m or higher. It is useable throughout the year.
  • Weather Considerations: The site is often wind-favored compared to higher areas. Easterly winds are generally manageable. The landing site is not visible from the launch; after takeoff, pilots must fly to the left (east).
  • Thermals: Radsberg is known for good thermals. The microclimate allows pilots to climb to 2500m or higher, especially in spring. However, pilots should be cautious of thermal connection with the northerly wind at higher altitudes.

Who Should Fly Here?

Radsberg is considered suitable for a range of pilot skill levels, from beginners to experienced XC pilots. However, the launch site is steep and requires good technique.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The site is accessible by car. From Klagenfurt, take the Südring to Ebentalerstraße. Turn right towards Ebental after the Jet & OMV petrol stations. Follow signs for Radsberg, turning left to reach the Sattnitz ridge. The launch is near the Jausenstation Mickl snack station in Oberkreuth.
  • Fees: While there isn't a formal launch fee, a "flight area contribution" of €3.50 per day is to be paid at the Jausenstation Mickl.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • West Wind Conditions: Caution is advised in West wind conditions. The hill located southwest of the main take-off, with its steep drop towards the Drau river, can create a rotor (a zone of turbulent, rotating air).
  • Steep Launch: The launch site is steep and requires good technique.
  • Transverse Cables: Take note of transverse cables in the vicinity of the takeoff.
  • CTR Klagenfurt: Pilots must be careful not to enter the Klagenfurt CTR (Control Zone). Flights towards the east, in the direction of Klopeinersee, require special attention to avoid infringing this airspace.
  • Airspace E: The airspace is limited to 9,500ft (approximately 2,895m).
  • TRA Gerlitzen: When flying in the direction of Gerlitzen, respect restrictions related to TRA (Temporary Reserved Area) Gerlitzen. Generally, pilots are restricted to a maximum altitude of 1,981m (FL65) or 300m above ground. With activation of TRA Gerlitzen, altitude may be extended to 2,896m after requesting permission via Flugplatz Feldkirchen.
  • Hangflugregeln: Adherence to "Hangflugregeln" (slope soaring rules) is mandatory.
search_recs: Radsberg Austria paragliding regulations Radsberg paragliding site information paragliding Radsberg (AT) Paragliding site Radsberg Austria Fluggebiet Radsberg Österreich

html:
Overview

Ternberg, located in Upper Austria within the Kalkalpen National Park Region, is a popular paragliding site nestled in the pre-alpine foothills. Known for its thermaling and ridge soaring opportunities, Ternberg offers a diverse flying experience with launch sites facing various directions in the Enns and Steyr river valleys.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals and Ridge Soaring: Ternberg is known for its reliable thermals and opportunities for ridge soaring, making it a good location for cross-country (XC) flights.
  • Flying Season: The typical flying season runs from spring to autumn (April to October), weather permitting.
  • Wind Conditions: Launching only possible in light winds on O-Start (1255m). Westerly, south-westerly and southerly winds make it impossible to take off on Herndleck.

Who Should Fly Here?

Ternberg caters to a range of pilot skill levels, making it suitable for both beginners and experienced pilots. The simpler, larger launch and landing areas are appropriate for 1- and 2-seater paragliders and hang gliders. The site is especially popular for training and tandem flights.

Access & Facilities

  • Transportation: Train stations are located in Ternberg, Trattenbach, Losenstein, Reichraming, and Großraming.
  • Herndleck Access: Reachable by car, but involves a 150m walk uphill to the launch.
  • Local Expertise: Contact the local flight school or club for the most up-to-date information regarding site access and conditions.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Time Restrictions: All flying activities (take-off, landing, and vehicle retrieval) must stop two hours before sunset and resume two hours after sunrise.
  • Brandkogel Restriction: The Brandkogel launch site is explicitly listed as "DO NOT FLY!". Use Postkogel instead.
  • Seasonal West Wind Restriction: From the beginning of April until the end of September, find alternative sites during Westwind conditions.
  • Herndleck Launch: Holes in the inrun can make the start difficult
  • Westwind Warning: Taking off in a westerly direction towards Bäckengraben in westerly winds is not advisable.
  • Legal Requirements: Pilots must hold third-party liability insurance and carry their license and insurance card. If you need an Austrian license, contact the local flying schools for a 'Guest-Licence'.
  • Camping Prohibition: Camping is not allowed in the parking lot at Herndleck.
search_recs: Ternberg paragliding site guide paragliding Ternberg Austria Gleitschirmfliegen Ternberg Österreich Ternberg Austria official paragliding site

html:
Overview

Hensler, located in Schnifis, Vorarlberg, Austria, offers stunning alpine paragliding. Situated on the Schnifnerberg mountain at 1359m, this site is known for its soaring and thermal activity, making it a popular destination for pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Suitable for southern winds, with launches also possible with west winds.
  • Thermal Activity: Characterized by spring thermals, with good thermal and cross-country (XC) flying opportunities from late summer into autumn.
  • XC Potential: XC flights can be made towards Switzerland (south) and the Rhine Valley (west).
  • Afternoon Conditions: Be aware that from approximately 1 p.m., you may encounter downdrafts or crosswinds at the Hensler launch site.

Who Should Fly Here?

Hensler/Schnifis is a popular site suitable for beginners. However, be aware that the area can experience strong valley winds during the summer.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Accessible by car (toll fees apply), public transport, or cable car (Seilbahn Schnifisberg).
  • Fees:
    • Cable car ride: EUR 8.50 per ride.
    • Start/landing card: EUR 2.50 (available at the cable car or Flight Connection Arlberg office).
    • Driving and parking: EUR 8.00.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • General Risks:
    • Valley Wind: In summer, a strong valley wind can develop, potentially causing tailwind conditions at the launch site in the afternoon (around 1 PM). This can lead to downdrafts or crosswinds at the Hensler launch.
    • Rotors: Be aware of rotors in the launch area, especially during strong west winds.
    • Turbulence: The Achensee region, which is near Hensler, can be tricky due to strong valley winds in the afternoon.
    • Mountain Weather: As with any mountain flying site, weather conditions can change rapidly.
  • Landing Regulations: At the Plateau landing site, there can be hazards caused by tailwind. Also, at the Sportplatz landing area, pilots should already have experience due to the risk of rotors when there is a strong valley wind.
  • Legal & Paperwork:
    • Pilots flying in Austria must hold third-party liability insurance and carry their license and insurance card with them.
    • If pilots do not hold a license from specific countries, they may need to obtain a 'Guest-License' from a local Austrian flying school.
    • Day or annual passes are required for this site.
  • Important Note: It is always recommended to contact the local flying school or club for the most up-to-date information and a site briefing before flying at Hensler. Information can be found at the Flight Connection Arlberg (FCA) website (www.fca.at) and the Municipality of Schnifis website (www.schnifis.at).
search_recs: Hensler paragliding access fees Hensler paragliding site Austria paragliding Hensler AT Hensler AT flying conditions

html:
Overview

Gelderkogel is a smaller ridge located south of Teichalm in Styria, Austria. Its southern landscape features gently rolling hills, while the area to the north is known for its thermal activity. This site, with its wide grassy launch area in a forest clearing, serves as both a training ground and a gateway to soaring and cross-country (XC) flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Gelderkogel is known as a training site, but also offers possibilities for soaring and cross-country (XC) flights, especially with a south wind.
  • The area to the north of Gelderkogel is known for being thermally active which aids in XC flights.
  • Pilots should pay attention to East, West, and tailwinds.

Who Should Fly Here?

Gelderkogel is considered an easy site, suitable for training and pilots of lower experience levels. It's a popular spot, particularly on weekends, and is frequently utilized by the Styria Flying School for training purposes.

Access & Facilities

  • To access the site, park at the parking lot near the Jausenstation Schachner.
  • The launch site is a 10-minute walk from the parking lot, following a path south to the forest edge and then a north-westward trail.
  • A fee of 2€ per day is to be paid in a letterbox (Postkasten) with a sign for paragliders at the farmhouse on the left side of the road when coming from the landing area.
  • Access to the launch site is restricted to the flying school bus and vehicles transporting hang gliders.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Pay attention to East, West, and tailwinds ("Ost- West- und Rückenwind beachten").
  • Turbulence: Turbulence can occur, especially during landing approaches ("Beim Landeanflug kam der Pilot in Turbulenzen").
  • Tree Collisions: Shortly after takeoff, pilots can drift and collide with trees. If after takeoff, pilots cannot clear the treetops, they should turn left (East) as there is a large emergency landing area in that direction ("Start in einer Waldschneise. Wenn nach Start das Überfliegen der Baumkronen nicht möglich ist, nach links (Osten) abdrehen - große Notlandemöglichkeit!").
  • Thalerhof Airport Approach: Pilots should pay attention to their altitude because the approach path to Thalerhof Airport begins over the launch site, especially with stronger south winds ("Weiters auf die Höhe achten, da über dem Startplatz (bei stärkeren Südwind) der Anflug zum Flughafen Thalerhof beginnt").
  • No Flying Before Sunrise and After Sunset: The site is not flyable after civil twilight.
  • Smoking Ban: There is an absolute smoking ban at the launch site ("absolutes Rauchverbot am Startplatz!").
search_recs: Gelderkogel paragliding access Gelderkogel Gleitschirmfliegen Gelderkogel paragliding Gelderkogel paragliding official site Gelderkogel paragliding fees Gelderkogel Fluggebiet

html:
Overview

The Grünberg, located in Gmunden, in the picturesque Traunsee-Almtal region of Upper Austria, offers a unique paragliding experience amidst stunning scenery. With panoramic views of the Traunsee lake and surrounding mountains, including the iconic Traunstein, this site is renowned for its thermaling opportunities, albeit with a demanding nature.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Known for strong thermals, allowing experienced pilots to soar towards the Traunstein under favorable conditions.
  • Typical Flight Duration: Flights typically last 15-20 minutes, but can be extended significantly with good thermal activity.
  • Prevailing Wind: The primary and only permitted launch direction is West (W).
  • Important Considerations:
    • Pilots must overfly the cable car cables when flying to the landing area.
    • Be aware of the presence of 4 cable car cables and a telephone cable.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Grünberg is NOT suitable for beginners. The Flying Swans Traunsee club emphasizes that pilots must hold the required certifications and insurance. A thorough briefing from an experienced pilot or club member is highly recommended due to the demanding nature of the launch site.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Access to the take-off is conveniently provided by the Grünberg cable car.
  • Day Ticket: A day ticket including the cable car ride and paraglider transport is required. As of Summer 2025, prices are: Adults €43.70, Youth €39.40, Children €24.10.
  • Membership: Only members of Union Flying Swans Traunsee are authorized to fly at the site. Non-members are encouraged to join the club.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Sensitivity: The Grünberg is highly sensitive to wind conditions.
  • Valley Wind (Talwind): Be acutely aware of the "Talwind," which can create a dangerous tailwind at launch, even with a West wind aloft. This can make launching from the short site very difficult and reaching the landing area impossible.
  • Limited Landing Options: Beyond the official landing area, options are severely limited, with only a small emergency landing meadow next to the lake available. The surrounding area consists of forest and the lake, posing significant hazards.
  • Cable Car Cables: After launch, pilots must fly close to the slope, over the forest, and over the cable car cables against the wind. This requires precise piloting skills.
  • Spontaneous Winds: Strong thermal activity can induce strong valley winds toward Ebensee, causing tailwinds at launch. Winds from North to East can develop suddenly. Launching is not advised under these conditions due to difficulties clearing obstacles.
  • Short Launch Site: The West launch site is relatively short. In low or zero wind, pilots must utilize the full launch area to allow for a safe aborted launch before the road.
  • Limited Space at Takeoff: The launch site is situated in a forest aisle near a transmitter mast.

Landing Restrictions

  • Schafwiese (Sheep Meadow): No longer available due to cattle grazing and fencing.
  • Weyer (Castle) Landing Area: Available free of charge, but pilots must be considerate and respectful to the landowners.
  • Road Restrictions: The road to the landing site is off-limits to cars.
  • Railway Line: The landing area is adjacent to a railway line. Pilots must maintain adequate clearance when flying over the overhead lines during the landing approach.
search_recs: Grünberg Gleitschirmfliegen Austria Grünberg paragliding site Austria Grünberg Fliegen Austria Grünberg startplatz Austria

html:
Overview

The Zwölferhorn, located in St. Gilgen am Wolfgangsee in the scenic Salzkammergut region of Austria, offers breathtaking views of the turquoise-blue Lake Wolfgangsee and the surrounding Alpine foothills. With a launch site sitting at approximately 1,500 meters above sea level, it is a popular site for both thermal and scenic flying. Tandem flights and pilot training are also common here.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Known for thermal and scenic flying, training, and tandem flights.
  • Seasonality: Best from April to October. Cable car operations are less frequent from November to March, with closures in November and snow from January to March.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • North (NE to NW) winds are safest for takeoff.
    • With West winds, a rotor can form behind the edge, simulating lift at takeoff. Observe windsocks carefully!
    • Landing can be tricky, especially in spring and summer afternoons due to the "Brunnwind" (thermal compensating wind from the north) pushing thermals towards the landing area.
  • Thermals: Strong thermals are common in the area during the summer.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Zwölferhorn is rated as a medium difficulty site. It's a popular spot for tandem flights and training. While suitable for pilots with some experience, the landing area can be tricky and should not be underestimated, particularly in the afternoon.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car: The primary access is via the Zwölferhorn cable car from St. Gilgen (approximately 11 minutes).
  • Hiking: Hiking to the top is also possible (approximately 2.5 hours).
  • Fees:
    • Cable Car: A day pass for paragliders costs €46.00.
    • Site Usage: A daily or annual ticket/membership from the "Verein Erhaltung Fluggebiet Zwölferhorn" is required for takeoff and landing sites. Purchase online or at flight schools/tandem companies.
  • Parking: The first 4 hours are free for cable car ticket holders.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Pay close attention to wind direction during takeoff; it should come from the front (North to Northeast). A rotor can form with West winds.
  • Landing Challenges: Thermic winds from the village and fields can create difficult landing conditions in the afternoon. Expect possible turbulence and longer landing approaches.
  • Rotor Risk: Risk of rotors near the launch site under certain wind conditions.
  • Takeoff Restrictions:
    • Voitlhütte Takeoff: Only usable when the pasture fence is not erected (usually May to September).
    • Takeoff is only allowed in a northerly direction (marked in red).
    • Taking off from Jagafleck (East) and Arnikahütte (South) is prohibited.
  • Designated Areas Only: Takeoffs and landings are only permitted at designated areas managed by the "Verein Erhaltung Fluggebiet Zwölferhorn".

html:
Overview

The Muckenkogel, situated in the Gutensteiner Alps near Lilienfeld, Lower Austria, is a popular paragliding site known for its good flying conditions with northern winds. Reaching an elevation of approximately 1248 meters (4095 feet), the site offers pre-alpine scenery and opportunities for thermal flying. Access is convenient via the Lilienfeld chairlift, making it a readily accessible option for pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Suitability: Primarily suited for northern winds.
  • Aircraft Type: Flying is permitted with both single and tandem paragliders. Hang gliders are not allowed.
  • Launch Sites: Multiple launch sites are available, including one for North-Westerly winds and another for Westerly winds.
  • Thermal Flying: The area is suitable for thermal flying.
  • Local Knowledge: It is crucial to get information from local pilots before your first flight.

Who Should Fly Here?

While popular, the Muckenkogel is not recommended for beginners by some. Guest pilots should always seek instruction from a club member before their first flight. Caution is advised when landing during thermically active times. This site is best suited for intermediate to experienced pilots comfortable with thermal conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Chairlift Access: Accessibility is facilitated by the Lilienfeld chairlift. Flying is dependent on the chairlift's operating hours, so check the summer schedule.
  • Flight Fee: A flight area fee (€2) is required, with free access for club members. This fee should be deposited in the designated collection box near the landing site's windsock.
  • Combined Ticket: The daily flight fee is included when purchasing a lift ticket.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Briefing Required: Guest pilots should be briefed by a club member before their first flight at Muckenkogel.
  • Launch Area: The main launch (Muckenkogel 1) is located at the upper end of a forest clearing. Launch direction is north at the very top or east in the forest clearing
  • Experienced Pilots Only: One source indicates Muckenkogel is "Nix für Anfänger !!!" (Not for beginners!!!)
search_recs: Muckenkogel Gleitschirmfliegen Muckenkogel paragliding site Paragliding Muckenkogel site information Muckenkogel Fluggebiet

html:
Overview

Hohe Salve, a panoramic mountain in the Kitzbühel Alps of Tyrol, Austria, offers paragliders stunning 360° views and excellent thermal conditions. With a distinctive conical shape and a summit reaching 1,829 meters, this popular site attracts pilots from all over.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Conditions: Known for excellent thermals, making it ideal for thermaling.
  • Take-off Points: Several take-off points are located near the summit, including Hohe Salve NW, Hohe Salve SW, and Hohe Salve SE.
  • Flying Season: Possible in both summer and winter, depending on cable car operating hours.
  • Cross-Country Potential: Pilots can fly towards the Kaisergebirge, following a marked route to the Inn valley. Connecting with thermals for XC flights is possible, but an overland authorization (B certificate) is required.
  • Landing Options: Hopfgarten and Söll offer designated landing areas.

Who Should Fly Here?

Hohe Salve is suitable for a range of pilots:

  • Beginners: Tandem flights are available for those without a paragliding license.
  • Licensed Pilots: Solo flights require a valid paragliding license as per Austrian regulations.
  • Experienced Pilots: Excellent conditions for thermaling and cross-country flying (with appropriate certification).

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: The summit is easily reached by cable car from Hopfgarten or Söll.
  • Fees: A single trip on the Hohe Salve cable car costs €24.00. Morning, afternoon, and day tickets are available. Special paragliding season passes for the SkiWelt or Kitzbühel Alps regions can also be purchased. Landing fees are included in the cable car ticket price.
  • Parking: Parking is available at the base of the cable car, free with a cable car ticket.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • "Eingesperrtwerden" (Being Trapped): Risk of getting trapped in flat wooded areas or behind the high-voltage power line, especially when flying towards Hopfgarten.
  • Lee Conditions: West winds can cause lee-side conditions above the Rigi-Station. Northerly winds can create lee conditions when turning from the NW launch site towards Hopfgarten over the Rigi-Scharte.
  • Turbulence: Strong sinking and turbulence can occur in the upper slopes of the Kelchsauer Ache valley in the afternoon due to valley wind lee.
  • Strong North Winds: Avoid flights on the south side with large-scale northerly winds due to strong lee and brutal lee thermals. Gusts of wind can affect glider control.
  • Prallhänge (Impact Slopes): With a large-scale northerly current, the valley wind from Kufstein through the Weissachgraben develops reliably, creating impact slopes on the north side of the Salve (Oberer Hausberg, Aukogel, and summit region) and on the north side of the neighboring Brandstadel peak.
  • Cable Car Collision: Risk of drifting into the path of the Gondelbahn/cable car.
  • Takeoff Hazards: All takeoffs are located in the summit area near skiers and ski slopes.
  • Landing Place: Only use the official landing site, located approximately 500m from the Söll valley station and 80m west of the lowest parking lot, marked by a clearly visible wind vane.
  • Landing Restrictions: Watch out for the nearby power line, especially in strong valley winds, and potential tractor traffic. Land only south (above) the path. Landing below the path or in unmown meadows incurs a €20 fee.
  • Access Restrictions: Driving and parking are banned on the private road to the landing site. Park only in designated parking areas of the cable cars.
  • Nature Reserve: A strict take-off ban is in effect in the Wilder Kaiser nature reserve.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Adhere to all airspace restrictions.
search_recs: Hohe Salve flying conditions Hohe Salve paragliding site Austria Paragliding Hohe Salve official site Gleitschirmfliegen Hohe Salve Hohe Salve paragliding access

html:
Overview

The Schmittenhöhe, located in Zell am See, Austria, is a popular paragliding site offering stunning panoramic views of Lake Zell and the surrounding Alps, including over 30 peaks exceeding 3,000 meters. Known for its excellent thermal conditions and popularity, the Schmittenhöhe is a favorite for both local and international pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Known for excellent thermal conditions, suitable for both thermal and cross-country (XC) flights. The Schmittenhöhe is the starting point for the "Pinzgauer Spaziergang" (Pinzgau walk), a popular XC route.
  • Seasonality: The prime time for thermalling and XC flights is from April to August. Paragliding is possible as early as February, offering flights over the snow-covered Pinzgau region in winter.
  • Wind Conditions: Pilots should be aware of west and north winds, as well as foehn wind conditions.
  • Thermal Activity: Strong thermals are common, especially during May, June, and July.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Schmittenhöhe is a versatile site suitable for both solo pilots and tandem flights with certified pilots. Tandem flights are a good option for first-time paragliding experiences. Solo pilots should be aware of air space restrictions. The site's popularity means pilots should be comfortable sharing thermals and airspace.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the launch sites is via cable car (Schmittenhöhebahn, trassXpress/Areitbahn III).
  • Fees: A cable car ticket is required to access the launch sites. There is a fee for taking off and landing, payable at the cable car station. The Zell am See-Kaprun Summer Card may offer free rides on the cable car and/or discounts on flights with partner companies.
  • Landing: The primary landing area is near Fürth, close to the train station, which provides public transportation back to the valley station. Other landing options include the meadow at the Fürth-Kaprun railway crossing and the Piesendorf landing site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Restrictions (LOWZ): Proximity of Zell am See Airport (LOWZ) is a major consideration. The restricted area of the airport reaches a height of 5,000 ft MSL (approximately 1500m MSL). Flying below the prescribed altitude and, in particular, landing in this area is strictly prohibited.
  • Landing Approach to Fürth: When approaching the landing site at Fürth, pilots are instructed to dissipate altitude north of the B311 road and above the houses. The eastern boundary is the road to Kaprun. Entry into the Zell am See Airport flight zone is only permitted below 150m above ground level.
  • Föhn Wind: Be aware of Föhn wind conditions. If the wind is coming from the east, the danger is less; however, southerly winds exceeding 25 km/h require caution. There is a risk of sudden, sharp increases in wind speed.
  • Turbulence: Turbulence can occur, especially in the lee of obstacles.
  • Takeoff Areas: Launching is permitted only from the marked area.
  • TMA Restrictions: To fly over the TMA, pilots must be at least 5000ft/QNH
  • Important Notes:
    • Pilots who do not comply with the mentioned conditions and generally valid regulations will be reported to the local police and the Federal Office for Civil Aviation.
    • The use of the flying area is at your own risk.
    • Always check current NOTAMs and weather conditions before flying.
    • Contact local paragliding clubs or schools for up-to-date information and advice.
search_recs: Schmittenhöhe paragliding fees Schmittenhöhe Gleitschirmfliegen Schmittenhöhe paragliding site Austria Paragliding Schmittenhöhe official site Schmittenhöhe paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Stoderzinken, nestled in the Ennstal valley of Austria, is a renowned paragliding site boasting stunning panoramic views of the Enns Valley and the majestic Dachstein massif. With a launch site soaring at 2,048m (6,719ft), Stoderzinken offers a diverse range of flying opportunities, making it a hotspot in the Alps for thermaling and cross-country (XC) flights since 1989.

Flying Conditions

  • Versatile Flying Site: Stoderzinken is suitable for training, hike & fly adventures, scenic flights, and exhilarating evening soaring, with thermals kicking in early, especially from the Peter Rosegger launch.
  • Launch Sites for All Winds: Benefit from launch sites tailored to accommodate various wind directions, ensuring optimal flight conditions.
  • Seasonal Considerations: The Peter Rosegger launch operates from March 31st to October 30th. During the winter closure (October 31st to March 31st), launches are limited to the summit, with flights directed eastward at high altitude to protect wildlife.
  • Afternoon Wind Shift: Be aware that the wind can shift to North-Northwest at the south launch in the late afternoon. Consider using the north launch to avoid tailwind conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Stoderzinken's popularity makes it a hub for paragliders. While the site is appealing for its XC potential, caution is advised for beginner pilots due to the potential for strong thermals and limited landing options. Seeking local support is highly recommended. Tandem paragliding flights are available.

Access & Facilities

  • Toll Road Access: Access the launch sites via a toll road (Mautstrasse).
  • Short Hike: A short walk from the parking area at Steinerhaus leads to the south launch (Peter Rosegger), or a 30-minute hike takes you to the summit launch sites.
  • Shuttle Service: Sky Club Austria provides a Fliegertaxi (shuttle) from May to October for a fee, including toll and insurance.
  • Sommercard Benefits: Inquire about Sommercard benefits, which may include toll road usage.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence Awareness: Stoderzinken can be turbulent, especially with wind from the North, Northwest, or East, and from midday due to valley winds. The Peter Rosegger launch may become leeward and turbulent.
  • Wind Direction Changes: In the afternoon, be prepared for wind shifts to North-Northwest at the south launch, potentially leading to tailwind conditions.
  • Hang Glider Ramp Turbulence: Avoid launching directly next to the hang glider ramp due to severe turbulence.
  • Takeoff Permission: Pilots with Austrian school confirmation for independent training flights must receive flight instruction from the Flugschule Sky Club Austria.
  • A-License Holders: Pilots with an A-license/Paragliding license are advised to launch before 11:00 AM on thermally active days.
  • FlyPark Dachstein Card: Use of take-off and landing areas in the FlyPark Dachstein is restricted to Sky Club Austria members or holders of the Sky Club Austria FlyPark-Dachstein Card. Registration is required for non-members.
  • Tandem Flight Restrictions: Tandem passenger flights are limited to pilots instructed by the Sky Club Austria flying school.
  • Hike & Fly Registration: Hike & Fly take-offs from Pleschnitzinken and Gumpeneck require prior registration with the Flugschule Sky Club Austria.
  • Wind Speed Limits: Take-off is prohibited if the wind speed exceeds 2/3 of the glider's trim speed.
  • Turbulent Wind Conditions: Flying is not allowed in highly turbulent wind conditions.
  • Sky Club Austria Lease: The flying area Stoderzinken is exclusively leased by the flying school Sky Club Austria for the operation of the flying school and for Sky Club Austria Club members. Check Sky Club Austria website for guest pilot rules.
search_recs: Stoderzinken access paragliding Stoderzinken paragliding official site Stoderzinken paragliding site information Stoderzinken Gleitschirmfliegen Stoderzinken Fluggebiet

html:
Overview

Penken is a prominent mountain in the Zillertal valley of Tyrol, Austria, near the vibrant town of Mayrhofen. Renowned for its stunning alpine scenery and reliable thermal conditions, Penken attracts paragliders from across Europe. With significant elevation differences and multiple launch options, it's a fantastic site for both local and visiting pilots seeking thermal and cross-country (XC) flying adventures.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Flying: Penken is known for its excellent thermals, making it ideal for gaining altitude and embarking on cross-country flights.
  • Launch Directions: Primary launch sites face North-Northeast-East. Alternative launch sites at Finkenberg/Penkenjoch (facing South-Southwest-West) provide options during unfavorable wind conditions.
  • Cross-Country Potential: Flights from Penken can extend over the Kreuzjoch and Gerlospass into Pinzgau, or along the Zillertal towards the Inntal.
  • Year-Round Flying: Penken offers opportunities for paragliding throughout the year, including winter flights with skis.
  • Valley Wind System: Pilots should be aware of the prevailing valley wind system and the potential for foehn wind conditions.
  • Glide Ratio Requirement: A minimum glide ratio of 6 is necessary to clear a flat ridge safely after launch.
  • Turbulence Consideration: Be mindful of potential turbulence near the south-side chairlift installation.

Who Should Fly Here?

Penken welcomes both tandem flights and solo pilots. While generally suitable for intermediate to advanced pilots, the launch site near the Knorrenlift requires more experience due to the steeper terrain. Experience with thermal flying is highly recommended.

Access & Facilities

  • Gondola Access: Reach the launch sites via the Penkenbahn gondola from Mayrhofen, followed by the Kombibahn.
  • Free Gondola Return: Pilots with equipment can use the gondolas to return to the valley for free if weather prevents flying.
  • Landing Areas: Designated landing areas include Bruggerstube (Mayrhofen), Hippach, Sidan, and near Hotel Edenlehen in Mayrhofen.
  • Landing Fees: Inquire about landing fees with the Zillertaler Flugschule.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Avoid flying directly over the chairlift on the south side due to turbulence risks.
  • Strong Valley Winds: Be prepared for strong valley winds, especially in the afternoon.
  • Takeoff Considerations (Penken East - Kombibahn):
    • The launch area transitions quickly from a slight incline to a steeper slope – avoid overshooting.
    • Maintain a minimum distance of 50 meters from the cable car after takeoff.
  • Takeoff Considerations (Penken South - Knorrenlift): The terrain is steep and requires experience.
  • Winter Restrictions: Starting and landing on prepared ski slopes is strictly prohibited during winter.
  • Power Lines: Exercise extreme caution regarding power lines near the Bruggerstube landing site.
  • Airspace Awareness: Be aware of Inn Valley flight restrictions when planning long-distance flights.
  • Minimum Glide Ratio: Gliders must have a glide ratio of at least 6 to overfly the initial flat section after launch.
search_recs: Penken Fluggebiet Penken Austria official paragliding information Penken paragliding site Austria Paragliding Penken Zillertal

html:
Overview

Feuerkogel is a popular paragliding site in Upper Austria, nestled in the scenic Salzkammergut region near Ebensee. Situated on a high plateau at 1,592 meters above sea level, it offers breathtaking views of the Salzkammergut region and Traunsee lake. Known for its thermaling potential and opportunities for cross-country flights, Feuerkogel is a favorite among experienced pilots seeking challenging and rewarding flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Best Time to Fly: Spring and Summer offer the most favorable conditions.
  • Launch Points: Multiple launch points are available, including a north-facing and an east-facing launch.
    • North Launch: A shorter, steeper launch site recommended for experienced pilots only. Thermal lift can sometimes obscure the main wind direction.
    • East Launch: Requires flying over relatively flat terrain after launch. Deviating to the left after launch poses a risk due to unlandable terrain and gondola cables.
  • Wind Conditions: Turbulence can occur even in moderate winds. West and South winds should be avoided.
  • Soaring: The area east of the landing zone (Haslergupf/Eibenberg) is suitable for soaring.

Who Should Fly Here?

While popular, Feuerkogel is not suitable for beginners or pilots in training. The North Launch, in particular, is recommended for experienced pilots only. An introduction by a local pilot is mandatory before flying here. Pilots should be comfortable with potentially turbulent conditions and have strong piloting skills.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: The primary access to the launch sites is via the Feuerkogel cable car.
  • Cable Car Tickets:
    • One-way ascent for paragliders: €22.10 (2025 price).
    • One-way ascent for hang gliders: €31.50 (2025 price).
    • Day ticket for both: €47.30 (2025 price).
    • "Naturally 365 Ticket" available for Dachstein plus Club members, providing access to multiple cable cars and ski regions, including Feuerkogel.
  • Landing Area: Located northeast of the B145 Ebensee/Rindbach exit.
  • Parking: No parking is available at the landing field. Short-term parking for loading/unloading is possible along "Alte-Traun-Str."

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Avoid flying in West or South wind conditions.
  • Turbulence: Be prepared for potentially strong turbulence, even in moderate winds.
  • Launch Considerations:
    • Beware of launching into an "scheinbaren Aufwind" (apparent updraft) or lee rotor.
    • Be aware of the cable car cables during launch and maintain a 50m distance.
    • The hang gliding ramp at the North Launch is like a cliff launch.
  • Landing Restrictions:
    • Landing is strictly prohibited at the Hutterer Böden middle station and on all ski slopes.
  • Landing Area Conditions: The landing area is surrounded by trees on three sides and often has strong valley winds. Pack equipment only in the windsock area after landing.
  • Documentation: Ensure you have the necessary certifications, liability insurance, and mountain rescue insurance.
  • Environmental Responsibility: Respect the local flora and fauna, private property, landowners, and residents to ensure the site remains open in the future.
  • VFR Rules: Adhere to Visual Flight Rules (VFR) and avoid flying in conditions with impaired visibility.
