html:
Overview

Hirschwaldstein is a popular paragliding and hang gliding site located in Upper Austria (Oberösterreich), near Micheldorf. Situated in the rolling hills and foothills of the Alps, with launch points near Altpernstein Castle, this site offers excellent cross-country (XC) potential and is known for its thermaling conditions.

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable for: Both paragliding and hang gliding.
  • Wind Direction: Flyable with west to northwest winds.
  • Thermals: Known for good thermal activity, offering excellent XC potential.

Who Should Fly Here?

  • Skybird Kremstal is the largest hang gliding and paragliding club in Upper Austria, indicating the site's popularity.
  • Suitable for both single and tandem flights.
  • One of the take-off points ("Hauserbauer/Kronbauer") is reserved for experienced club members.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easily accessible by car and on foot.
  • Fees: There is a fee of €8 to fly at Hirschwaldstein, payable at the Gasthof Veits near the landing area.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Landing Areas: Be aware that emergency landing areas may be limited due to rocky or rough terrain.
  • Wind Conditions: Strong gusts of wind can occur, potentially causing pitching mid-flight. It's crucial to check weather forecasts and use an anemometer. Spring conditions tend to be stronger than those in autumn.
  • Crowded Sites: Maintain awareness in crowded flying sites and adhere to priority rules. Do not assume conditions are suitable for you simply because other wings are in the air.
  • Hirschwaldstein Startplatz: When hang gliders are preparing to launch from the ramp, paragliders are prohibited from launching above them. Hang gliders should only approach the ramp immediately before launching.

Flight Restrictions

  • Skybird Kremstal Club: The primary users of the launch site are experienced pilots from the Skybird Kremstal club. Pilots might be required to show their club card and a special pilot certificate.
  • Launch Times: Launches are not allowed before 10:00 AM and after 5:00 PM.
  • Access: Access to the launch site must be via the forest road and designated hiking trails. Taking shortcuts through the forest is strictly prohibited.
  • Noise: "Jodeln od. Gröllen" (Yodeling or Groaning) after launch is not permitted. Violations may lead to an immediate launch ban.
  • Walk & Fly Only: Ascent via vehicle is not allowed.
  • Guest Pilot Regulations: Pilots holding a hang gliding or paragliding license from specific countries (including Australia, Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Hungary, France, Italy, Lithuania, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Romania, Sweden, Switzerland, Slovakia, Slovenia, Ukraine) may fly legally, provided they also have third-party liability insurance and carry both their license and insurance card. Pilots from other countries might need a special 'Guest-License' from a local Austrian flying school.

Important Note: Always observe the information boards at the site and seek advice from local pilots regarding site-specific conditions. Be aware that wind and weather phenomena can make even seemingly simple flying areas challenging.
search_recs: Hirschwaldstein paragliding club Hirschwaldstein Gleitschirmfliegen Österreich Hirschwaldstein paragliding Austria Hirschwaldstein paragliding site information Hirschwaldstein paragliding landing zones Hirschwaldstein paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

The Choralpe is a popular paragliding site located in Westendorf, Tyrol, Austria, within the beautiful Kitzbühel Alps. Known for its stunning high-mountain landscape and excellent flying conditions, the Choralpe attracts pilots seeking both thermaling and ridge soaring opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals & Soaring: The site is known for thermaling and ridge soaring opportunities. Thermals are easiest to find from late morning, especially to the right in front of the west launch site.
  • Flight Paths: With good thermals, pilots can fly towards Pinzgau. Shorter flights along the Brixental valley are also common. "Brixental hopping" to Hohe Salve and back is popular.
  • Dynamic Soaring: The edge to the left and right of the west launch is suitable for soaring in dynamic westerly winds.
  • Year-Round Flying: Flying is possible year-round, except during lift maintenance periods.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Choralpe, with its high mountains, multiple launch sites, and large landing area, is suitable for both beginner and experienced pilots. It also accommodates both single and tandem flights, as well as paragliding training.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Access to the launch sites is via the Alpenrosenbahn 1 & 2 cable car.
  • Walking Distance: In summer, a 15-minute walk from the mountain station will get you to the launch sites.
  • Lift Ticket: Fees are included in the lift ticket price. A single ascent with the Alpenrosenbahn 1 + 2 (Choralpe) costs €28.00. Various season tickets are also available.
  • Tourist Information: Additional details can be obtained from the Westendorf tourist office (Schulgasse 2, A-6363 Westendorf) or the SkiWelt mountain railways office (Bergliftstraße 18, A-6363 Westendorf).
  • Flying School: Further information may be available from the Flying School Westendorf (Bergliftstraße 22, A-6363 Westendorf).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Talwind Convergence: The Choralpe and Hohe Salve are subject to *Talwind* (valley wind) convergence, meaning the wind direction at the launch site may differ from the general forecast. Pilots should pay close attention to local wind indicators. Often there is an easterly wind even if the forecast indicates a westerly direction.
  • Lee Conditions: When the *Bayrische Wind* (Bavarian Wind) takes over, the south face of the Hohe Salve can experience significant lee conditions. This is particularly important to note on the ridge between Hohe and Niederer Salve.
  • North Launch Considerations: The north launch is narrower and steeper, suitable for only two gliders being laid out simultaneously. After launch from the east take off, pilots must ensure sufficient altitude to clear the ridge to the north to reach the landing area.
  • Winter Launch Restrictions: In winter, launches towards the north and east are virtually impossible due to ski operations.
  • License and Insurance: Pilots must possess a valid paragliding license and liability insurance.
  • Guest Pilot Requirements: Guest pilots may need a "Guest-Licence" from a local Austrian flying school if their national license isn't recognized. Proof of qualification (IPPI card or national license) is required.
  • Crowded Sites: Be aware of other pilots and overcrowding.
search_recs: Choralpe Gleitschirmfliegen Österreich Choralpe paragliding site Austria Choralpe paragliding official information

html:
Overview

Marsbach is a popular paragliding site located in Upper Austria (Oberösterreich), near the German border and the town of Hofkirchen im Mühlkreis. Renowned for its thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying opportunities along the scenic Danube River valley, particularly near the Schlögener Schlinge (a prominent bend in the Danube). Flying takes place near the Pühringer estate.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Primarily thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying. Ridge soaring is possible with suitable South-East to South-West wind conditions.
  • Seasonality: XC flights are most common from March through October.
  • Local Hotspot: The "Loch" (a hollow behind the Marsbach castle) is a well-known thermaling spot, offering strong thermals (the "Hausbart"). However, this area should only be flown with guidance from local pilots due to the potential for lee-side conditions and regional wind with an easterly component.
  • Danube Proximity: Due to the site's proximity to the Donau river, specific rules must be observed.

Who Should Fly Here?

Marsbach is a site with a long paragliding history dating back to around 1989. The takeoff area is considered easy, suitable for both forward and reverse launches. However, the landing area near the takeoff is not suitable for beginners. Novice pilots should be aware of cyclists and traffic when landing near the road. A site briefing from experienced local pilots is highly recommended, particularly before flying in the "Loch" thermaling area.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the takeoff is by car, followed by a short walk.
  • Fees: Guest pilots are welcome and are expected to purchase a day membership for €5. This can usually be acquired from club members at the takeoff during flyable weather, and may include a ride back to the top.
  • Club Operated: The site is club-operated. More information is available on the Gleitschirmclub (GSC) Marsbach website: https://gsc-marsbach.jimdo.com/.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Local Expertise is Key: The "Loch" area is known for strong thermals (the "Hausbart"), but should only be flown with guidance from pilots familiar with the area. An unpleasant lee-side thermal can develop at the eastern end of the "Loch" when the regional wind has an easterly component.
  • Takeoff Hazards: The takeoff area is crossed by a path. Pilots must ensure they are airborne before reaching it and account for possible aborted takeoffs *before* the path.
  • Membership and Licensing: The flying area is free for members of the GSC-Marsbach club. Guest pilots can use the flying area with a day membership from the Hochfichtflyers. To fly in Austria legally, pilots need an Austrian, Swiss, or German license. Otherwise, a "Guest-Licence" can be obtained from a local Austrian flying school with proof of qualification (e.g., IPPI card or national license).
  • Insurance: Pilots in Austria must have third-party liability insurance and carry their license and insurance card.

html:
Overview

Fulseck is a popular paragliding site nestled in Dorfgastein, within the scenic Gastein Valley of Austria. Situated in the mountainous Salzburg region, near the summit station of the Gipfelbahn Fulseck cable car, the site offers breathtaking panoramic views of the Austrian Alps, including the majestic Hohe Tauern mountain range. With altitudes ranging from 800 to 2,000 meters, Fulseck is a destination for pilots seeking pleasure, thermal, high-altitude, and cross-country flights.

Flying Conditions

Fulseck is renowned for its excellent thermal conditions, making it a year-round paragliding destination. The ideal launch site depends on the prevailing wind direction, with the Fulseck being particularly well-suited for westerly winds. Spring conditions can result in stronger wind gusts compared to autumn.

Who Should Fly Here?

Fulseck welcomes pilots of all skill levels, from novices to seasoned cross-country experts. Its reputation within the province of Salzburg and the presence of paragliding schools like Flugschule Salzburg, offering courses, further solidifies its appeal. Be mindful that the east-facing takeoff is small and can be challenging.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: The Gipfelbahn Fulseck cable car from Dorfgastein and the Kieserlbahn cable car from Großarltal valley provide convenient access to the launch sites.
  • Paragliding Ticket: A specific paragliding ticket is available for ascent via the Gipfelbahn Fulseck cable car. Cable car tickets including sports equipment transport are needed.
  • Winter Access: During winter months, access to the alternative take-off site 200 meters north of the main take-off site involves a short walk along the winter hiking trail.
  • Fees: A day ticket costs €38 for adults. Summer season tickets for Gastein-Großarl and the Ski amadé ALL-IN Card Green include unlimited use of the summer cable cars and equipment transport.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Foehn Winds: The Gastein Valley is prone to Foehn winds due to its north-south orientation, which can lead to hazardous flying conditions.
  • Hunting Zone: The Arltörl area between Fulseck and Schuhflicker is a designated hunting zone. A minimum altitude of 300 meters above ground must be maintained when overflying this area.
  • Turbulence: Strong west/northwest winds can create significant turbulence, particularly near the landing site due to nearby houses and trees.
  • Winter Takeoff: During winter operations, launching on the ski piste is strictly prohibited. Pilots should use the designated alternative take-off site.
  • Nature Reserve: Flight restrictions are in place within the nature reserve north of the ridge (Heukareck - Schuhflicker - Paarsee).
  • Bird Protection Area: Flight restrictions apply in the bird protection area in Rauris.
  • Hohe Tauern National Park: Flight restrictions apply within the Hohe Tauern National Park.
  • Landing Circuit: Always perform a right-hand circuit when landing at the main Dorfgastein landing site; position over the swimming pool, base leg over the parking lot, and final turn before the high and low voltage power lines.
  • Alternate Landing: If there is a strong south wind, pilots should use the 'Clubwiese' landing site.
  • Power Lines: Exercise caution around the high and low voltage power lines near the landing field in Dorfgastein. Approach from the north and avoid flying over railway tracks and high-voltage lines.
  • Minimum Altitude: In a soaring/thermal seeking situation or when on final approach or right after takeoff you are only allowed to fly closer than 150 m to the ground.
search_recs: Fulseck paragliding site information paragliding Fulseck Austria Fulseck paragliding official site Fulseck paragliding fees Fulseck paragliding requirements

html:
Overview

Nestled in the heart of Tyrol, Austria, the Zillertal valley offers a breathtaking alpine paragliding experience. Renowned for its stunning scenery, varied launch sites between 1100m and 3200m AMSL, and altitude differences of 600m to 1800m, Zillertal attracts pilots seeking both thermal soaring and cross-country adventures.

Flying Conditions

The Zillertal is celebrated for its outstanding thermal activity, making it a prime location for thermal flying and cross-country flights. Paragliding is possible year-round, offering unique winter flights over snow-covered landscapes.

  • Thermals: Excellent thermal conditions provide ample opportunities for gaining altitude and distance.
  • Seasonality: Fly year-round, enjoying both summer thermals and serene winter landscapes.
  • Weather Awareness: Always check detailed weather reports, paying close attention to thermal lift conditions before each flight.

Who Should Fly Here?

Zillertal caters to a wide range of skill levels. Beginners can enjoy tandem flights with experienced instructors, while seasoned pilots can tackle challenging cross-country routes. Note that some areas, particularly in Alpbachtal, are recommended for experienced pilots only.

Access & Facilities

Many launch sites in Zillertal are easily accessed via gondolas and cable cars, such as Penken, Spieljoch, and Finkenberger Almbahn. Gondolas provide quick access to the upper slopes and flying launch points.

  • Gondola Access: Utilize gondolas like Penkenbahn to reach high-altitude launch sites. A Penkenbahn ascent ticket costs approximately €18.00.
  • Lift Tickets: Lift tickets are required for gondola access; consider that some tandem flight packages may not include this fee.
  • Action Day Ticket: Consider an Action Day Ticket (e.g., for Mount Penken) which provides access for bikers and paragliders.
  • Return Transport: If weather conditions become unsuitable, many gondolas offer free return trips to the valley.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

While Zillertal offers incredible flying opportunities, it’s essential to be aware of specific risks and potential hazards.

  • Valley Winds: Be vigilant regarding strong valley winds, especially between June and September, which can reach 30-40 km/h up to 1600m AMSL.
  • Föhn Winds: The Zillertal is susceptible to Föhn winds, particularly in spring and autumn. Exercise caution, especially on Penken, during these conditions.
  • Thunderstorm Outflow: On unstable summer days, outflow winds from thunderstorms in nearby valleys can create dangerous conditions. Cold air can penetrate as far as Mayrhofen.
  • Turbulence: The area around Mayrhofen and the Penken can experience significant turbulence around midday. Fly during the morning or late afternoon for smoother conditions.
  • Lee Conditions (Hamberg): Be aware of potential lee-side conditions on the south side of Hamberg in strong valley winds.
  • Wire Cables: Recent incidents highlight the risk of encountering forestry cables, especially when launching from unofficial sites.
  • Speedriding Restrictions: Check for local restrictions on speedriding, as some ski resorts may prohibit it.

html:
Overview

Holzbauer is a popular thermaling paragliding site located high above Leoben, Austria, known for offering potential for cross-country flights. Set in mountainous terrain with grassy slopes, this site is managed in cooperation with local landowners and the Soaring Club Präbichl, ensuring a well-maintained and regulated flying environment.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Best winds for launching are from the South.
  • Thermal Activity: Expect good thermals approximately 500m in front of the launch. Even in winters with little snow, some lift can be found.
  • Important Note: The local soaring club requests that pilots respect closures if cattle are present on the launch area.

Who Should Fly Here?

Holzbauer is a popular site, and maintaining a good relationship with the local farmer is essential. It's recommended to check with local flyers or the Soaring Club Präbichl for up-to-date information and any temporary restrictions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the launch site is by foot only, requiring approximately a 1-hour hike from the Schwesternheim near the landing area. The Soaring Club requests that pilots not use a car to access the take off area.
  • Fees: There is no mention of fees to use the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Livestock:
    • Cattle on Launch Field: Respect closures when cattle are present and avoid flying over grazing animals.
    • Launch Restrictions: Launching is forbidden when cattle are in the immediate vicinity of the launch site.
  • Takeoff Procedures:
    • Single Launches Only: Pilots must launch individually.
    • Launch Position: Pilots must launch from the top right corner of the launch area.
  • Landowner Relations & Access:
    • Respect Landowners: Access to both the launch and landing areas is a privilege.
    • Foot Access: Foot access to the launch site is requested.
    • Landing Zones: Landing should be done in the marked landing areas. Landing on the farmer's meadow is only allowed when it has been freshly mowed.

html:
Overview

Zettersfeld is a popular paragliding site in Osttirol, Austria, near the town of Lienz. Renowned for its breathtaking panoramic views of the Lienz Dolomites, the Drei Zinnen, and the glaciated summits of the Tauern, Zettersfeld offers pilots a unique alpine flying experience. The main launch site, "Steinermandl," sits at an impressive 2,200m, providing excellent altitude for soaring and cross-country adventures.

Flying Conditions

Zettersfeld is known for its reliable thermal activity, which typically starts in late morning. These conditions offer great potential for both soaring and cross-country (XC) flights into the surrounding Gail, Drau, Möll, Isel, and Pustertal valleys. With a favorable southwest wind, the site offers "wonderful soaring conditions" in both summer and winter. Pilots can plan flights towards Matrei (west), the Pustertal (southwest), or the Mölltal (northeast).

Who Should Fly Here?

Zettersfeld is a popular destination for paragliding, attracting both solo pilots and tandem flights. The launch site at Kollnig is considered easy, making it accessible to a range of experience levels. While the site is well-frequented, it generally isn't overly crowded, allowing pilots to enjoy their flights without excessive congestion.

Access & Facilities

  • Main Launch Site (Steinermandl): Access is via the Lienzer Bergbahnen cable cars.
  • Ebnerfeld Launch Site: Accessible by car via a toll road to Faschingalm. Taxis can also provide access, though they might not reach Steinermandl.
  • Landing Site: Located on the access road, 500m before the Zettersfeld valley station.
  • Fees: Be prepared for fees associated with the cable car and potentially the toll road to Ebnerfeld.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

Before flying at Zettersfeld, pilots should be aware of specific dangers and flight restrictions to ensure a safe experience:

  • Summer Winds: Be mindful of considerable summer winds in the valley, which can affect flights.
  • North and Northwest Winds: Exercise caution with north and northwest winds due to the potential for a lee situation at Zettersfeld, creating turbulent conditions.
  • Föhn Wind: Be aware of the potential for northerly föhn wind, which can bring strong and gusty conditions.
  • Turbulent Lee Thermals: In northerly conditions, expect considerable, turbulent lee thermals.
  • Ebnerfeld Takeoff: Has a risk of side wind and no visibility to the landing area from this launch.
  • Airspace Awareness: Pilots should be aware of airspace restrictions in the area.
  • Nikolsdorf Traffic: Exercise caution during route flights and flights past Nikolsdorf due to glider traffic and rescue helicopter activity between Nikolsdorf and the Lienz hospital.
  • Power Lines: Be aware of high-voltage power lines above the Postleite landing area.
  • Ski Area Restrictions: Speedflying is prohibited in the ski area. Maintain a minimum distance to chairlift and ski lift cables.
  • Guest Flight Regulation: Tandem operation and powered flying may not be allowed, if holding a valid license issued by a country mentioned in the Guest Flight Regulation.
search_recs: fluggebiet Zettersfeld Zettersfeld paragliding official site Zettersfeld paragliding site information Zettersfeld Gleitschirmfliegen

html:
Overview

The Schoberstein is a popular "walk & fly" paragliding site nestled in the Upper Austrian Prealps (Alpenvorland), near Ternberg and Molln in Upper Austria (Oberösterreich). This thermally active mountain offers excellent potential for cross-country (XC) flying and ridge soaring, attracting pilots seeking both challenging and rewarding flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Primarily a "walk & fly" site, requiring a hike to the launch. Known for good thermals and the potential for cross-country (XC) flying. Ridge soaring is also possible.
  • Seasonality: Flying is possible throughout the year, including winter months, depending on weather conditions. January can offer hike & fly opportunities with light thermals.
  • Thermal Activity: The site is thermally active, especially on its south-facing slopes. Be aware of strong thermals during midday; mornings and late afternoons may offer milder conditions.
  • Wind Considerations: Wind direction is crucial. The south-facing launch can become turbulent with northerly winds. Check wind and gust strength before flying. A webcam and weather station are available for real-time information.
  • Landing Areas: Two main landing areas are available, depending on wind direction.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Schoberstein is recommended for pilots with a medium skill level due to the thermal activity and potential turbulence. Hang landing experience is highly advisable. The hike to launch also requires a decent level of fitness.

Access & Facilities

  • Access Routes:
    • From Ternberg/Trattenbach: Hike from the Gasthaus Klausriegler. Parking is available; a fee may apply unless you patronize the Gasthaus.
    • From Molln: Access via the Güterweg Kogler to the Koglergut, followed by approximately a 1.5-hour hike.
  • Hike to Launch: Requires a 60-90 minute hike with a 600m elevation gain.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Thermic Conditions: Strong thermals, especially during midday, can make top landing more challenging and potentially dangerous.
  • Power Lines: Be aware of a power line located near the Gasthaus.
  • Launch Site 1 (South): Steep and grassy. In snowy conditions, gliders may slide downhill.
  • Hunting Times (East Launch Site): Respect hunting times, which occur one hour before sunrise and one hour after sunset.
  • Distance from Cliffs: Maintain a safe distance from cliff edges during flight.
  • Fees: There is a fee of 4 Euro for launching and landing, payable at the launch site or via bank transfer using a QR code.
  • Proximity to Nationalpark Kalkalpen: The site is near the Kalkalpen National Park, so be aware of any regulations related to flying near protected areas.

Disclaimer: Always supplement this information with current, up-to-date information from local flying schools, clubs, and weather services before flying at Schoberstein. Prioritize safety and fly within your skill level.
search_recs: Schoberstein paragliding club Schoberstein paragliding site information Schoberstein paragliding Schoberstein Gleitschirmfliegen Schoberstein hike and fly

html:
Overview

Golzentipp, situated in Obertilliach, East Tyrol, Austria, offers a fantastic paragliding experience amidst the stunning alpine meadows and mountains of the Lesachtal valley, near the Lienz Dolomites. Known for its reliable thermals and scenic views, Golzentipp is an official site suitable for a wide range of pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal and Ridge Soaring: The site is well-regarded for providing excellent thermal conditions, making it perfect for extended flights.
  • Wind Directions: Prevailing winds are generally from the East and West.
  • Cross-Country Potential: Opportunities for cross-country flights are available from this site.

Who Should Fly Here?

Golzentipp is often described as an "easy airfield" and "simple flying area," making it an excellent choice for beginners. However, experienced pilots will also find plenty to enjoy with the potential for long flights and scenic views. Tandem flights are also available for those looking to experience paragliding for the first time.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Access to the main launch is via the Golzentippbahn cable car, followed by a 15-minute walk from the top station.
  • Landing Area: A large landing site with a windsock is conveniently located on the southern outskirts of Obertilliach.
  • Fees: There are fees associated with using the cable car. As of Summer 2025, a single ascent for paragliders costs €18.00 for adults and €11.00 for children. A day ticket costs €37.00 for adults and €22.50 for children. A 7-day ticket costs €112.00 for adults and €67.00 for children. These fees include start and landing fees.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Conditions:
    • Strong Valley Winds: Be aware of potentially strong valley winds.
    • Strong Northerly Winds Aloft: Strong northerly upper winds can also pose a risk.
    • Foehn Winds: Foehn wind conditions can create dangerous flying conditions.
    • Thunderstorms: Thunderstorms are a significant hazard.
    • Turbulence: Strong turbulence can create flying issues.
  • Takeoff-Specific Risks:
    • Golzentipp 1 Launch ("Scheibe"): Unfavorable wind directions and strong gusts can make this launch unflyable. Suitable wind directions are SO, S, SW.
  • Flight Restrictions and Regulations:
    • General Flight Rules: Pilots must ensure that the airspace is clear before initiating and during turns.
    • Guest Flight Regulation: Be aware of Austria's "Guest Flight Regulation" regarding pilot licenses and potential validation requirements.
    • Maximum Wind Speed: Launches are prohibited if the wind speed at the takeoff site exceeds 2/3 of the glider's trim speed.
search_recs: Golzentipp paragliding fees access Golzentipp paragliding official site information Golzentipp paragliding site Austria Golzentipp Gleitschirmfliegen Österreich Golzentipp paragliding difficulty

html:
Overview

The Markbachjoch is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Wildschönau valley in Tyrol, Austria, within the stunning Kitzbühel Alps. This high valley features a beautiful blend of grassy slopes and mountain peaks, making it an attractive destination for pilots of all levels.

Flying Conditions

Markbachjoch is renowned as an excellent area for beginners and leisure pilots. Its sheltered location provides protection from strong Inntal winds, allowing for flying on many days throughout the year, typically from mid-May onwards. The primary flying style here is ridge soaring, with thermals generally not being strong due to the site's northerly aspect, creating routine and consistent flying conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

This site is particularly well-suited for beginner pilots and those undergoing paragliding training. The popularity of Markbachjoch is partly due to the main launch being conveniently located next to the Markbachjochhütte, a gathering spot for spectators and hikers.

Access & Facilities

Access to the primary launch sites is easy via the Markbachjochbahn gondola from Niederau. Upon landing, a large landing area is situated near the Hotel Harfenwirt, about a 10-minute walk from the gondola base. Additionally, a smaller landing spot is available near the base station, but requires an A-license/SOPI. Keep in mind that the cost of the gondola ride is the primary fee associated with accessing the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Gusty Conditions: Be aware that the launch site can sometimes experience gusty conditions, particularly with NE winds.
  • Airspace: Pay attention to the CTA INNSBRUCK-OST airspace restrictions.
  • Training Flights: The Wildschönau flight school frequently uses the area for high-altitude training flights. Coordination might be necessary, especially at the training launch site.
  • Landing Zones: Ensure you land in the designated landing areas, which include the large landing meadow at the Niederau village exit and the smaller landing site near the valley station.
  • Accidents Happen: While considered a beginner-friendly site, accidents can occur, so always exercise caution and fly within your skill level.
search_recs: Gleitschirmfliegen Markbachjoch Info Markbachjoch paragliding site guide paragliding Markbachjoch Austria Markbachjoch Gleitschirmfliegen Markbachjoch Fluggebiet

html:
Overview

Brauneck is a popular paragliding site located in Lenggries, in the Bavarian Alps, approximately 50 km south of Munich, Germany. This easily accessible site offers a range of launch options and is known for its good thermals, making it suitable for both thermal flying and cross-country (XC) flights towards the Karwendel mountains.

Flying Conditions

  • Launch Sites: Offers north, south, and east-facing launch sites for various wind conditions.
  • Thermals: Known for good thermal activity, suitable for thermal flying and XC flights.
  • Valley Winds: Valley winds often develop around midday, blowing up the Isar valley. This can cause turbulence, especially at the Garland (east) launch site.
  • Wind Considerations: Local knowledge is advised due to strong Bavarian winds. The site is relatively protected from Foehn winds but caution is still advised.

Who Should Fly Here?

Brauneck is a versatile site suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding. It is generally suitable for beginners, but local knowledge is recommended due to potentially challenging wind conditions. Student pilots at the south launch site must have completed at least 10 high-altitude flights at other flying sites. Training flights are restricted at the north launch site and only permitted with instructed flight instructors at the Garland launch site.

Access & Facilities

  • Accessibility: Easily accessible by car and public transportation (train and bus to Lenggries).
  • Ascent: Ascent to the launch sites is via the Brauneck Bergbahn (cable car). Paragliders must ensure their kites can be packed short (4.20 m) for transport on the cable car.
  • Fees: A lift ticket is required to use the Brauneck Bergbahn. Contact the Brauneck Bergbahn for prices.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Wind can be unpredictable, with changes in direction. Strong Bavarian winds can create challenging launch conditions, especially at the northern launch site in the afternoon.
  • Lee Conditions: Be aware of potential lee conditions, especially with West winds.
  • Turbulence: The Garland (east) launch site can get turbulent, especially when the valley wind sets in. Strong thermals can overlay lee conditions in the Nordkessel with East or Northeast winds, creating challenging conditions.
  • Forested Terrain: The mountain is heavily forested to the south and north.
  • North Launch Restrictions:
    • Launches are restricted to the designated north launch site at the wind measuring station. Launches are not permitted at Kirchstein.
    • No training flights are permitted.
    • Takeoffs are only permitted in northerly winds.
    • After takeoff, pilots must turn towards the landing area promptly.
  • South Launch Restrictions:
    • Training is only permitted by instructed flight instructors. Student pilots must have at least 10 high-altitude flights at other sites.
    • Risk of being in the lee of trees in westerly winds. Limited launch abort options.
  • East Launch (Garland) Restrictions:
    • Training operations (including two-seaters) are only permitted by instructed flight instructors. Wind conditions must guarantee safe overflight of the Garland saddle.
    • Be aware of the chairlift.
    • Turbulence possible when the valley wind sets in.
  • Wildlife Protection: The north side of the Brauneck-Benediktenwand ridge must be flown over at a minimum altitude of 150m above ground to protect wildlife.
  • Military Activity: On weekdays, pilots should avoid the military low-flying zone between 150m and 450m above ground.
  • Airspace: Pay attention to the airspace ceiling.
  • General Launching Advice: Only launch with headwind. No launching with tailwind or crosswind due to risk of turbulence.
  • Brauneck Bergbahn: When using the Brauneck Bergbahn, paragliders and hang gliders must pack their equipment short (4.20m).

A landing card is required for guest pilots and can be obtained at the Bergbahn. Always check with local pilots and the Lenggrieser Gleitschirmflieger e.V. for the most up-to-date information and regulations before flying at Brauneck.
search_recs: Brauneck paragliding restrictions Brauneck Gleitschirmfliegen Brauneck paragliding site review Brauneck paragliding official site

html:
Overview

The Wallberg, located in the Mangfallgebirge mountains of Bavaria, Germany, offers a spectacular Alpine flying experience near the scenic Tegernsee lake, just 50 km south of Munich. This popular site, reaching an altitude of 1722m, is known for its soaring and thermaling conditions, and provides stunning views.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: The Wallberg is best flown with winds from West to North. Be aware that dangerous lee conditions can occur with East wind.
  • Soaring and Thermals: Expect good soaring and thermaling conditions, making it a frequent starting point for long cross-country (XC) flights. Popular routes include flights to Kössen, and with high cloudbases and North wind, towards Achensee and the Zillertal.
  • Takeoff Locations: Several takeoff locations are available, including Wallberg Westgipfel, Wallberg Hauptgipfel, Wallberg Hintermaurer Alm, and Wallberg Kircherl.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Wallberg is a very popular flying site, especially among Munich residents due to its easy access. It is considered suitable for beginners when the wind direction is favorable. However, all pilots should be aware of potentially turbulent conditions, especially in the afternoon at the Hintermaurer Alm takeoff.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easily accessible by public transport (train to Tegernsee, then bus to the Wallberg valley station) and by car.
  • Cable Car: The Wallbergbahn cable car provides easy access to the top.
  • Hiking: Hiking to the top is also an option, taking approximately 2.5 - 3 hours.
  • Fees: A day membership fee is compulsory to maintain the flying area and is paid at the Wallbergbahn ticket office.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Lee Conditions: Dangerous lee conditions can occur with East wind. South and east winds generally make Wallberg unsuitable for flying.
  • Golden Eagles: Golden eagles breed in the area, particularly around the Bodenschneid. Avoid eyrie areas; information is usually posted at the valley station.
  • Turbulence: The Hintermaurer Alm launch site can experience strong turbulence, especially in the afternoon. Instruction is recommended due to the risk of turbulence at this location. From May 15 to August 31, the Alm launch site is closed from 1 p.m. due to strong turbulence.
  • Hang Flying Hazards: Flying close to the slope may result in getting stuck in the trees.
  • Landing Hazards: The landing area is close to a public road. Avoid flying too close to the road during approach. The RVO buses drive at high speeds. The landing at the Wallbergstrasse is only allowed for paragliders.
  • Kircherl Takeoff: This takeoff is relatively narrow and steep, bordered by trees. Be careful during launch to avoid the trees. Takeoff must be done below the path, in order not to endanger pedestrians.
  • Hintermaurer Alm Takeoff: Takeoffs should only be made with sufficient wind so that the footpath below can be flown over safely. Watch out for pedestrians; this takeoff is only suitable for beginners to a limited extent. This is also known to be a stony takeoff.
  • South Starts Prohibited: South starts are not permitted for paragliders.
  • Tandem License: Club members intending to fly tandem require a Gebietslizenz (area license) from the club.
  • Mandatory Logbook Entry: All pilots must enter their flight in the logbook at the Kasse (ticket office) before each flight. This applies to tandem pilots and students as well.
  • Day Membership: Pilots who are not members of the DGCTT must purchase a day membership.
  • Landing Rules:
    • Always fly a left-hand circuit for landing.
    • In stronger wind, adjust the approach accordingly.
    • Ensure you are at least 50m above the Wallbergstrasse (road south of the landing site) when crossing it during the landing approach.
    • If you cannot clear the road with sufficient altitude, land on the "Außenlandewiese" (outlanding field) south of the road.
    • After landing, move your glider to the edge of the landing field to avoid obstructing other pilots.

Always check with local pilots and the DGCTT ([http://fliegerclubtegernsee.de/](http://fliegerclubtegernsee.de/)) for the most up-to-date information and site-specific regulations before flying at Wallberg.
search_recs: Wallberg paragliding fees Wallberg Gleitschirmfliegen Wallberg paragliding site information Wallberg paragliding official site Wallberg paragliding access

html:
Overview

Hochries, nestled in the Chiemgau region of Bavaria, Germany, on the Samerberg mountain, is a popular paragliding site renowned for its stunning Alpine views and excellent thermaling opportunities. With an altitude difference of around 900 meters, pilots can enjoy long and safe flights, especially during evening thermals. The site is easily accessible via the Hochriesbahn cable car.

Flying Conditions

  • Launch Sites:
    • Main launch sites face North and Northwest from the summit station.
    • A South-facing launch is available, but is currently restricted to paragliders with a B-license, instruction from the site warden and limited run up area.
  • Thermal Activity:
    • Known for evening/afternoon flying.
    • Usable thermals often start relatively late in the day (around 13:00-14:00) due to the north-facing slope.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • Unsuitable for: Pronounced easterly weather patterns, strong easterly winds, and all southerly wind directions.
    • Lee-Rotor: Danger of Lee-Rotor in south to west wind conditions.
    • Insufficient Wind/Upslope: May not be possible to clear the ridge after takeoff with too little wind or insufficient upslope lift.
  • Flying Season: Typically from April to October.

Who Should Fly Here?

Hochries is a great place to fly for pilots of varying abilities, but it is especially recommended for experienced pilots. While beginners can fly under the right conditions, they should be aware of the potential challenges.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car: Access to the launch site is conveniently provided by the Hochriesbahn cable car from Grainbach-Samerberg.
  • Hiking: Hiking to the top is also possible for those seeking a more physical ascent.
  • Parking: Paid parking is available at the Samerberg valley station.
  • Fees: Landing fees are included in the price of a Hochriesbahn mountain ticket. Discounts are available for members of associated clubs. A landing fee of €3 applies to Hike & Fly guest pilots, payable via PayPal.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Hazards:
    • Pronounced Easterly Weather Patterns & Southerly Winds: Avoid flying in these conditions.
    • Lee-Rotor: Be cautious of potential Lee-Rotor in south to west wind conditions.
    • Ridge Clearance: Ensure sufficient wind/upslope lift to clear the ridge after takeoff.
  • Takeoff Specific Risks:
    • Northeast Launch: Steep and short launch site that can be slippery. Limited space for 2-3 gliders.
    • Northwest Launch: Relatively short launch site.
    • South Launch: Demanding site only for paragliders (not hang gliders), B-license required, instruction by the site warden required due to a short run-up area and steep, uneven terrain.
  • Environmental Considerations:
    • Eagle Protection Zone: Be aware of and respect the eagle protection zone during the breeding and rearing season. Check https://www.kampenwand-flieger.de/steinadler/ for more information.
    • Flight Corridor/Altitude Restriction: From April 1st to June 15th, flights with hang gliders and paragliders up to 1500m MSL are only permitted within the flight corridor.
    • Wildlife Protection: Avoid breeding and mating grounds of Auerwild (capercaillie) and Birkwild (black grouse) throughout the year, maintaining a minimum altitude of 200m.
    • Cow Obstruction: Avoid launches if cows are on the launch area.
search_recs: Hochries paragliding site access Hochries paragliding site regulations Hochries paragliding site description Hochries Gleitschirmfliegen Information Hochries paragliding club

html:
Overview

Rammelsberg is a popular paragliding site located on the northern edge of the Harz mountains, south of Goslar, in Lower Saxony, Germany. Known as one of the northernmost slope flying locations in Germany with a significant altitude difference, it offers a thrilling experience for paragliding and hang gliding enthusiasts alike.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction:
    • Northwest Takeoff: Best for winds between 270° and 360°.
    • Southwest Takeoff: Available, but requires a briefing and specific pilot qualifications.
  • Soaring and Thermals:
    • Primarily a slope soaring site, offering excellent ridge lift.
    • Thermic activity is common, especially above the quarry.
    • Pilots should be aware that thermal conditions can cause sudden changes in wind direction.
  • Landing:
    • The landing area has a slope, requiring pilots to land across the slope.
    • Pilots should pay attention to the windsocks on launch and landing.

Who Should Fly Here?

Rammelsberg is rated as a medium difficulty site suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including training. Guest pilots need a briefing for the southwest take-off and a B-certificate (or equivalent). The HDGV welcomes guest pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The site is accessible by car and on foot.
  • Shuttle Service: On weekends and holidays, a driving service organized by club members is available to reach the mountain.
  • Day Tickets: Available for purchase at the Maltermeister Turm restaurant.
  • Fees: A day ticket or club membership with HDGV is required.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: The wind needs to be between 270-360 degrees to fly at Rammelsberg.
  • Turbulence: Can occur, particularly with west winds due to the quarry and lee thermals in the afternoon.
  • Southwest Takeoff: Special regulations apply, pilots require an introduction/briefing, and guest pilots need a B-license to fly from the southwest launch.
  • Hang Start Authorization: Required for hang gliding.
  • Club Membership/Day Ticket: The Rammelsberg site is the club area of the HDGV (Harzer Drachen- und Gleitschirmverein Goslar e.V.). To fly there you either need a day ticket or a membership in the club HDGV.
  • Flight Operation Regulations: Pilots must observe the flight operation regulations for the Rammelsberg.
  • B-Schein Requirement: Guest pilots need the B-certificate.
  • Airspace Information: Pilots are responsible for knowing current airspace information.
search_recs: Rammelsberg paragliding regulations Rammelsberg Gleitschirmfliegen Rammelsberg paragliding site Gleitschirmfliegen Rammelsberg site details Rammelsberg paragliding club Rammelsberg flying conditions

html:
Overview

The Osser is a popular paragliding site located in the Bavarian Forest near Lam, Germany. Situated on the Osserwiese at approximately 1,100 meters, it offers panoramic views and is known for its accessible thermal flying conditions. This site is suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding enthusiasts.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Suitable for South (S), Southwest (SW), West (W), and Northwest (NW) winds.
  • Soaring: Soaring is possible with Southwest (SW) winds.
  • Thermals: The Osser is known for its thermal activity, providing a great entry point into thermal flying.
  • Altitude Difference: The height difference between the take-off and landing area is approximately 530 meters.
  • Best Months: March, April, May, June, July, and August are the best months for cross-country flying.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Osser is a popular site that welcomes pilots with some experience. It is recommended that pilots have at least 10 high-altitude flights in other terrains before flying at the Osser. Training flights are allowed but require two flight instructors with constant radio contact.

Seasonal Restriction: From March 1st to June 30th, flying is restricted to members of the "1. Gleitschirmverein Bayerwald" (1. GVB).

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the take-off is by foot, taking approximately 30 minutes from the Sattel parking area.
  • Parking: Parking is available opposite the former bistro at the Sattel parking area.
  • Public Transport: A Rufbus (call bus) service is available from the Lam train station to the Sattel hiking parking lot (check schedule).
  • Fees: There is a fee to fly, costing €40 per year.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Pilot Briefing: Pilots should ensure they are briefed about the site via information boards, the internet, or local pilots.
  • Landing Approach: Pilots must ensure weather conditions allow them to reach the landing site with sufficient altitude for a safe landing approach.
  • Changing Conditions: Take-off and landing locations may change. Always observe information boards and consult local pilots.
  • Wind and Weather: Specific wind and weather conditions can create challenging situations.
search_recs: Gleitschirmfliegen Osser Deutschland paragliding Osser Germany Osser paragliding site information Osser mountain paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Tegelberg is one of Germany's most popular paragliding destinations, nestled in Schwangau near Füssen, in the Bavarian Alps (Allgäu region). This striking mountain massif offers stunning panoramic views of the Alpine upland, numerous lakes, and the iconic Neuschwanstein Castle. With an elevation difference of approximately 900 meters between launch and landing, Tegelberg provides a memorable flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Launch Sites: Multiple launch sites are available near the mountain station at approximately 1720m, facing Northwest and East.
  • Flying Style: Known for both thermal and scenic flying. The steep terrain ensures pilots can reach the landing area even with less efficient gliders.
  • Suitability: Suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding. Several flying schools operate at the site, offering courses and tandem flights.
  • Seasonality: No specific seasonality is mentioned, however, the Tegelbergbahn usually has a revision starting early November until mid-December.
  • Weather: Always check weather conditions before flying due to the rugged terrain.

Who Should Fly Here?

Tegelberg attracts many pilots and tourists, making it a busy site, especially during peak seasons. While the site is popular, a certain level of experience is recommended due to potentially challenging conditions. A briefing card ("green briefing card") is required, and pilots' licenses and insurance are subject to spot checks.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Access to the launch site is via the Tegelbergbahn cable car.
  • Cable Car Ticket: A single ride ticket costs €20.50 for adults and €8.50 for children (as of April 2025).
  • Landing Fee: A day ticket costs €3.00 for adults, and a year ticket is priced at €36.00.
  • Parking: Paid parking is available at the valley station.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Queueing at Takeoff: The popular NW takeoff can get crowded, requiring pilots to be ready for immediate launch.
  • Turbulence: The rugged terrain can create turbulence. Pilots should maintain a safe distance from the slope and avoid close-to-hang flying.
  • Cable Car Hazard: Maintain a safe distance from the cable car at all times to avoid collisions.
  • Lower Takeoff Risks: The lower takeoff involves a hike to a narrow chute where winds can rotate, and a rock wall is present.
  • Northeast Takeoff: Only experienced pilots with local knowledge should use the NE takeoff over a ramp.
  • Flight Regulations: The Tegelberg flight regulations must be observed.
  • Briefing Card Requirement: Every pilot needs a "green briefing card," and must present their pilot's license and proof of insurance at the valley station.
  • Launch Preparations: Launch preparations must be done outside the launch area, with pilots approaching the launch with the glider reefed.
  • Landing Rules: Adhere to landing rules, including separate landing areas for paragliders and hang gliders, and fly over the road at a minimum height of 10m.
  • Tandem Flight Restrictions: Only authorized providers with the consent of the Tegelbergbahn can conduct tandem flights.
  • Start Restrictions: Launches are only permitted outside the ski season due to the launch area being on a ski slope.
  • Flight Operation Restrictions: Prohibited if there is a risk to people or property.
  • Prohibitions: Smoking, acrobatic flying, and flying with non-approved mini-wing paragliders are prohibited.
  • Helicopter Operations: Flight operations must cease during helicopter operations by rescue services, police, or the military.
  • Flight Permission: A flight permission ("Grüne Karte") is required as proof of instruction about the flying site.
  • General Rules: Pilots must adhere to LuftVO (German aviation regulations) and the flight operation regulations (FBO) of the DHV (German Hang Gliding Association).
  • Required Documents/Equipment: Valid pilot's license or student under instruction, approved flying equipment, liability insurance (min. 1.5 million Euros), flight permit for Tegelberg/Buchenberg ("Grüne Karte"), and a landing site card.
  • Takeoff Procedures: Coordinate all takeoffs between pilots and follow instructions from the launch director if appointed.
  • Start Safety: Takeoffs are only allowed in safe, mostly turbulence-free wind conditions and students must be proficient in launching on flat ground.

html:
Overview

The Osterfelderkopf, located in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Bavaria, offers a stunning high-alpine paragliding experience. Launching from over 2000 meters (approximately 6,700 feet), pilots are treated to breathtaking views of the Alpspitze and Zugspitze. This popular site provides opportunities for thermaling and cross-country (XC) flights from spring to autumn.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Thermaling, cross-country (XC), and ridge soaring.
  • Seasonality: Best conditions are typically from spring to autumn. Tandem flights are common during this period. Winter flying is possible, but potentially limited.
  • Launch Directions: Offers both east and north-facing launch sites. The east launch is the primary site, while the north launch is used when the wind shifts. Only use the north launch if the wind is clearly and sufficiently strong from the front.
  • Weather Considerations: Located in the northern Alps, the area can experience frequent rain. Strong valley winds are common from April to October, especially from midday to early evening.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Osterfelder is best suited for experienced pilots. The launch site in front of the mountain rescue hut is only suitable for experienced and very safe launchers. Student pilots must have completed at least 15 high-altitude flights (10 for North-Startplatz HG) in another flying area before launching here.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the launch site is via the Alpspitzbahn cable car.
  • Fees: A start and landing fee is required (currently 4€/day, 15€/week, or 30€/year for guest pilots as of February 2025). This fee can be paid at the Bergbahn ticket office or online. The cable car ticket is an additional cost.
  • Briefing: A briefing is mandatory for all pilots.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Reintal Danger: Flying towards the Reintal (south of the Osterfelder area) is extremely dangerous due to the risk of losing lift, turbulent conditions, and landing in trees. Always fly on the north side of the Osterfelder area.
  • Landing Zone Turbulence: Strong tailwinds can occur at the landing zone from midday onwards. Avoid flying behind the "Erdwall" (earth wall/dike) due to strong turbulence.
  • Wind Conditions: Be cautious during Föhn conditions or strong winds from the North and East. Strong valley winds can occur into the late afternoon with easterly wind conditions.
  • Sprengseile (Blasting Cables): Be aware of blasting cables when thermaling at the Alpspitze.
  • Rotors: Small rotors can occur in the takeoff area with northerly winds. With westerly winds, be aware of lee rotors/lee thermals. Check the windsock on the mountain station and the flags on the "Sprengbahn" and be ready to abort the launch.
  • Alpspitzbahn Cable Car: Maintain a sufficient safety distance from the Alpspitzbahn cable car.
  • Hochalmbahn Gondola: Launches are only permitted when the gondola of the Hochalmbahn is in the station.
  • Osterfelder North-Startplatz HG (Hang Gliding), Rampe (Ramp): Maintain sufficient safety distance from the Alpspitzbahn cable car. Starting with hang gliders is not allowed from the Tandem launch.
  • Ski Operations: Starting on the ski slopes is prohibited during ski operations.
search_recs: Osterfelder access fees paragliding Osterfelder flying site guide Osterfelder paragliding site details Osterfelder Gleitschirmfliegen Information Osterfelder Thermikflug Osterfelder Fluggebiet Beschreibung Osterfelder paragliding club Osterfelder Streckenflug

html:
Overview

Hausstein, located near Schaufling and Deggendorf in Bavaria, Germany, offers thermaling and cross-country (XC) opportunities in the beautiful Bavarian Forest. As a club-owned site (Vereinseigene Gelände) associated with the Drachen- u. Gleitschirmclub Bayerwald e.V. (DGC Bayerwald), Hausstein presents a challenging but rewarding experience for experienced paragliding pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Known for good thermal activity, especially in the spring.
  • Wind Direction: Ideal start wind direction is from South-Southeast (120°).
  • Wind Speed: Optimal wind speed is between 5 and 15 km/h.
  • Takeoff: The take-off is a bumpy meadow start in a forest aisle (Liftschneise). Wind indicators are present at both takeoff and landing areas.

Who Should Fly Here?

Hausstein is recommended for experienced pilots ("Gelände für Geübte"). A German B-Schein (or equivalent) is recommended, and prior instruction from a club member is strongly advised ("dringend notwendig") for first-time visitors. This site is not suitable for beginners.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Drive to the "Langlauf- bzw Wanderzentrum Rusel" parking area, followed by a 700m walk uphill through the forest to the take-off.
  • Fees: A day membership fee of 5 Euros may apply for guests. Annual memberships are also possible.
  • Landing Areas: No official landing areas exist. Landings are tolerated on a specific meadow near the village of Böhaming. Other meadows are strictly prohibited due to farmer concerns. Top landings are also not permitted. Inspect the landing site at Böhaming before the first flight, due to the sloping terrain and the presence of houses.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Side Wind on Takeoff: Do not take off in side wind conditions due to rotors caused by the tall trees and the relatively narrow forest clearing used as a launch area.
  • Changing Wind Conditions: From midday, winds from the south become more prevalent, potentially introducing side wind.
  • Takeoff Run: The launch area is a bumpy meadow. At zero wind, a strong run is required for takeoff.
  • Restricted License: Suitable for single-seat paragliding with a restricted license.
  • Military Exercise Area: Be aware of potential temporary flight restrictions due to military exercises in ED-R Feldkirchen (1NM radius around N 48°49'41'', O 12'33'23''). Always check current NOTAMs before flying.
search_recs: Hausstein paragliding access Hausstein paragliding official site Hausstein paragliding site Germany Hausstein Gleitschirmfliegen Deutschland Hausstein paragliding pilot level

html:
Overview

Skrzyczne, standing at 1257 meters, is the highest peak in the Silesian Beskid mountains of southern Poland and a popular paragliding destination. The site attracts pilots from across Poland, drawn to its multiple launch options and thermaling opportunities. While offering diverse conditions, pilots should be aware of specific challenges and restrictions to ensure a safe and enjoyable flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Take-off Points: Skrzyczne offers three distinct take-off points, each suited to different wind directions:
    • ESE-NE Launch: Best for East-South-Easterly to North-Easterly winds. Located on a steep meadow, approximately 100 meters below the summit. This launch can be challenging due to the short run-up.
    • NE-N Launch: Suitable for North-Easterly to Northerly winds. Situated on the FIS route, this wide launch with a slight incline provides a simple launch.
    • N-NW Launch: Ideal for Northerly to North-Westerly winds. Located on the red ski run. While generally straightforward, it can be dangerous in stronger NW winds due to rotor from nearby trees.
  • Winds: Flying is possible with winds from ESE to NW. Strong, gusty winds exceeding 5 m/s (approximately 11 mph) can make flying unsafe.
  • Thermals: Skrzyczne is known for its thermaling opportunities.
  • Landing: The former official landing area "Kaimówka" is closed due to safety concerns. Landing is now possible at "Pańskie Pola" in Lipowa, a private landing strip used by ultralight aircraft. Pilots must not fly over the airfield.

Who Should Fly Here?

Skrzyczne caters to a range of pilot experience levels. While some sources suggest it is suitable for beginners, others indicate that certain launches may be more challenging. Pilots should honestly assess their skills, particularly regarding launch techniques on steep slopes (ESE-NE) and dealing with potential rotor (N-NW). The closure of the official Kaimówka landing highlights the potential for accidents, and careful judgment is essential.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The take-off area is accessible by car, public transport, cable car, or walking.
  • Chairlift: A chairlift is available to reach the top, with a fee of approximately 2 euros per ticket.
  • Support: The Beskidzkie Stowarzyszenie Paralotniowe (BSP) [Beskid Paragliding Association] maintains the take-off areas and the landing zone and encourages pilots to support their organization.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Dependence: Flights are heavily dependent on weather conditions. Pilots should carefully assess conditions such as rain, storm clouds, or strong winds.
  • Kaimówka Landing (Closed): The former landing site was closed due to a high number of accidents resulting from a small, sloped landing area, surrounded by trees, and subject to valley winds creating significant turbulence.
  • ESE-NE Launch Risks: The steep terrain and short takeoff run can make launching challenging. Pilots should avoid landing at the take-off location and flying near the take-off area when others are preparing to launch.
  • N-NW Launch Risks: Launching from the red ski route can be dangerous in strong northwest winds due to rotor from trees along the route.
  • Pańskie Pola Landing Considerations: Landing is possible at the "Pańskie Pola" landing site in Lipowa, which is a small, private airfield used by ultralight aircraft. Pilots must not fly over the airfield.
  • Airspace: Although temporarily reserved airspace (TRA 03C) was reduced, the bottom of the remaining TRA segments (A and C) is at FL95 (approximately 2850 meters), which does not restrict paragliding flights. Paragliding pilots cannot legally fly above FL95 due to radio communication requirements with ATC.
  • Certification: Pilots must be members of the Sports Aviation Federation of Australia, or be under the supervision of an instructor authorized by the Federation.
search_recs: Skrzyczne paragliding official information Skrzyczne paragliding site information Skrzyczne paralotniarstwo

html:
Overview

Żar Mountain is a popular paragliding site located in the Żywiec Mountains in southern Poland, within the Little Beskids range. The summit reaches 761 meters above sea level, providing scenic views of Lake Międzybrodzkie and the surrounding landscape. Known for both soaring and thermal flying, Żar attracts pilots of varying skill levels due to its accessibility and diverse flying conditions.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions:
    • Żar offers multiple take-off points for various wind directions, including North, Northeast, South, Southwest, West, and Northwest.
    • North-facing slopes are generally easier to fly, while westerly and southern winds can be more challenging.
  • Soaring:
    • Ridge soaring is possible along the north-south line of the mountain.
    • Be aware of potential rotor from trees with westerly winds.
  • Thermal Activity:
    • Żar is known for its thermal flying opportunities.
  • Airspace Awareness:
    • The site is near a glider airfield (Szybowisko Żar), requiring pilots to adhere to established flight procedures (IWLPL) to avoid conflicts with glider operations and respect the ATZ EPZR airspace.

Who Should Fly Here?

Żar is a versatile site suitable for both beginners and experienced pilots. Beginners can fly accompanied, taking advantage of the easier north-facing slopes. Experienced pilots can challenge themselves with the more demanding westerly and southern wind conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car: Access to the top of Żar Mountain is available via a paid cable car.
  • Hiking: Alternatively, access is also possible by hiking.
  • Parking: Paid parking is available near the lower cable car station.
  • Fees:
    • There are no fees for using the take-off sites for solo and non-commercial tandem flights.
    • Pilots are encouraged to support local paragliding associations for site maintenance through membership or daily fees.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions:
    • Easterly deviations are considered dangerous.
    • Stronger south winds can create a nozzle effect in the valley with limited landing options.
  • Rotor:
    • With Northwest winds, a rotor can occur at the takeoff point from the hilltop.
    • With westerly winds, there's a risk of rotor from nearby trees at the North-Northwest takeoff.
  • Turbulence:
    • The landing area to the North (Kozubnik) can be strongly thermal on sunny days.
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • Pilots should be aware of the ATZ EPZR airspace (related to the airport).
    • Adherence to the instruction manual "Instrukcja Wykonywania Lotów Paralotniowo-Lotniowych IWLPL" is required.
  • Sailplane Activity:
    • Pilots must be aware of sailplane activity and avoid the cross-hatched area.
    • Contact the glider flight director for up-to-date information.
  • Landing Restrictions:
    • Landing is forbidden at the takeoff area.
    • Emergency landings on the dam's embankment require contacting security.
  • Insurance:
    • Pilots from the EU need to have their national license to fly without an instructor.
    • Insurance against civil liability is required.
  • Support the site:
    • Support the Beskid Paragliding Association (BSP) when launching and landing near Żar, either through membership or daily fees.
