html:
Overview

Mieroszów is a popular paragliding site located in Wałbrzych County, Lower Silesian Voivodeship, southwestern Poland, near the Czech border. Situated on Jatki mountain (also called New Saddle or Krowiara) in the Kamienne Mountains, it offers a training slope with a hang-glider ramp, making it a frequented spot for both paragliding and hang gliding.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Known for dynamic soaring, ridge soaring, and training. Suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including tandem flights.
  • Wind Direction: Best wind direction is from the South (S) with a slight westerly deviation (around 210°), with usable winds ranging from 180° to 240°.
  • Wind Speed: The site works well even with wind speeds of 3-4 m/s, making it a popular choice when strong winds make flying in higher mountains challenging. Avoid launching if winds exceed 8 m/s.
  • Thermals: Thermal activity can be found due to the contrasting terrain in front of the launch.

Who Should Fly Here?

Mieroszów is highly frequented and suitable for training and beginner pilots. Basic skills are required, and caution is advised, especially regarding wind conditions. It's advised not to fly alone if you are unfamiliar with the location.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access is by car and then a short walk. In dry conditions, it's possible to drive close to the landing area via a dirt road.
  • Parking: It's advisable to park near the local paragliding school ("rancho") and walk about 15 minutes to the launch if the road conditions are poor.
  • Fees: There may be fees associated with using the site, potentially to the Aeroklub Ziemi Wałbrzyskiej who lease the land. Contacting local schools or the Aeroclub is recommended for the most up-to-date information.
  • Note: The site is not certified.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Small Hill Deception: Treat the site with the same respect as a larger mountain, despite the relatively small height difference (around 43m).
  • Wind Hazards: Many accidents have occurred due to launching in unfavorable conditions such as downwind (lee side) launches, crosswinds, and winds exceeding 8 m/s.
  • Rotor Risk: Rotor from nearby trees can be a hazard with more westerly winds.
  • Multiple Launch Points:
    • Launch 1 (N-NE): Located 50m down the black ski piste. Grassy lane, relatively flat, easy start.
    • Launch 2 (NE-SE): A small, steep spot east of Launch 1. Limited space (2-3 wings). Easy start with east wind.
    • Launch 3 (N-NW): Located 50m down the red ski piste. Lane with grass and rocks, relatively flat. Easy start with N-NNW winds. More challenging with west winds due to rotor risk.
  • Border Proximity: The Polish-Czech border is approximately 1000 meters east of the launch. Crossing the border in flight is "undesirable".
  • Landing Zone: Land in the designated area to avoid problems with local inhabitants. Ensure you know the specific landing spot.
  • Helicopter Rescue Operations: Be aware that helicopter rescue operations may occur in the area, which would require immediate landing.
  • Important Note: All activities are undertaken at your own risk.
search_recs: Mieroszów paragliding club paragliding Mieroszów Poland Mieroszów paragliding site information Mieroszów paragliding regulations Mieroszów gmina paragliding paralotnie Mieroszów

html:
Overview

Szczebel is a challenging paragliding site located in the Beskid Wyspowy mountain range in Poland. Characterized by isolated peaks and offering stunning views of the Tatra Mountains, Szczebel (955m / 3,133 ft) is known for thermal flying and the potential for soaring. The site is maintained by a local club and offers a unique experience for experienced pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Best suited for N, NE, and E winds. Intense free-flight paragliding can be experienced when the wind blows from NNE/NE/E.
  • Thermal Flying: Szczebel is known for its thermal activity, allowing pilots to explore surrounding valleys and ridges when conditions are right.
  • Season: The paragliding season in Poland generally extends from spring to mid-fall, with summer offering the most favorable conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Szczebel is best suited for experienced pilots due to its demanding takeoff. Intermediate pilots can fly solo if they are already familiar with the location. It is advised not to fly alone if you are unfamiliar with the site.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: A one-hour walk from Glisne Pass along a green-marked trail is required to reach the takeoff.
  • Tractor Lift: A local farmer may offer tractor lifts for groups of pilots.
  • Parking: Cars can be parked on the side of the road leading to the mountain, near the landing spot.
  • Landing: Precise landing is required due to the nature of the landing spot.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Demanding Takeoff: The takeoff is considered rather demanding due to surrounding trees and a short runway.
  • Short Runway: The launch area offers limited space, requiring proficiency in forward launches or the alpine start technique ("alpejka"). Errors during takeoff can lead to falls on the steep slope.
  • Wind Direction: Flying is not possible when the wind is blowing from the wrong direction. Ensure proper wind direction (N, NE, E) before launching.
  • Uncertified Site: Please note that the site is not officially certified.
search_recs: Szczebel paragliding regulations Szczebel paragliding official site Szczebel paragliding site information Szczebel paragliding club Szczebel mountain paragliding Szczebel hiking access Szczebel paragliding access

html:
Overview

Ciecień is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Beskid Wyspowy mountain range in Małopolska, Poland. Known for its isolated, island-like peaks, Ciecień (829m) offers pilots a chance to experience thermal flying, ridge soaring, and even cross-country (XC) flights. As one of the busiest sites in the area, Ciecień is a vibrant hub for paragliding enthusiasts.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Best suited for westerly winds with a slight northern or southern component.
  • Flight Paths: Primarily eastward flights are recommended, with opportunities to fly towards Śnieżnica or Łopień under good conditions, and further to other peaks within Beskid Wyspowy.
  • Soaring & Thermals: Ciecień is known for both thermal flying and ridge soaring. The area is suitable for XC flights, allowing experienced pilots to explore the beautiful Beskid Wyspowy range.
  • Flying Season: The prime flying season in Poland spans from spring to mid-autumn, with the most reliable and favorable conditions typically occurring during the summer months.

Who Should Fly Here?

Ciecień welcomes pilots of all experience levels. Its reputation as a good starting point makes it an ideal location for novice pilots, while advanced pilots can take advantage of the thermal activity for XC flights. Tandem flights and paragliding courses are frequently offered at Ciecień, making it an accessible site for newcomers to the sport.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the site involves driving to the area, followed by a fairly steep hike to the take-off point. Some sources suggest a 4x4 vehicle may be beneficial. One source mentions a 1-hour walk to the top.
  • Parking: It's recommended to park near the old gas station below the landing area, respecting requests from local residents of Wiśniowa.
  • Fees: A fee is associated with flying at Ciecień. Please inquire locally about the current pricing structure.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • High Activity: Ciecień experiences intense paragliding activity, especially with favorable west winds. This can increase the risk of mid-air collisions. Exercise caution and maintain vigilant awareness of surrounding aircraft.
  • Specific Landing Spot: It is essential to thoroughly familiarize yourself with the designated landing spot before flying.
  • Local Sensitivities: Be respectful of local inhabitants. Landing outside of the designated area may result in negative interactions with locals.
  • Takeoff Specifics:
    • N-NE Takeoff: Easy start on a grassy lane, relatively flat.
    • NE-SE Takeoff: Small, steep spot. Limited space.
    • N-NW Takeoff: Can be challenging with West wind due to rotor from nearby trees.
  • Airspace: Be aware of Poland's airspace structure. While primarily Class G up to FL95, controlled zones (CTRs) and terminal control areas (TMAs) exist.
  • Airspace Use Plan (AUP): Always check the AUP (www.amc.pansa.pl) for any planned restrictions.
  • Restricted Areas: Avoid Temporary Segregated Areas (TSA), Military Route (MRT), and Restricted Areas (EP R).
  • Flight Plan: It is strongly recommended to submit a flight plan before flying.
  • Radio & Transponder: Required when flying in Class C airspace.
search_recs: Ciecień paralotniarstwo Ciecien paragliding site Ciecien paragliding site official information Ciecien paragliding access fees paragliding Ciecien pilot level

html:
Overview

Andrzejowka is a paragliding site nestled in the mountainous terrain of the Central Sudetes range (Góry Suche/Stone Mountains) near Rybnica Leśna in southwestern Poland. With an altitude of approximately 825m, Andrzejowka offers opportunities for both thermal and ridge soaring, attracting pilots seeking a diverse flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions:
    • Suitable wind directions include S, SW, and NW-N.
    • Takeoff Andrzejówka: 320°-35°
    • Takeoff Andrzejówka (Klin): 315°-45°
    • NW 315° is considered the best wind direction.
    • Usable wind range is quite narrow, from 315° to 330°.
  • Soaring: Known for both thermal flying and ridge soaring.
  • Height Difference: The height difference between takeoff and landing is approximately 115-120m. Klin takeoff has a height difference of about 50 meters.

Who Should Fly Here?

Andrzejowka is considered a site of medium difficulty, making it suitable as a practice area for pilots with basic flying skills. More experienced pilots will also find the conditions appealing. Both paragliders and hang gliders use the site.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Typically, access is by car followed by a hike.
  • Fees: Some takeoff locations may require fees. It's crucial to verify current access conditions and associated fees locally before flying. Some sources indicate both "official (fee payable)" and "official (no fee payable)" options.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: A slight deviation from NW towards the west can be dangerous due to a reverse slope (protivostok).
  • Landing Area: Land near the wooden shed. The surrounding fields are private, and walking on them is prohibited.
  • Airspace: Free-flight paragliding is allowed up to 6000 ft AMSL between April 1st and October 31st, from sunrise to sunset, over take-off sites Dzikowiec, Andrzejowka, Grzmiaca, Chelmiec and Mieroszow. This excludes airspace above cities.
  • Polish Regulations: Pilots from the EU need their national license to fly without an instructor. Third-party liability insurance of at least 350.000 PLN (approximately 80.000 EUR) is required.
search_recs: Andrzejowka paragliding club Paragliding site regulations Andrzejowka Poland paragliding Andrzejowka Poland Andrzejowka paragliding site info Andrzejowka mountain Poland paragliding

html:
Overview

Fiesch, nestled in the Rhône valley of the Valais region in Switzerland, is a renowned paragliding site, often called the "track Mecca of the Alps". This area, also known as Oberwallis, boasts stunning views of high, glaciated peaks (up to 4,000m) and the Aletsch Glacier, the largest in the Alps. Takeoffs are typically from Fiescheralp.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Fiesch is famous for cross-country (XC) flying, thanks to its strong thermals and valley winds, making it ideal for large FAI triangles. Ridge soaring and thermaling are also popular.
  • Seasonality: The site is flyable year-round. March often offers ideal conditions. Summer brings strong thermals, while winter provides smoother air.
  • Weather Considerations:
    • The Rhône valley can experience strong valley winds (over 20 km/h).
    • Turbulent conditions can occur with north winds.
    • "Föhn" wind conditions should be avoided.
    • Checking with local pilots for weather advice is highly recommended.

Who Should Fly Here?

Fiesch is considered a challenging area and is best suited for experienced XC pilots. Less experienced pilots should only fly in calm conditions. The Heimatt launch is at 2,143m.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The main takeoffs at Fiescheralp are accessed via a gondola from the Fiesch train station. The gondola is equipped to transport hang gliders. There are also hike-and-fly options like Talegga and Salzgäb, but these are unofficial.
  • Fees: There are take-off/landing fees, approximately CHF 10. Mountain railway tickets are required to access the Fiescheralp launch; a GA travelcard provides free access. A site fee may also be required.
  • Information: Detailed information, including airspace regulations, can be found on the Fluggruppe Aletsch website.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • General Risks & Dangers:
    • Turbulence and Windshear: Strong turbulence and windshear can occur, especially with South or North Föhn wind conditions. Be cautious in all altitudes under these conditions.
    • Valley Winds: The landing site in Fiesch is located at the confluence of three valley wind directions. The windsock can change direction rapidly (within 5 minutes) and the winds can be strong.
    • Grimsel Wind (Grimseler): This wind can bring cold, humid air from the Haslital into the Goms valley and impact landing locations.
    • Lee Flying: There is a danger of lee flying with strong East to North wind (Bise) due to heavy wind shear above the ridge. This can also be a problem with West winds or simple valley winds. Days with a northern wind component may have more turbulent thermals.
    • Rapid Overdevelopment: Pilots should be aware of the risk of rapid cloud overdevelopment.
    • Turbulence at Landing: The landing site can be quite turbulent, especially in the afternoon when the wind can blow from the east over the hill, resulting in crosswinds. If the wind is too strong, pilots should switch to the Fieschertal landing site.
    • Cold Air Outflow: Cold air from the Fieschergletscher creates downdrafts on flying days.
  • Per Takeoff Risks:
    • Heimatt Takeoff: This launch faces south above the Rhône valley, an area known for "nuclear thermals and mighty valley winds".
  • Flight Restrictions:
    • Münster Airfield: A special regulation exists for the Münster airfield including caution zones and minimum flight altitudes.
    • Tavanasa Heliport: Increased caution should be exercised within 2.5km of the Tavanasa Heliport. Paragliders and hang-gliders are not allowed to fly below 1350m ASL in the designated zone.
    • Sion Airspace: Pilots may need to cross Sion airspace and must radio the control tower for permission before entering.
    • Altitude Limits: Airspace above 3950 meters ASL on weekdays and 4450 meters ASL on weekends and after 5:05 PM is off-limits to paragliders.
    • LS-D9 Reckingen / Gluringen: The area around LS-Rekingen is a DANGER Zone (military firing) which is only active a few days a year and is published in the DABS (NOTAM).
search_recs: Fiesch Gleitschirmflug Fiesch paragliding take-off paragliding Fiesch CH site information Fiesch paragliding site regulations Fiesch paragliding club Fiesch paragliding fees

html:
Overview

The Weissenstein, located in the Solothurn Jura near Solothurn, Switzerland, is a popular paragliding site known for its accessible launch and scenic flights. Situated below the Kurhaus Weissenstein, the site offers opportunities for both paragliding and hang gliding.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Best conditions are with southern winds or a light "Bise" (northeasterly wind). West wind conditions can create dangerous rotor.
  • Rotor Risk: Even a few km/h of west wind can create dangerous rotor conditions in the treeline. Pay attention to the Swiss flag at the Hotel Weissenstein for accurate wind indication.
  • Suitable for: Single and tandem flights.
  • Airspace Awareness: Be aware of TMA Basel airspace and the Grenchen airport control zone. Check if the TMA sector is active before launching.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Weissenstein is well-known and caters to a range of pilot abilities. However, caution is advised regarding wind conditions, particularly the risk of rotor in west winds.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Primarily via a cable car from Oberdorf.
  • Fees: There is a fee of 2 CHF per flight/take-off.
  • Accessibility: The cable car is wheelchair accessible.
  • Seasonal Access: The pass road to Weissenstein is often closed in winter due to snow.
  • Driving Restrictions: On Sundays and public holidays, there's a driving ban on the pass road between 9:00 and 16:00.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Even a few km/h of west wind can create dangerous rotor conditions in the treeline. The windsock at the launch can be misleading.
  • Takeoff Area: Access must be via the signposted path.
  • Start Restrictions: Launches are only permitted from the designated area below the fence (except from November to the end of February, when launches from above the fence are permitted).
  • Tree Clearance: Be aware of possible lee rotors after launch at the treeline.
  • Turbulence: The launch area can be quite turbulent in windy conditions, and rotors can be present shortly after takeoff.
  • Top Landing: Strictly forbidden on the entire Weissenstein.
  • Landing Zone: Landings in Oberdorf are only permitted in the designated field.
  • Landing Approach: Perform a volute appropriate for the wind conditions, following the procedures on the DCW website. Avoid making tight turns over the village due to power lines east of the landing area.
  • Airspace: TMA Basel (Class D airspace from 1750m AMSL) may be active.
  • Altitude Restrictions: Airspace above 3950 meters AMSL (Weekdays) and 4450 meters AMSL (Weekend and after 17:05) is off-limits.
search_recs: Weissenstein paragliding club paragliding Weissenstein Switzerland Weissenstein paragliding site information

html:
Overview

Brunni is a popular paragliding site situated on the sunny side of Engelberg in Central Switzerland. This mountainous landscape offers stunning views of the Titlis glacier and the surrounding Alpine peaks. Known for its reliable thermals and accessible launch sites, Brunni attracts pilots looking for both scenic flights and opportunities to improve their skills.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals:
    • Brunni is known for reliable thermals due to its south-southwest orientation.
    • The thermals often shield the site from northerly and easterly winds.
  • Season:
    • Flying is possible year-round, with thermal flights being most common from March to September.
  • Launch Sites:
    • Three launch sites are available: Tümpfeli (1800m), Härzlisee (1870m), and Schonegg (2000m).
  • Wind Considerations:
    • Pilots should be aware of föhn winds and increasing valley winds in the afternoon.
    • Be aware of turbulence when the wind is westerly.
  • Flight Potential:
    • The site offers opportunities for thermal flying and small cross-country flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Brunni is suitable for a range of pilots, from novice to intermediate. Its easy take-off and landing areas make it ideal for training and first high-altitude flights, and it is used by several flying schools.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car: Access to the launch sites is via the Brunni cable car and chairlift.
  • Hiking: From the top of the chairlift, there's a 5-20 minute walk to the launch sites.
  • Fees: A paragliding day ticket is available, which includes launch and landing fees. In winter, a deposit is required for the ticket, which is refunded at the Brunni cash point.
  • Landing Sites:
    • The official landing site is located on the meadow between the sport field Wyden and the Sportingpark in Engelberg.
    • Other official landing sites are on the Herrenrüti meadow (at the Fürenalp cable car) and in the Engelberger valley (in Grafenort at the valley station of the Grafenort - Brunniswald cable car).
  • Parking: Pilots must use public parking at the Brunni cable car valley station and adhere to parking restrictions along Bänklialp street.
  • Insurance: Pilots must have a CHF 1 million third-party insurance.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Cables: The Engelberg valley has numerous, unmarked, and barely visible cables. Check for information at gondola stations or ask local pilots.
  • Föhn Winds: Do not fly with Föhn (southerly wind combined with high differences in pressure between the south and the north of Switzerland). Observe Föhn indicators like lenticularis clouds, dust clouds, and pressure differences (Locarno - Zürich > 3 hpa difference).
  • Airspace: At the valley entrance (about 5 km north of the launch), there is the CTR (Control Zone) of Buochs and Alpnach. Clearance is required to enter or cross this airspace. Check the Daily Airspace Bulletin Switzerland (DABS).
  • Wildlife Protection:
    • Take-offs and landings are prohibited in the federal hunting areas ("Eidgenössischen Jagdbanngebieten").
    • When overflying, wildlife must be respected, and distance must be kept.
    • There is a no-fly zone over the Engelberg Hahnen wildlife reserve ("Sperrzone Engelberg Hahnen - Wildschutzgebiet"). Disregarding this restriction can result in high fines.
  • Landing Rules:
    • Parking and stopping are prohibited along Bänklialp street and near surrounding properties.
    • The dirt road along the Engelberger Aa river may not be used by cars. Use public parking and toilets at the Brunni cable car valley station.
    • After landing, leave the landing area towards the folding area and pack the paraglider there, not on the landing area itself.
    • In winter, be aware of snowmaking equipment and the cross-country trail.
    • Keep the landing site clean.
    • The football pitch Wyden (artificial turf) must not be entered or used for landings.
search_recs: Brunni Switzerland paragliding club Brunni Switzerland paragliding regulations paragliding Brunni Switzerland Brunni paragliding site information Brunni paragliding landing zones

html:
Overview

Amisbühl is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Interlaken region of Switzerland, near Beatenberg. Offering stunning views of the Eiger, Mönch, and Jungfrau peaks, as well as Lakes Thun and Brienz, it's a scenic spot for both paragliding and hang gliding.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Conditions: Known for its easy, light thermal activity.
  • Flyable Season: Suitable for flying year-round, with the best conditions typically found between March and October.
  • Flight Duration: Expect average flight times of 10-20 minutes, with opportunities for longer flights via thermaling.
  • Wind Awareness: Be mindful of potential tailwind takeoffs and general wind conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Amisbühl is generally suitable for pilots of all skill levels, including beginners. However, it's a popular spot, especially for tandem paragliding, which can lead to crowded conditions. Be prepared to share the skies!

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Take a post bus to Waldegg and then walk for approximately 35 minutes to the takeoff.
  • Parking: Parking near the takeoff is prohibited. Use the parking lot at the Hohwald ski lift.
  • Shuttle: Shuttle buses may be available for a fee.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • Be aware of airspace restrictions in the Interlaken area due to the Meiringen military control zone (HX).
    • The CTR/TMA Meiringen can be activated at any time, even on weekends.
    • Check if the zones are active before flying by calling the free phone number 0800 HX MEIR (0800 496 347).
  • Wildlife Protection: Be aware of the wildlife protection agreement in the Hohgant area.
  • Cables and Obstacles: Be aware of cables and other air traffic obstacles. Consult the DABS (Daily Airspace Bulletin Switzerland) and the Geodata Portal of the Swiss Confederation for information.
  • Launch Priorities:
    • Amisbühl oben (Upper Launch): On Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays, the left launch lane is reserved for solo pilots, while the right lane is for tandem paragliders, tandem deltas, and solo deltas. Pilots without priority are expected to yield to those with priority.
    • Chalet Launch: Restricted to Paragliding Interlaken and DCI (Deltaclub Interlaken) flight schools only. Not open to private pilots.
  • Commercial Use Restrictions:
    • Commercial tandem flights are subject to specific restrictions. Contact the Verein kommerzieller Piloten Interlaken (VkPI) for information.
    • Guest flight schools need to coordinate with DCI schools in advance and must comply with the "Reglement Gastflugschulen". An online registration is needed on the Deltaclub Interlaken DCI website, costing CHF 40 per day.
  • Landing Restrictions: Respect the no-fly zones around the Heliport Interlaken and maintain a safe distance from flight routes!
  • Winter Restrictions: Amisbühl is not an official launch site in winter due to skiing operations.
search_recs: Amisbühl takeoff Amisbühl Gleitschirmfliegen Amisbühl paragliding site Switzerland Amisbühl paragliding regulations Amisbühl landing

html:
Overview

Grindelwald, nestled in the heart of the Bernese Oberland region of Switzerland, is a world-renowned paragliding destination. Surrounded by the majestic Eiger, Mönch, and Jungfrau peaks, the lush green valleys and towering alpine terrain create a stunning backdrop for an unforgettable paragliding experience.

Flying Conditions

Grindelwald offers scenic tandem paragliding flights with spectacular views of the Eiger North Face and the surrounding peaks. Flying is feasible in a range of weather conditions, with thermals typically peaking from mid-morning to late afternoon. Several launch sites provide varied experiences:

  • Launch Sites:
    • First: A popular launch site accessible via cable car.
    • Pfingstegg: Reached by cable car, offering stunning views.
    • Männlichen: Another easily accessible launch via cable car.
    • Eigergletscher: Only possible in stable and calm wind conditions due to downwind from the glacier.
  • Landing Site:
    • Grund: The official landing site located on the valley floor.
    • Bodmi: Also a possible landing site, be aware of possible restrictions from 3500 feet to 6500 feet.
  • Thermals:
    • Grindelwald is known as one of the best thermalling spots. Expect strong thermals on some days.

Who Should Fly Here?

Grindelwald caters to a wide range of pilots:

  • Beginners: Tandem flights are readily available, providing a safe and accessible introduction to paragliding.
  • Intermediate and Advanced Pilots: Several launch sites and thermal conditions offer challenges and opportunities for experienced pilots. Top landing at First, for example, requires experienced pilots due to potential turbulence.

Access & Facilities

Getting to the launch sites is convenient:

  • Cable Cars: Access to First, Pfingstegg, and Männlichen is primarily via cable car from Grindelwald or Wengen.
  • Fees: Cable car rides to the launch sites will incur fees. Tandem paragliding flights start from approximately CHF 220, often excluding the cable car ticket. While the use of some launch sites (Pfingstegg, First) is generally free, commercial operations should consult with the respective operating companies.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

Safety is paramount. Be aware of the following potential risks and restrictions:

  • General Risks:
    • Sudden Wind Changes: Unforeseeable shifts in wind conditions.
    • Mountainous Terrain: Gusts, turbulence, and unexpected downdrafts are inherent risks in mountainous areas.
  • Specific Risks:
    • Restricted zone for paraglider launches at First: Launches are only permitted south of the starting tower or west of the path to the launch site.
    • Swiss army exercises: The Swiss army may conduct exercises in the area with low-flying aircraft. Pilots should check for information beforehand.
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • Consult the DABS (Daily Airspace Bulletin Switzerland) for potential restrictions due to military exercises or the Axalp live firing range.
    • Be aware of the altitude limit at 3960m AMSL.
    • Check the DABS for information on airspace restrictions east of the line Brienz – Grindelwald.
search_recs: Grindelwald paragliding official site paragliding Grindelwald site information Grindelwald paragliding flying type Grindelwald paragliding access fees Grindelwald paragliding pilot level

html:
Overview

Marbachegg, located in the heart of the UNESCO Biosphere Entlebuch in the Emmental region of Switzerland, is a paragliding and hang gliding paradise. Offering panoramic views of the Schrattenfluh mountain chain, the Emmental source region, and the Bernese Alps, Marbachegg provides a stunning backdrop for memorable flights. With a 600m vertical height from take-off, this site is a popular choice year-round.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Marbachegg is renowned for its excellent thermal activity, enabling pilots to fly towards Lucerne and enjoy scenic routes around Marbach.
  • "Bisen" Flying: The site is well-suited for flying in north-east wind conditions (known as "Bisen").
  • Year-Round Flyable: Marbachegg offers flying opportunities throughout the year.
  • Valley Wind: Be aware that the valley wind can become strong during the summer months.

Who Should Fly Here?

Marbachegg caters to pilots of all experience levels, making it an inviting destination for both beginners and seasoned flyers.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easy access is provided by the Sportbahn Marbach gondola.
  • Launch Site Proximity: The primary launch site is a short walk from the mountain station.
  • Parking: Free parking is available at the base station.
  • Fees:
    • Landing fee: CHF 3 per day or CHF 30 for an annual pass (payable at the Sportbahn or Flugschule Marbach).
    • Day ticket (Gleitschirm): CHF 35.00 for adults.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Strong Valley Wind: Be aware that during the summer months, the valley wind can become very strong.
  • Turbulence: Risk of turbulence, especially in Bise (north-east wind) conditions. If turbulence is significant, consider switching to the Gurli launch site.
  • Startplatz Nord (North Launch): Considered a difficult launch.
    • Short runway.
    • Potential for lee rotors (rotor turbulence) caused by the forest.
    • Recommended for experienced pilots only.
  • Ramp near Bergstation (Mountain station): The ramp for hang gliders near the mountain station is steep, short, and drops off sharply, limiting the possibility of aborting a launch.
  • Brienzergrat Agreement: Flying over Brienzergrat is restricted from April 1st to June 30th (Monday to Friday).
  • Temporary Airspace Restrictions: Always check NOTAMs for temporary airspace restrictions due to events (e.g., conferences).
search_recs: Marbachegg paragliding license Marbachegg paragliding site guide paragliding Marbachegg Switzerland Marbachegg Gleitschirmfliegen

html:
Overview

Crêt du Midi is a popular paragliding site located in Vercorin, a mountain village in Valais, Switzerland. Situated on a mountain terrace at 1330m above sea level, with the take-off at 2332m, it offers stunning panoramic views of the Valais and the Rhone Valley. Known for its varied flying conditions and strong thermals, Crêt du Midi attracts pilots looking to experience the beauty of the Swiss Alps from above.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Activity: Renowned for generous thermals, often providing lift to altitudes exceeding 4000m in the Val d'Anniviers and the Val d'Hérens.
  • Wind Conditions: Somewhat protected from the wind, but can be influenced by strong valley winds, particularly in the afternoons. Be aware of potential northerly winds (Bise) that can make take-off inadvisable later in the day. Turbulence may be present with West or North winds exceeding 20 kph at 2000m.
  • Seasonal Flying:
    • Summer: Pilots often take off from Vercorin village and land in Chalais in the Rhone Valley.
    • Winter: Take-off is from Crêt-du-Midi (2300m), with landing in Vercorin village.
  • Best Time to Fly: Generally, the morning offers the most favorable conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Crêt du Midi caters to a range of pilots, from intermediate to advanced. While the Crêt du Midi Est take-off is considered easy, and the site benefits from an 1800m drop allowing for extended flights, pilots should be aware that the site can have strong thermals, especially in the afternoons, requiring experienced pilot skills. One of the landing areas, Vercorin, is considered difficult, so choose landing areas appropriate for your skill level. Tandem flights are also common here.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Access to the Crêt du Midi take-off is convenient via a cable car that operates in both summer and winter.
  • Short Walk to Take-Off: From the top of the cable car, it's a short walk to the take-off area.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Thermal Activity: Strong thermals, especially in the afternoons, require experienced pilot skills.
  • Valley Wind: Strong valley winds can make landing difficult, particularly in the afternoons.
  • Turbulence: Expect strong, turbulent conditions with West or North prevailing winds exceeding 20 kph at 2000m.
  • Cable Car Cables: Be aware of the Brevent cable car cables and the ski lift cable near the takeoff.
  • Takeoff Difficulty: Be aware of takeoff difficulty for the takeoff "Crêt du Midi Ouest" which is considered medium difficulty.
  • CTR/TMA Sion Airspace: When landing at Chalais, stay close to the Vercorin terrain in Briey (<150m GND) to avoid entering the CTR/TMA Sion airspace.

Disclaimer: This information is based on available reports and research. Always consult local pilots and check current conditions before flying at Crêt du Midi. Pay close attention to weather forecasts, airspace restrictions, and potential hazards.
search_recs: Cret du Midi paragliding club Cret du Midi paragliding Switzerland Cret du Midi paragliding site information Cret du Midi paragliding site regulations Cret du Midi vol libre

html:
Overview

The Niesen, a striking pyramid-shaped mountain in the Bernese Oberland region of Switzerland, is a popular paragliding site offering significant altitude differences and reliable thermals. Located south of Lake Thun and between the Simmen and Kander valleys, the Niesen provides stunning views and exciting flying opportunities. The best flying season spans from May to the end of October, with morning conditions often proving superior.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Known for reliable thermals, allowing for extended flights.
  • Altitude Difference: Flights to Spiez are common, capitalizing on an impressive altitude difference of approximately 1800m.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • North winds can render paragliding flights impossible, so checking the forecast is essential.
    • Experienced pilots recommend starting early (from 9:30 am) in questionable conditions and flying towards Fromberghorn to gain altitude.
    • Caution should be exercised between 11:00 am and 4:00 pm from May to August due to strong thermal activity.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Niesen caters to a range of pilots, though some experience is beneficial due to the steepness of the launch sites. It's suitable for both paragliding and tandem flights. However, overcrowding can be an issue during winter weekends if thermals don't reach high altitudes (over 2400m), potentially impacting the enjoyment of the flight.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The site is accessed via the Niesenbahn funicular from Mülenen.
  • Transportation: Mülenen station is easily accessible by train on the Bern-Kandersteg-Brig line.
  • Fees: Transport fees apply for the use of the funicular.
  • Logistics:
    • Only a limited number of paragliders can be transported per trip.
    • Pilots are responsible for reloading their paragliders at the Schwandegg intermediate station.
  • Information: Information boards are present at both the valley station and the launch site. Consult the Air Base Flyers paragliding club website for information on flying, landing sites and transport.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: As a cone-shaped mountain at the beginning of a valley, the Niesen can experience unpredictable wind conditions.
  • Lee Side Risk: Strong thermals in the Alps can lead to a northerly compensating flow during the day, potentially causing the Niesen to be overblown and "lee-contaminated".
  • Rotor Risk: Starting from official launch sites with northerly winds is not recommended. The windsock on the ridge between the main and west peaks may falsely indicate lift, which can be a tricky rotor situation.
  • Launch Considerations:
    • Startplatz Süd (South Launch): Relatively steep terrain; good footwear is recommended. Be cautious with northerly winds.
    • Startplatz West (West Launch): Moderately steep terrain; good footwear is recommended. Be cautious with northerly winds.
    • In spring and summer, before 5:00 pm, conditions at the launch can be rough and may not suit occasional pilots.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Flying into the Reichenbach airfield traffic zone is strictly prohibited. The red zone of the airfield must not be overflown. Pilots must adhere to the agreement with the airfield to prevent the closure of the Frutigen landing site.
  • Landing Area: When approaching to land in Frutigen, do not fly over the yellow hatched area.
  • Radio Communication: Blind radio calls to Reichenbach airfield are not allowed.
search_recs: Niesen paragliding site information paragliding Niesen Switzerland Niesen Switzerland official paragliding site

html:
Overview

Ebenalp is a highly popular paragliding and hang gliding site located in the Alpstein area of Appenzell, Switzerland. Situated at approximately 1600m above the Rhine Valley, this area boasts stunning alpine scenery, including the Wildkirchli caves and the Berggasthaus Äscher. Known for its favorable location and excellent thermal conditions, Ebenalp attracts pilots looking for ridge soaring and thermaling opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Excellent thermal conditions allow pilots to gain significant altitude quickly.
  • Ridge Soaring: Well-regarded for ridge soaring.
  • Take-off Points:
    • Multiple take-off points cater to various wind directions.
    • Northwest (NW-NNO): Suitable for beginners. Rotor danger in strong westerly winds. Landing back at the takeoff is difficult. Uneven ground.
    • South (SO-S): A cliff launch. Considered difficult and only recommended for very experienced paraglider pilots.
    • Northeast (Schulstartplatz Nordost): Be aware of lines wrapped around sharp rocks. Avoid drifting left into the ski lift cable.
    • Site is popular for tandem flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Ebenalp attracts pilots of varying experience levels, but it is particularly popular, especially on weekends, which can lead to queues at the take-off points. While the main take-off is considered easy, some take-off locations are only recommended for experienced pilots due to the cliff launch and often strong thermals.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Access to the take-off points is via the Wasserauen-Ebenalp cable car.
  • Fees: A fee for take-off and landing is included in the cable car ticket price. Special tickets are available for paragliding and hang gliding pilots.
  • Landing Site: Located south of the Wasserauen train station and east of the main parking area. Separate landing areas are designated for hang gliders and paragliders. Paragliders should land south of the train station, while hang gliders land north of the Ebenalp cable car base station.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Cables: Several poorly visible cables pose a significant hazard. Pilots must be vigilant and aware of their location.
    • Cable running from the summit of the Schäfler to the Lehmental.
    • "Tumbler" cable near the Berggasthaus Ebenalp.
    • Cable car cables at the Ebenalp and landing area. Underflying the cable car cables near the valley station is strictly prohibited.
  • Föhn Conditions: Föhn winds can create extremely dangerous conditions and turbulence.
  • Helicopter Traffic: Frequent helicopter traffic in the Alpstein area. Be aware of wake turbulence and wait before flying in areas where helicopters have recently operated.
  • Wildlife Protection Areas: Overfly wildlife protection areas (Wildschutzgebiet „Äscher") at a minimum altitude of 1500m. Starting, flying low, or making loud noises over these areas is prohibited.
  • Wind Conditions: Strong winds, especially with a westerly component, can create rotor turbulence.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Check local conditions via NOTAM, DABS, and aviation maps. There are flight restriction zones that must be overflown at a minimum altitude.
  • Landing Procedures: A left-hand turn is generally flown when approaching the landing area.
search_recs: Ebenalp paragliding take-off Ebenalp paragliding official site Ebenalp paragliding site information Ebenalp Gleitschirmfliegen

html:
Overview

Zugerberg is a popular paragliding site located near the city of Zug in Central Switzerland. Despite its relatively flat terrain, it offers stunning views of the city, Lake Zug, Lake Lucerne, and even Lake Sempach on clear days. Maintained in part by the Paradeltaclub Zug, it’s a favorite among local and visiting pilots for both thermal soaring and scenic evening flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Flying: Zugerberg is renowned for thermal activity, especially on warm spring and summer days.
  • Cross-Country Potential: Opportunities exist for shorter cross-country flights into the lowlands.
  • Evening Flights: The site is very popular for evening flights, thanks to the beautiful sunsets.
  • Altitude: The launch site sits at 947m above sea level, offering a height difference of approximately 526 meters to the landing area.
  • Wind Conditions: West wind conditions are generally considered the easiest, especially for less experienced pilots. Launching can be more challenging with North-West or South-West winds. Suitable for southwest to northwest, northeast to east winds at Ramenegg takeoff.
  • Year-Round Flying: The site can be flown year-round, provided it is free of snow.

Who Should Fly Here?

Zugerberg attracts pilots of varying skill levels, from intermediate to experienced. While landing is considered straightforward, and launching is easy under West wind conditions, the site is rated as medium difficulty overall. Beginners might find it easier to fly at sites with simpler access, like those with cable car access. Be aware that the site is popular, and therefore often busy with local pilots, visitors, and flight schools.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The launch site is accessible by cable car (Zugerbergbahn) or by car via Blasenberg or Allenwinde. From the Zugerberg mountain station, it's a 10-minute walk to the takeoff area.
  • Landing: The designated landing site (Bröchli) is located in Oberwil, with parking available nearby, but not directly at the landing site.
  • Fees: A fee of CHF 2 per start is required, excluding members of Paradeltaclub Zug and Flugschule Paraworld.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Lee Conditions: Be cautious of lee conditions with wind from a northerly direction.
  • Turbulence: The Zugerberg can be challenging for thermalling and may not be immediately obvious to visiting pilots.
  • Variable Launch Difficulty: Launching is simple with a West wind but presents medium difficulty with Northwest or Southwest winds.
  • TMA 14 Zürich Airspace: This airspace is classified as "HX" and can be activated within 30 minutes. Pilots must check its status every 30 minutes on 129.000 MHz or 043 816 2295 (Zürich Departure Information ATIS DEP) when TMA 14 is active.
  • Landing Restrictions: Landing is only permitted near the windsock.
  • Access to Takeoff: Access to the takeoff area should only be via the edge of the meadow and forest, and not directly across the fields.
  • Minimizing Ground Damage: Avoid practicing kiting/ground handling at the takeoff area. Only use the meadow for landing and packing up. The meadows above or east of the windsock must not be used.
  • Respect Regulations: Strict adherence to regulations is crucial due to the high usage of the site, particularly by non-resident pilots and flying schools. Regulations are communicated via the homepage and on-site signs and information boards.
  • Report Damage: Any damage to fences must be reported immediately to the landowners:
    • For the takeoff area, contact Herr Weiss at 079 452 56 33.
    • For the landing area, contact Herr Iten at 079 723 77 74.
search_recs: Zugerberg paragliding official site Zugerberg Gleitschirmfliegen Zugerberg paragliding Gleitschirmclub Zugerberg Zugerberg paragliding access Zugerberg paragliding fees

html:
Overview

Fanas, nestled in the Prättigau region of Graubünden, Switzerland, is a popular paragliding site renowned for its stunning Alpine scenery and excellent thermaling conditions. With multiple launch points accessible via the Fanas gondola, it offers opportunities for both panoramic flights and ambitious cross-country adventures. Fanas is a well-regarded site among Swiss paragliders, attracting pilots of varying skill levels.

Flying Conditions

  • Launch Points:
    • Eggli (1650m): Accessible via the Fanas gondola, suitable for southeast, south, and moderate southwest winds.
    • Höreli (1800m): Also accessible via the gondola, featuring a north-facing launch ideal for northwest, north, and northeast winds.
    • Sassauna (2300m): Requires a hike & fly.
  • Thermal Activity: Known for its strong and turbulent thermal conditions, Fanas provides ample opportunities for thermaling and XC flights.
  • XC Potential: Pilots can embark on XC flights towards Arlberg, Innsbruck, Bozen, Liechtenstein, and the Rhine Valley.
  • Wind Considerations: Avoid flying when strong northwest to northeast winds are present or when 'Föhn' conditions are predicted.

Who Should Fly Here?

Fanas caters to a wide range of pilot experience levels. Beginners can enjoy scenic panorama flights, while experienced pilots can challenge themselves with thermaling and cross-country flying. The site is also utilized for training and testing purposes. Due to its popularity, especially in spring, it's highly recommended to reserve gondola space in advance.

Access & Facilities

  • Gondola Access: The Eggli and Höreli launch sites are easily accessible via the Fanas gondola. Note that the gondola is closed between 12:00 and 13:00.
  • Getting There:
    • By Car: Take the Zürich-Chur route, exit at Landquart towards Klosters/Davos, then via Grüsch to Fanas. Parking may be limited.
    • By Public Transport: Take the train to Schiers and then a bus to Fanas.
  • Fees: Gondola tickets are required (check the gondola's website for current pricing). There are currently no take-off or landing fees.
  • Landing Zones: Landings are possible in Fanas, Grüsch, and Schiers. The official landing zone in Fanas is located approximately 200m northeast of the valley station and is indicated by a windsock.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Talwind (Valley Wind): From April to the end of August, be cautious of the valley wind, which can reach dangerous speeds with strong gusts, especially when combined with regional winds. This is most dangerous for the lower takeoffs.
  • Mountain Flying Challenges: Alpine flying requires local knowledge and experience due to complex wind systems.
  • Hidden Cables: Be aware of unmarked cables, especially those used for logging operations.
  • Turbulence: Expect strong and turbulent thermals.
  • Höreli North Launch: Immediately after launching from Höreli towards the north, turn left and begin soaring at the northern slope above the Höreli-Ochsenstein ridge. You must reach at least 1950m at Luderenegg.
  • Wildlife Protection: The Tobel area in front of the Höreli North launch is a wildlife retreat in winter and should not be entered until the end of spring; flights are only permitted above the ridge. Pilots must adhere to agreements concerning wildlife protection and the Bad Ragaz Airport to ensure continued tolerance of paragliding activities in the area.
search_recs: Fanas paragliding club Fanas paragliding official site Fanas paragliding site information Fanas Gleitschirmfliegen

html:
Overview

Cimetta is a stunning mountain located above Locarno and Lago Maggiore in Ticino, Switzerland, offering a breathtaking 360-degree panorama of Lake Maggiore, surrounding mountains, and valleys. Easily accessible via public transport, this popular site provides a significant height difference of around 1450m from take-off to landing, making it a favorite for both local and international pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Soaring and Cross-Country (XC) Flying: Cimetta is renowned for its excellent soaring conditions and opportunities for cross-country flights.
  • Wind Direction: The prevailing wind usually blows from the South, offering an "easy take-off."
  • Thermals: Pilots can enjoy extended flight times thanks to favorable thermal activity.
  • Valley Wind: In the afternoon, pilots should be mindful of the valley wind and avoid drifting too far towards Locarno to ensure a safe return to the landing area.

Who Should Fly Here?

Cimetta is suitable for pilots of all skill levels, from beginners taking their first flights to experienced XC pilots seeking to push their limits. It's also a popular site for paragliding schools and tandem flights.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Reach Cimetta via public transportation from Locarno: a funicular to Orselina, then a cable car to Cardada, followed by a chairlift to Cimetta. Hiking or biking to Cardada-Cimetta is also an option.
  • Takeoff Area: The take-off area is conveniently located near a restaurant, close to the chair lift station.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Strong Winds: Be aware of potentially strong winds in the Valle Maggia, especially during summer afternoons, and over Locarno in the summer.
  • Rotor Risk: North wind may not always be apparent at Cimetta, and rotors can appear directly in front of the launch. If a breeze from the south is present, seek advice from local pilots, flight schools, or meteorological services.
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • Pilots need to be aware of the Locarno TMA (Terminal Control Area).
    • Airspace above 3950 meters above sea level on Weekdays and 4450 meters above sea level on Weekend and after 17:05 is restricted for paragliders.
  • Takeoff Area: Adhere to the marked paragliding take-off area and follow all posted signs.
  • Takeoff Hazards: Pay attention to the chair lift cable on the left and the house and tree on the right of the take-off area.
search_recs: Cimetta paragliding official site Cimetta paragliding site guide Cimetta paragliding Switzerland pilot level Cimetta paragliding fees Cimetta paragliding access

html:
Overview

Riederalp, nestled in the Upper Valais region of Switzerland, is a paragliding paradise situated on a sunny, car-free high plateau nearly 2000 meters above sea level. Surrounded by picturesque landscapes, it boasts panoramic views of the Valais Alps, including the iconic Matterhorn and Dom. As a gateway to the Aletsch Glacier, a UNESCO Natural World Heritage Site, Riederalp offers a unique and breathtaking backdrop for paragliding adventures.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Known for excellent thermaling conditions and significant potential for cross-country (XC) flights.
  • Seasonality: Paragliding is possible year-round. Summer provides favorable anabatic winds and strong thermals, while winter flying also presents opportunities.
  • Thermal Activity: Riederalp is renowned for its potent thermals, allowing experienced pilots to achieve extended flight durations. Strong thermals can create gusty updrafts in the afternoon.

Who Should Fly Here?

Riederalp is best suited for experienced pilots due to its strong thermals and XC flight possibilities. However, tandem flights are also popular, making it accessible for beginners and tourists seeking a taste of paragliding. Pilots should be proficient in managing strong thermal activity, especially during afternoon flights.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Reach Riederalp via cable car from Mörel.
  • Fees: Site fees may apply. Refer to the Fluggruppe Aletsch website for detailed information.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Starts outside of the official launch site: The Fluggruppe Aletsch (Aletsch Flying Group) has asked pilots to only use the official launch site to avoid endangering the flying area Brig.
  • Morning Conditions: Generally easy and unproblematic at the official Riederalp (Abraham's Schoss) launch.
  • Afternoon Thermals: Strong thermals can create gusty updrafts requiring significant pilot skill to manage at the Abraham's Schoss launch. Pilots should pay close attention and monitor their glider after launch.
  • Launch Site Restrictions: Launching outside the official launch site is prohibited to avoid endangering the flying area of Brig.
  • Federal Hunting Ban Area: Launches and landings within the Aletschwald federal hunting ban area are strictly prohibited.
  • Airspace Awareness: Always check for NOTAMs and the DABS (Daily Airspace Bulletin Switzerland) for any temporary airspace restrictions (e.g., forest fire operations).
search_recs: Riederalp luftraumbeschränkungen paragliding Paragliding club Riederalp paragliding Riederalp Switzerland Riederalp paragliding site information

html:
Overview

Mentschelenalp is a scenic paragliding site near Blumenstein in the Bern region of Switzerland, offering stunning views and excellent flying conditions. Located at 1400m above sea level, it's a popular spot for both paragliding and hang gliding, especially during Bise (northeasterly wind) conditions. Managed by the Para-Deltaclub Stockhorn (PDCS), Mentschelen provides an ideal alpine flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Best Conditions: Well-suited for flying in Bise (northeasterly wind).
  • Soaring: Known for ridge soaring, utilizing alpine thermals rising on the north side of the Stockhorn range.
  • Season: The best time to fly is from the end of March to October.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Mentschelen take-off is considered an easy launch site, often used by flight schools. While suitable for a range of skill levels, pilots should be aware that mountain flying can present demanding conditions based on the weather. Therefore, any pilot should be capable to evaluate the wind and weather situation.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Private vehicles are prohibited on Mentschelenalp. Access is via the Para-Deltaclub Stockhorn bus service from the Blumenstein landing site.
  • Fees: There is a take-off/landing fee of CHF 2 per flight for guest pilots.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Alpine Weather: Be prepared for strong gusts of wind and rapidly changing conditions due to complex alpine weather patterns. Turbulence can occur with strong gusts.
  • Shooting Range: Flights are prohibited during shooting times at the shooting range north of the take-off site. A rotating light at the take-off site indicates when the range is active. Check online for shooting schedules.
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • Maximum altitude: 3950 meters AMSL on weekdays, 4450 meters AMSL on weekends and after 17:05.
    • Pilots must respect all Swiss airspace regulations.
search_recs: Gleitschirmfliegen Mentschelen Bewilligungen Mentschelen Gleitschirmfliegen Mentschelen paragliding site Mentschelen paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

The Metschstand is a popular paragliding launch site nestled in the scenic Bernese Oberland region of Switzerland, near Lenk. Boasting panoramic views of the surrounding mountains, this site offers a memorable flying experience in a stunning alpine setting. With an easy difficulty take-off, Metschstand is accessible and enjoyable for a range of pilot skill levels.

Flying Conditions

Metschstand is known for tandem flights, and soaring is possible on top of Metschstand depending on the weather. There are other launch sites in the area, such as Mülkerblatte (Betelberg) and Seewlenalp (Schatthorn), that may be used depending on the time of day, wind, and weather. Landing sites include Lischmatte (village) and the Metsch valley station (Rothenbach).

  • Wind Considerations:
    • Soaring is optimal when wind speeds are between 16-25km/h.
    • Avoid flying in gusty wind, and avoid flying when wind speeds exceed 25 km/h, especially for inexperienced pilots.

Who Should Fly Here?

Metschstand is considered an easy difficulty take-off. The site appears suitable for a range of pilot skill levels.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the take-off is via the Metschstand Xpress cable car from Rothenbach to Metsch, and then a chairlift. From the top station, it is a 15-minute walk to the launch.
  • Tickets: Pilots can get special day tickets for paragliding at the Betelberg and Metsch valley stations.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

As a mountain site, pilots should be aware of rapidly changing wind conditions, strong thermals, and limited escape routes. Unfamiliarity with mountain air movement can catch pilots out, particularly air moving up, down, and sideways. Soaring and scratching close to rock faces should be approached cautiously. Pay close attention to the following:

  • Mountain Flying Hazards: Be aware of rapidly changing weather conditions, strong thermals, and limited escape routes.
  • Turbulence: The landing area can be turbulent. Pilots should be prepared to actively control their glider.
  • Prohibited Maneuvers: "Kratzen" (low soaring) on the flanks below the Metschhorn is prohibited.
  • Landing Zones: Land only in the designated areas. Ground handling is not allowed. In winter, do not land on the "Loipe" (cross-country ski track).
  • Wildlife Protection: Respect wildlife quiet zones.
  • Airspace: Be aware of the St. Stephan airfield airspace. The minimum altitude is 600m above the airfield height (min. 1607m).
  • Seewlen Takeoff: At the Seewlen takeoff, avoid low and unnecessary "Kratzen". If no thermal lift is found, leave the area directly. If flying over the area with the minimum height is unavoidable for thermal or flight technical reasons, fly as considerately and as high as possible.

html:
Overview

Motta Naluns is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Unterengadin region of Switzerland, above the picturesque village of Scuol. Renowned for its thermaling and XC (cross-country) flying opportunities, the site boasts stunning panoramic views of the Engadine Dolomites and the Lower Engadine valley. With a high alpine environment ranging from 1250 to 2800m, Motta Naluns offers exhilarating flying experiences throughout the year.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals & XC: Motta Naluns is known for its excellent thermaling and cross-country flying conditions.
  • Year-Round Flying: The site offers good flying conditions throughout the year, making it a versatile destination.
  • Launch Sites:
    • East-Facing Launch: Ideal for "Bise" (northeasterly wind) and light wind conditions.
    • South-Facing Launch: Recommended for south to west wind conditions.
  • Wind Awareness: Pilots should be prepared for potentially rapidly changing wind systems. Afternoon northerly or northeasterly winds can develop at the launch, so pilots shouldn't delay entering thermals.
  • Seasonal Considerations: Be aware that strong northwest winds can create downdrafts at the launch site in the mornings during winter, spring, and early summer. The Engadin valley can experience intense thermal conditions, especially in mid-June.

Who Should Fly Here?

Motta Naluns caters to a wide range of pilot skill levels, from beginners to experienced XC enthusiasts. The main launch sites are rated as "easy to medium" in difficulty, making it suitable for instruction. However, pilots should be aware that accidents occur as a result of pilots overestimating themselves or misjudging the weather or wind.

Access & Facilities

  • Gondola Access: Access to the launch sites is conveniently provided by the Motta Naluns gondola from Scuol.
  • Landing Zone: The landing site is located near the base station of the lift, above the parking lots.
  • Lift Tickets: A lift ticket is required to access the launch sites.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Changing Wind Systems: Wind conditions can change rapidly, demanding constant vigilance.
  • Turbulence: The valley wind system can create dangerous turbulence, especially during spring thermals.
  • Downdrafts: Be prepared for downdrafts at the launch site with Northwest wind conditions, particularly in the mornings during winter, spring, and early summer.
  • Cable Car Proximity: Use caution when using the south launch site due to the proximity of the cable car. Maintain a safe distance, especially in winter when launching parallel to the cable car.
  • Designated Areas: Adhere to official takeoff and landing areas. Respect enclosures and avoid taking off or landing within them.
  • Winter Sanctuaries: Observe wildlife sanctuaries during the winter months.
  • Landing Etiquette: Avoid landing in high grass.
  • CTR Innsbruck: Be aware that flying too far downwind towards Martina-Landeck may enter the CTR (Controlled Traffic Region) of Innsbruck. Austrian authorities strictly enforce airspace violations.
  • Tidiness: Keep the takeoff and landing areas clean.
search_recs: Motta Naluns paragliding access Motta Naluns Gleitschirmfliegen Motta Naluns paragliding site characteristics Motta Naluns paragliding official information Motta Naluns paragliding fees

html:
Overview

Vounetz, located above the picturesque village of Charmey in the Gruyère region of Fribourg, Switzerland, offers stunning paragliding opportunities. Accessible via cable car, the take-off area near the summit (1,620m) provides panoramic views of the Gruyère region, including the Moléson, Dents Vertes, Lac de Montsalvens Reservoir, and Jaunbach Gorge. Vounetz is officially recognized as a paragliding site and offers ideal conditions for both solo and tandem flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Ideal Wind Conditions: East to Southeast winds are considered ideal. The site is also flyable with the "Bise," a specific northeasterly wind common in Switzerland.
  • Thermals: Charmey's geographical conditions create opportunities for thermal activity.
  • Take-off Terrain:
    • The summit launch is next to a farm, featuring a flat area for layout followed by medium-steep terrain.
    • The Ski Lift Launch has a medium to steep slope.

Who Should Fly Here?

Vounetz caters to a range of pilots. The site is suitable for both single and tandem paragliders and is considered to have a medium difficulty level. Pilots should be aware of potentially stronger spring conditions that may create turbulence.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: The primary access to the take-off area is via the Charmey-Vounetz cable car.
  • Cable Car Fees (as of April 8, 2025):
    • Ascent to Summit: CHF 13 (Child 6-15), CHF 15 (Young 16-24), CHF 17 (Adult 25-63), CHF 15 (Senior 64+)
    • 3 hours: CHF 26 (all)
    • Day pass: CHF 25 (Child 6-15), CHF 31 (Young 16-24), CHF 36 (Adult 25-63), CHF 31 (Senior 64+)
  • Parking: A communal parking lot is located in front of the lift building, with rates of CHF 1 per hour (first hour free) and a daily maximum of CHF 5. Payment can be made with cash, card, Twint, or via the Parkingpay app.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Awareness: Always check the weather forecast and anemometer readings before flying. Strong gusts can lead to loss of control. Spring conditions can be stronger and create turbulence.
  • Terrain Considerations: Be mindful of potentially limited emergency landing areas due to rocky or rough terrain.
  • Altitude Limits: Flights are restricted to a maximum altitude of 3950 meters above sea level on weekdays and 4450 meters above sea level on weekends and after 17:05.
  • Airspace: Vounetz is likely in Class G airspace up to a certain altitude, but proximity to airfields could mean controlled airspace is nearby. Be aware of controlled (classes C, D, and E) and uncontrolled (class G) airspace in Switzerland.
  • Swiss Regulations:
    • Pilots with an IPPI card level IV or V can fly freely.
    • Pilots with IPPI card level III can only fly with supervision.
    • A CHF 1 million third-party insurance is mandatory. Pilots must carry proof of insurance.
    • Tandem flights are not allowed without a Swiss tandem license.
    • Foreign speedflying pilots require a speedflying license extension.
  • Landing Area Etiquette: After landing at the designated landing area near the gondola parking lot, pilots are instructed to fold their paragliders in the parking lot, not on the grass.

html:
Overview

Balderen is a paragliding site located on the Uetliberg mountain near Zurich, Switzerland. Managed by the Paragliding Club Zürich (PGZH), this site offers ridge soaring opportunities with specific wind conditions. Note that Balderen is not a certified site.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind: Best flown when the "Bise" wind (easterly wind) is blowing between 15 and 25 km/h. Flyable in weak to moderate breeze (NE wind).
  • Launch: Known as a difficult, demanding cliff launch. Requires active flying immediately after takeoff due to potential eddies caused by tall trees, especially with a northern wind component.
  • Soaring: Primarily a ridge soaring site.

Who Should Fly Here?

This site is rated as "hard" in difficulty. It is suitable for paragliding and hang gliding, including single and two-seater flights. Due to the small and exposed launch area, a good command of the reverse (back) launch technique is essential. Only one pilot can prepare and launch at a time.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Accessible via public transport (bus to Leimbach, "Im Hüsli" stop, followed by a 30-minute walk) or cable car from Adliswil to Felsenegg, then a 20-minute walk along the ridge.
  • Parking: Parking is available at the landing site, with restrictions to be noted with the farmer. No car access to the launch site itself.
  • Fees: A landing and parking fee of CHF 5.00 per flight is payable. An annual pass can be obtained from the PGZH for CHF 40.00.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Cliff Launch: The site features a "cliff launch" which is narrow and steeply dropping, potentially posing a risk, especially to less experienced pilots.
  • Small Takeoff Area: The takeoff area is small, requiring skillful reverse takeoff techniques.
  • Wind Conditions (Bise): Strong Bise conditions can make launching difficult.
  • Airspace: The entire flying area is located below controlled airspace and borders the CTR (Control Traffic Region) of Zurich Airport, where flying is strictly prohibited.
search_recs: Balderen paragliding official site Balderen paragliding site information Balderen Gleitschirmfliegen informationen Balderen paragliding access Balderen paragliding fees Balderen paragliding club

html:
Overview

The Rotenfluh, standing at 1,571 meters high, is a renowned paragliding site located in the picturesque Mythen region near Schwyz, Switzerland. This "flying paradise" offers stunning views of Grosser Mythen and Lake Lucerne, attracting pilots with its reliable updrafts and breathtaking scenery.

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable Winds: Best flown in westerly winds, offering excellent thermaling and soaring opportunities.
  • Thermals: Known as a thermally active site, providing strong thermals for experienced pilots. Experts recommend flying early to make the most of thermals before the valley wind takes over.
  • Soaring: Reliable updrafts create ideal soaring conditions. A route via Grosser Mythen to Mostelegg is often possible in the late afternoon.
  • Unsuitable Conditions: Avoid flying during "bise" (specific wind condition) and "hairdryer" wind conditions, as launches can be challenging.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Rotenfluh caters to a wide range of pilots, from professionals seeking challenging thermal flights to student pilots gaining experience. All pilots should have a good understanding of thermalling techniques.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Access to the launch site is via the Rotenfluebahn cable car.
  • Launch Site Access: A short 2-minute walk along a gravel road from the top station leads to the launch area.
  • Tickets: A round-trip ticket on the Rotenfluhbahn is required. Consider purchasing tickets that may include a lunch coupon for the Restaurant Gipfelstuebli at the summit.
  • Landing Fees: Tickets including landing fees are available. The designated landing area is A. Rickenbach.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Takeoff Difficulty: The Bergstation (Mountain Station) takeoff is rated as "difficult" (NW-N orientation). The Südwest (Southwest) takeoff is rated as "easy" (SO-SW orientation).
  • Airspace Restrictions: Be aware of Swiss airspace regulations. As of 2012, airspace above 3950 meters ASL (weekdays) and 4450 meters ASL (weekends and after 17:05) was off-limits to paragliders. Always consult the most current airspace information.
  • Local Briefing: Obtain a briefing on local requirements and conditions before flying, and contact the administrating club for site rules, protocols, and potential hazards.
  • Skill Level: Ensure you have suitable qualifications, skills, and experience for the site.
  • Weather Monitoring: Always check weather conditions before flying.
  • Insurance: Have travel insurance that covers adventure activities like paragliding. In Switzerland, compulsory accident insurance covers costs.
  • Site Manager: Ideally, a site manager should monitor safety and pilot skill levels based on wind and weather conditions.
search_recs: Rotenfluh paragliding site guide paragliding Rotenfluh (CH) Rotenfluh paragliding official information

html:
Overview

Scheidegg is a popular paragliding site located in the picturesque Zürcher Oberland region of Switzerland, near Wald. The site, maintained by the Delta Club Zürcher Oberland (DCZO) for over 45 years, offers stunning views of the Zürichsee (Lake Zurich) and the surrounding Oberland landscape. Situated next to the Alp Scheidegg restaurant, it provides a convenient and attractive flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Scheidegg offers good thermaling opportunities, making it a favorite among pilots looking to gain altitude.
  • Airspace: Be aware that the Alp Scheidegg flying area is located in the middle of TMA 2 Dübendorf, which is permanently active with a lower limit of 1700m above sea level. Therefore, pilots must adhere to the maximum permitted altitude of 1700m.
  • Bachtel Ost Gliding Area: At certain times (Sat/Sun, MilOff) the gliding area Bachtel Ost can be activated. When using this airspace, pilots are required to monitor radio communications.

Who Should Fly Here?

Alp Scheidegg is likely best suited for intermediate pilots and above, given the airspace restrictions and thermaling opportunities. Beginner pilots might consider tandem flights. The site's popularity means it can get busy, so awareness of other pilots is essential.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easily accessible by car via Gibswil or Wald.
  • Parking: Signposted pilot parking spaces with a turnaround area are available near the Alp Scheidegg restaurant. Carpooling is recommended due to limited parking.
  • Fees:
    • Day ticket: CHF 10
    • Annual ticket: CHF 50
    • Club membership (including annual pass): CHF 80
    Tickets can be purchased from the Alp Scheidegg restaurant or from club members.
  • Restaurant: The Alp Scheidegg restaurant provides food and refreshments.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Restrictions: Pilots must not exceed 1700 meters above sea level due to the TMA 2 Dübendorf. Failure to comply may result in the closure of the flying site.
  • Bachtel Ost Gliding Sector: When activated, pilots are required to monitor radio communications in Segelflugraum Bachtel Ost. Detailed information can be found on the postings at the launch site or on the Deltaclub Zürcher Oberland (DCZO) website.
  • Wind Conditions: Northwest wind and Bise (a cold, northeasterly wind) are considered unfavorable. Flying during Föhn wind conditions is strongly discouraged.
  • High Voltage Power Lines: Be aware of high-voltage power lines near the Wasserschloss Greetz (water castle Greetz).
  • Landing Restrictions: During the vegetation period, landing is only permitted on designated areas of the alpine meadow.
search_recs: paragliding site Scheidegg official info paragliding Scheidegg Switzerland Scheidegg Switzerland paragliding access fees Thermikfluggebiete Scheidegg Scheidegg paragliding skill level

html:
Overview

Oberi Wängi is a popular paragliding site located near Matzendorf in the Jura region of Switzerland. Known as a fantastic cross-country (XC) site, especially in spring, it attracts paragliding and hang gliding enthusiasts alike. The site is situated behind a farm (Bergwirtschaft Obere Wengi) and offers stunning views and excellent thermal conditions.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions:
    • Primary launch directions are South, Southwest, and Southeast.
    • Avoid launching with westerly, north-westerly, or northerly winds due to the risk of being pushed into trees below the takeoff area.
    • Be aware of potentially strong Bise (NE - E Wind).
  • Thermals:
    • Known for good thermal activity, with thermals often forming 100 meters to the left of the takeoff.
  • Cross Country:
    • Considered a fantastic cross-country (XC) site, especially in spring.

Who Should Fly Here?

Oberi Wängi is suitable for a range of pilot skill levels due to its easy to medium difficulty takeoff. However, given the potential wind hazards and airspace considerations, awareness of wind conditions and airspace regulations is crucial. It is also suitable for tandem flights. The site is heavily frequented on good weather days, so be prepared for other pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Typically via Oensingen - Balsthal - Matzendorf.
  • Parking: Park private cars 100m below the restaurant at the edge of the forest, not at the restaurant itself.
  • Transportation: In summer, a club bus service might be available.
  • Fees: Gastpiloten (guest pilots) are expected to contribute a start fee to the farmer. Use the collection box ("Kässeli") located at the gate. This is separate from any consumption at the restaurant.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Hazards:
    • Strong Bise (NE - E Wind) can be dangerous.
    • Westerly, north-westerly, or northerly winds pose a significant risk of being pushed into trees below the takeoff area.
  • Airspace:
    • The Basel TMA (Terminal Control Area) is above the site.
    • The ceiling is 1700 meters ASL (Above Sea Level).
    • Do not exceed this altitude without radio clearance and a good understanding of the airspace regulations for the area.
    • Compliance with local rules and regulations is crucial.
  • High Traffic: The site is heavily frequented on good days, so be aware of other pilots.
  • Local Knowledge: It is advisable to ask locals for information about airspace regulations.

html:
Overview

Crap Sogn Gion, nestled near Flims in the Swiss canton of Graubünden, is a premier paragliding site within the Glarus Alps. Offering stunning mountainous landscapes and take-off points at 2200m AMSL, it forms part of the Flims Laax Falera destination and is listed in the DHV (Deutscher Hängegleiterverband) database.

Flying Conditions

  • Take-off Points:
    • South-Southwest Facing: Generally considered easy with flat terrain.
    • Northeast Facing: Rated easy to medium difficulty with moderately steep terrain.
    • Naraus: Additional take-off site available.
  • Optimal Conditions:
    • Known for excellent thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying.
    • Often influenced by the foehn wind, making it suitable for both summer and winter flying.
    • XC potential towards Disentis and back, even as early as March.
    • Winter thermaling possible when snow melts from the trees.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • Exercise caution during foehn conditions.
    • Avoid flying east towards Reichenau/Chur or west towards Brigels/Disentis due to strong turbulences.

Who Should Fly Here?

Crap Sogn Gion is a popular site suitable for a range of pilot skill levels. The south-southwest take-off is more forgiving, while the northeast take-off presents a moderate challenge. Note that the recommended landing site at Flims-Dorf is better suited for experienced pilots due to sloping terrain and thermal activity.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Via the Laax Murschetg cable car.
  • Tickets: Discounted day tickets are available at the cable car ticket office upon presentation of a flight certificate. Alternatively, regular single ride tickets can be purchased.
  • Day Pass Costs (Zone 2):
    • Adults: CHF 60.00
    • Children/Teenagers (6-17 yrs): CHF 30.00
    • Seniors (>64 yrs): CHF 54.00
  • Keycard: A keycard purchase may be required in addition to the normal ticket.
  • Information: Official information, including webcams and wind turbines for checking conditions, can be found on the LAAX app and at the cable car stations.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wildlife Protection Areas: Maintain the following minimum distances:
    • Flimserstein: At least 300m horizontal and vertical distance.
    • Nagens: Below 1900m AMSL, at least 300m vertical distance.
    • Alp da Schnaus and Alp Muota: 300m vertical distance. When flying over from Crap Sogn Gion to the west, a minimum of 2400m AMSL.
  • Föhn Winds: High risk of strong and dangerous turbulence during Föhn conditions.
  • Winter Hazards: Be aware of skiers and snow groomers ("Pistenbullys") during takeoff and landing.
  • Turbulence: Expect a "flushing" effect.
  • Restaurant Flybys: Dangerous and not permitted; maintain a sufficient safety distance.
  • Landing Options: Many landing sites in the Surselva valley are not official.
  • Camera Drones: Be aware of camera drones, especially when approaching to top land in winter.
  • Takeoff specific considerations:
    • Crap Sogn Gion - Starting point no. 1 (S-SW): Pay attention to freestylers in the Pro Line and Pistenbullys.
    • Crap Sogn Gion - Launching site no. 2 (NE): Be careful at the entrance and exit of the Laax cable car.
  • Flight Restrictions
    • Plaun Wildlife Protection: When flying to Plaun, always stay southeast of the Plaun slope (Wildschutz). Maintain a 300m distance.
    • Landing at Falera: Not permitted in summer (May to October).
    • Alp Muota/Alp da Schnaus Overflight: Observe the overflight regulations for Alp Muota/Alp da Schnaus (refer to map).
    • Unofficial Landing Sites: The landing sites further down in the valley (Garage Caflisch Schluein, football field Schluein and Ilanz) are currently not official.
