html:
Overview

Braunwald is a renowned paragliding destination nestled in the Glarus region of Switzerland. This car-free village, situated on a sunny plateau at approximately 1300 meters, offers breathtaking mountainous scenery reminiscent of the Dolomites. Accessible by funicular from Linthal, Braunwald provides a paragliding mecca for pilots of all skill levels, from beginners to experienced XC enthusiasts.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying:
    • Excellent thermaling and ridge soaring opportunities.
    • The area is known for its reliable thermals.
  • Seasonality:
    • Flying is possible year-round.
    • Summer: Launches from Braunwald-Dorf (Kiosk) or Gumengrat.
    • Winter: Launches from Gumen.
  • Weather Considerations:
    • Be cautious of north to northeast winds, which can cause strong rotor.
    • Pay attention to the "Spion" (likely a wind indicator) on Gumengrat.
    • Strong wind shear can occur with northerly winds.
    • Side winds (valley or mountain winds) at the Kiosk launch can cause collapses after takeoff.

Who Should Fly Here?

Braunwald is a popular site suitable for paragliding, including tandem flights, and hang gliding. The difficulty is generally considered medium, making it accessible to a wide range of pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access:
    • Braunwald is car-free; access is via the Braunwaldbahn funicular from Linthal.
    • From Braunwald, cable cars provide access to higher launch points like Gumen and Gumengrat.
  • Fees:
    • A day ticket costs CHF 5.
    • A paragliding day pass is available for CHF 47 (CHF 40 with a Swiss Half-Fare travelcard), which includes start and landing fees from Linthal.
    • A map is available for CHF 45 for non-GKG members.
    • A one-way ticket on the cable car costs CHF 7.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • General Risks:
    • Proximity to Motor Aircraft: Be vigilant due to potential visual acquisition difficulties in the airspace.
    • Mountain Weather: Be aware of Föhn winds and strong high winds in the area. Watch out for lenticularis clouds and dust clouds, and pressure differences between north and south, which are indicators of Föhn conditions.
    • Turbulence: Turbulence can occur in the summer, especially in the afternoon.
  • Per Takeoff Risks:
    • Gumen/Gumengrat: Be aware that pilots have crashed on a steep meadow after launch.
  • Flight Restrictions:
    • Wildlife Sanctuary: Note the wildlife sanctuary on the opposite side of the valley.
    • Landing Site Rules: Be aware of the exact location of the landing site and relevant rules.
    • Engelberg Landing Site: Specific rules apply, including parking bans and designated areas for packing your glider.
    • Landing Restrictions: The football pitch Wyden (artificial turf) must not be used for landings.
    • Snowmaking equipment: Watch out for snowmaking equipment in Winter at the Engelberg landing site.

html:
Overview

Niederwiler Stierenberg is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Solothurn region of Switzerland, near Günsberg. Situated on a south-east facing terrace on the lower southern slope of the Jura mountains, approximately 500m above the Swiss plateau, this site offers stunning views and diverse flying opportunities. The launch is conveniently located in a forest clearing.

Flying Conditions

Niederwiler Stierenberg is renowned for its excellent thermal, ridge soaring, and cross-country (XC) flying potential. It is ideally suited for southeast wind conditions, offering the chance to fly along the beautiful Jura mountain chains.

Who Should Fly Here?

This site's potential for XC flights suggests that it is best suited for intermediate to experienced pilots looking to explore the Jura region from above. Although popular, pilots should be comfortable with thermal activity and XC flight planning.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Reach the Balmberg Kurhaus (summit) either by bus from Solothurn main station or by car. From there, follow the gravel road along the ridge eastward. The launch site is situated 100m behind the Stierenberg mountain restaurant.
  • Fees: There is no launch fee required for guest pilots. However, voluntary contributions are appreciated to help cover land lease costs.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • TMA Basel Airspace: Be aware that the launch site is located near the TMA Basel (Luftraum D), which starts at 1750 meters AMSL. This sector's activation status can change rapidly.
  • Mandatory Check: Before launching, pilots MUST check the activation status of TMA Basel by calling 061 325 34 67 (recorded message) or by radio on 134.675 MHz (recorded message) or 121.250 MHz. Activation can occur with only 30 minutes' notice.

html:
Overview

Büelen is a popular paragliding site located in the Engelberg valley in Switzerland, known for its scenic green hills and mountains. The site, at approximately 1100m, is well-established and often flyable even when Foehn winds ground pilots elsewhere. It is particularly well-suited for training, tandem flights, and even paragliding exams.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Suitable for Northeast (NE), East (E), and South (S) winds.
  • Height Difference: Offers a substantial height difference of approximately 551-560m.
  • Protected Location: The Engelberg valley is generally well-protected from strong winds, making it a reliable flying site.

Who Should Fly Here?

Büelen is a popular training site, ideally suited for paragliding schools and tandem flights. While accessible for many experience levels, pilots should be aware of obstacles near the landing zone. Pilots should be aware of obstacles near the landing zone and be under supervision if inexperienced.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easily accessible via the aerial cable car from Geissmattli (Wolfenschiessen), located at 550m.
  • Fees: A fee applies for the cable car ride, approximately CHF 10.
  • Landing Area Amenities: The landing area provides facilities such as a seating area and a kiosk.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Cables: Numerous cables are present, particularly near the landing zone. Information about cable locations can be found at the gondola station.
  • Airspace: Be aware of complex Swiss airspace regulations; acquire comprehensive information before flying.
  • Takeoff Proximity: The takeoff area is situated immediately beside a farmhouse at the gondola station.
  • Regulations: Pay attention to the info board at the launch site for current regulations and always observe landing rules.
search_recs: Büelen Gleitschirmfliegen Schweiz Büelen paragliding site Switzerland Büelen paragliding club

html:
Overview

Mauborget is a popular paragliding site located in the Jura region of Switzerland, overlooking the stunning Lake Neuchâtel. Known for its scenic beauty and accessible flying conditions, it attracts pilots of various skill levels. With its expansive meadow launch and potential for both soaring and cross-country flights, Mauborget offers a memorable flying experience.

Flying Conditions

Mauborget is well-suited for both paragliding and hang gliding, including tandem flights. The primary launch directions are South, South-East, and East, providing ample opportunities based on wind direction. The site benefits from thermals that develop along the Jura mountains towards Le Suchet and over the flatlands towards Lake Neuchâtel, making it ideal for extending flights and practicing cross-country techniques.

Who Should Fly Here?

Rated as a site of medium difficulty, Mauborget is suitable for a wide range of pilots. It's particularly beneficial for beginners looking to build airtime, especially in early spring due to its large and easy launch area. More experienced pilots will appreciate the potential for cross-country training and enjoying scenic flights above the lake. The terrain is also suitable for training.

Access & Facilities

Reaching Mauborget is convenient by car or Post bus to the Mauborget terminus. From there, a short 5-minute walk will take you to the launch site. Parking is available, however, it is not clear if there are any fees associated with using the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Restrictions: Be aware of airspace regulations in Switzerland. Generally, the ceiling is 3950 meters ASL on weekdays and 4450 meters ASL on weekends and after 17:05.
  • Agricultural Considerations: Be respectful of agricultural activities, especially during the growing season. Avoid walking through high grass and be courteous to farmers. Beware that cows in the Jura region are reported to dislike paragliders.
  • Turbulence: Be vigilant for turbulence, which can occur unexpectedly.
  • Right of Way: When ridge soaring, a paraglider overtaking another glider that is flying in the same direction should pass between the ridge and the glider being overtaken.

The landing is at Fontaines sur Grandson.

html:
Overview

Lai Alv is a paragliding site located in the mountainous Disentis/Mustér region of Graubünden, Switzerland, within the Flims-Oberalp area. Offering both summer and winter launch options, Lai Alv provides a stunning backdrop for thermal and glide flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Launch Orientation: Southerly.
  • Flying Type: Gliding and thermal flying. The summer launch is particularly suited for thermalling.
  • Wind Conditions: Ensure no tailwind before launching. Be prepared for potentially unpredictable weather patterns.

Who Should Fly Here?

  • Lai Alv is used for local thermal flights and glide flights to Disentis, with the potential for XC (cross-country) flights.
  • One source gives it a 1-star rating.
  • The winter launch is considered easy, while the summer launch is considered difficult due to being only accessible by foot.

Access & Facilities

  • Winter Access: Via the second section of the chairlift to the winter launch site (east of the restaurant).
  • Summer Access: The second section of the chairlift is closed in summer, meaning the summer launch site is only accessible by foot, 130m east of the lift.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather: Unpredictable weather patterns and strong winds pose significant risks. Always check weather forecasts and consult local experts before flying.
  • Pilot Error: Insufficient training and poor decision-making can lead to dangerous situations.
  • Equipment Failure: Regularly inspect and maintain equipment.
  • Takeoff Risks:
    • Backwind: Do not launch with any tailwind!
    • Winter Launch: Requires setting up a safety net (located under the restaurant terrace) before launch due to being on a ski slope.
    • Running Risk: Be aware of the "running risk" during takeoff and landing phases.
  • Gendusas Launch Site (Alternative):
    • Located 100m back along the chairlift from Caischavedra to Gendusas, near the windsock.
    • An upper, more southerly oriented launch site can be reached by following the hiking path northeast over the creek (approx. 60 meters altitude).
    • No launch with backwind!

Important Note: Paragliding activity must comply with Swiss laws. Do not use drugs or alcohol before or during flight activities.

html:
Overview

Mornera, located in Ticino, Switzerland, is a renowned paragliding site offering exceptional thermal conditions and stunning views of the Bellinzona region, the Magadino Plain, and the Alps. Situated at approximately 1380 meters above sea level, this gentle, south-facing terrace surrounded by larch and fir trees is a favorite among paragliders seeking long-distance flights and tandem experiences.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Hotspot: Mornera is known for its outstanding thermal activity, making it ideal for achieving significant altitude gains. Flights reaching over 3000 meters are common, weather permitting.
  • Year-Round Flying: The site is operational throughout the year, with favorable conditions allowing for memorable flights in all seasons.
  • Foehn Wind Caution: Pilots should be vigilant about Foehn wind conditions blowing from the north, as they can significantly impact flight safety.
  • Valley Winds: Be cautious of moderate to strong "Bise" (a type of wind). With thermal conditions in the afternoon, strong or excessively strong valley winds can be expected.

Who Should Fly Here?

Mornera caters to a wide range of paragliding enthusiasts. Tandem flights are popular and accessible to all, including families and children, with no specific age limit or skill requirement. However, solo pilots should consult with local clubs like Club Volo Libero Ticino (cvlt.ch) for site-specific recommendations and to assess their suitability based on experience.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: The take-off area is conveniently accessible via the Monte Carasso-Mornera cable car.
  • Cable Car Schedule: The cable car operates from 06:30 to 21:30, with intermediate stops at Curzùtt (600 meters) and Pientina (1000 meters). Note that the cable car is closed every Wednesday from 08:00 to 10:00 for routine maintenance.
  • Public Transportation: Reach the cable car base via bus 311 from Bellinzona or Locarno, or via bus 2 from Giubiasco.
  • Driving Directions: If driving, take freeway A2 exit Bellinzona Sud.
  • Cable Car Contact: For cable car inquiries, call +41 58 203 14 50 or email carasc@bellinzona.ch.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Side Winds on Launch: The launch site can be prone to side winds, making it more suitable for experienced pilots who are comfortable with challenging launch conditions.
  • Difficult Launch: The launch site is considered difficult and located in a pine forest, which is approximately 15 minutes walking distance from the mountain station.
  • CTR Locarno-Magadino: When flying cross country towards Locarno, be aware of the CTR (Control Zone) of Locarno-Magadino airport.
  • Cable Car Schedule: Check the cable car schedule before heading to the site. The flying site is accessible year-round, but is dependent on the operating hours of the cable car.
search_recs: paragliding Ticino Switzerland Monte Tamaro paragliding paragliding Mornera Switzerland Mornera paragliding site guide Mornera hike paragliding official paragliding sites Ticino Switzerland Mornera funicular paragliding

html:
Overview

Tschentenalp, located in the stunning Bernese Oberland region of Switzerland near Adelboden, is a popular paragliding site known for its accessibility and thermaling opportunities. The main takeoff, Schwandfälspitz, is easily reached via gondola from Adelboden, followed by a short walk, offering pilots a quick route to launching into the breathtaking alpine scenery.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Tschenten is renowned for strong thermal activity, even in January, with climb rates reaching 2-3 m/s.
  • Best Season: The site is particularly well-suited for winter flying, especially with Bise wind conditions.
  • Wind Considerations: Avoid flying with West or Southwest winds, as they are not suitable for this site. Late spring conditions can be challenging, with thermals disrupted by strong winds. Downdrafts can occur in winter due to cold slopes and snow.

Who Should Fly Here?

Tschenten is rated as an "easy" site on paragliding maps, making it accessible for a wide range of pilots. It's suitable for both single and two-seater paragliders. The launch area is a convenient, grassy meadow.

Access & Facilities

  • Gondola Access: Take the gondola lift from Adelboden to Tschentenalp. Check the Tschentenalpbahn timetable for operating hours. A lift pass is required.
  • Short Hike: A 10-15 minute walk from the Tschentenalp mountain station will bring you to the Schwandfälspitz takeoff.
  • Landing Zone: The primary landing site is located in Oey, near the cemetery.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Föhn Winds: Be aware of potential Föhn winds, which can create hazardous flying conditions in the Tschentenalp - Schwandfeldspitz area.
  • Wildlife Reserves: Respect closures and altitude restrictions in the following Wildlife Reserves:
    • Lohner Wildlife Reserve: The entire flank is closed from the beginning of January to the end of June.
    • Furggi and Silleren Wildlife Reserves: Maintain a minimum altitude of 2200 meters above sea level.
  • Abrisskante: Flying below the cliff edge (Abrisskante) is strictly prohibited.
  • Landing Field Sommer: Landings are only permitted at the Sommer landing field during the summer months.

html:
Overview

Monte Tamaro, located in the Canton of Ticino, Switzerland, near Lugano, offers a stunning 360-degree view encompassing Pizzo Vogorno, Camoghé, Monte Bar, and the Denti della Vecchia. This popular site, easily accessible via cable car, provides opportunities for both solo and tandem paragliding flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Launch Site: Situated near the Alpe Foppa mountain station.
  • Wind Conditions: Best suited for morning flights with winds from NE-SE.
  • Afternoon Flying: Gliding towards Cima di Medeglia is possible in the afternoon.
  • Acro Training: Mornings are popular for acro training.
  • Valley Wind: Be aware that the valley wind can become strong after 12-13:00, potentially causing turbulence at the landing site.
  • Landing Site: The Bironico landing site coordinates are 2 715 370 / 1 107 880 (CH1903+) – 8° 55′ 51.4″ / 46° 6′ 45.2″ (WGS84).

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Tamaro is suitable for pilots of varying experience levels. The launch site is considered easy, making it accessible for both 1- and 2-seater paragliders.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Via public transport and a cable car (Alpe Foppa).
  • Walk to Launch: A short, 0-minute walk from the cable car to the launch site.
  • Cable Car Fees (as of October 2023):
    • Paragliding one-way ticket: CHF 22.00
    • Paragliding day pass: CHF 31.00
  • Cable Car Closure: The Monte Tamaro cable car is closed for replacement works from September 2, 2024, to the beginning of June 2025.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Föhn Conditions: Flying in Föhn (specifically Nordföhn - north föhn) conditions is dangerous and should be avoided.
  • Turbulence: Afternoon turbulence can occur, especially with strong valley winds.
  • Summit Launch Risk: At the Vetta Tamaro (Summit Launch), be aware that the launch site is located under an antenna.

Important Restrictions

  • Flying Season: Generally possible from March to November. Check www.montetamaro.ch for current information.
  • Cable Car Closure: Note the Monte Tamaro cable car is closed for renovation work from September 2, 2024, to the beginning of June 2025.
  • Hunting Season: Flights are prohibited during the hunting season.
  • Snow Conditions: Exercise caution when there is snow.
  • Landing Restrictions: When the grass is high at the landing site, landing should be avoided.
search_recs: Monte Tamaro access paragliding paragliding Monte Tamaro difficulty Monte Tamaro paragliding site Monte Tamaro paragliding official information

html:
Overview

Kronberg is a popular paragliding site located south of Jakobsbad in Appenzell Innerrhoden, Switzerland, within the stunning Alpstein region. Easily accessible via cable car, the mountain peak offers breathtaking views of the Alpstein range, Säntis, and Lake Constance. With four official launch sites accommodating various wind directions, Kronberg is a favorite for both thermaling and enjoying longer flights, particularly in westerly weather conditions.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Conditions: Kronberg is known for thermaling, offering good soaring with "Bise" winds. Variable weather conditions require vigilance, as strong gusts can cause mid-flight issues. Spring conditions tend to be stronger than autumn conditions.
  • Launch Sites:
    • There are four official launch sites, enabling launches in all directions. Three are near the mountain station, and the East launch is a 15-minute walk from the summit.
    • South Launch: The only option in the Alpstein area for Southwesterly winds.
    • Prevailing Winds: Northwest winds are common.

Who Should Fly Here?

Kronberg is a popular training area for local paragliding schools and is suitable for a range of skill levels. However, the North launch is recommended only for experienced pilots with sufficient wind due to limited space. Student pilots generally have priority on the launch site.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car: The primary access to Kronberg is via the Jakobsbad-Kronberg cable car. Check http://www.kronberg.ch for current pricing.
  • Hiking: It is also possible to hike to the summit.
  • Landing: Landing is near the valley station.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Crowded Site: Expect to see student pilots and potentially crowded launch areas, especially given Kronberg's popularity as a training site.
  • South Launch Risks:
    • Lay out below the tow lift cable.
    • Immediately after takeoff, make a 90-degree right turn to avoid trees.
    • If you can't gain enough altitude, there's a small saddle where you can land straight ahead.
  • West Launch Risks:
    • Be aware of a drop-off to the right (north) and trees to the left.
    • Beware of southerly winds and turbulence from the edge of the forest.
    • Don't lose too much altitude near the launch, as it's a long way to the landing area.
  • North Launch Risks:
    • Only suitable for experienced pilots and with sufficient wind.
    • Limited space to lay out the glider; you're close to a steep slope when the lines are tensioned.
  • Airspace: Be aware of Swiss airspace regulations. Use the MeteoSwiss app for airspace information.
  • Landing Zones: Consider wind direction for landing at the designated landing spot (L1) near the valley station. With valley wind or NW wind, right turn to land. With mountain wind, left turn to land. Pilots should account for the angle between the cable car and tree line.
  • Wildlife Protection: Observe wildlife protection rules.
search_recs: Kronberg Switzerland paragliding official site paragliding Kronberg (CH) Kronberg paragliding site information Kronberg (CH) paragliding club

html:
Overview

Niederbauen is a popular paragliding site near Lake Lucerne in central Switzerland. With spectacular views over the lake and surrounding Alps, the mountain setting offers a fantastic backdrop for thermaling and scenic flights.

Flying Conditions

Niederbauen is considered a relatively simple flying area, making it suitable for training and pilots of varying skill levels. The site is known for good soaring conditions, especially in the late afternoon. Launch is possible in almost any wind direction except in Foehn conditions. During the summer, pilots can typically expect a light north-westerly thermal wind.

Who Should Fly Here?

Niederbauen is an excellent training ground, making it ideal for pilots looking to build their skills. The site's accessible nature also makes it popular for tandem flights. While a range of pilots can enjoy Niederbauen, it is generally considered an easy and forgiving site.

Access & Facilities

Access to the launch site is conveniently provided by the Niederbauen cable car from Emmetten. A short (5-minute) walk from the cable car top station will bring you to the launch. Please note that there is a fee for the cable car.

  • Cable Car Fees (as of 2023):
    • Single ascent: Fr. 12.- (person), Fr. 13.- (with paragliding equipment)
    • Return ticket (10 trips): Fr. 115.-

Risks & Airspace Considerations

While generally a forgiving site, pilots should be aware of potential risks and restrictions.

  • Foehn Wind: Flying is not recommended in Foehn conditions or when a Foehn tendency is present.
  • Winter Closure (Unofficial): While not officially closed, lift staff may indicate the site is unofficially closed in winter, likely due to the proximity of a children's ski lift.
  • CTR Buochs Airspace: Be mindful of the CTR (Control Zone) of Buochs Airport. The CTR begins immediately west of the village of Emmetten (at the first hairpin turn) and must be observed.
  • Radio Communication: For flights from Niederbauen towards Beckenried, pilots must register with TWR Buochs (tower frequency 119.62 MHz) and maintain radio contact.
search_recs: Niederbauen tourism paragliding Niederbauen paragliding club Niederbauen paragliding site information Niederbauen Gleitschirmfliegen

html:
Overview

Les Pléiades is a mountain in the Swiss Prealps, located in the canton of Vaud, Switzerland, overlooking Lake Geneva. This popular site offers stunning views of Lake Geneva to the south, the Rhone Valley, and the Alps, including Mont Blanc. Accessible via a cogwheel railroad, Les Pléiades attracts paragliders, hikers, and mountain bikers alike.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Optimal wind conditions are from the West-South-West (O-SO).
  • Inappropriate Conditions: Flying in Bise (a cold, dry north-easterly wind) is strongly discouraged.
  • Flight Type: Suitable for both single and tandem flights. Offers cross-country (XC) flying opportunities.

Who Should Fly Here?

Les Pléiades is a popular site, however, the take-off is described as "hard" and "steep," suggesting that it is more suited to experienced pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easily accessible via the Montreux-Vevey-Riviera transport cogwheel railroad from Vevey via Blonay.
  • Swiss Travel Pass: Check if the Swiss Travel Pass covers the train journey to Les Pléiades.
  • Maintenance: An annual cleaning event is organized to maintain the take-off and landing zones.
  • Fees: While there is no specific fee mentioned for using the site, transportation costs on the cogwheel railroad will apply.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Avoid flying in strong south-westerly winds or "Bise" (North-easterly wind).
  • Turbulence: Be aware of potential turbulence near the terrain above the plateau, depending on the takeoff.
  • Tree Hazards: A line of trees exists 100m from the takeoff, requiring a glide ratio of 4 to clear.
  • Takeoff Slope: The takeoff area has an abrupt slope.
  • Airspace Regulations: Pilots must be aware of Swiss airspace regulations, particularly concerning controlled airspace (Classes C, D, E). Paragliders are generally restricted to Class G and E airspace.
  • Altitude Restrictions:
    • Be aware of altitude restrictions, especially concerning military flight times (MIL ON/MIL OFF), which affect maximum flight altitude in the Alps.
    • During MIL ON (Monday-Friday 0730-1205 LT and 1315-1705 LT), the maximum flight altitude in the Alps is FL130 (3950m).
    • During MIL OFF, the maximum flight altitude is FL150 (4550m).
    • Airspace above 3950 meters asl (Weekdays) and 4450 meters asl (Weekend and after 17:05) is off-limits for paraglider pilots.
search_recs: Les Pléiades paragliding fees Paragliding regulations Les Pléiades Paragliding Pléiades Switzerland Les Pléiades paragliding site information Access to Les Pléiades paragliding Pléiades Switzerland flying conditions

html:
Overview

Grandvillard is a popular paragliding site located in the Gruyère region of French-speaking Switzerland, nestled within the Fribourg Prealps and Swiss Alps. The site offers stunning views of the green, hilly landscape and Gruyère castle. Known for tandem flights, Grandvillard provides a diverse flying experience suitable for various skill levels.

Flying Conditions

Flying is possible throughout the year at Grandvillard. Depending on wind and atmospheric conditions, flights may also take place at nearby sites like Charmey or Moléson. Experienced pilots can enjoy thermal soaring and even aerobatic maneuvers here.

Who Should Fly Here?

Grandvillard caters to a wide range of experience levels. Beginners can experience the thrill of flight through tandem paragliding, while more experienced pilots can take advantage of expert flights that challenge their soaring skills.

Access & Facilities

  • Meeting Point: Typically between the villages of Grandvillard and Estavannens, in front of the shooting stand with gravel parking. Some operators may meet in front of the gondola cash desk, located 20 minutes from Bulle.
  • Fees: Some sites may have small takeoff or landing fees, typically CHF 2-5 per flight. Cable car fees are not included in the flight prices.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Danger Area (LS-D): A historical Danger Area (LS-D) for drone activity may have existed until December 31, 2022. Confirm the current status of drone activity in the area before flying.
  • Airspace Restrictions: In Switzerland, airspace above 3950 meters AMSL on weekdays and 4450 meters AMSL on weekends and after 17:05 is off-limits to paraglider pilots.
  • General Swiss Airspace: Be aware of the general Swiss airspace structure. Airspace "G" covers the whole of Switzerland from the ground to 600m above ground level (AGL). Above "G" is the airspace "E". In the Jura and the Plateau, the upper limit of "E" is FL100 (3050m AMSL). In the Alps, the upper limit of E varies according to hours and seasons.
  • Important: Always check current NOTAMs (Notice to Airmen) and local regulations before flying.
search_recs: Grandvillard paragliding fees Grandvillard paragliding site information paragliding Grandvillard Switzerland Grandvillard Switzerland official paragliding site Grandvillard paragliding access Grandvillard flying site details

html:
Overview

Le Suchet is a mountain summit in the Jura range, located in the canton of Vaud, Switzerland. This popular site offers a variety of flying options, from ridge soaring to thermaling, with stunning views overlooking the flatlands towards Lake Neuchâtel. With multiple take-off points to accommodate various wind directions, Le Suchet attracts pilots of all skill levels.

Flying Conditions

Le Suchet offers varied flying conditions suitable for both ridge soaring and thermaling:

  • Thermals: Thermals form over the flatlands towards Lake Neuchâtel, providing excellent climbing opportunities.
  • Ridge Soaring: A north-westerly wind allows for soaring on the side of the mountain facing France.
  • Multiple Take-off Points:
    • La Croix (West facing, 1550m)
    • La Rampe (North-East to South-West facing, 1530m)
    • Le Sommet (North-East to South-West facing, 1588m)
    • Falaise (North-West facing, 1588m)
    • Balise (North-East facing, 1570m)
    • La Côtelette (East or South-East facing, 1320m)
    • La Mathoulaz (East or South-East facing, 1200m)

Who Should Fly Here?

Le Suchet is considered an easy site, suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including tandem flights. It's a popular site, especially during the summer when a paragliding school operates there. The site can get busy, so be aware of other pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: By car to the Chalet du Suchet, followed by a short 5-15 minute walk to the various take-off points.
  • Shuttle Service: Philippe Briod's flying school offers shuttle services from late April to October (when flying is possible). The cost is CHF 10 for pilots (CHF 5 with a loyalty card).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Exposure: As a mountain summit at 1588 meters, Le Suchet is quite exposed and unsuitable in strong breezes.
  • Joran Wind: When there is a Northwest wind at the summit, be aware of the Joran wind, which can rise suddenly.
  • Turbulence: Flying in the area can be technically demanding and turbulent if the prevailing wind is above 20 km/h at 2000m. Foehn winds can cause strong, gusty turbulence that may strengthen without warning.
  • Takeoff Specific Risks:
    • La Croix – A: Be aware of stones and barbed wire in crosswinds. If you cannot pass the ridge on the left, a rescue landing is possible at La Poyette just below.
    • La Rampe – B: Watch out for stones at the bottom.
    • Falaise – D: This is a cliff launch. Pilots must have their glider overhead before launching.
    • Baulmes – H: When there is a north-west wind at the summit, be aware of the Joran wind that can suddenly pick up. Avoid passing behind the grove when there is a Bise wind (a cold, north-easterly wind).
  • Airspace Restrictions: In Switzerland, paraglider pilots must be aware of airspace restrictions above 3950 meters ASL on weekdays and 4450 meters ASL on weekends and after 17:05.
  • Visual Flight Rules: No flight without visibility; flying in clouds is dangerous and forbidden. Maintain adequate distance from cloud base to allow collision avoidance.
  • Mountain Rescue Operations: Avoid flying below 1000m above ground level (AGL) or below flight level FL 115 (11,500 feet). This zone protects mountain rescue helicopter operations.
search_recs: Paragliding club Le Suchet Le Suchet official paragliding regulations paragliding Le Suchet Switzerland Le Suchet paragliding site information Le Suchet paragliding access fees

html:
Overview

Pizol is a popular paragliding site in Eastern Switzerland, located in the Heidiland region, near Bad Ragaz and Wangs. With a significant altitude difference of 1,800 meters and stunning views of the Alps foothills and Lake Walen, Pizol offers a great experience for paragliding enthusiasts.

Flying Conditions

  • Pizol is suitable for both summer and winter paragliding.
  • In summer, pilots can launch from any suitable spot, provided they don't disturb the alpine economy.
  • In winter, only Pizolhütte and Laufböden are available to avoid interfering with skiing operations.
  • The site is known for ridge soaring and thermaling.
  • When flying from Laufböden in a southerly direction, pilots must fly around the mountain to reach the landing sites in the Rhine Valley.

Who Should Fly Here?

Pizol is a popular site suitable for a range of pilot skill levels, although some starting places are considered rather demanding.

Access & Facilities

  • Access to the launch sites is via gondola and chairlift:
    • Wangs-Furt-Gaffia-Pizolhütte (1 hour)
    • Bad Ragaz gondola and chairlift to Pardiel-Laufböden (1 hour)
  • There are four official launch sites: Pizolhütte, Laufböden, Gaffia, and Furt.
  • The official landing site is located in Vilters-Wangs, at the Pizolpark.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Cables: The Pizol area has numerous unmarked cables, including cables for logging operations, which may be temporarily strung and difficult to see. Gather information about their locations before flying.
  • Wildlife Protection: Respect wildlife, avoid unnecessary noise, and maintain sufficient distance from animals.
  • Laufböden: Considered a difficult flying area. Winter flights from this launch are discouraged.
  • Official Takeoff/Landing Areas: Takeoffs are only permitted from official takeoff areas. Landing is only permitted on the official landing site in Wangs.
  • Airspace: When crossing the valley, pilots must observe the airspace of Bad Ragaz airfield (SG) and Balzers heliport (FL). The zones of Bad Ragaz and Balzers may be overflown with 600m AGL. Fly considerately to avoid airspace violations.
  • Restricted Sectors:
    • Sector A (Schwarze Hörner - Mugg – Garmil): Avoid flights in this sector, or fly over it at a high altitude, from May until the start of the cable car operation (breeding season for chamois and ibex).
    • Sector B (Eidgenössisches Jagdbanngebiet Graue Hörner): This is a federal hunting ban area; only fly over it at a great height, year-round.
  • Flight Route Pizol-Süd: Gliding flights from the south side require flying close to the slope so that the high-voltage power line is crossed at the Furt launch site "Dreieck".

html:
Overview

Hohwacht is a popular paragliding site located in the Jura region of Switzerland, near the villages of Lauwil and Reigoldswil. Managed by the Delta-/Paraclub Hohwacht (DPCH), the site offers a mix of ridge soaring and thermaling opportunities with scenic views over the Jura mountains. Known for its accessibility and ease of flying, Hohwacht attracts pilots of various skill levels.

Flying Conditions

  • Launch Directions: The main launch site faces north, northwest, and northeast. East and west launches are possible but only in light wind conditions.
  • Soaring & Thermaling: Hohwacht is known for both ridge soaring and thermal activity. The site benefits from its location on the north side of the Jura mountains.
  • Important Note: Pilots should be aware of the complex topographical structure of the Jura region and avoid flying into lee areas.
  • Weather Information: The DPCH operates a meteo station to provide current weather information.

Who Should Fly Here?

Hohwacht is considered an easy site, suitable for paragliding and hang gliding, including both single and two-seater flights. While accessible to a wide range of pilots:

  • IPPI card level IV or V pilots: Can fly freely.
  • IPPI card level III pilots: Need supervision according to Swiss regulations.
  • First-time Visitors: Pilots unfamiliar with the area should contact the DPCH for a site briefing.

Access & Facilities

  • Access Options:
    • From Lauwil: Approximately a 45-minute hike.
    • From Wasserfallen mountain station: Approximately a 35-minute hike.
    • To Ulmethöhe: Drive to Ulmethöhe (requires a club card for access) and then walk for 10 minutes.
    • To Holzerplatz: On weekdays, drive to Holzerplatz (before the Bürten farm) and walk for 20 minutes. Driving to Wasserfallen is prohibited on Saturdays and Sundays.
  • Fees: Non-club members are required to pay a launch/landing fee of CHF 2.00, which can be paid via TWINT.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • TMA Basel Airspace: The entire flying area is within the influence area of the TMA (Terminal Control Area) Basel airspace. Pilots must be aware of the airspace restrictions and comply with them. Check current restrictions before flying. The village is near the edge of Basel airport controlled airspace. Depending on which runway the airport is using, the airspace can extend to the takeoff, so you need to phone to check.
  • Wind Conditions: Strong East wind (Bise) should be avoided. East and West launches should only be attempted in light wind conditions. Wind is often channeled at the Chellechöpfli launch site.
  • Chellechöpfli (Schätti) Launch: Recommended only for experienced pilots familiar with the local conditions. Avoid flying in strong Bise (southeasterly wind) as it creates side wind conditions at this launch.
  • Landing Considerations: Landing in Lauwil can be tricky and needs some experience.
  • No-Fly Zones: Overflying the "Gämse" (Chamois) area is prohibited.
  • Minimum Altitude: A minimum altitude of 100m AGL (Above Ground Level) must be maintained when flying over horses.

Always consult the DPCH website for the most up-to-date information and regulations.
search_recs: Hohwacht Switzerland paragliding site information Paragliding Hohwacht Switzerland Hohwacht CH paragliding regulations Hohwacht paragliding club

html:
Overview

Carì is a charming alpine village in the Leventina Valley of Ticino, Switzerland, offering fantastic paragliding opportunities amidst stunning mountain scenery. Situated at 1650m on the southern side of the Alps, Carì benefits from a sunny climate and is an officially recognized paragliding site.

Flying Conditions

  • Take-off Access: Chairlifts provide easy access to higher take-off points, reaching elevations near Carì Lake at 2,300 meters.
  • Soaring: Known for both thermal and ridge soaring, providing varied flying experiences.
  • Cross-Country Potential: Opportunities for cross-country flights towards Faido.
  • Best Time to Fly: Ideal conditions are often found in the autumn.
  • Take-off Points: Multiple take-off points available, including one near the tennis court in Carì Paese, known for being more technical.

Who Should Fly Here?

Carì is popular among paragliders. Tandem flights are available for beginners. Pilots should have some experience if launching from the Carì Paese take-off, due to its technical nature.

Access & Facilities

  • By Car: Accessible via the A2 motorway (exit Faido).
  • By Train & Bus: Take the train to Faido, followed by a bus to Carì.
  • Parking: Large, free parking lot available near the chairlift.
  • Chairlift: Use the chairlift to access higher take-off areas.
  • Fees: A paragliding day pass is required; as of April 2025, an adult pass costs 22 CHF.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Alpine Conditions: Alpine winds and thermal structures can be complex and require local knowledge and experience. Weather conditions can vary greatly.
  • Wind Variability: Be aware of sudden changes in wind conditions. Check weather forecasts and use an anemometer to assess wind strength and direction. Spring conditions can be stronger than autumn conditions.
  • Takeoff Spots: Several takeoff spots exist (Carì 1, Carì 2, and Carì 3) with varying access options (car, public transport, cable car, and on foot). Ensure you select one that matches your abilities and the day's conditions.
  • Airspace Awareness: Be aware of Swiss airspace regulations to avoid infringements. Check the Daily Airspace Bulletin Switzerland (DABS) and NOTAM for current restrictions and dangers.
  • Airport Proximity: Maintain a distance of at least 5 km from military or civil airport runways without a control zone (CTR), and 2.5 km from heliports.
  • Military Activity: Be aware of military training flights in the area.
  • Insurance: All pilots must have CHF 1 million third-party insurance and carry proof of it. Short-term insurance is available online from SHV-FSVL.
  • Pilot Requirements: Pilots with an IPPI card level IV or V can fly freely. Pilots with IPPI card level III can only fly with supervision.
  • Tandem Flights: Tandem flights are not allowed unless you have a Swiss tandem license.
search_recs: Carì paragliding pilot level Carì Switzerland official paragliding site paragliding Carì Switzerland Carì paragliding site information Carì paragliding access Carì Switzerland paragliding club

html:
Overview

The Niederhorn is a mountain situated high above Lake Thun in the Bernese Oberland region of Switzerland, offering stunning panoramic views of the Alps, including the Eiger, Mönch, and Jungfrau peaks, as well as the sparkling blue-green waters of Lake Thun and Lake Brienz.

Flying Conditions

  • The Niederhorn is renowned for scenic tandem and thermal flights, especially under the morning sun.
  • Flying season typically extends from April to the end of October, with morning flights available year-round.
  • Prevailing winds are from the South to Southeast. Avoid launching in strong West wind conditions due to potential rotor. Thermic activity tends to increase towards midday, which can result in stronger downdrafts.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Niederhorn is popular for both tandem and solo flights:

  • Tandem Flights: Suitable for beginners; no prior experience required. Passengers should be at least 6 years old.
  • Solo Pilots: Should be aware of the changing wind and thermic conditions, especially the potential for strong valley winds from midday in unstable Northwest weather conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access to the Niederhorn is via a funicular from Beatenbucht to Beatenberg, followed by a cable car from Beatenberg to the Niederhorn summit.
  • A short walk (approximately 5 minutes) from the mountain station is required to reach the launch sites. The Burgfeldstand launch site is about a 45-minute hike from the Niederhorn summit.
  • Fees:
    • Round trip for adults from Beatenbucht: CHF 59.00
    • Round trip for adults from Beatenberg: CHF 43.00
    • Paragliding Hike & Fly charge: CHF 5.00
    • Landing fees may apply in Interlaken.
    • Guest flying schools may need to register with the Deltaclub Interlaken (CHF 40/day).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions:
    • The launch site is exposed to wind. Unfavorable with North-West wind (turbulent). Unfavorable if strong high altitude winds are present.
    • Avoid launching if there is a "Bise" wind, as the launch site will be in the lee.
  • Talwind (Valley Wind):
    • Strong valley winds are possible from midday in unstable Northwest weather conditions at all launch and landing sites.
    • Avoid the lee of the valley wind near the Luegibrüggli restaurant.
    • NEW: Right turn in valley wind. Left turn in mountain wind.
  • Turbulence: Turbulence due to valley wind and thermal lift-offs.
  • Airspace: Pay attention to airspaces and flight routes.
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • No flying in violet airspaces. Keep distance from flight routes.
  • Heliports:
    • The landing site is in the restricted area of the Interlaken heliport.
    • Maintain sufficient distance from approach and departure routes of the heliports. These are marked with arrows!
    • Flying in the 2.5 km zones of the heliports is allowed outside of the violet marked airspaces.
    • Flying over Heliport Gsteigwiler: A lower overflight can be approved with prior telephone arrangement. Tel: Swiss Helicopter: +41 33 828 90 00.
  • Niederhorn Takeoff:
    • Ideal start time from midday until sunset.
    • In case of mountain wind at the Lehn landing site, the takeoff site is in the lee, do not launch!
  • Launch sites and the ramp are maintained by VKPI and DCI and are not an offer of the Niederhornbahn (Niederhorn Railway).
  • A rule of the Deltaclub Interlaken DCI must be observed.
  • Special rules for Interlaken: In the area Breitlauenen-airfield applies the following agreement: In the 2.5 km zones the heliports may be flown outside the violet marked airspaces.
search_recs: Niederhorn paragliding restrictions Niederhorn Gleitschirmfliegen Niederhorn paragliding site CH Niederhorn official paragliding information Niederhorn paragliding fees

html:
Overview

Sonchaux, located above Villeneuve in the Vaud region of Switzerland, is a popular paragliding site offering stunning panoramic views of Lake Geneva (Lac Léman), the Swiss Riviera, and the Château de Chillon. Managed by the Rochers de Naye Vol Libre (RNVL) club since 1974, Sonchaux provides accessible flying conditions and is suitable for a wide range of pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Scenic tandem flights are a common sight at Sonchaux.
  • The site offers a 1000m altitude difference.
  • Multiple take-off orientations cater to various wind directions.
  • The site is often used for SIV courses, benefiting from minimal thermal wind in the evolution box.
  • Opportunities for thermal flights are available, depending on the prevailing conditions.
  • Acrobatic flights are also possible, with Sonchaux having hosted the Sonchaux Acro Show in the past.
  • The Villeneuve region, where Sonchaux is located, enjoys a sunny climate and a micro-climate specific to the Montreux region, enhancing the flying experience.

Who Should Fly Here?

Sonchaux is suitable for pilots of all skill levels, from beginners to experienced fliers. It's a particularly popular site for tandem flights and is generally considered "not-too-busy."

Access & Facilities

  • Access is available via a shuttle service from Rennaz, operated by the RNVL club and local paragliding schools.
  • Alternatively, you can drive to the Auberge de Sonchaux and then walk approximately 10 minutes to the take-off area.
  • There are landing taxes for private individuals who are not members of the RNVL club.
  • Schools that are not club members must request access to the take-off area.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wildlife Disturbance: Be mindful of wildlife and avoid flying too low, especially over sensitive areas. Paragliding activities can disturb animals, and agreements with organizations aim to provide refuge zones. Chamois have been observed fleeing when overflown even at 600m altitude.
  • Take-off and Landing Injuries: Potential injuries like ankle strains or falls are possible during take-off and landing.
  • Federal Game Reserves: Taking off and landing within federal game reserves is strictly prohibited.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Always be aware of airspace restrictions and ensure your GPS data is up to date. Violations can result in penalties.
  • Designated Paragliding Areas: Keep your activities within designated paragliding areas to maintain safety.
  • Landing Restrictions: Avoid landing on bathing beaches or private property without prior permission.
search_recs: para-club Sonchaux paragliding Sonchaux Switzerland Sonchaux paragliding site information vol libre Sonchaux informations officielles

html:
Overview

Hüsliberg is a popular paragliding site located near Schänis in the St. Gallen region of Switzerland, at the eastern end of Lake Zurich. With a take-off at 1012m, it offers stunning views and a variety of flying conditions for pilots of all skill levels.

Flying Conditions

Hüsliberg is known for both thermal and ridge soaring, making it suitable for leisure pilots and ambitious cross-country (XC) pilots alike. The site is generally flyable throughout the year. However, flying is restricted for approximately three weeks in June and September due to alpine farming activities, as well as on Good Friday, Easter Sunday, and Whit Sunday. Be aware of potential rotor with Bise wind conditions and the possibility of rapid Föhn wind development. Also, note the proximity to the Schänis glider airfield.

Who Should Fly Here?

Hüsliberg is a popular site suited for pilots of varying experience levels. While less experienced pilots can enjoy the site, it is important to be aware of potential hazards and flying restrictions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the take-off is possible via a taxi service from the landing site in Rufi. Hike & Fly is also an option, taking approximately 1.5 hours using the official hiking path. Private transport to the take-off is discouraged due to limited parking.
  • Fees: A daily fee of CHF 5 is required to fly at Hüsliberg.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Restricted Flying Dates: No flights are allowed on Good Friday, Easter Sunday, and Whit Sunday (Pfingstsonntag).
  • Alpine Farming Restrictions: The launch site is closed for approximately three weeks in June and September due to alpine farming activities. Exact dates vary, so pilots must check the calendar for specific closures, usually published two to three weeks in advance. Contact info(ät)gkg.ch for inquiries.
  • Flight School Limitations: A maximum of two flight schools are permitted to operate at Hüsliberg per day, with each school limited to a maximum of 10 students. Coordination is managed by Flugschule Robair in Mollis (Thomas Kühne). Registration is required by phone or WhatsApp at +41 79 691 04 14 the day before.
  • SHV Number Required: Launches and overflights are only allowed with properly marked wings (SHV number). Unannounced official checks are planned.
  • No alternative starting places: The current zone plan of the municipality of Schaenis prohibits starting in the core zone.
  • Leerotoren bei Bise: Lee Rotors can occur during Bise wind conditions.
  • Föhntendenz: With Foehn conditions, very rapid Foehn wind development is possible.
  • ACHTUNG KABEL!!: Watch out for cables south of the Federihütte in the fall line.
  • Important Notes: The information on websites and links is for informational purposes only. Pilots are responsible for consulting officially valid publications for flight preparation.
  • FLARM Use: FLARM use is recommended to avoid collisions with sailplanes.
search_recs: Hüsliberg access and fees Hüsliberg paragliding official information Hüsliberg paragliding site Hüsliberg Gleitschirmfliegen Hüsliberg paragliding club

html:
Overview

Schwängimatt is a popular paragliding and hang gliding site nestled in the Jura region of Switzerland, near Balsthal/Thal. Managed by Deltaclub Falk (DC Falk), this site offers a mix of ridge soaring and thermaling opportunities, with the potential for exciting cross-country (XC) flights. With rolling hills, meadows, and a strategic location, Schwängimatt is a favorite among local and visiting pilots alike.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Ridge soaring, thermaling, and cross-country flying.
  • Best Wind Conditions: Northerly winds are ideal (300°-360°). North-easterly to easterly winds allow launches from the east-facing slope. Westerly winds require caution.
  • Seasonality: Flyable early in the year, with good thermals available from March to the end of May, sometimes into June. Summer can be too stable.

Who Should Fly Here?

Schwängimatt is suitable for both paragliders and hang gliders. The launch is considered medium difficulty, best suited for intermediate to advanced pilots, especially those comfortable with steep meadow launches and navigating obstacles.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Accessible by car from Laupersdorf or Niederbipp (approx. 15 minutes). A 5-minute walk west from the parking lot leads to the wind vane.
  • Transportation: On weekends and holidays, a club bus is often available for transport to the launch.
  • Fees: A start fee of CHF 2 is charged for non-members of DC Falk.
  • Parking: Parking is available at the restaurant, in the pit, and on both sides of the road to the pit. Keep the road clear.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Launch Challenges:
    • Steep Meadow: The launch site is a steep meadow requiring careful technique.
    • Trees: 2-3 trees are near the launch and must be avoided. Success at clearing the trees from the upper launch site, Schwängimatt oben, is not always guaranteed.
    • Shallow Start: The start can be shallow, with potential for landing in the lee of the woods about 300m out.
  • Landing Considerations:
    • Landing is slightly diagonal to the slope, and the position of the landing area can change.
    • Tail winds can be stronger than in other parts of the valley.
    • Use cut meadows near the windsock to avoid land damage.
    • Beware of landing in the lee of the forest.
  • Airspace: Adhere to the Basel TMA "Tango" airspace restrictions, with a maximum altitude of 1750m ASL.
  • Local Rules: Follow local rules to help preserve the flying site.
search_recs: Schwängimatt paragliding access Schwängimatt paragliding site official information Schwängimatt paragliding site details Schwängimatt Gleitschirmfliegen Schwängimatt flying conditions

html:
Overview

The Schildgrat is a scenic paragliding site located near Mürren in the Jungfrau region of the Swiss Alps. Situated beside a ski field and accessed via cable car, this site offers stunning views of the Lauterbrunnen valley, Mürren, snow-covered pine forests, and the surrounding alpine landscape. It's a popular choice, especially in winter, for pilots seeking spectacular flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Winter Focus: The site is particularly active during the winter season, offering an alternative when other sites are closed.
  • Scenic Flights: Known for flights over the Lauterbrunnen valley, Mürren, and along the cliffs, providing unparalleled views.
  • Ridge Soaring: Suitable for ridge soaring due to the mountainous terrain. Thermaling opportunities may also exist.
  • Launch Area: Relatively flat, machine-groomed area next to a ski piste, making for easier launches.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Schildgrat is best suited for intermediate pilots and above, given its mountain environment. Experience and confidence in mountain launches are beneficial.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Access requires taking a cable car from Stechelberg to Mürren, followed by a chairlift to the launch site next to the Schiltgrat ski field.
  • Fees: While there are no specific fees mentioned for using the launch site itself for private pilots, be aware of the costs associated with the cable car and chairlift. Tandem flights typically cost around CHF 260, excluding transport.
  • Information Board: A situational plan and information board regarding the Mürren flight area can be found at the landing site near the Schilthorn cable car.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Conditions: Sudden changes in wind conditions pose a risk. Strong winds and gusts can lead to loss of control or canopy collapse. Always monitor weather updates closely.
  • Pilot Error: The majority of incidents are attributed to pilot error. Build skills progressively and apply knowledge safely.
  • Takeoff and Landing: Be aware that takeoff and landing are statistically the most dangerous phases of paragliding.
  • Situational Awareness: Ensure you are familiar with the information on the situational plan and information board at the landing site near the Schilthorn cable car.
search_recs: Schildgrat paragliding club Schildgrat Gleitschirmfliegen Schildgrat paragliding site Switzerland Schildgrat paragliding official site

html:
Overview

The Jakobshorn, situated in Davos, Klosters, Switzerland, is a renowned paragliding destination in the Graubünden Alps. Known as the main flying mountain in Davos, it offers year-round flying opportunities suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding.

Flying Conditions

  • Flying is possible in almost all directions, with several official launch sites.
  • The area is known for its thermaling and soaring conditions.
  • Brämabüel, easily accessible from Jakobshorn, provides excellent soaring, especially with valley winds.
  • Even in winter, thermals are present, allowing for top landings at Jatzhütte.
  • Parsenn is a nearby area popular for morning flights, and Gotschnagrat also offers good soaring conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Jakobshorn caters to a range of pilots. While the summit launch is rated as medium difficulty, and the north launch is reserved for experienced pilots, launches such as Jatzhütte are considered easy.

Access & Facilities

  • Access to the summit is via the Jakobshorn cable car (Jakobshornbahn). Look out for special tariffs for paragliding pilots. You may require a mountain railway pass, Topcard, or ski ticket.
  • In summer, the primary landing site is the large meadow in front of the Restaurant Bolgen Plaza.
  • In winter, pilots typically land behind the base station of the Carjöl chairlift, near the cross-country ski trail.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Strong Valley Winds: Be prepared for strong valley winds, which can create challenging flying conditions.
  • Lee Turbulence: Strong North to Southeast winds can cause lee turbulence, potentially making launches from Jakobshorn inadvisable. Consider alternative sites like Brämabüel or Parsenn Schatzalp in such cases.
  • Summit Launch (Jakobshorn Gipfel):
    • The launch site is located just below the Jakobshorn mountain station (2560m), accessible via a 3-minute walk. It faces SW-NW.
    • The launch area's terrain transitions from a slight incline to a steeper scree slope, making it moderately difficult.
    • Local pilots generally advise against launching over the rock band towards NNW.
    • With weak to moderate North winds, launching against the Jakobshornbahn cables towards the North is possible but is an unofficial launch reserved for experienced pilots only and rated as difficult.
    • Be aware of skiers and snowboarders when launching on the slope.
    • Avoid flying over or under the cable car cables for safety. After launch, turn left and fly out between the masts and rocks before the masts.
    • Launching from this site is not recommended in summer due to the strong valley wind from the North lee of Brämabüel.
    • Use the new windsock on top of the Jakobshorn to help you choose the right starting place.
  • Jatzhütte Launch:
    • The Jatzhütte launch site is often used in winter and can be reached in approximately 10 minutes from the Jakobshorn summit.
    • The SW-W launch site directly in front of the hut is quite steep.
    • The S launch site behind the hut is very flat, requiring a fast sprint in zero-wind conditions.
  • Brämabüel Launch:
    • Brämabüel can be reached in a 20-minute walk from Jakobshorn in summer and is ideal with strong valley winds. The ideal wind direction is NW-NO.
    • The launch site is at 2490m and considered easy. The launch area goes from flat to steep, without notable obstacles.
  • WEF Restrictions: During the World Economic Forum (WEF), a no-fly zone is enforced for drones, hang gliders, paragliders, delta flyers, model helicopters, model airplanes, and tethered balloons in the area from Davos Monstein to Schiers.
  • General Airspace Restrictions: Airspace above 3950 meters ASL on weekdays and 4450 meters ASL on weekends and after 17:05 is off-limits to paraglider pilots in Switzerland.

Always check current weather conditions and NOTAMs before flying.
search_recs: Jakobshorn paragliding site regulations paragliding Jakobshorn Switzerland site information Jakobshorn paragliding site access Gleitschirmfliegen Jakobshorn Informationen Jakobshorn Gleitschirmfliegen

html:
Overview

Schynige Platte, nestled in the Interlaken-Oberhasli district of the Bernese Oberland in Switzerland, offers breathtaking paragliding experiences. Renowned for its stunning panoramic views of the Eiger, Mönch, and Jungfrau peaks, as well as the shimmering Lakes Thun and Brienz, this site provides pilots with unforgettable scenic flights amidst the Swiss Alps. Accessible via a charming cogwheel train, Schynige Platte is a popular destination for both solo pilots and tandem flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Schynige Platte is ideal for scenic flights, ridge soaring, and evening flights before sunset. Thermalling is also possible.
  • Seasonality: The optimal flying season is from May to October, coinciding with the operation of the Schynige Platte Bahn.
  • Weather Considerations:
    • The site is exposed to winds from the West and Northwest.
    • Always check wind speed and direction before launching.
    • Be cautious of strong turbulence due to thermal activity and valley winds.

Who Should Fly Here?

Schynige Platte caters to a range of experience levels. The lower Breitlauenen launch site is considered easier, making it suitable for less experienced pilots or tandem flights. The upper Breitlauenen launch site presents a medium difficulty challenge. Tandem flights are a popular option for those wanting to experience the site with an experienced pilot.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The primary access to the launch sites is via the Schynige Platte Bahn, a cogwheel train from Wilderswil. The scenic train journey takes approximately 50 minutes.
  • Train Schedule: The last two trains of the day often accommodate paragliders.
  • Fees: A train ticket is required. Tandem paragliding flights typically cost around CHF 250-290. Check for any specific launch site fees with a paragliding operator.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Strong thermal activity and valley winds can cause significant turbulence.
  • Mountain Winds: Be extremely cautious of strong mountain winds or Bise (northeasterly wind), and avoid launching in lee conditions.
  • Wind Exposure: The launch sites are generally exposed to wind, requiring careful monitoring of wind speed and direction.
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • Be aware of controlled airspace in the region, including areas around Meiringen, and adhere to no-fly zones.
    • Check NOTAMs and the Daily Airspace Bulletin Switzerland (DABS) for temporary restricted areas (D-Areas).
    • The alternate landing place is in the restricted area of the Heliport Interlaken.
    • General altitude restrictions apply, with airspace above 3950 meters ASL restricted on weekdays and 4450 meters ASL restricted on weekends and after 17:05.
  • Takeoff Priority: At Breitlauenen "Kamel", solo paragliders have priority on the left runway from Friday to Sunday. Tandem and Delta gliders use the right runway.
search_recs: Schynige Platte paragliding regulations Schynige Platte paragliding official information Schynige Platte paragliding site information Schynige Platte Gleitschirmfliegen Schynige Platte paragliding pilot level Schynige Platte paragliding access fees

html:
Overview

Bassano del Grappa, nestled in the Veneto region of Italy near Monte Grappa, offers a unique paragliding experience. Situated in the foothills of the Southern Alps, this popular site allows pilots to combine mountain ridge soaring with exhilarating flights over the Italian plains. Known for its reliable thermals and stunning scenery, Bassano attracts pilots from across Europe.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: The area is known for consistent thermal activity, particularly during March to May and September to November. Flyable conditions are often present even from June to August, though temperatures can be high and the air more stable.
  • Wind Protection: Bassano benefits from protection against strong north winds, thanks to the mountains behind the site. However, excessive northern winds can still create dangerous conditions.
  • XC Potential: Excellent cross-country opportunities exist along the front ridge, heading east or west. However, be mindful of potential unlandable valleys along the ridge.
  • Valley Winds: Afternoon SE valley winds can create rotors.
  • Dust Devils: Pilots should be aware of dust devils.

Who Should Fly Here?

Bassano caters to pilots of all experience levels. The spacious launch sites are beginner-friendly, and the area is frequently used for training courses. However, the site can get very busy, especially on weekends in winter and early spring. Be prepared for a high volume of pilots in the air.

Access & Facilities

  • Accessibility: Take-off sites are easily accessible by car, and shuttle services are available from locations such as the Garden Relais car park.
  • FlyCard: A FlyCard is required to cover take-off and landing fees. Purchase it at the Garden Relais, or the tourist office in Semonzo.
  • Parking: Parking can be limited at some take-off areas, so adhere to local parking regulations.
  • Green Smoke Flare: Carry a green smoke flare in case of landing in unexpected places, such as a tree, to signal that rescue is not needed.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Overcrowding: The site's popularity can lead to overcrowding, increasing the risk of collisions, especially on weekends and during good weather.
  • Turbulence: Can become turbulent in the afternoon.
  • Unlandable Valleys: Be aware of unlandable valleys along the ridge. Gain sufficient altitude before attempting to cross them.
  • Northern Winds (Föhn): While Bassano can tolerate some northern winds, excessive wind from the north can be dangerous.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Pilots need to be aware of the restricted airspace around the US Airbase at Aviano (CTR to the east) and the CTR to the south, which is Treviso airport. Pilots should consult an air map and avoid these areas.
  • Takeoff Risks:
    • Da Beppi Tappeti Launch: Avoid this launch with any side-on winds and be aware of overcrowding on good days.
    • Southeast Launch: The southeast launch can become dangerous due to valley winds.
search_recs: paragliding regulations Bassano Italy paragliding site Bassano Italy official information paragliding Bassano Italy paragliding Bassano Monte Grappa paragliding club Bassano Italy

html:
Overview

Cornizzolo, also known as Monte Cornizzolo, is a popular paragliding site nestled between the provinces of Como and Lecco in Lombardy, Northern Italy. Situated near the village of Suello, and approximately an hour from Chiasso, close to Lake Como, the peak rises to 1,241 meters (4,072 ft), offering stunning panoramic views of Lake Annone and the Brianza region. Known internationally, Monte Cornizzolo offers a diverse flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Cornizzolo is renowned for thermaling, offering opportunities for both leisurely area flights and challenging cross-country (XC) adventures.
  • Seasonality: Flyable most days of the year, weather permitting, with April highlighted as an excellent month for XC flights.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • North Winds: Pilots must exercise extreme caution. Strong north winds are dangerous, and even light north winds combined with strong sun can create hazardous lee conditions. Flying with north winds is strictly prohibited. Always check the windsock at the "Centrale" takeoff.
  • Launch and Landing:
    • Launch Sites: "Risparmio" (easy, south-facing, directly accessible from the shuttle drop-off) and "Centrale" (larger, 10-minute walk west of Risparmio, used for competitions).
    • Landing Areas: A large field near Suello close to the "Cielo e Terra" restaurant, and an alternative landing site called "Palude" in Cesana Brianza (also suitable for hang gliding).

Who Should Fly Here?

Cornizzolo is suitable for pilots of all experience levels, from beginners to experts. The landing site is easy to manage. Experienced pilots can use the site for long cross-country flights. Be mindful that weekands can be busy.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Private vehicles are not permitted to drive up to the launch sites. Access is via foot or shuttle bus.
  • Shuttle Service: A shuttle bus service operates between the landing area in Suello and the top of Monte Cornizzolo on weekends. Contact Antonio from Cornizzolo in Volo (+39 339 504 1615) to be added to the WhatsApp group for shuttle information (especially for hang glider pilots).
  • Fees: Shuttle services are operated by Aero Club Monte Cornizzolo and Cornizzolo in Volo. Contact them for current fees and schedules.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • General Risks:
    • Thermic Conditions: Strong thermals can lead to turbulence.
    • Lee Side Flying: Can be very dangerous; avoid flying on the lee side of the mountain.
    • Cumulus Nimbus Clouds: Potential for violent updrafts/downdrafts, hail, lightning, and strong winds. (Historical incident: five hang glider pilots died in 1988 due to Cumulus Nimbus).
    • Overcrowding: Weekends can be crowded, increasing the risk of collisions, especially in the landing zone.
  • North Wind: Under no circumstances fly if there is a north wind.
  • Flight Restrictions:
    • Takeoff Access: The takeoff is closed to the public; access is only available via the shuttle service.
    • Altitude Limit: Maximum altitude is restricted to 1250m or 1400m depending on regulations.

Important Note: Always check the weather forecast and wind conditions before flying at Cornizzolo. The local radio frequency is 142.950 (43-430 MHz).

html:
Overview

Meduno is a popular paragliding site in the Friuli region of Northern Italy, near the town of Meduno. Located at the foot of Monte Valinis on the southern edge of the Alps, it offers excellent soaring conditions with a kilometer-long ridge and flatlands ideal for cross-country flights. It's known for its beautiful scenery and reliable flying conditions, especially during Spring and Autumn.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Ridge soaring and thermaling are the main draws. Evening "restitution" flying is also common.
  • Seasonality: Best flying conditions are found in Spring and Autumn.
  • Weather Considerations:
    • Easterly Winds: Be cautious of easterly winds, as they can quickly become turbulent.
    • North and East Winds: Exercise caution with north and east winds, as they can make reaching the landing site difficult.
    • Cool air from the Adriatic Sea creates predictable airflow.
    • Thunderstorms can occur in the mountains behind the launch.
  • Cross-Country (XC) Flights: XC flights southwards are restricted due to the Aviano control zone.

Who Should Fly Here?

Meduno is suitable for pilots of all skill levels. Novices can practice ridge soaring and top landing, while experienced pilots can undertake XC flights. Some sources recommend being cautious of EN-D gliders in active conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The Monte Valinis launch site is accessible by car via a newly asphalted road. Shuttle services are available from the landing area.
  • Fees: A FLY CARD is required, costing €15 per calendar year (since 2022).
  • FLY CARD Purchase: The FLY CARD can be purchased at the Fliegerbar at the landing site, which is open during busy flight operations.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: The site can become crowded.
  • Easterly Winds: Be very careful with easterly winds; they can quickly become turbulent.
  • High Cornfields: During the summer, high cornfields can limit outlanding options.
  • Landing Fees: Local farmers may charge fees for landing in their fields during the summer when cornfields are high.
  • Top Landing: Top landing is possible but can be challenging in the middle of the day. Be careful not to approach too far behind the launch site when top landing.
  • Takeoff: The takeoff is a large, grassy area and is considered easy.
  • Aviano Control Zone: Be mindful of the Aviano U.S. Air Force base control zone (CTR/CTZ) located approximately 30 km southwest of Meduno.
  • Prohibited Maneuvers: Acro flying and strong wingovers near the ridge are prohibited.
