html:
Overview

Norma is a well-regarded paragliding site located approximately 50 km southeast of Rome, Italy, near the Monti Lepini range. Situated near the ancient ruins of Norba at about 400 meters above sea level, the site offers panoramic views stretching from Rome to the Circeo promontory and the Pontine plain.

Flying Conditions

Norma is known for its reliable thermal flying conditions, which can extend into the winter months due to a favorable microclimate. The site is suitable for ridge soaring, thermaling, and cross-country (XC) flights. Top landing is easily and safely possible. Locals often fly in the late afternoon and into the evening.

  • Wind Considerations:
    • All wind directions are suitable for takeoff except East and Southeast winds, which are considered dangerous.
    • Be aware of potential strong breezes during midday hours.

Who Should Fly Here?

Norma is a popular site that caters to a wide range of pilot skill levels, from novice to experienced. It's considered one of the best-equipped sites in central Italy and is ideal for learning and practicing advanced flying techniques. The site is also used as a training ground for pilots from the Alps during their off-season.

Access & Facilities

The launch site is accessible by car, with parking available in the archaeological area. From the parking, it's an easy 800-meter walk to the takeoff.

  • A "flycard" costing 15 Euros per year is required for access to the shuttle service and to use a specific corridor.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: East and Southeast winds are considered particularly dangerous and not suitable for takeoff.
  • Venturi Effect: A venturi effect has been reported on the right side of the takeoff. Pilots should be positioned in front of the launch area, especially when the wind is strong during midday hours.
  • Launch Area: When launching with a south wind (180°), launch only from the right side of the field, after the little central tree. Do not launch from the left side of the field.
  • Trees: Two tall trees are present at the takeoff location.
  • Military Airspace (Latina CTR): Pilots must avoid flying beyond the vertical of Doganella di Ninfa (41°36N; 12°50E) to prevent entering the military airspace (CTR) of Latina Military Airport (LIRL). Do not fly in SW direction, as it will immediately enter the forbidden/prohibited zone. Violations could lead to the site being closed.
  • Landing Restrictions: Landing is restricted to the main airfield. Landing on the road near Ninfa is prohibited. Never land in the "Giardini di Ninfa" (protected wildlife park) or its related parking area.
  • Flycard: To use the landing zone in the valley, pilots need the Norma flycard and must adhere to a specific regulation.
  • Area di Volo: Flight area is restricted to takeoff and landing zones.
search_recs: paragliding Norma Italy difficulty paragliding Norma Italy official site paragliding site Norma Italy Norma Italy paragliding club Norma paragliding fees Norma Italy paragliding access

html:
Overview

Gemona del Friuli, nestled in the Friuli region of northeastern Italy near the Slovenian border, is a renowned paragliding destination. Situated on the southern edge of the Julian Alps, it offers breathtaking views of the Po Valley, the Tagliamento River, and Lago dei Tre Comuni. This unique location combines mountain and flatland flying, providing diverse and exciting opportunities for pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Enjoy a mix of mountain and flatland flying with ridge soaring, thermaling, and cross-country (XC) opportunities. The site provides reliable conditions for both mountain flying along ridges and over high pastures, as well as flatland racing.
  • Seasonality: Flying is possible year-round, with the best conditions typically occurring in spring and autumn. Summer also offers good flying. Midday flights, with their stronger thermal activity, are recommended for experienced pilots, while evening flights are particularly enjoyable and suitable for beginners.
  • Weather Considerations: Expect an average cloud base of 2,000-2,500 meters, sometimes reaching 3,000 meters. Winds are usually light south-westerly. Be aware that rain is common in the Alps, and strong turbulence can occur when taking off towards the north.

Who Should Fly Here?

Gemona caters to pilots of all experience levels. The main take-off, Mont Cuarnan, is suitable for everyone. Beginners will find evening flights ideal, while experienced pilots can challenge themselves with midday thermals. Note that some sources suggest a pilot rating of IPPI 4 or 5 with 25km+ XC experience for guided trips.

Gemona is also a world-class paragliding competition venue, having hosted numerous Italian and international events.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Mont Cuarnan take-off is accessible via a tarmac road suitable for all vehicles. However, the local club often prefers pilots to use their provided transport. Private cars can drive to a parking area, followed by a 30-minute walk to the take-off. A shuttle service, coordinated by Volo Libero Friuli, operates from the Bordano or Godo-Gemona landing sites. Alternatively, when snow blocks the Malga Cuarnan route, pilots can use the Garzette launch, accessible from Montenars via CAI trail 715.
  • Fees: Contact local operators like Volo Libero Friuli for information on site usage fees, shuttle services, or guided flights. Tandem pilots practicing consistently may need to pay a yearly contribution.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Technical Takeoff: One takeoff is described as technical and is not recommended for beginners due to terrain and strong thermal activity.
  • Microclimate: The local microclimate can create flyable conditions when other sites are grounded but may also result in unexpected or rapidly changing conditions.
  • Landing Zone Visibility: Be aware that the Godo-Gemona landing site is not visible from the take-off. It's recommended to check it out before flying.
  • Bernadia Takeoffs (Alto and Basso): These are impossible to use with winds from the northern quadrants. Landing can be dangerous with north winds, even if takeoff conditions seem favorable. The "Alto" takeoff is particularly technical in the absence of wind.

Flight Restrictions

  • Airspace: Paragliding is only allowed in Class G airspace (which applies to areas near Gemona), with a limit of 2900m MSL. Standard VFR (Visual Flight Rules) apply.
  • Populated Areas: Flying over populated areas, groups of houses, or gatherings of people is forbidden, as is dropping objects or liquids during flight.
  • Night Flying: Flying at night is prohibited, only during the period from 30 minutes before sunrise to 30 minutes after sunset.
  • VFR Only: All flights must be conducted under Visual Flight Rules.

Contact the local club, Volo Libero Friuli, for the most up-to-date information on site conditions, rules, and restrictions.
search_recs: paragliding clubs Gemona Italy Gemona paragliding site information paragliding Gemona Italy Gemona paragliding official site Monte Glemina paragliding Gemona Italy paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Santa Elisabetta is a picturesque paragliding site located in Piedmont, Italy, high above the town of Castellamonte, on the north-eastern shoulder at the entrance to the Valle di Locana. Characterized by its alpine setting, complete with a church and restaurant near the take-off, it offers stunning views stretching from the Aosta Valley to the Valchiusella valley. This site is popular among pilots from Milan and surrounding areas, especially when other sites are affected by strong North/Northwest winds.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Southeast, South, and Southwest winds are ideal. Unlike nearby sites like Cavallaria, Santa Elisabetta is more sheltered from North and Northwest winds.
  • Take-off Options: The site offers both a lower and an upper take-off.
  • Landing Area: The landing area is vast and unobstructed, ensuring safe and easy landings.
  • XC Potential: Santa Elisabetta is suited for cross-country (XC) flights. Transitioning from the lower to the upper takeoff is recommended as a good introduction to XC flying.

Who Should Fly Here?

Rated as an "easy" site, Santa Elisabetta is suitable for pilots of various experience levels. It accommodates both 1- and 2-seater paragliders and hang gliders. Tandem paragliding flights are available for beginners with certified pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easily accessible by car.
  • Camping: Camping is permitted at the lower take-off, but not at the main take-off area.
  • Transportation: Volo Libero Santa Elisabetta offers transport to the take-off point as part of their tandem paragliding flight packages.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Terrain: Be aware that the terrain can be rocky or rough, potentially limiting emergency landing options.
  • Airspace: Check airspace restrictions before flying, and refer to the "Spazi aerei" section on the Volo Libero Santa Elisabetta website for details.
search_recs: Santa Elisabetta paragliding site description paragliding Santa Elisabetta Italy paragliding site Santa Elisabetta Italy official information Santa Elisabetta paragliding access fees paragliding club Santa Elisabetta Italy

html:
Overview

Cavallaria, also known as Monte Cavallaria, is a popular paragliding site located in the Canavese area of Piedmont, Italy. It offers stunning flights over a morainic amphitheater, with views stretching from the Aosta Valley to Valchiusella. Managed by the Parapendio Club Cavallaria, this site is known for its soaring and cross-country (XC) opportunities and a welcoming club atmosphere.

Flying Conditions

  • Best Season: Particularly favorable in spring, but flyable in summer and autumn as well.
  • Height Difference: Approximately 1200 meters.
  • Takeoff Points:
    • Cima Cavallaria: 1446m
    • Manifestazione: 1380m
    • Casette: 1300m
    • Felci: 920m
  • Soaring & XC: Known for excellent soaring and cross-country potential.
  • Top Landing: Possible at this site.
  • Nordföhn Winds: Be aware of Nordföhn winds, which can become strong at Cima Cavallaria and Manifestazione.
  • Weather conditions: Strong gusts of wind can cause pitching mid-flight. It's essential to check weather forecasts and use an anemometer to assess wind strength and direction to understand turbulence risks. Spring conditions may be stronger than autumn conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Cavallaria is suitable for pilots of all experience levels. Several takeoff points are well-suited for students and newly qualified pilots. The site is also used for training and tandem flights.

Access & Facilities

  • Club Management: The site is managed by the Parapendio Club Cavallaria.
  • Shuttle Service: Access to the Cima Cavallaria and Manifestazione takeoffs is restricted to the club's shuttle service due to regulations on the access road.
  • Shuttle Fee: Approximately 8 Euros. Check the Parapendio Cavallaria website for the current schedule.
  • Club Access: Access to the club's facilities, including take-off access, bar, and other amenities, is restricted to club members and those with a daily/weekly Flycard.
  • Lower Takeoff: The lower takeoff "Monte Cavallaria" at 263m can be reached by car or walking.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • General Risks:
    • Collision Risk: There's a potential danger of collision with hang gliders, especially immediately after launch at the Bassano - Stella Alpina / Camillo site.
  • Per Takeoff Risks:
    • Bassano - Stella Alpina / Camillo Takeoff: Do not turn left immediately after launch due to the risk of collision with hang-gliders.
  • Nordföhn Winds: Pay attention to Nordföhn winds as they can be particularly strong at Cima Cavallaria and Manifestazione.
  • Access Restrictions: Unauthorized driving to Cima Cavallaria and Manifestazione can result in fines.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Paragliding is prohibited within airport approach and takeoff zones without prior authorization. Any aerial activity in controlled airspace requires coordination with air traffic control authorities.
  • General Rules: It is forbidden to fly over the biotope at an altitude lower than 500 meters.
search_recs: volo parapendio Cavallaria Italia Cavallaria paragliding official site paragliding Cavallaria Italy Cavallaria paragliding site information Cavallaria paragliding access Cavallaria paragliding fees

html:
Overview

Col Rodella, situated in Val di Fassa in the heart of the Italian Dolomites, is a renowned paragliding site offering breathtaking panoramic views of the Sella Towers, Sassolungo Group, Sass Pordoi, and Marmolada. With a launch altitude of 2,387 meters, this location provides excellent opportunities for thermal flying and cross-country adventures. However, its demanding conditions make it best suited for experienced alpine pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Flying: Col Rodella is famous for its strong thermal activity, providing significant lift and XC potential.
  • Evening Soaring: Evening soaring around Col Rodella and Sasso Lungo is a popular option.
  • Valley Winds: The general Fassa valley flow runs from south to north. Be aware of valley winds creating rotors, especially in the afternoon.
  • Seasonality:
    • The primary paragliding season runs from September through October, offering the most stable conditions.
    • Spring and summer can be turbulent and are recommended for experienced alpine pilots only.
    • Flights are possible during the winter season when the cable car is operational.
  • Weather Considerations:
    • Strong, turbulent upper winds, especially from the north, can occur. Flying in a north foehn wind should not be attempted.
    • Be cautious of dust devils, particularly from midday onwards, as they can create dangerous rotors.

Who Should Fly Here?

Col Rodella is not suitable for beginners. The site demands sharp skills and extensive experience in alpine flying due to strong thermals and complex terrain. This site is recommended for experienced pilots who can handle rapidly changing conditions and turbulent environments. Rescue helicopters are frequently needed during the season, highlighting the challenges of this site.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: The most convenient access to the launch sites is via a cable car from Campitello di Fassa, with a journey time of less than 10 minutes. Cable car tickets are required (approximately 12 euros as of 2021).
  • Hiking Option: It is also possible to hike up from Passo Sella.
  • Landing Zones: Large and grassy landing zones are available in the valley. However, be aware that long walkouts have been reported behind the Marmolada in case of landing out.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Strong, turbulent upper winds are common, especially from the north. Do not fly in a north foehn wind.
  • Dust Devils: Be cautious of dust devils, especially from midday onwards.
  • Overcrowding: The site can get very crowded, especially during peak season (end of August to mid-October), increasing the risk of collisions.
  • Helicopter Operations: If you see a rescue helicopter (red or yellow), fly at least 2km away from the rescue area, or land immediately. Do not take off during helicopter operations. Tandem always has the way in landing.
  • Radio Frequency: Monitor the safety radio channel PMR channel 8 with CTSS subtone 16 (frequency 446,09375 Mhz + subtone 114,8 Hz).
  • Smoke Bombs: Carry a red (medical help) and a green (accident, no medical assistance needed) smoke bomb.
  • Takeoff Specific Risks:
    • East/Southeast Takeoff: Avoid launching in the afternoon due to rotors from the SE valley wind.
    • North Takeoff: Do not fly with a north wind and avoid turning to the lee side.
    • South-West Takeoff: The Fassa Valley wind approaches this launch site very early and can be quite strong.
    • North Col Rodella takeoff: Pay attention to the ropes of the two chairlifts, and avoid taking off near them; also be aware of avalanche barriers.
    • West takeoff: The upper part of the launch site is very steep and should only be used by experienced pilots with sufficient reverse launch skills.
  • Landing Restrictions: Do not land on the top of Marmolada.
  • Rapidly Changing Conditions: Be prepared for conditions to change quickly, requiring vigilance and adaptability.

Note: The Dolomites area is at risk of being closed to free flight if these rules are not adhered to.
search_recs: paragliding requirements Col Rodella Col Rodella paragliding official information Col Rodella paragliding site Italy Col Rodella paragliding access Col Rodella flying season Col Rodella pilot skill level paragliding club Col Rodella

html:
Overview

Laveno, nestled on the Lombard shore of Lake Maggiore in Italy, is a popular and strategic paragliding site known for its thermal flying and cross-country potential. The landscape combines the beauty of the lake, surrounding mountains (including Monte Rosa and the pre-Alps), and the Varese plain. With established infrastructure and stunning views, Laveno attracts pilots of all skill levels.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Primarily thermal flying with great potential for cross-country (XC) flights.
  • Thermals: The ridges of Sasso del Ferro and Monte Nudo generate strong thermals, allowing pilots to reach altitudes above 2,000 meters in spring.
  • Seasonality: Flights are possible throughout the year, but the summer season is ideal due to mild climate and consistent thermals. Flying is possible even in winter depending on weather conditions.
  • Wind Considerations: Takeoff sites are unusable with northerly winds. Sunny days with light winds are preferred.

Who Should Fly Here?

Laveno caters to a wide range of pilots, from beginners to experienced XC enthusiasts. The site is home to multiple flying clubs and schools, making it an excellent learning environment. Tandem flights are also popular, offering newcomers a chance to experience paragliding with an instructor. Sasso del Ferro is known as an easy site. Monte Nudo is particularly well-suited for tandem paragliding.

Access & Facilities

  • Landing Field: Easily accessible by car with ample parking. Also located near the Laveno and Cittiglio railway stations and a cycle/pedestrian path.
  • Sasso del Ferro Takeoff: Reached via a 15-minute cable car ride from Laveno. The launch ramp requires only a few steps to become airborne.
  • Monte Nudo Takeoff: Accessible via shuttle vans from the landing field, with a trip time of approximately 30 minutes.
  • Fees: Shuttle services to Monte Nudo may cost around €8. The cable car to Sasso del Ferro has a fee.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • North Wind: Takeoff sites are unusable with northerly winds.
  • Mountain Flying: The area is bordered by the Alps, Lake Maggiore, and the Varese plain. While not strictly alpine, pilots can encounter good flying conditions, especially with foehn winds when conditions in the north are poor.
  • Airspace: Generally Class G airspace up to FL95 (approximately 2894m), allowing VFR flights without specific clearance or radio contact.
  • Landing Rules: Observe the landing rules for hang gliders and paragliders as indicated on the information board at the landing site.
  • Paramotors: Paramotors are prohibited at the Icaro 2000 landing field.

Always check local regulations, weather conditions, and site-specific information before flying. Contacting local flying clubs or schools is highly recommended for the most up-to-date information.
search_recs: paragliding Laveno flying conditions paragliding Laveno Italy paragliding Laveno official site paragliding Laveno pilot skill level paragliding Laveno access fees

html:
Overview

Feltre, nestled in the Piave valley of the southern Dolomites in Italy's Veneto region, offers a stunning backdrop for paragliding. Monte Avena, the primary launch site, rises to approximately 1,400 meters (4,593 feet) amidst a landscape of green forested ridges, vineyards, and the dramatic Dolomite mountains. Known for its excellent thermaling and cross-country flying potential, Feltre attracts pilots seeking both scenic beauty and challenging flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Monte Avena's large south-facing flank creates ideal conditions for thermals, with activity peaking around noon.
  • Wind Directions: Flyable in nearly all wind directions except northerly winds. The valley wind typically blows from the east.
  • Cross-Country (XC): The site offers the possibility to fly along a main ridge for 100km or venture into the flatlands.
  • Peak-to-Peak Flights: Excellent thermals make flights from peak to peak across the Val Belluna possible.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Avena is a popular site suitable for a wide range of pilot skill levels, including those undergoing training. It serves as a less crowded alternative to other popular sites like Bassano.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The main take-off area is a 25-minute drive from the main landing area in Pedavena. The road is mostly asphalted, with the last 2 km unpaved.
  • Local Club: The Para & Delta Club Feltre A.S.D. is active in the area. Contact them at paradeltaclubfeltre@gmail.com or visit their website at www.paradeltafeltre.it.
  • Fees: The Para & Delta Club Feltre may require membership or a "FlyCard" for site usage. Contact them for specific details.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Dependence: Be aware of potential dangers associated with bad weather, especially strong winds, rain, or thunderstorms. Gusts can cause pitching mid-flight. Always check forecasts and use an anemometer. Spring conditions can be stronger than autumn.
  • Terrain: Rocky or rough terrain may limit emergency landing options.
  • Italian Regulations: Free flight in Italy is strictly controlled by law. Foreign pilots need to be aware of the rules governing hang gliding and paragliding practices to avoid penalties.
  • Airspace: Be aware of airspace restrictions, including controlled airspace and airport approach zones. Paragliding is prohibited within airport approach and takeoff zones without prior authorization. Any aerial activity in controlled airspace requires coordination with air traffic control authorities. Violations can result in fines, equipment seizure, and even criminal charges if aviation safety is compromised.
  • Local Rules: Follow specific indications for each site, considering flight characteristics and site access, to avoid potential conflicts with landowners.
search_recs: Feltre Italy paragliding official site paragliding Feltre Italy site guide paragliding club Feltre Italy paragliding regulations Feltre Italy

html:
Overview

Revine is a scenic paragliding site located in the Veneto region of Italy, nestled near the picturesque Revine Lakes at the foot of the Prealps. Offering views over the lake and valley, Revine provides a great experience for pilots seeking thermal flights in a beautiful setting.

Flying Conditions

  • Revine is known for its thermaling opportunities, providing pilots with the chance to gain altitude and enjoy extended flights.
  • The site caters to both paragliding and hang gliding enthusiasts.

Who Should Fly Here?

Revine is considered an easy site, making it suitable for pilots of varying experience levels. It accommodates both single and two-seater paragliders and hang gliders.

Access & Facilities

  • The primary take-off at Revine La Posa is reachable by car.
  • A landing area is provided at Revine La Posa.
  • To use the Revine La Posa landing and take-off, an annual fee of €12 is required. This fee must be paid *before* takeoff at the "Osteria PRA DE' Boi" bar in the village of Soller, where pilots are also requested to register prior to flying. Contact information: +39 347 5768418 and segreteriavlp@libero.it.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Monte Valbella Takeoff: One launch site, Monte Valbella, is situated near a military base. Flying is strictly prohibited on weekdays near this base. This takeoff is also described as very technical and difficult to find.
  • Turbulence: Be aware that turbulent conditions can be expected under northerly wind conditions.
  • Radio Requirement: Although Revine isn't in the Dolomites, it's nearby. Consider carrying a license-free PMR radio dedicated to a local safety channel (PMR 8-16) for communication with rescue helicopters.
  • General Italian Regulations:
    • Pilots must hold third-party insurance covering paragliding activities.
    • Flights must adhere to visual flight rules (VFR), avoiding clouds and maintaining constant visual contact with the ground or water.
    • Flying is restricted to between 30 minutes before sunrise and 30 minutes after sunset.
    • Pilots are required to respect distances from controlled airspace.
    • Official takeoff and landing areas must have adequately sized wind indicators.

Always check local sources, consult with local pilots or schools, and observe posted signs for the most up-to-date information before flying. Regulations are subject to change.
search_recs: paragliding site Revine Italy official paragliding Revine Italy Revine paragliding club Revine Italy paragliding fees Revine Italy paragliding landing zones

html:
Overview

Panarotta, situated in the Valsugana valley in Trentino, Italy, offers stunning views of the Brenta Dolomites, the Lagorai range, and the lakes of Levico and Caldonazzo. With take-off points on Cima Panarotta and Vetriolo Terme and landing zones in the meadows at Barco di Levico, it's a popular spot for both local and visiting pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Known for excellent thermaling and cross-country (XC) opportunities, with potential flights towards the Fiemme and Fassa valleys along the Lagorai mountain chain.
  • Seasonality: Flying is possible year-round, including winter, but the best season is spring (April, May). Summer can sometimes be affected by overdevelopment or thunderstorms.
  • Wind Direction: Take-off is possible with south, southeast, and north winds. South-facing take-offs are generally recommended.

Who Should Fly Here?

Panarotta caters to pilots of all experience levels. South-facing take-offs are optimal for both beginners and experienced pilots. East and North take-offs are best suited for experienced pilots only.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Take-off areas are accessible by car from Levico Terme, following signs for "Panarotta 2002" or Vetriolo Terme. Public bus service from Barco or Levico to Vetriolo Terme is available during summer.
  • Registration: It is recommended that pilots register with the Volo Libero Trentino club. Tandem flights require mandatory registration with the club.
  • Tandem Pilots: Any tandem pilot practising consistently must pay a contribution of 400€ each year for use of the structures managed by Trentino Adventures.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Collisions: Be aware that a fatal collision involving a hang glider and paraglider occurred at Monte Panarotta/Levico Terme in September 2023. Exercise caution and maintain situational awareness.
  • Pilot Error: As always, pilot error is a significant risk. Carefully assess wind conditions and your own abilities before launching.
  • Takeoff Direction: The south take-off is optimal for both beginners and experts. The take-offs towards the east and north are recommended only for expert pilots.
  • Airspace: Flights must be conducted under Visual Flight Rules (VFR) conditions, requiring a minimum visibility and remaining clear of clouds with a visible ground reference. Flying at night is not allowed. Be aware of controlled airspace (CTR/TMA) around airports.

html:
Overview

Monte Farno, nestled in the Val Gandino of the Province of Bergamo, Italy, is a popular paragliding site known for its accessibility and stunning views. Separating the Val Gandino from the Seriana Valley, this elongated mountain reaches an altitude of 1,250m and has been a favorite among paragliders since 1990.

Flying Conditions

Monte Farno offers year-round flying opportunities, with the best conditions generally found on weekends and weekday afternoons, weather permitting. This site caters to a wide range of skill levels, from beginners taking tandem flights to experienced pilots seeking to hone their skills. The area is known for free flight and tandem paragliding. Take-off points include Manerot, which faces South-Southeast.

Please note that flying is strictly prohibited on rainy, turbulent, or windy days.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Farno is an ideal site for both beginners and experienced paragliders. Tandem flights are readily available for those new to the sport, while experienced pilots will appreciate the site's consistent conditions and scenic flights.

Access & Facilities

To reach Monte Farno from the town of Gandino (530m), follow the signs for Monte Farno/Parafulmine Hut. At the curve called Groaro (870m), there's a small free car park. From there, you can hike up using path CAI 549 to Biv. Baroncelli(1260m). Alternatively, you can drive along the road to Loc. Monte Farno (1248m) and walk the remaining 300m to the takeoff. Daily shuttles are available from the landing area parking during all seasons.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

While Monte Farno offers excellent flying conditions, it's important to be aware of potential risks and adhere to safety guidelines:

  • Weather Conditions: Sudden changes in weather may lead to flight postponements. It is crucial to fly only under suitable conditions.
  • Takeoff Assistance (Tandem Flights): Passengers on tandem flights must actively cooperate during takeoff by running with the pilot to gain speed.
  • Pilot Discretion: All aspects of the flight are managed by the pilot, including decisions to alter the flight or postpone due to weather.
  • Landing Instructions (Tandem Flights): Passengers must be prepared to run with the pilot during the final meters of landing to avoid sitting down abruptly.

Please consult with the local flying club, "Volo Libero Monte Farno – Diego Servalli" (VL MonteFarno), for the most up-to-date information and local regulations.
search_recs: Monte Farno volo libero Monte Farno paragliding site information paragliding Monte Farno Italy Monte Farno official paragliding site Monte Farno paragliding club

html:
Overview

Monte Caio, nestled in the Parma Apennines of the Emilia region, Italy, is a popular paragliding site known for its stunning mountain scenery within the Parco dei 100 Laghi (Park of 100 Lakes). With take-off points at approximately 1452m ASL and a max height difference of 878m, it offers fantastic opportunities for thermal soaring and cross-country flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Soaring: Monte Caio boasts excellent thermal soaring conditions, making it ideal for cross-country (XC) flights along the Emilian Apennines.
  • Variable Conditions: The site's location, 50 km from the Tyrrhenian Sea and 30 km from the Padanian flatland, creates challenging and variable conditions with strong thermals and convergences.
  • Suitable Wind Direction: Flyable with S wind directions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Caio is a highly frequented site suitable for both beginners and experienced pilots. Tandem flights are also popular. Paraclub Monte Caio- Delta club Melloni offers paragliding courses and tandem flights.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the take-off is by car followed by a walk.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Flying is not recommended with winds exceeding 20 km/h from the east or west quadrants.
  • Turbulence: Be aware of turbulence, especially in the lee of obstacles.
  • Monte Caio Official Takeoff (1584m): May be more exposed or susceptible to strong wind conditions.
  • Steep Delta Launch: The delta launch is steep and may pose a challenge.
  • Airspace: Be aware of airspace restrictions, most of the area is Class G airspace up to 6500ft, except controlled areas.
  • Restricted Areas: SKE zones (SKE 12, 13, 41, 42) exist in the Valle del Cauca which may impact the flying area.
  • No Low Altitude Flying: Low altitude flying over ski lifts is prohibited.
  • Contact Local Clubs: Contacting local paragliding clubs (A.S. VOLO LIBERO MONTE CAIO E DELTA CLUB MELLONI) is recommended for the most up-to-date information and site-specific guidance.
search_recs: paragliding club Monte Caio paragliding Monte Caio regulations Monte Caio paragliding site information Monte Caio paragliding site official information Monte Caio hike and fly

html:
Overview

Monte Dolada is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Alpago region of the Belluno province in Veneto, Italy. Located approximately 80 km north of Venice and 11 km northeast of Belluno, this site offers stunning views of the Alpago basin, Lake Santa Croce, and the Belluno Pre-Alps. Known for its reliable flying conditions in spring and autumn, Monte Dolada attracts pilots seeking both thermal flying and cross-country opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Excellent for both thermal flying and cross-country (XC) flights. It's a recognized waypoint for the classic XC route from Feltre or Fonzaso via Monte Avena.
  • Seasonality: Flying is possible from March to November, depending on weather conditions. Spring and autumn offer the most reliable conditions.
  • Weather Considerations: Ideal conditions involve relatively dry weather with wind speeds between 3 km/h and 15 km/h. The site is south-facing, ensuring sun exposure throughout the day.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Dolada accommodates a range of pilot experience levels. Tandem flights are available for beginners. Solo flying necessitates appropriate certification (IPPI 4 or 5). The site is popular and sometimes hosts national and international paragliding and hang gliding competitions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The take-off area is accessible by car from Pieve d'Alpago, continuing to Rifugio Dolada via a tarmac road.
  • Shuttle Service: A shuttle service from the landing site to the take-off area is available for customers of Rifugio Dolada.
  • Fees: Contact local operators or Rifugio Dolada for the most current pricing for shuttle services and any site-related fees. Previous competition entry fees have included transportation to takeoff, retrieve, lunch, and a T-shirt.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Strong Thermals: The calcareous rocks heat up quickly, creating strong and potentially startling thermals. Pilots inexperienced in managing strong thermal activity should exercise caution.
  • Weather Dependence: Flying is highly dependent on weather conditions. Sudden changes in weather can make flying dangerous. Only fly when conditions permit.
  • Turbulence: The Alpago region is known for strong wind gradients and rotor turbulence.
  • Proximity to Belluno Airfield: Be aware of the local airfield near Belluno and avoid flying through its circuit. Contacting the airfield for regulations is recommended.
  • Waldschneise Launch: One launch site involves a ramp in a forest clearing. Monitor wind conditions carefully at this launch due to its location.
  • Snow Conditions: If there's snow near Rifugio Dolada, a lower launch site requiring a short hike from the parking area is used.
  • General Compliance: Adhere to Italian law regarding free flight, including holding the necessary qualifications and insurance.
  • Airspace Awareness: Be aware of local airspace regulations.
  • Radio Requirement: In the Dolomites area, keep a dedicated radio tuned to the local safety channel (PMR 8-16).
  • Flying to the North: Avoid flying to the north, beyond Ponte D'Alpi.
search_recs: Monte Dolada paragliding site guide paragliding Monte Dolada Italy Monte Dolada paragliding official site Monte Dolada paragliding access fees Monte Dolada paragliding club Monte Dolada paragliding restrictions

html:
Overview

Poggio Bustone, located in the province of Rieti, within the Lazio region of Italy, offers paragliding and hang gliding amidst the stunning Apennine mountains. This official site, favored by schools and clubs, provides spectacular views of the Piana Reatina, the Sabini Mountains, and the "Sacred Valley."

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable for: Paragliding and Hang Gliding, including single and two-seater flights.
  • Thermals: Known for good thermalling conditions and cross-country (XC) potential.
  • Terrain: Offers both mountain and flatland flying possibilities.
  • Landing Options: Multiple landing areas are available in the valley.
  • Wind Directions: Recommended wind directions are South, South-East, and South-West. Flying with winds from the North is prohibited due to strong rotors.
  • Best Time to Fly: Typically from Spring to Autumn.

Who Should Fly Here?

Poggio Bustone is considered an easy site, making it suitable for a wide range of pilots. Its popularity sometimes leads to hosting paragliding competitions. Basic thermal flying skills are beneficial, especially for those interested in cross-country flying.

Access & Facilities

  • Take-off Access: The take-off sites are accessible by car and a short walk.
  • "Delta" Take-off Directions: From the landing zone, proceed towards Poggio Bustone. After passing the small square with parking, continue for 1.5 km. Look for white signs on the right indicating "piste di lancio deltaplani" (hang gliding launch tracks) and turn left onto the asphalt road leading to the take-off (approximately 7 km away).
  • "Le Collinette" Access: Note that the road to "Le Collinette" is unpaved and rough. A four-wheel-drive vehicle is recommended.
  • Fees: There may be costs associated with XC courses offered at the site.
  • Glider Right of Way: Be aware that the area experiences glider activity, and gliders have the right of way.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Restrictions: The area is within controlled airspace. Free flight is prohibited unless temporary authorization is granted by ENAC (Ente nazionale per l'aviazione civile) for specific events. Flying from Monte Rosato without special authorization is forbidden.
  • Weather Dependence: Paragliding is weather-dependent and requires favorable conditions. Sudden gusts, turbulence, or unexpected downdrafts can destabilize a glider.
  • Pilot Error: Pilot error is a significant cause of paragliding accidents.
  • Tandem Weight Limitations: Be aware of weight limitations for tandem flights if applicable.
  • NOTAMs: It is essential to check for temporary flight restrictions (NOTAMs) before flying.
search_recs: Poggio Bustone take off paragliding Poggio Bustone paragliding site information paragliding Poggio Bustone Italy Poggio Bustone paragliding club Poggio Bustone comune paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Castelluccio is a picturesque village nestled in Umbria, within the Sibillini Mountains National Park in Italy. Known as the "Valley of the Eagles," the landscape boasts the high plateau of Piano Grande, surrounded by rolling hills and the majestic Vettore massif. The plateau is famous for its stunning bloom of colorful flowers (gentians, daffodils, violets, buttercups, and daisies) from late June to early July, making it a truly unique location.

Flying Conditions

Castelluccio offers excellent conditions for thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying. The area benefits from good convection and fluffy clouds during typical high-pressure Italian weather, often prevalent during the travel season. This can result in thermally active flying conditions for up to nine hours a day.

The bowl-shaped landscape is ideal for finding suitable wind conditions for takeoff and soaring, while the obstacle-free valley floor allows for top landings. The best flying season is from June to September, but spring also provides good thermals, and sunset flights offer calm alternatives to midday turbulence.

Who Should Fly Here?

Castelluccio is suitable for pilots of all experience levels, from beginners to seasoned XC enthusiasts. Tandem flights and instruction are readily available, and paragliding schools in the area offer courses for all skill levels.

Access & Facilities

Castelluccio is easily accessible, and take-off points are relatively simple to reach. Shuttle services to take-off locations are often offered by local schools. Tandem paragliding flights typically cost around €120-€150. Check with local operators for any site-specific fees or permits required.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

Be aware of the following risks and restrictions:

  • Turbulence: Significant turbulence can occur in landing areas during midday (approximately 12:00 to 14:00) due to thermal activity. Be prepared to manage these conditions.
  • Venturi/Rotor Effect: Very windy conditions during the central hours of the day can create dangerous venturi and rotor effects in certain areas. Avoid flying during these hours.
  • Mountain Generated Turbulence: On days with winds from the North-East, turbulent conditions may exist due to downwind generated by Vettore Mountain. Flying on such days is not advised.
  • Fontanile (Poggio di Croce) Takeoff: With strong winds from the North-East, avoid using this takeoff due to turbulence caused by the downwind from Vettore Mountain (and Veletta Mountain).
  • Forca di Presta North-West Takeoff: With moderate intensity winds from the Southwest, Monte Guiaidone, located in front of the takeoff on the left, could generate downwind turbulence.
  • Natura 2000 Site: Castelluccio is within the Monti Sibillini National Park, which includes Natura 2000 sites. Paragliding is permitted in Zone A of the Park plan, but compatibility with conservation needs is essential.
  • Ranch Proximity: Flying over the horse ranch is strictly forbidden for safety reasons.
  • Vehicle Access: A special PASS is required to access the street connecting the horse ranch to the school fields “La Rotonda” and “La Dogana”. Inquire with “La Valle delle Aquile” and the Castelluccio information office for access.
search_recs: paragliding clubs Castelluccio Italy paragliding rules and regulations Castelluccio Italy paragliding Castelluccio Italy Castelluccio paragliding site official info Castelluccio Italy landscape paragliding

html:
Overview

Piossasco is a popular paragliding site located in the Piedmont region of Italy, near Turin. Soar over the scenic Parco Naturale del Monte San Giorgio, reaching an elevation of 837 meters, and enjoy panoramic views of the Turin metropolitan area and the Cottian Alps. Piossasco is known as good winter airfield.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions:
    • South Takeoff: Suitable for South-Westerly to South-Easterly winds.
    • East Takeoff: Best for East to East-South-Easterly winds.
    • Wind Restrictions: Takeoff is prohibited with winds from the Northeast-Northwest directions.
  • Thermals: The area around Monte San Giorgio is known for thermals, especially near the rock walls close to the launch sites, the meadow south of the launch, and above the Castello dei Nove Merli.
  • XC Potential: Piossasco is known for cross-country (XC) flying opportunities.

Who Should Fly Here?

Piossasco is popular and also used by a local flying school for bi-glider flights. A valid paragliding license is required.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the launch is possible by car followed by a walk.
  • Shuttle Service: A shuttle service is available for a fee (approximately EUR 6.00 in 2024).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • General Flying Considerations: Pay attention to the busy road near the landing area. Avoid flying with west winds.
  • CTR4 Airspace: Monte San Giorgio is located entirely within the CTR4 area, where flight is prohibited above 5500 feet (approximately 1650 meters) AMSL. Flight is permitted below this altitude.
  • CTR2 Proximity: Moving East, beyond the town of Piossasco, or South, beyond the Statale 589 road, pilots enter the CTR2 area. Flight is prohibited above 2500 feet (approximately 740 meters) AMSL in CTR2.
  • Parachute Zone Awareness: Moving West towards Pinerolo and the Tre Denti mountain range, there are no airspace restrictions unless you cross Statale 589 heading South from the Cumiana junction, to avoid interfering with the Cumiana paragliding dropzone.
  • Overflying Restrictions: It is forbidden to fly over populated areas.
  • Important Note: Always consult up-to-date airspace maps of the area before flying.
search_recs: Piossasco paragliding club Piossasco paragliding regulations paragliding Piossasco Italy Piossasco paragliding site information

html:
Overview

Monte Belpo, situated near the picturesque Lake Garda in the Veneto region of Italy, offers a fantastic paragliding experience amidst stunning mountain and hill landscapes. The primary takeoff, known as "Gas," is located on Monte Belpo and serves as a launching point for memorable flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Takeoff Direction: The "Gas" takeoff area faces SSW.
  • Suitability: The site is well-suited for both paragliding and hang gliding, with opportunities for tandem flights.
  • Hike & Fly: Monte Belpo is renowned for hike & fly adventures. The "King of Belpo" event is held here every year.
  • Landing Options: Pilots can enjoy scenic flights culminating in landings near the shores of Lake Garda.
  • Webcam: The local Volo Libero Scaligero club provides a webcam for real-time condition checks before takeoff.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Belpo is a popular destination, particularly favored by local pilots and schools. All pilots must possess a valid paragliding license and insurance. Please note that one of the Monte Belpo sites is sensitive and is at risk of being closed, requiring strict adherence to regulations.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the takeoff area is "By car, walk."
  • Private Ownership: The "Gas" takeoff area on Monte Belpo (VR) is privately owned and used by Deltaland Verona flight school and Volo Libero Monte Baldo club.
  • Permission: Pilots may need to obtain permission from the flight school before flying.
  • Landing Area: Landing at the main "Deltaland" landing area requires a valid paragliding flight license and insurance. This landing area is privately owned.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Private Property Concerns: Access to Monte Belpo 1 launch is threatened by previous disturbances. Strict adherence to rules is essential to maintain access.
  • Certification: The site is not certified.
  • Need Permission: Flying at Monte Belpo requires permission from the local flying school.
  • Monte Belpo 1 (SENSITIVE!) Access Restrictions:
    • Access is *only* by foot; cars are prohibited. Park at Hotel Adla Pineta and follow the "dirt track" on foot.
    • Use the back path and avoid disturbing B&B guests.
  • Mountain Pasture Areas: Be aware of areas reserved for mountain pasture are present near the take off.
search_recs: paragliding sites near Monte Belpo Italy Monte Belpo paragliding site info Gas Monte Belpo paragliding Monte Belpo paragliding club Monte Belpo paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Speikboden, nestled in the Ahrntal valley of South Tyrol, Italy, is a renowned paragliding destination south of the Zillertal Alps. With breathtaking panoramic views extending to the Dolomites, this high-alpine site caters to both beginners and experienced pilots. Known for its excellent conditions and accessibility, Speikboden is a popular choice for long-distance (XC) flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Best Time to Fly: Year-round, with optimal conditions from June to September.
  • Wind Conditions: While the site can be flown in multiple wind directions, caution is advised during strong north winds. The Durreck massif provides partial protection.
  • Takeoff Altitude: 2,450 meters above sea level, offering varied launch options.
  • Landing Zone: Located in Sand in Taufers at 870m, near the gym hall and swimming pool. Look for signs and a windsock.

Who Should Fly Here?

Speikboden is suitable for pilots of all experience levels, from beginners to seasoned XC enthusiasts.

Access & Facilities

  • Lift Access: Use the Speikboden cable car to the upper terminal (2,000m), followed by a seven-minute walk to the Sonnklar chairlift (2,400m).
  • Lift Assistance: Pilots are often offered free rides on the Speikboden and Sonnklar lifts.
  • Landing Area: Well-marked landing area in Sand in Taufers with signs and a windsock. Parking available nearby. Bus connections provide easy return to the Speikboden lifts.
  • Hang Gliders: Transport of hang gliders is generally not possible on the lifts unless they can be folded to a length of 2 meters. Contact the "Falkenclub" for SUV rides to the launch site if needed.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • North Wind: Speikboden is exposed to north winds, which can be strong. Monitor wind conditions carefully before flying.
  • Valley Crossing: Be aware of the valley crossing directly in front of the Speikboden takeoff.
  • Foehn Wind: Exercise caution for Foehn winds in Sand in Taufers.
  • Launch Sites: The stony launch site near the mountain station has two benches, while another launch is 150 meters to the west.
  • General Flight Rules: Adhere to all general flight rules.
  • Legal Requirements: Pilots and flying schools must comply with local and national legal requirements, especially regarding pilot's licenses and insurance (www.aeci.it).
  • Landing Procedures: Follow landing approach instructions posted at the landing site. Approach from the right with a south wind and from the left with a north wind.
  • Landing Restrictions: No ground handling or hoisting exercises are allowed at the landing site or surrounding areas during flight operations.
  • Compliance: Follow the instructions of the tourism association and its agents. Non-compliance may result in being prohibited from flying.
  • Launch Site Perimeter: Pilots must stay within the perimeter fence at the launch site.
search_recs: Speikboden paragliding official site paragliding Speikboden Italy Speikboden paragliding site information Speikboden Italy paragliding access fees Speikboden Italy paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Monte Maddalena, located near Brescia, Italy, is a popular paragliding destination offering a substantial height difference of approximately 710 meters. This mountain provides multiple take-off points at various elevations, making it a versatile site for soaring and cross-country (XC) flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions:
    • Multiple take-off points cater to various wind directions, including SE, S, SW, W, N-E, E, and N-O.
    • The upper East launch is reportedly the primary one in use.
  • Site Suitability:
    • Suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including tandem flights.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • Pilots should be cautious of west winds creating rotor over the trees on the SW start.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Maddalena is a popular site. While one source rates it as "easy," pilot skill level recommendations vary. Consulting with local pilots or clubs like Brixia Flying is essential to determine suitability based on current conditions and personal skill level.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Generally by car, followed by a short walk to the take-off areas.
  • Directions: Exit the A4 highway at Brescia Centro and follow signs towards Monte Maddalena. Specific routes to different take-off points are available.
  • Road: A single road leads to Monte Maddalena with take-off points at different elevations.
  • Fees: No information available regarding site usage fees.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Rotor Risk: Be very careful of west wind creating a rotor over the trees on the SW start, as several collapses and one tree landing have been observed.
  • Takeoff Specific Risks:
    • Monte Maddalena 1 (South-West Start): West wind can create rotor over the trees.
  • Flight Restrictions:
    • Clean turns without "abachtern" are desired.
    • The landing area is exclusively reserved for landing paragliders, hang gliders, VDS-VL and VDS-VM. Ground handling is prohibited within the landing and folding areas.
    • Adhere to all current regulations regarding recreational or sport flying, including holding a valid certificate, medical examination, and insurance, and wearing a helmet.
search_recs: Monte Maddalena paragliding site information paragliding Monte Maddalena Italy Monte Maddalena paragliding official site

html:
Overview

Kronplatz, also known as Plan de Corones, is a prominent mountain in the Dolomites region of South Tyrol, Italy. Rising to an elevation of 2,275m in the Val Pusteria-Pustertal valley, it offers stunning panoramic views of the Dolomites and the main ridge of the Alps. This popular site is known for its accessible flying conditions, making it a favorite among paragliders and hang gliders alike.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Excellent thermaling conditions and potential for cross-country (XC) flights along the Pustertal valley.
  • Wind Directions: Launch possibilities exist for South, Northeast, and Northwest winds. Southwest and West takeoffs offer good thermals but are slightly more challenging.
  • Seasonality: A popular flying area in both summer and winter.
  • Weather Considerations: Particularly suitable for flying in northern wind directions, except during Föhn conditions. Pilots should consult the Kronplatz Weather Station for current and detailed weather information.

Who Should Fly Here?

Kronplatz is considered an easy site suitable for pilots of all levels, including beginners. It's also a popular destination for tandem flights, requiring only sturdy shoes, warm clothes, and the ability to run a few meters during takeoff and landing.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The mountain is easily accessible by cable car.
  • Fees: Cable car tickets are required. Tickets that include the transport of bike & paraglider can be purchased. Landing may involve a small fee to the local farmer. Visiting pilots may need to ask local farmers for permission and possibly pay a small fee to land.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Conditions: Unpredictable weather patterns, such as strong winds and sudden changes, can make flying dangerous. Strong southerly winds, in particular, can be hazardous. It's crucial to check weather forecasts and consult local experts before flying.
  • Landing Zone Caution: The landing zone can be dangerous in north wind conditions.
  • Limited Landing Options: Landing options to the south are limited.
  • Proximity to Lift Facilities: Paragliding in proximity to the routes of lift facilities is strictly forbidden. Violations may result in administrative penalties and withdrawal of access permits to lift facilities.
search_recs: Kronplatz paragliding flying conditions paragliding Kronplatz Italy site information Kronplatz paragliding official site Kronplatz paragliding access fees

html:
Overview

Monte Cucco, nestled in the Umbria-Marche Apennines, marks the border between Umbria and Marche in Italy. This popular site, located within the Parco di Monte Cucco, offers stunning mountainous terrain with forests, grasslands, and valleys. Reaching a summit of 1566 meters (5138 feet), Monte Cucco attracts paragliders and hang gliders from around the world.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Known for reliable thermals, making it excellent for cross-country (XC) flying.
  • Wind Directions:
    • Pian di Monte (South/West): Suitable for northwest to southwest winds.
    • Northeast Takeoff (Alberto's Restaurant): Suitable for northeast to southeast winds.
  • Launch & Landing:
    • Takeoff Areas: Pian di Monte (southwest facing) and northeast-facing takeoff accessible via Alberto's restaurant.
    • Landing Zones: Located near Sigillo. Top landing is also possible.
  • Year-Round Flying: Operational year-round, though weather conditions, especially snow, should be checked in advance.
  • Venturi Effects: Local rules prohibit low-altitude passes near the landing area due to venturi effects.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Cucco is suitable for pilots of varying experience levels. It's a popular spot, especially on weekends. Tandem flights are available. The south launch (Pian di Monte) is generally considered easier, while the north launch requires more experience. A medium difficulty rating is generally assigned to the site.

Access & Facilities

  • Accessibility: Take-off areas (north and south) are easily accessible by car via paved roads.
  • Regulation: Access and area usage are authorized and regulated by the town hall of Sigillo.
  • Requirements: Pilots must possess a valid free flight license, appropriate insurance, and safe equipment (including a helmet and emergency parachute).
  • Authorization: The town hall of Sigillo reserves the right to prohibit site use to anyone not complying with regulations.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Flying crosswind up to Monte Cucco can be challenging.
  • Rotor: Be aware of rotor, especially downwind of steep lee-sides, obstacles, or sharp edges of ridges.
  • Cows: Be mindful of cows that may wander across the meadow, particularly near the main takeoff and landing area.
  • Takeoff Attempts: Competitors are normally allowed only one take-off attempt unless launching from the south side of Monte Cucco.
  • Regulations: All pilots must comply with current regulations and fly in a safe manner, especially concerning right-of-way rules.
  • Environmental Respect: The use of the flying site is allowed on the condition of respecting the environment and people.
  • Landing on Private Property: In the event of landing on private property, the pilot is responsible for any damages.
  • Banned Conduct: The town hall of Sigillo reserves the right to ban people from the area for non-compliance with regulations, unacceptable behavior, disrespect to the general public, discrimination, or any conduct contrary to sportsmanship.
search_recs: Monte Cucco paragliding access paragliding Monte Cucco Italy site information Monte Cucco paragliding official site Monte Cucco paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Sale Marasino, located on the eastern shore of Lake Iseo in Lombardy, Italy, is a scenic paragliding site offering breathtaking views. From the take-off point at Forcella di Sale, pilots can enjoy panoramic vistas of the lake, Monte Isola, and the pre-Alps, including Punta Almana and Monte Guglielmo. This site is known for its stunning flights over Lake Iseo and supports both paragliding and hang gliding activities.

Flying Conditions

  • Sale Marasino (Forcella di Sale) offers opportunities for both thermaling and ridge soaring, depending on the day's conditions.
  • Flights are generally possible throughout the year, given favorable weather.

Who Should Fly Here?

The site is suitable for a range of pilots. Tandem flights are available for beginners, while independent flying at Forcella di Sale likely requires an intermediate skill level due to the mountainous terrain and potentially variable conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • The typical meeting point is in Sale Marasino.
  • Pilots (or tandem passengers) are transported to the Forcella di Sale take-off, often using 4WD vehicles.
  • Expect to pay around €5 per person for the transfer to Forcella di Sale, payable on-site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Shared Airspace: The flying area is frequented by both powered aircraft and free-flying paragliders and hang gliders, especially on weekends. Pilots of powered aircraft are urged to pay particular attention to the presence of free-flying vehicles, especially near ridges.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Be aware of reserved airspaces in the area that may force ultralight motorized aircraft to transit near areas used by free-flying gliders, increasing the risk of collision. Check updated airspaces before flying.
  • Take-off Points:
    • DECOLLO FORCELLA: 1100 m s.l.m. (45° 45' 26,8'' N – 10° 08' 46,5'' E)
    • DECOLLO di GOLE: 1022 m s.l.m. (45° 41' 23,5'' N – 10° 08' 01,9'' E)
    • Assess conditions at the chosen launch site before commencing flight.

Disclaimer: Seek a site-specific briefing from a local guide or instructor before flying at Sale Marasino, especially if you are unfamiliar with the area. ASD Parapendio Sebino is a local association.
search_recs: paragliding Sale Marasino Italy Sale Marasino paragliding site volo parapendio Sale Marasino paragliding Lake Iseo Sale Marasino paragliding official site

html:
Overview

Monte Ripoli is a paragliding site located near Tivoli, in the Lazio region of Italy, not far from Rome. This site, characterized by a small hill, offers scenic views towards Abruzzo and the Lazio plains. Managed, at least in part, by the Asd Altivoli club, Monte Ripoli is considered an accessible and relatively easy site to fly.

Flying Conditions

  • Launch Directions: Suitable for Southwest to West (SW-W) and Northeast (NE) launches.
  • Site Suitability: Good for both single and tandem paragliding flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Ripoli is considered easy and is suitable for both beginner and experienced pilots. Both single and two-seater paragliding flights can be performed from here. Note that the site is regulated and is only for approved and registered pilots.

Access & Facilities

The site is accessible by car, followed by a short walk to the launch area. For detailed access information and usage regulations, it's recommended to contact info@altivoli.it.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Fences: Be aware of potential fences, particularly in the northeastern area of the launch site. Pilots should exercise caution during takeoff and landing.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Always check for current NOTAMs (Notices to Airmen) which may indicate temporary flight restrictions in the area.
  • Prohibited Areas: Be aware of permanent prohibited areas like LI P244 near Rome (Edifici Istituzionali), which has restrictions on overflying due to security reasons. While this isn't directly *at* Monte Ripoli, it's important to be aware of airspace limitations in the general region.

Important: It's crucial to check with local pilots and the site operator (info@altivoli.it) for the most up-to-date information before flying at Monte Ripoli.
search_recs: Monte Ripoli paragliding regulations paragliding Monte Ripoli Italy site information Monte Ripoli paragliding take off Monte Ripoli paragliding club

html:
Overview

Monte Alpo, nestled in the Valle del Chiese near Lake Idro on the border between Trento and Brescia in Italy, is a popular paragliding site within the Trentino region. Offering stunning views of the Brenta Dolomites, Monte Alpo provides opportunities for soaring, thermaling, and cross-country flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Soaring, thermaling, and cross-country (XC) flying.
  • Seasonality: Flyable year-round, weather permitting.
  • Thermal Activity: Good thermal activity in the mid-afternoon at higher altitudes.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • The valley experiences the "Ander" wind, which blows from south to north in the afternoon.
    • Pilots should be cautious of the strong "Ora" wind.
    • Check the weather station before heading to the takeoff as stronger winds tend to occur mid-afternoon, which can make it difficult to reach the landing area.
  • Weather Forecasts: It is advisable to check weather forecasts from METEOTRENTINO before flying.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Alpo is suitable for pilots of all experience levels, from beginners to experienced cross-country pilots. Tandem flights are available for beginners. For learners, the best flying times are between 8 AM and noon, and after 6 PM.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the launch site is typically organized with a shuttle or by driving up to the "malga/alp" and then proceeding on foot.
  • Takeoff Points:
    • Monte Alpo (1508 m) above Baitoni.
    • "Alpo" Take-off Zone (Altitude: 1650m)
    • "Calva" Take-off zone (Altitude: 1000m)
  • Fees: A "Fly Card" may be required for flight schools, but not for individual pilots.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Strong Winds: Stronger winds tend to occur mid-afternoon, making it difficult to reach the landing area. Always check the weather station before heading to the takeoff.
  • "Alpo" Take-off Zone (Altitude: 1650m) Specific Risks:
    • Ensure the wind is blowing in the right direction based on the weather station.
    • Parking is restricted; it's prohibited to drive through the meadows.
  • "Calva" Take-off zone (Altitude: 1000m) Specific Risks:
    • If the wind socks are not turning south, take-off might be dangerous.
    • Parking in the pastures is prohibited.
  • General Behavior Rules (Idroland Fly Zone - likely relevant to Monte Alpo):
    • Do not fly over the biotope at an altitude lower than 500 meters.
    • Move promptly from the landing zone to the paraglider folding area.
  • Regulations: Flying is regulated by Italian law n°106 (published on March 25th, 1985) and DPR (Decree of the President of the Italian Republic, n°133 published in 2010).
  • Radio Use (Dolomites Area - proximity may be relevant): In the Dolomites area, pilots are required to have a separate license-free PMR radio dedicated to a local safety channel (PMR 8-16) for communication with rescue services.

Always check with local flying schools or clubs for the most up-to-date information before flying at Monte Alpo, as regulations can change.

html:
Overview

San Donato Val di Comino is a renowned paragliding site nestled in the Central Apennines, within the province of Frosinone, Lazio region, Italy. Located near the stunning Abruzzo National Park, this site offers breathtaking views of mountains and valleys, especially the picturesque Comino Valley.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermalling and Cross-Country (XC) Flying: San Donato is famous for its exceptional thermalling and XC flying opportunities, even during the winter months.
  • Favorable Winds: Southwest winds provide pleasant take-off conditions, making it accessible for pilots of varying skill levels.
  • Orographic Lift and Dry Air: The area's unique orographic orientation, combined with dry air from northern winds, creates optimal flying conditions. Pilots can achieve impressive altitudes, often exceeding 3000 meters.
  • Strong Thermals: Expect powerful thermals, with variometric values reaching +8 or +9 m/s during spring and summer.

Who Should Fly Here?

San Donato caters to a wide range of pilot skill levels. Beginners can enjoy shorter, scenic flights, while experienced pilots can challenge themselves with thermal and XC adventures. The site is described as typically not being overly crowded, enhancing the overall flying experience.

Access & Facilities

  • Take-Off Point: The primary take-off is located at "Tre Ponti Superiore" on the road connecting San Donato Val di Comino and Pescasseroli.
  • Altitude: The take-off sits at an altitude of 1100 meters.
  • Features: The take-off is well-equipped with wind sleeves and a platform for easy launching.
  • Access: Access to the take-off is convenient via car, followed by a short walk.
  • Landing Area: The official landing area is at "Campo Guerrano" in the municipality of Alvito.
  • Landing Area Altitude: The landing area sits at 420 meters altitude.
  • Landing Area Features: The landing zone boasts large, flat meadows, ensuring safe and comfortable landings.
  • Fees: Be aware that some sources mention potential fees for site usage or association memberships.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Awareness: Always check the weather forecast and use an anemometer to assess wind strength and direction before flying. Strong gusts can be particularly dangerous. Spring conditions are typically stronger than autumn.
  • Site-Specific Hazards: Be mindful of rocky or rough terrain that may limit emergency landing options. Avoid flying at sites without wind indicators.
  • Crowded Sites: Exercise caution at crowded sites and adhere to priority rules. Don't assume conditions are suitable for you just because other pilots are in the air.
  • Technical Limitations: Avoid taking undue risks without the necessary technical expertise. Begin with easier sites or safe areas that require simple techniques.
  • Equipment Maintenance: Ensure your equipment is of good quality and regularly checked to minimize risks.
  • Compliance with Regulations: Pilots must comply with current regulations for recreational or sport flying (VDS), including holding a valid license/certificate, a current medical certificate, and insurance.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Be aware of controlled airspace.
  • Landing Area Regulations: Respect landing area regulations, including designated landing zones and restrictions on ground handling.
  • Radio Communication: Pilots in flight should be reachable via radio for safety communication.
  • Local Rules: Adhere to site-specific rules regarding launch procedures, landing zones, and local customs. It is highly recommended to consult with local pilots before flying the site for the first time.
search_recs: paragliding club San Donato Italy paragliding San Donato Italy paragliding regulations San Donato Italy volo parapendio San Donato San Donato paragliding site description

html:
Overview

Caltrano is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Veneto region of Italy, within the province of Vicenza. This area boasts a diverse mountain and hill landscape, providing a significant height difference of approximately 459 meters at the primary takeoff. You'll find several takeoff options situated between Pra de Giglio and Foroaro.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Caltrano is renowned for its thermal soaring opportunities and excellent potential for cross-country (XC) flights.
  • Best Season: Ideal takeoff conditions occur with winds from the South, South-East, or South-West.
  • Thermal Activity: The area is known for good thermal activity, which allows for longer and more adventurous flights. Be aware that strong thermals and associated turbulence can be expected.

Who Should Fly Here?

This site is rated as having a medium difficulty level. All pilots must be able to launch from the top of the takeoff area without needing to run down the slope.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Reach the takeoff by taking the local road from Garziere, Piovene Rocchette to Asiago, then from Caltrano to Cogollo del Cengio. In Mosson, ask for directions to Colombare.
  • Fees: It's advisable to contact the local paragliding club, Delta Club Vicenza, to confirm any fees associated with using the site. They can provide the most up-to-date information.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Be cautious of turbulence near the rocks in the M. Pau area.
  • General Risks: As an alpine environment, pilots should be aware of thinner air and rapidly changing weather conditions at higher altitudes.
  • Campanara Takeoff (736m): This wide launch is exposed to the South and Southeast. Pay close attention to wind direction here.
  • Airspace: Familiarize yourself with and respect all airspace regulations.
  • Radio: It's highly recommended to carry a radio, especially given the site's proximity to the Dolomites, where a dedicated safety radio tuned to PMR 8-16 is required for rescue operations communication.
  • Certification: Ensure all equipment, including helmet, harness, and paraglider, is certified. If your glider is older than 2 years, have proof of airworthiness (valid technical check) available.
  • Local Rules: It is the pilot's responsibility to understand and abide by all local site rules.
search_recs: Caltrano paragliding difficulty Caltrano paragliding landing zones paragliding Caltrano Italy site description Caltrano paragliding official site Caltrano paragliding fees Caltrano paragliding access

html:
Overview

Bernadia is a paragliding site located in Friuli-Venezia Giulia, Italy, near the village of Torlano, nestled at the foot of Monte Bernadia-Lonza. This picturesque area, with its wooded hills, pastures, and vineyards, offers soaring and cross-country opportunities. The mountain summit reaches 844 meters above sea level.

Flying Conditions

Bernadia is best known for its evening flights, although it can present more technical challenges during midday thermals.

  • Wind Directions:
    • High Takeoff: Ideal for South and Southwest winds. The terrain is rough and particularly technical in the absence of wind.
    • Low Takeoff: Best suited for East, Southeast, South, and Southwest winds, or in the absence of wind. This takeoff is generally easier than the high takeoff due to the less rough terrain.
    • North Winds: Takeoff is impossible with winds from the northern quadrants. Furthermore, landing with north winds can create dangerous situations even if takeoff conditions seem favorable.
  • Suitable for: Both paragliding and hang gliding, including 1- and 2-seater configurations.

Who Should Fly Here?

Bernadia is rated as a medium difficulty site. The takeoffs are considered technical and are not suitable for beginners. While occasionally used by local pilots, careful consideration should be given to experience level before flying here.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The takeoff can be reached by car and on foot.
  • Restricted Access: Only members of CFP (Centro Friulano Parapendio) with a visible membership card are permitted to drive the final 500 meters of dirt road leading to the launch site due to a "no-trespassing" sign.
  • Local Club Contact: It is essential to contact the local club, Centro Friulano Parapendio (http://www.centrofriulanoparapendio.it), possibly to arrange access, before planning a flight. Marco is a contact person.
  • Fees: No information is available about site fees.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Technical Takeoffs: The takeoffs are considered technical due to the terrain and potentially strong thermal activity, especially when thermal activity is strong.
  • North Wind Dangers: As mentioned above, takeoffs are impossible with northerly winds, and landings can be dangerous under these conditions.
search_recs: Bernadia Italy flying site details Bernadia paragliding site information paragliding Bernadia Italy Bernadia paragliding club volo libero Bernadia Italia parapendio Bernadia Italia Bernadia paragliding official site

html:
Overview

Monte Baldo is a stunning mountain range in the Italian Alps, offering breathtaking panoramic views of Lake Garda and the surrounding landscape. Located near Malcesine, this popular paragliding site provides a unique experience with its significant height difference and year-round flying opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Takeoff Altitude: 1700 meters (Tratto Spino)
  • Height Difference: Approximately 1700 meters, offering flight times around 30 minutes.
  • Takeoff Directions:
    • West Takeoff: Ideal for gaining altitude over the lake and SIV courses.
    • East Takeoff: Suitable for thermal flights, potentially enabling longer XC flights.
  • Winds:
    • Pelèr: Northern wind, typically strong in the morning until around 11:00 AM.
    • Ora: Southern wind, usually replaces the Pelèr in the early afternoon and can be strong around noon before decreasing in the evening.
    • Montès: Evening wind descending from Monte Baldo, potentially pushing pilots towards the mountain.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Baldo attracts pilots of varying skill levels, including tandem pilots and those undertaking SIV courses. While popular, the site presents challenges due to potentially strong winds and proximity to Lake Garda. Careful attention to wind conditions and local advice is essential.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Via the Funivia Monte Baldo cable car from Malcesine.
  • Fees: Cable car fees apply. Landing is free for individual, non-commercial flights. The Paragliding Club Malcesine charges for a rescue service in case of landing in the water.
  • Landing Area: Located approximately 2 km north of Malcesine.
  • Transportation: A tourist bus provides transportation back to Malcesine from the landing area.
  • Tickets: Online tickets are available for paragliding and passengers, valid only for the selected date and time slot.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Lake Landing Risk: High risk of landing in Lake Garda, necessitating a mandatory life jacket.
  • Mandatory Equipment: License, insurance and life jacket are mandatory.
  • Weather Changes: Rapid weather changes are common; stay updated on local conditions and advice.
  • Wind Conditions: Be cautious of strong and shifting winds, especially the Pelèr and Ora. The Montès wind in the evening can push pilots towards the mountain.
  • Turbulence: Mountain flying may be subject to turbulence.
  • Overflying Restrictions: Overflying the state road at an altitude of less than 150 metres is strictly prohibited.
  • Prohibited Maneuvers: Acrobatic maneuvers, simulation of in-flight problems, and any maneuvers other than those for the correct approach to the landing area are strictly prohibited.
  • Landing Area Rules: Pilots must move the paraglider to the designated area after landing. Registration ("Fly Card") at the "Paragliding Bar" next to the landing field is required before using the landing area. The landing area is exclusively for landing paragliders and rescue vehicles.
  • Recovery Dinghy: Avoid any maneuver or action such as to present the risk of falling into water unless assistance with a recovery dinghy has been arranged in advance.
  • General Conduct: Respect the environment and other persons. Littering, camping in prohibited areas, obstructing other pilots, or engaging in unsuitable activities may result in denial of use and notification of authorities.
search_recs: paragliding flights Monte Baldo Monte Baldo paragliding official site Monte Baldo paragliding site information paragliding Monte Baldo paragliding club Monte Baldo

html:
Overview

Colonei is a paragliding site located in Caprino Veronese, in the Province of Verona, Italy. Situated in the pre-alpine foothills near Lake Garda, it offers a height difference of 1082m from take-off (278m).

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including single and two-seater flights.
  • Known for thermal soaring, especially in light wind conditions during the late afternoon.
  • Current weather conditions can be foggy with light winds and variable wind directions.

Who Should Fly Here?

While the exact skill level is not specified, the thermal soaring opportunities suggest that intermediate pilots could benefit most from this site. The site has a low star rating on Paragliding Map, which may indicate it's less popular or well-regarded compared to other sites.

Access & Facilities

  • Access to the site is by car followed by a walk.
  • No site fees information available.
  • Site certification status is "No", further information can be found at vololiberoscaligero.org

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • No specific risks or dangers were identified for Colonei other than general paragliding hazards.
  • Pilots should seek local advice on site conditions, weather patterns, and any temporary restrictions before flying.
  • Ensure you are aware of and comply with all Italian aviation regulations related to paragliding.
  • Verify that you have appropriate insurance coverage for paragliding activities in Italy.
