html:
Overview

Rocca Canavese is a popular paragliding site located in the Piedmont region of Italy, near Turin. The area offers a diverse landscape, characterized by the Torinese plain and surrounding mountains. It is known for its suitability for both thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals & XC: The site is known for good thermal activity and XC potential, with pilots achieving flights of nearly 100km. It is used for regional competitions.
  • Suitable for: Paragliding and paramotoring.
  • Takeoff Altitude: 1005m
  • Madonna della Neve Takeoff: Located in the municipality of Rocca Canavese, bordering Levone and Forno Canavese, on the ridge descending from Corio "Testa Brusa" towards Levone. It faces South-South/East and sits at an altitude of 930 meters. GPS coordinates (WGS84) are 45°19'39.53946″ N 7°34'21.45162″E.

Who Should Fly Here?

While specific skill level recommendations are not available, the ability to thermal and XC fly suggests that it is best suited for intermediate to experienced pilots. The site hosts events and competitions, indicating a supportive environment for skilled pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Meeting Point: Bar La Branda.
  • Shuttle: Shuttle services are available to the take-off.
  • Contact: Contact RoccaVolando Asd for the most up-to-date information on site access and any associated fees.
  • Information: Information can be found via the Italian Free Flight Association (FIVL) and the local club, RoccaVolando Asd.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Private Property: The area in front of the church and facing the town of Rocca Canavese is private property. Free flight activities are prohibited in this area unless agreed upon and authorized in advance by the property owners.
  • Terrain: Rocky or rough terrain can limit emergency landing areas.
  • Authorization Required: Free flight activities in the area are prohibited unless agreed upon and authorized in advance by the property owners based on regulations that are under approval.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Paragliding is prohibited within airport approach and takeoff zones without prior authorization. Any aerial activity in controlled airspace requires coordination with air traffic control authorities.
  • Landing Restrictions: Do not land in unauthorized areas. Landing in areas outside designated spaces can cause conflicts with landowners or harm the environment. Sites without wind indicators should be avoided. Be aware of crowded sites and respect priority rules.
search_recs: Rocca Canavese paragliding official site paragliding Rocca Canavese Italy Rocca Canavese paragliding regulations paragliding clubs near Rocca Canavese

html:
Overview

Trubbio is a beautiful paragliding and hang gliding site located in the Vigezzo Valley, within the Ossola Valley of Italy. Known for its classic alpine scenery and stunning views, Trubbio offers an unforgettable flying experience in the Western Alps. With a substantial altitude difference, it's a popular destination for pilots seeking dynamic and scenic flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable Season: The site is considered suitable for flying in every season of the year.
  • Altitude Difference: Expect altitude differences between 900 and 1300 meters, providing ample opportunity for soaring and cross-country flights.
  • Views: A flight in the Vigezzo Valley is considered an experience because of the great views.

Who Should Fly Here?

Trubbio is a site of medium difficulty, appealing to a range of pilots. The Vigezzo Valley is renowned as one of the best locations in the Western Alps for both paragliding and hang gliding, attracting pilots seeking both scenic beauty and challenging conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Ascent: Access to the Cima Trubbio take-off point from Piana di Vigezzo is possible either on foot or via chairlift (when in operation).
  • Chairlifts: The gliding take-off points in the Vigezzo Valley have the advantage of being served by chairlifts.
  • Cable Car Schedule: Be sure to check the cable car schedule in advance: pianadivigezzo.it/impianti.php.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Awareness: Be vigilant about weather conditions. Strong gusts of wind can cause collapses. Check weather forecasts and use an anemometer to estimate wind strength and direction, especially as Spring conditions can be stronger than autumn conditions.
  • Environmental Hazards: Rocky or rough terrain could limit potential emergency landing areas.
  • Pilot Responsibility: Many accidents stem from pilot errors. Regular practice and continuous learning are crucial. Overconfidence and taking unnecessary risks can also lead to accidents.
  • Cumulus Nimbus Clouds: Avoid flying near Cumulus Nimbus clouds due to the risk of rain, snow, hail, lightning, and strong updrafts.
  • Overflight Restrictions: European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) is working to provide greater clarity and transparency in overflight restrictions at the local level. Restrictions must be published in the Member State's AIP (Aeronautical Information Publication) and a NOTAM (Notice to Airmen) issued.
search_recs: Trubbio paragliding take off Trubbio paragliding official site paragliding Trubbio Italy site information paragliding club Trubbio Italy

html:
Overview

Brosso is a mountain commune nestled in the Turin province of Piedmont, Italy, at an altitude of 797 meters. This popular paragliding site, dominated by Monte Cavallaria (1464m), offers opportunities for both soaring and cross-country (XC) flights amidst the beautiful landscape of the Morainic Amphitheater of Ivrea.

Flying Conditions

  • Season: Flying is most favorable in spring but is also possible in summer and autumn.
  • Takeoff Points: Multiple takeoff points are available at varying altitudes. The primary takeoff and a secondary takeoff at 1291 meters altitude with a 1022 meter height difference. Intermediate takeoffs are available for strong wind conditions.
  • Soaring: Excellent soaring conditions can be found in the evening when the sun shines all day on the upper takeoff. Top landing is possible.
  • Thermals: Thermals are common.

Who Should Fly Here?

Brosso is a suitable paragliding site for a range of pilots. Some sources mention that it is suitable for both training and tandem flights. The site is popular, and it's recommended to check in with local resources for the most current information.

Access & Facilities

  • Shuttle Service: A shuttle bus service is operated by the local club for 8 Euros. Contact information:
    • Monday to Friday: 13:00, 17:00 (additional trips possible with a minimum of 3 passengers)
    • Saturday and Sunday: approximately every hour
    • Gianni (weekends): Tel: 339 8409842
    • Remo (weekdays): Tel: 333 4376212
  • Access Restriction: Unauthorized driving on the alpine road can result in fines starting from 230 Euros.
  • Local Meeting Point: Bar Trattoria 'Al Fojot' at via V.Veneto, 210 - LESSOLO (Tel: 0125 58101, closed on Mondays).
  • Website: Additional information can be found on the website http://www.parapendiocavallaria.it/.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

Paragliding is inherently risky, and pilots must be aware of the potential dangers.

  • General Risks: Pilot error, equipment failure, and sudden changes in weather conditions are significant risks.
  • Takeoff Risks: Prematurely sitting, pendulum effect, collisions during takeoff, and asymmetric rising of the wing can lead to accidents.
  • Airspace: Pilots must understand and respect airspace rules and avoid entering controlled airspace without prior authorization.
  • Regulations: Paragliding activities must comply with the laws of Italy.

Disclaimer: Always check with local paragliding clubs or schools for the most up-to-date information, site briefings, and local regulations before flying at Brosso. On-site briefings from a qualified local pilot are often required.
search_recs: paragliding regulations Brosso Italy paragliding Brosso sito ufficiale paragliding Brosso Italy Brosso paragliding takeoff

html:
Overview

Alpe Giumello, situated in Valsassina near the picturesque Lake Como in Lombardy, Italy, is a popular paragliding destination. Offering stunning mountain views and the serene backdrop of Lake Como, the take-off is located at approximately 1500 meters above sea level. This site is well-established and attracts pilots of all skill levels and nationalities, potentially being used for Paragliding World Cup (PWC) heats.

Flying Conditions

Giumello is known for its excellent ridge soaring and thermaling opportunities, opening the door for exciting cross-country (XC) flights.

  • Takeoff: The wide takeoff area faces southwest.
  • Landing: The easy top landing makes the site accessible to pilots of all levels, depending on the time of day.
  • Potential: Pilots can fly over woods, villages, pastures, and peaks, reaching altitudes over 3000 meters and distances exceeding 50 km.
  • Unflyable Winds: Winds from the North, Northeast, and Northwest directions render the site unflyable.
  • Flying Season: The flying season extends year-round, from January to December.

Who Should Fly Here?

Alpe Giumello is a welcoming site for pilots of all skill levels. The easy top landing makes it accessible, although the suitability for different skill levels can vary depending on the time of day. Pilots come from many countries to enjoy this site.

Access & Facilities

  • Landing Zone: The landing zone is located in Taceno, approximately 30 minutes away from the takeoff by car.
  • Lift Service: A lift service is available to quickly return to the top after landing.
  • Transportation: Some operators, like Flylibell, offer transport from Milan airports (Malpensa or Orio).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Conditions: Be aware of unpredictable weather patterns, including strong winds and sudden changes. Always check forecasts and consult local experts.
  • Pilot Error: Mistakes can contribute to accidents. Ensure you have sufficient training and experience.
  • Landing Accidents: Practice proper landing techniques due to potential misjudgment of wind or obstacles.
  • Airspace: Paragliding is permitted only in Class G airspace.
  • VFR Rules: All standard Visual Flight Rules (VFR) apply in the air.
  • Pilot Certification: According to Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) regulations, a level 4 certification is required for local unsupervised flying, and level 5 for XC flying. Pilots without an IPP card or with a stage below 4 must fly under the supervision of an instructor.
search_recs: Giumello paragliding landing zones Giumello paragliding access fees Giumello paragliding site details Giumello paragliding official information Giumello paragliding difficulty

html:
Overview

Liretta is a paragliding site located in the Maira Valley (Valle Maira) in the Piedmont region of Italy, near Busca and Villar San Costanzo in the province of Cuneo. Takeoff from Colle della Liretta offers panoramic views of the beautiful Maira Valley.

Flying Conditions

Liretta is known for its ridge soaring opportunities and the potential for impressive cross-country flights. South winds are generally favorable for flying at this site.

Who Should Fly Here?

The site is suitable for both single and tandem paragliding flights, making it accessible to a range of pilot skill levels. However, its popularity is moderate, as indicated by its 1-star rating on paragliding maps.

Access & Facilities

Liretta is accessible by car, followed by a short walk to the takeoff area. There is currently no information available regarding any fees associated with using the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Restrictions: The "Liretta" launch is situated very close to LI R64 (Cuneo) restricted airspace. Pilots must be acutely aware of these boundaries and ensure they do not enter this restricted zone.
  • Licensing Requirements: While an IPPI card may suffice for short vacation flights, longer stays and residency might necessitate a local Italian paragliding license. Due to potential changes in Italian paragliding regulations, it's advisable to contact a local flying school to obtain the latest, most accurate licensing information.
search_recs: paragliding Liretta Italy official site information paragliding Liretta Italy site guide Liretta Italy paragliding club paragliding regulations Liretta Italy Liretta Italy paragliding access

html:
Overview

Valcava is a popular paragliding site located in the Lombardy region of Italy, near the Valcava pass and close to Bergamo and Lecco. The takeoff is situated on a ridge approximately 1300m above sea level, part of the ridge extending from Monte Linzone to Monte Resegone. The site offers stunning views overlooking the Po Valley.

Flying Conditions

Valcava is known for its excellent soaring conditions, made possible by the arrangement of the surrounding mountains. The site boasts good cross-country (XC) potential, with ambitious pilots frequently completing flights to Como and back during the summer months. Takeoff directions are South-East, South, and South-West.

Who Should Fly Here?

Valcava is considered an easy and popular site, suitable for pilots of varying experience levels.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The takeoff is accessible by car or via a shuttle service from the landing zone.
  • Landing Zone: Located near the "Latterraggio" restaurant in Caprino Bergamasco.
  • Shuttle Service: The Volo Libre Orobica club provides a shuttle service for pilots and their equipment, operating on Saturdays, Sundays, and public holidays. Contact them for more details.
  • Additional Information: Further details about the site can be found at the Volo Libero Bergamo club website and the Orobica Volo Libre club.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

As with all paragliding sites, certain risks and considerations apply. While general paragliding safety measures are essential, the following points are specific to Valcava:

  • Weather Conditions: Sudden changes in weather can affect flight safety. Checking the weather forecast before flying and using an anemometer to estimate wind strength and direction are strongly recommended. Spring conditions can be much stronger than autumn conditions.
  • Site Environment: Be aware that rocky or rough terrain can limit emergency landing areas.
  • Turbulence and Strong Winds: Flying is not recommended in turbulent or strong wind conditions. Strong gusts of wind can cause pitching mid-flight.
  • Cumulonimbus Clouds: The sight of a cumulonimbus cloud should induce pilots to suspend takeoffs and recall all pilots in flight due to the violent horizontal winds they generate.
  • Takeoff Area: Be aware that the launch area is near antennas.
  • Wind Direction: With winds from the North, North West, and West, it is not recommended to fly. Exercise extreme caution with weak winds from the west.
  • Airspace: Paragliders and Hang-Gliders can fly VFR in GOLF airspace, but must avoid airspaces classified A, B, C, D, E, Prohibited areas (P), Restricted areas (R), and any space within a 5 km radius surrounding controlled aerodromes.
  • Aeronautical Charts: It is crucial to have an up-to-date Italian aeronautical chart if flying cross-country or anywhere other than familiar club sites.

Note: Always prioritize safety and consult with local pilots and clubs for the most current information and advice before flying at Valcava.
search_recs: Valcava paragliding site information paragliding Valcava Italy Valcava paragliding official site Valcava paragliding regulations Valcava paragliding club

html:
Overview

Aviano is one of the oldest paragliding sites in the Friuli Venezia Giulia region of Italy, offering excellent thermaling and cross-country (XC) opportunities. Located in the Carnic Pre-Alps, near the Aviano (PN) flying club, the site presents stunning views of the Friulian plain. However, its proximity to the Aviano Air Base (a NATO base) results in significant flying restrictions and requires strict adherence to regulations.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Aviano is renowned for its beautiful and reliable thermals, making it a favorite for XC enthusiasts.
  • Cross-Country: Cross-country flights are possible in all directions, with the crucial exception of flying towards the Aviano military airport.
  • Flying Days/Times:
    • Flying is generally permitted only from Friday around 13:00 (1 PM), Saturday, and Sunday.
    • Flying is strictly prohibited during NATO operations.
  • Altitude Restrictions:
    • Fridays: Maximum altitude of 150 meters above ground level (AGL).
    • Saturdays and Sundays: Maximum altitude of 300 meters AGL.
    • When MATZ is active: Pilots can fly at a height greater than 1210m (3971ft) AMSL

Who Should Fly Here?

Aviano is considered a site of medium difficulty. It is suitable for pilots with some experience who are comfortable with thermaling. All pilots *must* be fully aware of and willing to comply with the complex and strict restrictions due to the nearby military base. This site is definitely not recommended for casual visitors unfamiliar with the regulations.

Access & Facilities

  • Takeoff: The primary takeoff is from Col del Lovo, at an altitude of 1,100m. Another suitable launch point is near Castaldia, at 1,108 meters altitude. These are large grassy areas allow multiple paragliders to spread out. Access to the takeoff is by car.
  • Membership: Flying from Aviano requires association with the ASD Delta Club Montecavallo (€20/year) or affiliating your membership (€10/year). This is essential for checking if the area is open through direct contact with the Aviano Base.
  • Official Information: Updated information and permission to fly can be obtained from the local club, ASD Montecavallo, and their official website: parapendioaviano.it.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Military Airspace: The most significant risk is the location within a Military Aerodrome Traffic Zone (MATZ) and Controlled Traffic Region (CTR).
  • Strict Compliance Required: Free flight is strictly regulated by a NOTAM (Notice to Airmen) and a Letter of Agreement (LOA) with the Aviano Air Base. Failure to comply can severely compromise safety.
  • Membership is Mandatory: Taking off, landing, or transiting the Montecavallo area requires membership with the Delta Club Montecavallo and being on the authorized pilots list.
  • Southern Boundary: Pilots must *never* fly over the road to the south (Pedemontana SP29, extending from Giais to Case Franzago). This area is strictly forbidden. Pilots must remain North of this limit.
  • Turbulence: The aerology on the Italian (North) side of mountains can be particularly turbulent, and winds can be strong.
  • ENAC Authorization: The free flight zone in Aviano is subject to the annual release of a NOTAM by ENAC (Italian Civil Aviation Authority).
search_recs: Aviano paragliding access fees permits Aviano paragliding official site information paragliding Aviano Italy site details Aviano paragliding flying conditions

html:
Overview

Cà del Monte is a popular paragliding site situated on Monte Penola (687m above sea level) in the Oltrepò Pavese area of Lombardy, Italy. Located in the municipality of Cecima (PV), between the Staffora and Curone valleys in the northern Apennines, it offers picturesque views of the surrounding hills and, on clear days, the Piedmontese/Lombard Alps and the Po Valley. The site is managed by the paragliding club "Le Poiane d'Oltrepo."

Flying Conditions

Cà del Monte is known for its thermaling potential and favorable air currents. The site features two take-off points:

  • Decollo Nuovo (New Take-off): Used with winds from the West/North-West.
  • Decollo Vecchio (Old Take-off): Used with winds from the South-West. This take-off is at approximately 800m above sea level, overlooking the Curone valley.

The landing area is located in Brignano Frascata (Alessandria) at approximately 385m above sea level. In good weather, cross-country flights over the hills are possible. However, the valley's take-off and flying conditions are considered technically challenging.

Who Should Fly Here?

Due to the technical nature of the site, Cà del Monte is better suited for intermediate to experienced pilots.

Access & Facilities

Directions: To reach Cà del Monte, take the A7 Milano-Genova motorway, exit at Casei Gerola, and follow the signs for Voghera. Alternatively, take the A21 Torino-Piacenza motorway, exit at Voghera. GPS coordinates are LAT:44.826413 LON: 9.069557.

  • Accommodation and Dining: The take-off is close to the Cà del Monte farmhouse/resort, which offers accommodation and restaurant services.
  • Real-time Weather: The Le Poiane d'Oltrepo club has installed Holfuy weather stations with cameras at both take-off points. These are accessible via browser or the Holfuy app.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Technical Site: The site is considered technically challenging.
  • Lee Side Conditions: With West or North prevailing winds exceeding 20 km/h at 2000m, pilots may encounter strong, turbulent conditions.
  • Turbulence: The aerology on the Italian side of mountains can be particularly turbulent and the winds strong.
  • West/North-West Takeoff: Landing back at the takeoff ("fare top") from the West/North-West takeoff is strongly discouraged due to potential leeward conditions.
  • Landing Zone (South Wind): If the wind is coming from the South, a field above the official landing zone is used. This landing zone is slightly downhill and not very long, increasing the risk of overshooting.
  • Pilot Discretion: It's crucial to evaluate weather conditions and forecasts prior to flying, as the feasibility of flights is at the discretion of the pilot based on safety considerations.
search_recs: Cà del Monte paragliding site info paragliding Cà del Monte Italy Cà del Monte paragliding official site Cà del Monte volo libero

html:
Overview

Massanera, located near Reggello in the Tuscany region of Italy, offers fantastic thermaling and cross-country (XC) opportunities. Situated on the Pratomagno massif, pilots can enjoy breathtaking views of the rolling Tuscan hills, woods, olive groves, and vineyards while soaring through the skies. This site is a popular destination for pilots looking to experience the dynamics of Tuscany, and the Pratomagno, Casentino, and Chianti regions.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Thermaling and cross-country (XC). Hang gliding is also possible.
  • Seasonality: The flying season typically runs from April to November, contingent on weather conditions. July is noted as a particularly favorable month.
  • Wind Exposure: The Reggello (Massanera) take-off is exposed to winds from the southwest to the north.

Who Should Fly Here?

While the take-off is considered easy, Massanera is generally considered suitable for advanced pilots seeking to experience the unique flying conditions of Tuscany. All pilots should possess the necessary technical expertise to handle the conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The take-off point is accessible by car. Be aware that one access road requires a vehicle with high ground clearance.
  • Local Club: Landings in Reggello and Pian di Scò are managed by the local club "Uccellacci del Pratomagno." They can be contacted for up-to-date information.
  • Contact Information: Website: http://www.uccellacci.com/massanera.htm, Email: info@uccellacci.com.
  • Fees: No specific fees are mentioned, but contacting "Uccellacci del Pratomagno" is recommended to confirm current site usage costs or requirements.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Hazards: Be vigilant for strong gusts of wind and sudden changes in weather conditions. Always check the forecast and use an anemometer to assess wind strength and direction. Spring conditions may be stronger than autumn conditions.
  • Terrain Considerations: Be aware of limited emergency landing options due to rocky or rough terrain in the surrounding area.
  • General Regulations: Flying is permitted from dawn to sunset, only in visual meteorological conditions (VMC) with continuous visual reference to the ground.
  • Airspace: Maintain safe distances from controlled airspace and always adhere to Visual Flight Rules (VFR).
  • Radio: While specific to the Dolomites, it's generally good practice to have a PMR radio dedicated to a local safety channel for communication.
  • Takeoff: The Massanera takeoff, exposed to the West, comfortably accommodates 4-5 wings and offers a potential top landing option.
search_recs: paragliding sites in Italy Massanera Massanera paragliding site information paragliding Massanera Italy Massanera paragliding club Massanera Italy geography Massanera Comune paragliding Massanera paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Tocco da Casauria is a paragliding site nestled in the Abruzzo region of Italy, within the province of Pescara. Situated on a hill in the Pescara river valley, it offers stunning views of Mount Morrone and the Maiella National Park. Characterized by wooded areas and olive groves, the "Raffaello Toro" takeoff provides pilots with access to a diverse landscape and rewarding flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Season: Flying is generally possible from March to October, taking advantage of the most favorable weather conditions.
  • Wind: The site is influenced by sea breezes, which typically arrive in the early afternoon (13:30-14:30). Be aware of the potential for strong and turbulent conditions early in the day, especially during summer. Spring conditions tend to be stronger than those in Autumn.
  • Cross-Country Potential: This site is renowned for its excellent cross-country (XC) flight opportunities. Pilots can aim for Mount Morrone and, for experienced flyers, even the Gran Sasso mountain range.
  • Wind Direction: The site is exposed to winds from the East to North-East.
  • Best Time to Fly: Flying is usually best from late morning until sunset. During hotter summer days, delaying takeoff until the afternoon is recommended to allow the breeze to weaken and stabilize.

Who Should Fly Here?

Tocco da Casauria is considered suitable for pilots of all skill levels, making it a welcoming site for beginners and a challenging playground for experienced XC pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Takeoff Access: The "Raffaello Toro" takeoff is accessible by car, followed by a short, approximately 100-meter uphill walk from the parking area.
  • Road Condition: While the road to the takeoff is not in perfect condition, it's usually accessible by most types of cars.
  • Fees: It is currently unclear if any specific fees are required for using the site. Participation fees may apply for events organized by local paragliding associations.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Variability: Pay close attention to weather forecasts, as sea breezes can create strong and turbulent conditions, especially early in the day during the summer.
  • Mountainous Terrain: The site's location on the slopes of the Morrone mountain range (reaching peaks of 2000m) requires pilots to be aware of potential mountain flying conditions.
  • Limited Landing Options: Be aware that the surrounding terrain may offer limited options for emergency landings.
  • Majella National Park Regulations:
    • The site is located within the Majella National Park, and flying is subject to their regulations.
    • A limited number of pilots (max. 20) are permitted to fly per day to minimize disturbance to wildlife.
    • The park defines areas accessible for free flight, areas with restrictions, and prohibited areas, detailed on a dedicated map ("Carta generale della Zonazione del Parco"). Refer to [www.vololiberotocco.it](http://www.vololiberotocco.it/) and [www.parapendioabruzzo.com](http://www.parapendioabruzzo.com/) for these maps and regulations.
  • Live Tracking: Live tracking is recommended and may be mandatory during competitions. See [http://www.vololiberotocco.it/livetrack24-2/](http://www.vololiberotocco.it/livetrack24-2/) for more information.
search_recs: paragliding club Tocco da Casauria paragliding Tocco da Casauria Italy Tocco da Casauria paragliding official site parapendio Tocco da Casauria Tocco da Casauria landscape volo libero Tocco da Casauria

html:
Overview

Orero is known as one of the best thermal paragliding sites in Liguria, Italy, near Costa di Soglio in the Genoa region. Nestled in a mountainous landscape, Orero offers excellent potential for cross-country (XC) flights, attracting intermediate to advanced pilots seeking challenging and rewarding conditions.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Activity: Orero is renowned for its strong thermal activity, making it a premier site for experienced thermal pilots.
  • XC Potential: The site boasts an average of 55 XC days per year, with many flights exceeding 10 km, showcasing its excellent cross-country capabilities.
  • Wind Considerations: During spring and summer, pilots should be aware of potentially strong and turbulent valley winds.

Who Should Fly Here?

Orero is best suited for intermediate to advanced pilots due to the strong thermal activity and cross-country flying conditions. It is not recommended for beginners or schools.

Access & Facilities

  • Location: The launch point is located at Località Costa di Soglio, 130, 16040 Orero Genoa, Italy.
  • Access Details: Specific details on road conditions and parking are not provided and should be confirmed with local pilots before visiting.
  • Fees: Information on potential fees associated with flying at Orero is not available and should be verified with local pilots or clubs.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Valley Winds: Be cautious of potentially strong and turbulent valley winds, especially during spring and summer.
  • Power Lines: Large power lines are present in the area, requiring careful flight planning and awareness.
  • Radio Communication: Pilots must have an LPD radio on channel 8 to communicate with the airfield in the landing area in case of traffic.
  • Low Altitude Ascent: Immediately after takeoff, if insufficient lift is encountered, immediately turn left and pass the next ridge.
  • Landing Approach: If unable to pass the ridge with adequate altitude, access to the official landing zone will be limited. Alternative fields are available, but caution is advised due to wind conditions and power lines.
search_recs: Orero Italy flying conditions Orero paragliding club paragliding Orero Italy paragliding site Orero official information

html:
Overview

Monfestino is a popular paragliding site located in the Emilia-Romagna region of Italy, near Modena, on the northern edge of the Apennine Mountains. This green oasis offers stunning views from the cities of the plains to the Apennine mountains, starting from the ancient medieval village next to the castle. Known for both soaring and cross-country (XC) flights, Monfestino attracts pilots looking for a rewarding flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable Wind Directions: N, NE, E, SE.
  • Thermal Activity: The area is known to have thermals. Local advice suggests avoiding flying between 12:00 and 15:00 in the summer due to intense thermal activity.
  • Takeoff Areas:
    • East Takeoff (Monfestino 1): An easy, grassy slope. Pilots should pass to the left of the oak tree with the windsock during launch.
    • North Takeoff: Suitable for N, NE winds. This takeoff is short, narrow, and steep, and can be intimidating. Be aware of potential rotor if the wind is from the North or Northeast.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monfestino welcomes pilots of varying skill levels. The main site, Monfestino, is considered easier and more accessible. Monfestino 1, with its East takeoff, is classified as a more challenging site.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Takeoff areas are accessible by car, and also by walking.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Pay close attention to the wind conditions, especially checking the windsock on the antenna at the North takeoff. Rotor is possible with North or Northeast winds.
  • Mountain Weather: Be prepared for variable mountain weather conditions and dress accordingly.
  • North Takeoff Caution: The North takeoff is short, narrow, and steep. Ensure your glider comes up cleanly before committing to launch.
  • General Airspace: Paragliders are permitted to fly in airspaces G and E, adhering to VFR regulations.
  • Radio Requirement (Dolomites): If flying in the Dolomites, pilots must monitor PMR 8-16, the official radio channel for free flight safety in the Dolomites.
  • Rescue Operations (Dolomites): In case of rescue operations in the Dolomites, helicopter rescue teams will broadcast information in English and Italian on PMR 8-16. Pilots are required to vacate the area and suspend takeoffs immediately.
  • Tandem Flight Restrictions: Tandem flights must not carry photo/video equipment or extra objects that could fall and cause damage or hinder piloting.
  • Items to Avoid: Avoid wearing earrings, bracelets, rings, sunglasses with metal frames and non-shatterproof lenses.
  • Pilot Responsibility: Pilots must behave prudently and responsibly, strictly following the directives of the Aeroclub Emilia in Volo staff.
search_recs: Monfestino Italy paragliding access paragliding club Monfestino Italy paragliding Monfestino Italy site information Monfestino paragliding official site Monfestino paragliding difficulty

html:
Overview

Monte Tovo is a paragliding site located in the Valsesia area of the Piedmont region, Italy. Characterized by pre-alpine terrain and offering scenic views of the surrounding mountains, Monte Tovo provides a unique flying experience in Northern Italy.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: The site is suitable for winds from the east to south quadrants, potentially with a gentle northerly wind.
  • Thermals and Soaring: Valsesia offers a range of flight opportunities, from short hops to scenic flights over glaciers, ridges, and pastures.
  • Turbulence: While one source indicates it is difficult to find turbulence, pilots should remain vigilant as mountain flying can be subject to sudden changes in wind and the development of turbulence.

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Tovo is considered suitable for beginners, making it an accessible site for those new to paragliding. Tandem flights are also available. Experienced pilots will also enjoy the varied flying conditions and stunning scenery that Valsesia has to offer.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The take-off area at Monte Tovo is accessible from Quarona, in the hamlet of Doccio.
  • Landing: The designated landing area is in Locality Gabbio, near Doccio. The landing area is near a restaurant, roughly 300 meters from the barrier.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Pilots should always check current weather conditions as severe weather can occur without prior warning.
  • Takeoff Hazards: Pilots should always assess the launch area for hazards such as rocks, trees, or uneven ground. The takeoff elevation is 1252m.
  • Landing Zone Hazards: Pilots should familiarize themselves with the landing area and any potential hazards there, such as the nearby motocross track.
  • Airspace: Pilots should be aware of general airspace restrictions in Italy, especially concerning CTR (Control Traffic Region) or ATZ (Aerodrome Traffic Zone).

Contact Information: For additional information, contact the Parapendio Club Valsesia at Piazza Libertà- 13017 Quarona (VC) or call 347 8003228 / 348 6016288.
search_recs: Monte Tovo paragliding site information paragliding Monte Tovo Italy Monte Tovo paragliding club

html:
Overview

Val della Torre is a paragliding site located near Turin, Italy, in the Piedmont region. With over 30 years of history, it offers pilots the opportunity to experience thermal flying and scenic views of the Turin plain, Superga, and Colle della Maddalena. The take-off point is situated at 1000m, descending to a landing area at 400m.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Val della Torre is known for its thermals, making it an ideal location for pilots taking their first steps in thermal flying. Expect strong thermals during the flying season.
  • Ridge Soaring: Opportunities exist to ridge soar along the slopes of Monte Barone.
  • Cross-Country Potential: The site offers XC potential, with routes towards the valley floor or longer flights along the Piedmont foothills towards Corio.
  • Best Season: The best flying season is from February to November, snow permitting.
  • Unsuitable Conditions: Avoid flying in North-East winds and Föhn winds. Weak west winds can be flown from an alternative take-off behind the main one, but strong west or Föhn winds make flying impossible.

Who Should Fly Here?

Val della Torre is suitable for beginner to intermediate pilots looking to develop their thermal flying and XC skills. Its proximity to Turin makes it a popular choice. Mountain flying experience is recommended, including awareness of strong winds, lee-side turbulence, and rapidly changing weather conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: A rough dirt road provides access to within 50 meters of the take-off. Be aware that this road may not be suitable for regular cars; the remaining distance must be covered on foot.
  • Transport: Some operators charge a small fee for transport to take-off.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Strong Thermals: Be prepared for potentially strong thermals.
  • Mountain Flying: As a mountain site, be prepared for strong winds, lee-side turbulence, and rapidly changing weather conditions.
  • Airspace: Be aware of airspace restrictions in the area and adhere to any limitations.
  • Landing Restrictions: Avoid landings on cultivated land or with livestock. Be polite if you need to deal with landowners.
search_recs: paragliding regulations Val della Torre Italy Volo libero Val della Torre paragliding Val della Torre Italy paragliding club Val della Torre

html:
Overview

Muanda is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Biellese Alps, in the Piedmont region of Italy. The site offers stunning views of the mountainous terrain and presents opportunities for both thermaling and cross-country flights towards the Aosta Valley. Managed and maintained by local paragliding organizations, Muanda is a well-regarded location for pilots seeking accessible and rewarding flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Muanda is flyable in East, Southeast, South, and Southwest wind conditions.
  • Thermals & Cross-Country: The site is known for its thermal activity and cross-country (XC) potential, offering the possibility to fly towards the Aosta Valley. Smaller XC flights are favored.
  • Valley Winds Caution: When flying towards the Aosta Valley, be aware of potentially strong valley winds.

Who Should Fly Here?

Muanda is accessible to pilots of all experience levels due to its easy take-off conditions and multiple launch areas. Whether you're a beginner looking for your first thermals or an experienced pilot aiming for cross-country adventures, Muanda provides a welcoming environment.

Access & Facilities

  • Access Route: From Oropa, follow the Tracciolino road to reach the take-off area.
  • Landmark: Look for a grey sign with a windsock visible above the road to identify the access point.
  • Parking & Private Road: Park on the Tracciolino road as driving on the private road leading to Muanda may result in a fine from the Forestry Corps. A barrier marks the private road.
  • Shuttle Service: A shuttle service is available. Contacting the shuttle is recommended to avoid the inconvenience of car retrieval after the flight.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

While no site-specific risks were identified in the report, standard paragliding risks apply. Pay close attention to weather conditions, wind gusts, and thermal activity. Pilot error, misjudgment of weather, mismanagement of equipment, and overconfidence can all lead to accidents. Remember to regularly check gear and do not fly beyond your skill level.

It is always important to check with local flying clubs or schools for the most up-to-date information, weather conditions, and any site-specific hazards before flying at Muanda.

html:
Overview

The Hirzer paragliding area, nestled in the Passeiertal Valley near Merano, South Tyrol, Italy, is renowned as one of the most captivating flying locations in the Alps. Characterized by stunning Alpine scenery, including forests, meadows, and dramatic rock faces, Hirzer offers unforgettable flights with opportunities for thermal soaring. Access is convenient via the Hirzer cable car, making it a popular choice for both tandem flights and solo adventures.

Flying Conditions

  • Best Time to Fly: Flights are best in the morning to avoid potentially strong valley winds that develop in the afternoon.
  • Launch Sites:
    • Top Station Takeoff: Located a 15-minute walk from the Hirzer cable car's top station (2150m).
    • Middle Station Takeoff: Situated directly at the middle station of the cable car (Prennanger Hotel terrace, 1450m).
    • Klammeben Takeoff: A spacious launch site above Klammeben, accessible via the cable car and a short walk.
    • Taser Alm Refuge Takeoff: Takeoff is at 1,600 m at the Taser Alm Refuge.
  • Wind Conditions: The site is not flyable in North wind conditions. Be aware of the strong tailwind in the valley.
  • Landing Area: The landing site is located next to the "Apfelhotel Torgglerhof", directly on the banks of the Passer river.

Who Should Fly Here?

Hirzer is suitable for pilots of all experience levels. Its accessibility and scenic beauty make it a popular choice for tandem flights, introducing beginners to the joys of paragliding. Experienced pilots will appreciate the opportunities for thermal soaring and cross-country flights amidst the breathtaking Alpine landscape. Saltaus and the Hirzer flying area are also known for their quality among experienced tandem pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: The primary launch sites are accessed via the Hirzer cable car. A cable car ticket is required.
  • Landing Zone: Landing is typically in Saltaus/Saltusio, near the Torgglerhof Hotel, next to the Passer river.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Valley Winds: Be aware of the possibility of strong valley winds developing from midday, potentially making afternoon flights challenging.
  • North Wind Inoperability: The site is not flyable in North wind conditions.
  • Takeoff Considerations: The takeoff from above Klammeben involves stepping down a 10 – 15 m downhill track before lifting off over the edge. Inform the pilot about any previous leg injuries and operations, fractures, including problems with tendons or anything else. This is for your own safety!
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • In Italy, flights outside Class G airspace (1000m AGL) are technically prohibited, but this is often unenforced.
  • Potential Hazards: Be aware of the strong tailwind in the valley. Power lines and a river are in the vicinity of the landing site.
  • Radio Requirement: In the Dolomites, pilots are required to have a separate, license-free PMR radio dedicated to the local safety channel (PMR 8-16). This is to allow rescue helicopters to communicate about ongoing operations. While Hirzer isn't specifically mentioned, it's close enough to the Dolomites that this rule might apply.
search_recs: Hirzer flying site difficulty Hirzer paragliding site information paragliding Hirzer Italy Hirzer Italy paragliding official site

html:
Overview

Ganda is a paragliding site located in the scenic mountains of Italy. Supported by the "Paragliding Club Ali Orobiche parapendio Ganda", it offers a launch point for cross-country (XC) adventures and provides pilots with access to the stunning landscapes of the region.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Primarily suited for cross-country (XC) flights, allowing pilots to explore the surrounding mountainous terrain.
  • Weather Considerations: As with any mountain site, carefully monitoring weather forecasts is crucial. Strong gusts can occur, especially during spring. Anemometers are recommended to assess wind strength and potential turbulence.

Who Should Fly Here?

While specific details on required skill levels are limited, pilots should be aware of mountain flying conditions and potential hazards. Contacting local paragliding clubs is essential to gather first-hand information before launch.

Access & Regulations

Specific details regarding access and associated fees are best obtained by contacting the local paragliding club. A valid FlyCard may be needed to access some areas. It's important to ensure compliance with all Italian paragliding laws, possessing the required VDS qualifications, a valid flying license, and an insurance policy. Flight documents should be readily available for checks.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Related Risks: Strong gusts of wind can cause pitching mid-flight. Always check weather forecasts, especially during spring.
  • Terrain: Be aware of potentially rocky or rough terrain which may limit emergency landing options.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Paragliding is prohibited within airport approach and takeoff zones without prior authorization. Always coordinate with air traffic control authorities.
  • Flying Rules: Adhere to general behaviour rules, overtaking guidelines, and right-of-way protocols. The first pilot to enter a thermal establishes the turning direction, and all others must follow.

Disclaimer: The Monte Farno, Monte Arera, Ganda, Monte Blum and Scanapà are starting points for paragliding in ValSeriana and Val di Scalve.

It is essential to consult with local paragliding clubs or schools in Ganda for the most up-to-date information on site-specific hazards and regulations.

html:
Overview

Kobala is a renowned paragliding site located above the picturesque town of Tolmin in the Soča Valley, Slovenia. Nestled on the southern crest of the Julian Alps, this site offers stunning views of the Soča River and the surrounding mountain landscape. Kobala is known for its excellent cross-country (XC) potential, ridge soaring, and thermaling opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable Wind Directions: East (E), Southeast (SE), Southwest (SW), and West (W).
  • Optimal Conditions: The best conditions for long cross-country flights occur with a very weak general North (N) or East (E) wind. Western winds are more suited for local flying.
  • Flying Season: Typically runs from April to October.
  • Altitude:
    • Maximum allowed altitude: 2900m AMSL.
    • Takeoff altitude: 1080m AMSL.
    • Landing place Tolmin Altitude: 160 m.

Who Should Fly Here?

Kobala is a popular site that hosts paragliding competitions at both European and world levels. It is suitable for:

  • Beginners: In mild conditions (morning or late afternoon).
  • Experienced Pilots: All levels can enjoy Kobala, with moderate take-off and flying difficulty levels.

Note that the site can get busy, especially during the summer months and competition periods.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The takeoff is accessible by a 13.6 km drive from Tolmin via Polijubinj to Lujubinj, right to the take-off area.
  • Parataxi (Shuttle): Available during the summer from the landing place in Tolmin to Kobala, typically starting around 11 a.m.
  • Fees:
    • Take-off and landing fees apply, with day tickets available for 5 EUR.
    • Tickets can be purchased at Camp Gabrje, Kobala center Tolmin, and FlyZone Čiginj.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

Pilots should be aware of the following risks and restrictions:

  • Strong Valley Winds: The Soča Valley is known for strong valley winds, which can create challenging and potentially dangerous flying conditions.
  • Rapidly Intensifying Winds: With general southwesterly winds and thermals, the wind at Kobala can intensify very quickly.
  • Mountain Weather: Always check the weather situation and conditions in the nearby mountains before heading to take-off. The road to Kobala can be icy at the top in April.
  • Steep Takeoff: In strong winds, be careful as the Kobala takeoff is quite steep, and there is a danger of being pulled over the top if you are not able to control your wing.

Flight Restrictions

  • Maximum Altitude: 2900m AMSL.
  • Airspace: Paragliding is only allowed in Class G airspace.
  • Takeoff and Landing Zones: Pilots must use only official, marked takeoff and landing places.
  • Organized Flying: Organized flying outside registered takeoff places is prohibited without prior agreement.
  • Tickets Required: A valid ticket is required to use the takeoff area and landing place, controlled in the season from April 15 to October 31.
  • Official Frequency: Use the official frequency of 147.800 MHz.

Important Safety Information

  • Rescue Services: In case of an accident, call 112. Secure the zone for helicopter operations.
  • Pilot Requirements: According to safety regulations by CAA, level 4 is required for local unsupervised flying and level 5 for XC flying.
  • Environment: Respect the environment, animals, and plants. Do not drive or park on grassland. Take all litter.
search_recs: Kobala paragliding take off paragliding Kobala Slovenia Kobala paragliding site information Kobala paragliding club

html:
Overview

Lijak is a well-known and popular paragliding site in Slovenia, located in the lower Vipava Valley, near the border with Italy. Situated below the Trnovo Plateau, it features a grassy take-off area at the edge of the Trnovski gozd forest. The landing zone is conveniently located in the valley below, near the village of Livešče.

Flying Conditions

Lijak offers excellent flying conditions throughout the year. It's well-suited for ridge soaring, thermaling, and cross-country (XC) flights. In the mornings, gliding flights are common, with thermic flights developing in the afternoons. Evening soaring is enhanced by the sea breeze. The site is a popular starting point for long flights along the southern ridge of the Trnovska plateau up to Nanos (1,313 m).

Who Should Fly Here?

Lijak is suitable for pilots of all skill levels, including beginners. It is often frequented by paragliding schools and students, and tandem flights are readily available. While the takeoff is rated as medium difficulty, the flying conditions are also considered medium difficulty.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The take-off site is accessible by car, approximately 10 minutes from the main road.
  • Parking: A marked parking area is located a short 10-minute walk from the take-off.
  • Fees: Some operators charge a takeoff fee (approximately €30 per week).
  • Shuttle Service: Shuttle rides are available for a fee (approximately €8 per flight). Campsite Park Lijak, near the landing zone, offers parataxi services to the take-off point.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Altitude Limits:
    • 750 m above ground level (AGL) to the South and East.
    • 2900 m above sea level (ASL) to the North.
    • 300m AGL over the valley.
    • Maximum allowed altitude is 2500 ft above ground.
  • Protected Bird Nesting Area: Avoid flying low over the ridge east of the takeoff to protect nesting birds.
  • Ajdovščina Airport: Be aware of the Ajdovščina sports airport in the vicinity, especially when flying cross country.
  • Local Weather & Terrain: Be aware that local weather knowledge and familiarity with the terrain is critical. Unreliable conditions can occur due to climate change, especially from Easterly winds.
  • Airspace Activity: Pilots must be careful of air traffic around the Ajdovščina airport when flying cross country.
  • Airspace Rules: Flying with a paraglider is only allowed under Visual Flight Rules (VFR) and during daylight hours (from half an hour before sunrise until half an hour after sunset).
  • Prior Agreement: All activities such as schooling, tandem flights, competitions, meetings and other commercial activities must take place with the agreement of the POLET Nova Gorica Association.
  • Valid Vignette: Only pilots with a valid vignette, which proves that the pilot is familiar with all the provisions and conditions of the mentioned take-off area, can use the take-off point and landing area.
  • Flight Notification: All paragliders and glider pilots must report the flight with an SMS message to the manager of the Ajdovščina airport.
  • Bird Collisions: Be aware of the risk of bird collisions.
search_recs: Lijak paragliding fees Lijak paragliding site information paragliding Lijak Slovenia Lijak paragliding official site jadralno padalstvo Lijak Lijak paragliding access

html:
Overview

Stol, also known as Kobariški Stol, is a renowned paragliding site situated on a mountain ridge stretching from Kobarid in Slovenia to Gemona in Italy. Located in the picturesque Soča Valley, it offers stunning panoramic views of the Julian Alps and, on clear days, the Adriatic Sea. This site is a favorite among pilots for its excellent thermal conditions and potential for long cross-country flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Primarily thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying.
  • Seasonality: Ideal conditions occur with a very weak general North or Northeast wind for cross-country flights and a weak Southwest wind for local flying.
  • Wind Considerations: Be aware that with a general Southwest wind and thermal activity, the wind can quickly become significantly stronger. Always check weather conditions and NOTAMs before flying.
  • Soaring Opportunities: The ridge spans over 20 km, providing ample opportunities for soaring.
  • Inversion Layer: Stol is often the only take-off above the inversion layer in the Soča Valley, enhancing its appeal for XC flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Stol is a popular site suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding. While the take-off is rated as easy for paragliding and moderate for hang gliding, it is recommended that pilots have a certain level of experience, particularly as the wind can strengthen rapidly. According to safety regulations by CAA, level 4 is required for local unsupervised flying and level 5 for XC flying. Pilots with no IPP card or with IPP stage below 4 can only fly under supervision of the instructor.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the Stol take-off is via a road from Kobarid. The road from the south side (Kobarid – Sedlo - Božca) is approximately 24 km, and from the north side (Kobarid - žaga - Učja - Božca) approximately 28 km.
  • Road Conditions: The road to the take-off is unpaved and bumpy in some places. A terrain vehicle or shuttle is recommended.
  • Shuttle Service: A shuttle bus service is available from the north side.
  • Fees: Take-off and landing fees are required and can be obtained from the Adrenalin paragliding club. Contact them for current pricing.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Limit: The airspace limit in the Soča Valley is 2900m AMSL (Above Mean Sea Level).
  • Mountain Weather: Mountain weather can change rapidly. Pilots unfamiliar with mountain flying should exercise extra caution.
  • Variable Winds: The wind usually intensifies quickly with the general SW wind and thermals. Be prepared for rapidly changing conditions.
  • Rescue Helicopter Procedures: Monitor the 147.800 MHz frequency for rescue helicopter activity. If a rescue helicopter is operating in the area:
    • Land immediately and clear the area.
    • Pack and remove all gear well away from the helicopter's downdraft.
    • Evacuate the operation zone and establish a large security perimeter.
    • Do not take off while the helicopter is operating in the zone.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Paragliding is only allowed in Class G airspace. Flying within CTR (Control Zones) is prohibited.
  • VFR Rules: All standard Visual Flight Rules (VFR) apply.
  • Flying Times: Flying is permitted from 30 minutes before sunrise to 30 minutes after sunset.
  • Permits/Vignettes: Flying in some Slovenian sites requires day or weekly permits/vignettes. Contact the local club for information on permits, costs, and selling points.
  • Organized Flying: Any organized flying must be notified to a club at least 72 hours in advance, including the group leader's name.
  • Commercial Tandem Flying: Commercial tandem flying is not permitted without a special permit from the government.
  • Instructor Authorization: Foreign paragliding instructors need special authorization to perform flight training activities in Slovenia.
search_recs: Slovenia paragliding site regulations Stol paragliding site information Slovenia paragliding Stol Slovenia Stol paragliding take off paragliding club Stol Slovenia

html:
Overview

Saint Hilaire du Touvet, located on the Plateau des Petites Roches in the French Alps near Grenoble, is a world-renowned paragliding site. Situated on the edge of the Chartreuse massif, it boasts a dramatic landscape with high cliffs and a 700-meter vertical drop to the valley of Grésivaudan, offering breathtaking views overlooked by the Dent de Crolles.

Flying Conditions

Saint Hilaire is celebrated for its excellent thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying potential, thanks to its east-facing slopes in the Chartreuse mountains. It also provides opportunities for ridge soaring.

  • Wind Directions: Suitable for winds from South to Southwest. Avoid West winds due to the risk of being downwind of the cliffs.
  • Takeoff Zones: Three main take-off zones: North, East, and South.
  • Season: Active from Spring to Autumn, with ideal conditions for long-distance flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

This popular site attracts paragliders from all over the world. Saint Hilaire is suited for both beginners taking tandem flights with certified instructors and experienced pilots seeking XC opportunities. Tandem flights and courses are readily available.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Take-off areas are accessible by car or via a funicular. The funicular operates from spring to autumn.
  • South Takeoff Access: Park in Saint Hilaire near the tourist office for the South takeoff, which is a short walk away.
  • North & East Takeoffs Access: Located near the funicular arrival station.
  • Landing Zone: Located in Lumbin, with large parking lots behind the landing area.
  • Coupe Icare: The annual free flight festival charges an entry fee on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, but is free from Tuesday to Thursday.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Be cautious of South winds. Spring conditions can be strong, especially near the cliffs.
  • Thermal Conditions: Strong thermal conditions may cause downwind conditions on the last third of the carpet on the North take-off.
  • Turbulence: Unstable atmospheric conditions can generate turbulence. Thermal updrafts can be powerful and unpredictable.
  • Proximity to Cliffs: The site features a 400-meter vertical cliff immediately after takeoff.
  • Oule Waterfall: Be aware of the Oule waterfall, located below the takeoff amidst large limestone cliffs.

Per Takeoff Risks

  • North Takeoff: The carpeted North takeoff can be downwind of thermals blowing in front.
  • South Takeoff: The South takeoff, in grass, may have more of a thermal wind facing it.
  • Décollage du Chalet (parapente): Technical takeoff in strong thermal conditions and strong South to Southwest winds. Landing with paragliders is forbidden on the takeoff area and in the vicinity.

Flight Restrictions

  • Maximum Altitude: Flights must not exceed 3000m due to the proximity of Lyon International Airport.
  • Speed-riding: Permitted on all slopes after resort closure or on specific runs when closed to skiers during agreed slots.
  • Airspace: Be vigilant regarding controlled airspace (EAC) and avoid unauthorized entry.
  • FFVL Registration: Check the French Free Flight Association (FFVL) website for the most recent updates.

html:
Overview

St. Andre-les-Alpes, nestled in the southern French Alps near Lac de Castillon in the Verdon Natural Reserve, is a world-renowned paragliding destination. This picturesque village offers stunning views and exceptional flying conditions, drawing pilots from around the globe. The site lies within the protected Geological Nature Reserve of Haute-Provence.

Flying Conditions

St. Andre is celebrated for its excellent cross-country (XC) flying potential. Key characteristics include:

  • Type of Flying: Renowned for cross-country (XC) flights, with reliable thermals, valley wind convergences, and interconnected ridges. Suitable for both learning and advanced XC flying.
  • Seasonality: Blessed with reliable weather throughout the paragliding season, with September being a particularly favorable month due to long days and plentiful sunshine.
  • Launch Points:
    • Mont Chalvet: The main launch site features south-east and south-west facing take-offs. Use the south-east launch early in the day and switch to the south-west as the valley wind picks up.
  • Weather Considerations:
    • Valley Wind Circulation: Understanding valley wind circulation is crucial for safety.
    • South-West Launch: Can become unusable in the early afternoon when the valley wind combines with thermals.
    • Switching Valley Winds: Be cautious of rapidly changing valley winds in the landing area.
    • Mistral Wind: Northwest winds (Mistral) can be delicate and turbulent.

Who Should Fly Here?

St. Andre caters to a wide range of pilots:

  • While suitable for beginners under instruction, the site's primary appeal lies in its XC potential.
  • Ideal for experienced pilots seeking long-distance flights. It is recommended for pilots who have already completed one or more XC trips.

The site is very popular and has hosted numerous European and international competitions, including FAI Cat 1 events and the Paragliding World Cup.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: A tarmac road leads to the take-off, although it can be narrow and potentially snowed in from December to March. Car parking is available.
  • Uplift: Shuttle services are available from mid-June to mid-September, organized by the local paragliding club (ASAVL). Taxi services also provide shuttle runs.
  • Fees: Since it is not a free-flying site, pilots should contact Aerogliss and understand the usage agreement before flying.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

Pilots should be aware of the following potential risks and restrictions:

  • Thermic Turbulence: Strong thermals can create significant turbulence, especially in the summer afternoons.
  • Valley Winds: Valley winds in the landing area can switch direction rapidly.
  • Mistral Wind: The NW wind (Mistral) can be delicate but turbulent.
  • South-West/West Takeoff (Le Chalvet): Can become dangerous due to strong winds, especially after midday.
  • South/South-East Takeoff (Le Chalvet): Be aware of the breeze changing from South to South-West in late morning, which can create turbulence on the west side.
  • Contact Aérogliss: All visiting pilots are required to contact Aérogliss before flying as it is managed jointly by the Association St Andréeenne Free Flight and the paragliding school Aérogliss.
  • Commercial Authorisation: Any commercial activity is subject to authorization (+33 (0)4 92 89 11 30).
  • Landing Restrictions:
    • Use only the 3 official landing areas.
    • Beach landings on the lake are strictly prohibited from 15th June to 31st August.
    • Do not land in campsites from 15th June to 31st August.
    • Avoid landing in fields, especially during cultivation or when animals are present.
search_recs: St. Andre les Alpes paragliding popularity paragliding St. Andre France site description St. Andre les Alpes paragliding official site information St. Andre les Alpes paragliding access and fees

html:
Overview

Planfait, nestled near Annecy in the Haute-Savoie region of France, is a renowned paragliding site offering breathtaking views over Lake Annecy and the bay of Talloires. Situated in a forest on the edge of a cliff, approximately 400 meters above the Perroix landing area, Planfait provides an unforgettable flying experience amidst a stunning landscape of mountains and lake.

Flying Conditions

  • Take-off Orientation: NW/W/SW.
  • Wind Conditions:
    • Best flown with light winds from the north to southwest.
    • Northeasterly to southerly winds can make the site turbulent and potentially dangerous.
    • Valley breezes often dominate, allowing flying in various wind directions.
    • Pilots should be cautious of specific conditions like northeast winds, which can cause turbulence.
  • Thermal Flying: Known for its thermal flying and cross-country (XC) potential. The "Grand Tour du Lac" is a classic XC route.
  • Season: Generally possible from April to September, earlier in the year compared to Col de la Forclaz.

Who Should Fly Here?

Planfait can be very busy, especially during peak season. The take-off is considered relatively easy under appropriate conditions, suitable for beginners under appropriate conditions. However, the ease of access and traffic can be deceptive. Pilots with low airspeed can be surprised by thermals or the cliffside location during take-off. In strong winds or with a south or northeast wind, the site is not recommended for beginners. It's better suited for intermediate and advanced pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easily accessible by car, about 15 minutes from Vérel, following signs for "AcroAventure".
  • Parking: There is a car park, which may have a fee during the summer.
  • Eco-Shuttle: A free eco-shuttle operates in the summer (July-September).
  • Hiking: A path from the landing area provides access on foot (approx. 35 minutes).
  • Montmin Take-off: The Montmin take-off site has regulated & paying access for cars (except for people with reduced mobility). An access card can be obtained from the Talloires Town Hall for a nominal charge, which is rechargeable.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions:
    • Northeast Wind: Can create very turbulent or dangerous flying conditions. Fly in the morning until 12 PM or 1 PM in these conditions.
    • East Wind: Pilots need to be careful when ascending to the Dents de Lanfon and the Col des Frêtes, as they are more exposed to stronger turbulence at that altitude.
    • South Wind: Watch the lake for increasing wind.
  • Lake Breeze: Avoid taking off from Planfait after 1:30 PM in summer when the breeze is well established.
  • Site Congestion: Respect flight rules and be careful during takeoff and landing.
  • Turbulence: Be aware of turbulence, especially when thermals trigger near the cliff-side takeoff.
  • Proximity to Relief: The takeoff is located on a cliff.
  • Takeoff: The takeoff is considered easy, with a naturally sloping area. However, pilots flying at low speed can be surprised during their takeoff phase due to a natural right-angle break or thermals triggering just outside the takeoff area. In crosswinds the takeoff is difficult.
  • No-Fly Zones: Flying over houses to the south of the landing area is prohibited.
  • Minimum Altitude: Maintain a minimum altitude of 300 meters above dwellings to comply with local laws.
  • Landing Area Rules: Respect the landing direction (PTU left-hand over the ZA).
  • Folding Area: Respect the area dedicated to folding sails.
  • Terrain: Do not cross meadows to reach car parks or restaurants.
  • Structures professionnelles: Professional structures not installed on Perroix cannot come to Planfait to perform tandem flights when the flight conditions do not allow takeoffs in Montmin.
  • Navettes: Structures installed on Perroix organize themselves to limit to 3 shuttles every 20 minutes (i.e. 9 shuttles maximum per hour) accessing the site in order to ensure fluidity on the roads and on the site. This limitation is global and not a limitation per structure.
