html:
Overview

Gourdon is a popular paragliding site located in the Alpes-Maritimes department of southeastern France, near the Gorges du Loup. Just 28 km inland from Cannes on the French Riviera, this site offers breathtaking views of the coastline from the Esterel mountains to the Cap of Nice. With its southeast-facing take-offs and thermal-rich environment, Gourdon is a favorite among pilots seeking cross-country adventures.

Flying Conditions

  • Take-Off Orientation:
    • The site features two straightforward southeast-facing take-offs situated on a rugged ridge above the village.
  • Thermal Activity:
    • Gourdon is renowned as a thermal flying site, making cross-country (XC) flights possible throughout the year. Flights up to 170 km have been recorded.
    • The proximity to the sea ensures thermic conditions, even when inland hills are snowbound. The sea breeze typically kicks in around midday, enhancing soaring opportunities.
  • Altitude Limit:
    • The maximum flight altitude is FL65 (2000 meters) under Nice 13 (class D) airspace.

Who Should Fly Here?

Gourdon is considered an easy site, making it accessible to a wide range of pilots. However, its popularity means it can get busy, especially on weekends. The flying level at the Embarnier take-off can be high, with test pilots present. Pilots should not assume it's safe for them just because others are flying.

Access & Facilities

  • Take-Off Access:
    • The upper launch site is accessible by car, followed by a short 10-minute walk.
    • The road to the lower take-off requires a car with good ground clearance.
  • Parking:
    • Parking is available near the take-off area.
  • Landing Zones:
    • There are no official landing agreements, and pilots are tolerated in the landing zones.
    • Landing is not authorized when the ground is snow-covered.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Landing Challenges:
    • The landing area at Gourdon - Saint Ambroise is described as small and technical.
    • Thermals can trigger in the landing area, making the approach challenging.
  • Kennedy Takeoff:
    • Be aware of danger from North and North-West winds.
    • The launch has small stones on which lines can snag, typical of the area (no mats).
  • Airspace:
    • Flights are conducted under Nice TMA (Terminal Management Area) FL65 (6500 feet), a significant restriction.
  • Landing Restrictions:
    • During events, landing between Gourdon village and the official Valettes landing zone is forbidden and penalized.
    • No landing is authorized if the ground is snowy (access for rescue becomes impossible). Mini wings are forbidden at the landing.
  • Respect for Locals:
    • Pilots must respect local residents and landowners and apologize if landing on private property.
search_recs: Gourdon paragliding difficulty Gourdon paragliding site access fees paragliding site Gourdon France Gourdon paragliding site official information

html:
Overview

Treh, also known as Le Treh or Treh Markstein, is a popular paragliding and hang gliding site nestled in the Vosges mountains of France, near Le Markstein. Overlooking the scenic Alsatian Sankt Amarin valley, this site offers a blend of thermal flying and cross-country potential, making it a favorite among pilots of varying skill levels. Located within a Natura 2000 protected area, it boasts grassy stubble fields and stunning views.

Flying Conditions

  • Takeoff Directions: The site features two distinct takeoff points:
    • South-facing: Caters to southerly wind conditions.
    • West-North-West facing: Suitable for winds from the West-North-West.
    • Takeoff points are approximately 150m apart and not visible from each other.
  • Wind Speed: Flying is not recommended when winds exceed 25 km/h. Northerly winds are reported to create less pleasant air masses.
  • Thermals: Known for thermal activity, offering good potential for cross-country (XC) flights for experienced pilots. Be cautious during takeoff of downdrafts.
  • Top Landing: A large, slightly curved grassy area provides space for top landing; however, pilots are asked to minimize trampling to protect the area.

Who Should Fly Here?

Treh is a versatile site welcoming pilots of all levels, from beginners to seasoned cross-country enthusiasts. Paragliding schools and professional tandem pilots frequently use the site. While considered easy, caution is advised in strong thermal conditions due to risk of downdrafts.

Access & Facilities

  • Directions: From Fellering/Oderen, follow the road through the valley to the lake and turn right towards the Route des Crêtes.
  • Location: The take-off is situated on the "chaumes" (high-altitude pasture) above the road, near the Treh farmhouse inn.
  • Parking:
    • Roadside asphalt parking is available.
    • A dirt parking area ascends towards the "chaumes." Parking is compulsory on the left-hand side before the "Canadian pass" (cattle grid).
    • Driving and parking are prohibited beyond the "Canadian pass."
    • Keep the maneuvering area before the barrier clear for emergency services.
  • Walk to Takeoff: Expect a 10-minute walk from the parking to the takeoff area.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Be aware of potential turbulence, especially when winds exceed 25 km/h or with northerly winds.
  • Downdrafts: During thermal activity, be cautious during takeoff as you may encounter downdrafts from an upstream thermal.
  • Sensitive Area: The takeoff area is located on stubble fields within a sensitive Natura 2000 area.
  • Crowded Site: The site can be very busy, especially on Sundays and holidays.
  • Takeoff Restrictions: Taking off from the sail preparation area is prohibited for safety reasons.
  • Landing Restrictions: The valley in front of the site is off-limits for landings.
  • Trampling Restrictions: Inflation and folding on the "dome" is prohibited (only resting is tolerated). Avoid trampling forage stubble; stay as close as possible to the footpath.
  • Temporary Flight Restrictions: Temporary flight restrictions may be in place during events such as the Tour de France.
search_recs: Treh paragliding site description FFVL Treh paragliding paragliding site Treh FR paragliding Treh France vol libre Treh

html:
Overview

Planpraz, located on the north side of the Chamonix Valley in France, is one of the most popular paragliding sites in the area. Situated near the city center at the Brévent resort, it offers stunning views of the Mont Blanc range and the Mer de Glace glacier. This site is registered with the FFVL (Fédération Française de Vol Libre) and caters to a wide range of pilot experience levels.

Flying Conditions

  • Planpraz is known for its thermaling and cross-country (XC) potential.
  • The site features two take-off areas in close proximity: one south-facing and the other north-easterly.
  • Flying is typically best from 08:00 to early afternoon, as winds can become too strong later in the day.
  • Be cautious of west and north winds above 20 km/h at 2000m, which can create turbulent conditions.
  • Horizontal cables connect the cable car between the Brévent and La Flégère stations in the Lachenal combe at approximately 1700 m altitude, posing a hazard for cross-country flights to La Flégère.

Who Should Fly Here?

Planpraz welcomes pilots ranging from supervised beginners to experienced cross-country (XC) enthusiasts. During the summer, the site can be very busy with local schools and clubs, so be prepared for potential traffic.

Access & Facilities

  • Access to Planpraz is via the Planpraz gondola. A one-way ticket costs €10.50, but reduced day rates may be available in the summer.
  • The Planpraz gondola is included in the MONT BLANC Multipass, Mont Blanc Unlimited pass, and Chamonix Le Pass.
  • From the gondola station, it's a 10-minute walk uphill to the launch site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Cable Car Cables: The most significant hazard is the Brévent cable car cables located southwest of the main takeoff. Move well to the right after launch to pass safely under the cables.
  • Thermal Conditions: The site can become quite thermic, requiring experience. Beginners should fly early when conditions are calmer.
  • Wind Conditions: Be cautious of west and north winds above 20 km/h at 2000m, as these can create downwind and turbulent conditions.
  • Turbulence: Once the wind develops on the south takeoff, the corridor northeast of the Planpraz restaurant and the "ENSA" corridor below Le Brévent can become turbulent.
  • Cable Car to La Flégère: Be aware of horizontal cables linking the cable car between the Brévent and La Flégère stations in the Lachenal combe at around 1700m altitude for cross-country flights towards La Flégère.
  • Busy Takeoff: Planpraz is very busy with tandem operations, especially between ten past the hour and half past the hour. Consider taking off during quieter periods (H+30 to H+10).
  • Mountain Flying Conditions: Deep narrows glacier valleys surrounded by high peaks create challenging flying conditions. Strong thermic contrasts, expansive ascending airflows can result in extremely strong and rough turbulences. It is generally not recommended to fly in this area with altitude winds stronger than 20km/hour at 2000m, resulting in very technical conditions to fly under.
  • North/North-East Takeoff: Once the wind picks up on the south takeoff, the north/north-east takeoff and its exit can become increasingly downwind and turbulent. Note that the north-east takeoff is a ski piste in winter and is forbidden for paragliding when in use.

Flight Restrictions

  • Landing Restrictions: Landings at Le Bouchet and Le Savoy are prohibited by municipal decree when the alpine and cross-country ski trails are open. During these periods, you must land on the delta terrain of the Bois du Bouchet, which is known to be turbulent and enclosed.
  • Aiguilles Rouges Nature Reserve: Overflight of the Aiguilles Rouges nature reserve is prohibited at less than 1000m above ground level beyond the summit ridge west/northwest.
  • Mini Wings: Mini wings are currently forbidden from landing at Clos du Savoy by Mayoral order.
  • July/August Restrictions: Free flying in the Chamonix valley is restricted from July 1st to August 31st by ministerial decree.
  • Event Specific Restrictions: Always check for any special rules affecting the landing fields as they may occasionally be used for civic functions. Renseignez-vous sur les arrêtés municipaux possibles posés lorsque les terrains de Chamonix sont utilisés pour des évènements ponctuels.

Always check the notice boards at the take-off and landing areas for the most up-to-date information, which is generally available in French and increasingly in English.
search_recs: Planpraz paragliding access and fees Planpraz paragliding official site information paragliding Planpraz France site review Planpraz paragliding site regulations

html:
Overview

Puy Aillaud, nestled in the Pays des Écrins region of the Hautes-Alpes, France, serves as a stunning gateway to the Écrins massif. This popular site, recognized by the FFVL (Fédération Française de Vol Libre), offers exceptional thermaling and cross-country (XC) opportunities with breathtaking views of the surrounding mountains.

Flying Conditions

  • Orientation: Southeast-facing, making it ideal for morning and early afternoon flights.
  • Thermals: Thermals can develop early in the season, around 9:30 AM. The Vallouise valley benefits from moderate breezes, aiding in thermal development and making it suitable for learning thermal flying.
  • Wind Considerations: Generally well-protected from Northwest winds by the Écrins massif. Be cautious of strong westerly, northerly, and easterly winds. West flows often return in the evening via the Bans (right crosswind to the landing site) and always from the north.
  • Season: Open for flying from July 1st to October 31st. Flying is prohibited from November 1st to April 30th. From May 1st to June 30th, take-off from certain summits is allowed with specific routes.
  • Cross-Country Potential: A popular starting point for cross-country flights in the Écrins and Durance valleys, offering access to peaks like the Barre des Écrins (4000m).

Who Should Fly Here?

Puy Aillaud caters to a wide range of experience levels. Beginners are advised to fly in the morning before 11 AM when conditions are calmer. Experienced pilots can enjoy flights later in the day when thermals are more established. The FFVL recommends a "green level" (IPPI 3, beginner). However, be aware that the take-off is considered challenging due to its rocky surroundings.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Reachable by car, followed by a 15-minute walk from the parking area at the top of the village. Alternatively, a marked trail leads from Vallouise church, taking approximately 1 hour.
  • Landing Area: The designated landing area is farmland. Ensure you only land in the official area, pack your gear, and exit via the campsite.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Mountain Flying: Mountain flights demand strong piloting skills, understanding of aerology, and adequate margins for error. Be prepared for strong aerology, even in seemingly good conditions.
  • Launch Area: The launch site is challenging, surrounded by rocks, and offers limited protection from northerly winds. North winds just above the south-facing takeoff can cause shears in the paraglider. Beware of minor turbulence from the rows of trees near the launch.
  • Ecrins National Park Regulations: Adhere to the regulations concerning paragliding within the Ecrins National Park, particularly regarding seasonal access.
  • Lauvitel Integral Reserve: Flights are prohibited above the Lauvitel Integral Reserve year-round.
  • Landing: Avoid landing and walking in the field outside the designated area. Landing in the village may be downwind; proceed with caution. The safest aerology for landing is at the new takeoff, but landing there is technical and should only be attempted by experienced pilots.
  • Dangerous Areas:
    • West Faces (Tête d'Amont to la Condamine): Downwind when the breeze is strong. Fly at a high altitude.
    • Entraygues Valley: Narrow and windy with no comfortable landing options.
    • Fournel Valley (Crossing between Puy-Saint-Vincent and Fressinières): Should be crossed at a high altitude to avoid landing in this narrow, turbulent valley (for cross-country pilots only).
search_recs: Puy Aillaud paragliding site details paragliding Puy Aillaud France Puy Aillaud site FFVL

html:
Overview

Plaine Joux, located in Passy, Haute-Savoie, France, offers stunning views of Mont Blanc from its south-facing plateau at 1360m. This popular site is officially registered with the FFVL (Fédération Française de Vol Libre) and welcomes both paragliding and hang gliding enthusiasts.

Flying Conditions

  • General: Known for its favorable slope breeze conditions and afternoon thermal activity, making it suitable for flying year-round.
  • Thermals: A popular site for thermal flying with cross-country (XC) potential.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • Well-protected from north winds.
    • Flying is not recommended in strong westerly winds due to turbulence.
    • Pilots should always check the Foehn forecast before flying.

Who Should Fly Here?

Plaine Joux caters to a wide range of skill levels, from supervised beginners to experienced cross-country pilots. Be aware that the site can get crowded, especially during peak season.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easily accessible by car with a large car park at the Plaine Joux station.
  • Fees: Access to the site is free.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Foehn Wind: Be cautious of Foehn winds, which can create very turbulent conditions. Avoid flying if the Foehn is not between -4 hPa and +4 hPa. The valleys most exposed to Foehn winds in the Mont Blanc region are Chamonix and Les Contamines.
  • Turbulence: The region's geography, with narrow glacial valleys and high mountains, creates unusual aerological conditions. Strong thermal contrasts can cause powerful and turbulent thermals.
  • Crowd Awareness: Plaine Joux is a popular site, which can lead to congestion in the air and on the ground. Pay close attention to flight priorities and right-of-way rules.
  • West Winds: Flying is not recommended in strong westerly winds, as landing can be difficult, and conditions may become very turbulent.
  • Terrain: Be mindful of the terrain you are flying over, as landing in forests or scree slopes can present additional hazards.
  • Nature Reserve: The cliff located to the north of the takeoff, from Pointe de Platé eastward, is a classified Nature Reserve. Overflying this area at less than 300 meters above the ground is prohibited.
  • Chamonix/Mont Blanc Restrictions: If flying towards Chamonix/Mont Blanc, observe flight restrictions regarding take-off, landing, and overflight.
  • Hang Glider Landing: Hang gliders must land at the Marlioz landing site.
  • July/August Restrictions: Free flying in the Chamonix valley is restricted from July 1st to August 31st by ministerial decree.
  • Airspace: General restrictions apply in the area LF-R30 A and B that have been modified. Also a Temporary Regulation Zone ZRT 30 C has been created, active H24 from June 1st to October 15th.
search_recs: Plaine Joux paragliding flying characteristics Plaine Joux paragliding site France Plaine Joux paragliding official website Plaine Joux paragliding access fees

html:
Overview

Mont Lachat is a renowned paragliding site located in Le Grand-Bornand, Haute-Savoie, France, approximately 30 km east of Annecy. The primary take-off is situated at the summit of Mont Lachat, the highest point of the ski resort, at an altitude of approximately 2100 meters. From here, pilots can enjoy breathtaking views of the Bargy massif to the East, the Aravis mountain range to the West, and even Mont Blanc in the distance.

Flying Conditions

Mont Lachat is celebrated for its thermal flying and cross-country (XC) potential, making it a popular choice year-round. The primary take-off orientation is West-South-West, ideal for catching the valley breeze, with a secondary take-off option to the North-East.

  • Type of Flying: Thermal and Cross-Country (XC)
  • Seasonality: Year-round, with excellent XC opportunities from April through summer.
  • Favorable Wind Directions: Northeast and Southwest.
  • Unfavorable Wind Directions: North, East, Southeast, South, West, and Northwest (beware of potential lee-side conditions and turbulence).

Who Should Fly Here?

This site caters to a wide range of pilots, from beginners honing their thermal skills to experienced XC pilots seeking challenging flights. It is considered a relatively safe location for learning to thermal. It is recommended that pilots be at least "blue level" (IPPI 4, autonomous).

Access & Facilities

Access to the take-off is primarily via the Rosay gondola and then the Lachat chairlift. Alternatively, a 90-minute hike from the Potais landing area in the Bouchet valley is also possible. In winter, access is mainly for skiers or paragliders using the lifts.

  • Lift Access: Rosay gondola and Lachat chairlift.
  • Hiking Option: 90-minute hike from the Potais landing area.
  • Fees: A special paragliding day pass for the lifts costs 16.40 EUR.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

Pilots need to be aware of several risks and restrictions to ensure a safe flight:

  • Winter Restrictions: Snowkiting, speed-riding, speed-flying, paragliding, and hang gliding are strictly prohibited on ski slopes. "Soaring" above the slopes or ski facilities is also not allowed.
  • Proximity to Ski Lifts: Maintain a safe distance from ski lifts; overflight and navigation within 50 meters of the ski lifts are prohibited.
  • Mont Blanc Restrictions: Be mindful of regulated zones (LF-R30 A and LF-R30 B) near Mont Blanc, which protect helicopter rescue operations. Do not enter these zones unless 1000m above ground level and above FL 115 (3500m). Zone LF R 30 B has temporary no-go zone during July and August, which includes the area from the lower tip of Tricot to the collar of Mont-Lachat, and from Mont-Lachat Pass to Petit Béchard.
  • Local By-Laws: Always consult local by-laws for specific regulations.
  • Takeoff Area Usage: In winter, the area located right next to the avalanche barriers is reserved for those professionals.
  • Wind Conditions: Best performance in SW. Danger with a northerly tailwind. Rolls to the right of the deco in a WNW wind. Rolls to the left of the deco below Parmelan on a S'ly wind.
  • Landing Zones: Use only designated landing zones.
  • "Soaring" Restrictions: Soaring is prohibited within 50 meters of the takeoff area or over open ski slopes.
  • Restricted Activities: It is forbidden to rest on the summit, and soaring below 50m/ground is strictly forbidden during winter.
search_recs: Mont Lachat paragliding access Mont Lachat paragliding site guide paragliding Mont Lachat France FFVL Mont Lachat parapente Mont Lachat France

html:
Overview

Samoëns, nestled in the Savoy Alps of France's Haut-Giffre region, is a popular paragliding destination known for its stunning views of the Mont Blanc mountain range. Situated at 699m altitude, the village offers excellent thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying opportunities for both paragliding and hang gliding enthusiasts. With multiple take-off points and a vibrant paragliding community, Samoëns provides an unforgettable flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: The site is suitable for flying with winds from East (E), Southeast (SE), West (W), and Northwest (NW).
  • Thermals & XC Potential: Samoëns is renowned for its thermaling capabilities, allowing pilots to undertake cross-country flights towards areas such as Plateau des Saix or west towards Mieussy.
  • Take-off Points:
    • Les Saix: Accessible via the Grand Massif Express (GME) or Vercland lifts, located 900-1000m above Samoëns.
    • La Bourgeoise: Offers spectacular views of the valley and surrounding mountains and is typically flyable from May to December, depending on snow conditions.
  • Daily Flyability: Good flying conditions allow for all-day flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Samoëns is rated as a medium difficulty site, making it suitable for a range of pilots. Tandem flights are a popular option, welcoming participants of all ages (from 4 or 5 years old) without prior experience. Discovery flights are also available for first-time paragliders. Pilots should be aware of priority rules at crowded sites.

Access & Facilities

  • Lift Access: The primary take-off at Plateau des Saix can be reached via the Grand Massif Express (GME) or Vercland lifts. A lift ticket costs approximately €10 per day for unlimited access.
  • Alternative Access: Driving by car to the takeoff location with a short walk or using the path along the pool is also possible.
  • Landing Zone: The designated paragliding landing zone is located by Samoëns' municipal swimming pool.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Be aware of potential turbulence, especially during moderate to strong valley breezes.
  • Valley Breeze: Strong valley breezes can complicate landings, particularly in the afternoon. Pilots are advised to use the Bois du Bouchet landing if valley breezes are strong.
  • Les Saix Takeoff: With favorable conditions by North wind, breeze regime, low thermal activity and restitution. Danger of rollers by West wind.
  • Landing Zones:
    • Chedde/La Frasse: The official landing site is near the factory under the viaduct.
    • Surrounding Fields: Landing in the surrounding fields is permitted, but be mindful of cattle and light electric fences during spring and summer.
  • Winter Landing: During winter, use only the hang gliding landing site.
  • Summer Landing: In summer, paragliders can use the Savoy and Bois du Bouchet landing sites. Hang gliders can only land at the designated hang gliding landing or fly out of the valley to the Batistock landing field.
  • PTU: Respect the PTU (Point de Tour Utile - Useful Turning Point) on the south side.
  • Information Signs: Always read the information signs for the latest updates and guidelines.
search_recs: Samoens paragliding access fees paragliding Samoens flying conditions paragliding Samoens France site review Samoens paragliding official site info FFVL Samoens site Samoens paragliding site regulations

html:
Overview

Millau, nestled in the Aveyron department of southern France within the Grands Causses Regional Natural Park, is a renowned paragliding destination. This stunning area, characterized by the Grands Causses limestone plateaus, the Tarn River valley, and the Gorges du Tarn and Dourbie, offers panoramic views including the iconic Millau Viaduct. With several official take-off sites, Millau attracts pilots of all skill levels seeking unforgettable free flight experiences.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Millau is celebrated for its thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying opportunities, along with scenic flights. Ridge soaring is also possible depending on the specific site and wind conditions.
  • Best Time to Fly: The optimal flying season generally spans from April to September, although flying is feasible year-round, weather permitting.
  • Wind Considerations: The sites around Millau can accommodate various wind directions. However, it's crucial to be aware that westerly and southeasterly winds can create turbulent conditions.
    • Pouncho d'Agast: Popular, but can be turbulent in strong winds.
    • Pic d'Andan: A good alternative when winds are too strong at Pouncho.

Who Should Fly Here?

Millau is a popular site for both experienced pilots and beginners, offering a diverse range of flying opportunities. Tandem flights are readily available, and paragliding schools in the area cater to all skill levels. The Brunas site is even rated as "easy," making it accessible for newer pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Take-off sites are generally accessible by car or shuttle services.
  • Site Locations:
    • Pouncho d'Agast and Brunas: Approximately 20 minutes from Millau.
    • Pic d'Andan: Requires a 4x4 vehicle for access.
  • Fees: Liability insurance is mandatory for flying, typically obtained through a license with the FFVL (Fédération Française de Vol Libre). Some operators may include access to take-off sites and equipment in their service fees.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Be aware of potential turbulence, especially with west and southeast winds at Millau Plage. The Novis site is known for strong winds and thermals.
  • Crop Landings: Exercise caution to avoid landing on crops, particularly at the Millau Plage landing zone.
  • Novis Specifics:
    • Avoid landing at the top of the field to respect farmers' access.
    • Do not park at the entrance of the field above the launch.
    • Smoking or making fires is strictly prohibited due to past fire incidents.
  • General Vol Libre Regulations: Ensure compliance with local paragliding regulations and maintain liability insurance. Parental authorization is required for minor pilots.
  • Respect Displayed Rules: Always adhere to rules displayed on take-off panels.
search_recs: Millau paragliding difficulty Millau paragliding access fees paragliding Millau France Millau paragliding site information official Millau paragliding site description parapente Millau France infos officielles Millau paragliding terrain

html:
Overview

Chabre, located in the French Alps near Laragne-Montéglin, is an internationally recognized and popular paragliding site known for its exceptional aerology and abundant sunshine. The diverse landscape, featuring semi-flat land, medium-altitude mountains, and proximity to the higher Alps, makes it ideal for free flight. Chabre is famous for ridge soaring, thermaling, and offers enormous potential for cross-country (XC) flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable for most wind directions.
  • Known for ridge soaring and thermaling.
  • Excellent potential for cross-country (XC) flights with records broken on round-trip distances and triangular routes.
  • Expect strong thermal conditions, especially in mid-summer.
  • Consistent weather with high cloud bases; possible to fly 200+ km flights and reach altitudes over 4000m on good days.

Who Should Fly Here?

Chabre is suitable for pilots of all experience levels, from aspiring cross-country pilots to experienced XC pilots. While accessible to all, pilots should be aware that summer afternoons can bring strong winds and turbulent thermals.

Access & Facilities

  • The ridge is easily accessible via a paved forest road (except for the last kilometer to the summit).
  • Numerous roads cross the valleys, facilitating pilot recovery.
  • Access to the site itself is free.
  • Note that events like the Ozone Chabre Open may have entry fees.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Dust Devils: Be aware of dust devils, especially when a northerly wind trend clashes with a southerly breeze. They can be very violent.
  • Turbulence: Rough, turbulent thermals can be triggered off the rocky slopes below the take-off, particularly in the summer with N-/NW- wind (after approximately 1300).
  • Strong Winds: During summer afternoons, the wind might be too strong for take-off. The Mistral wind can also halt flying when sufficiently strong. North winds can become very strong quickly and often turn West in the evening, creating turbulence.
  • Chabre Nord Takeoff: With a North-West wind, the paragliding launch can be in the lee of the cliff, resulting in turbulence and collapses. The slope is steep.
  • All Takeoffs: Ondulatory phenomena are frequent with North and South winds.
  • Airspace: The airspace near Chabre is affected by the R71 Salon area, which is a French military training zone. When active (Monday to Friday), the vertical limit is FL075 (approximately 2286m). At weekends and on bank holidays when R71 is confirmed inactive, the airspace limit rises to FL115 (3500m).
  • French Regulations: Ensure you have the agreement of the local council, aviation liability insurance, and the permission of landowners. Only airspace classified as E and G are authorized for free flying. The Ministry of Sport requires a helmet to be worn.
search_recs: Chabre paragliding access fees Chabre paragliding site information paragliding Chabre France pilot level

html:
Overview

This page details two paragliding locations in France, both named St. Jean. The first, St. Jean Montclar, is located in the Southern Alps and renowned for its excellent thermal conditions and suitability for cross-country flying. The second, Saint-Jean-en-Royans, is situated inland within the Parc Naturel Régional du Vercors and offers ground-based flying with different levels of difficulty.

Flying Conditions

St. Jean Montclar

  • Aerology: Known for its generous thermal activity, allowing for excellent cross-country (XC) potential.
  • Winds: The "plateau de La Chau" take-off is best suited for winds from the southwest to northwest.
  • Thermals: Thermals typically begin around 11:00 over 2000m and between 12:00-13:00 at the take-off, lasting until 19:00, with areas of convergence. The optimal launch time is around 14:00.

Saint-Jean-en-Royans

  • Winds: Protected from strong winds from the Rhône valley. Favorable wind sectors are North and Northwest.

Who Should Fly Here?

St. Jean Montclar

St. Jean Montclar is a popular site that caters to a range of pilots, from intermediate to advanced. It has a history of hosting major competitions like the French and British Open.

Saint-Jean-en-Royans

This site is recommended for autonomous pilots with a blue level (IPPI 4) certification or higher. The cliff take-off is suitable for experienced paragliders only.

Access & Facilities

St. Jean Montclar

  • Access: The primary access to the Plateau de la Chau take-off is via the Montclar ski resort's chairlift. Alternatively, a hiking trail with a 600m elevation gain takes approximately 1 hour.
  • Landing: Typically, landing occurs at Col Saint-Jean.

Saint-Jean-en-Royans

  • Landing Area: Located 2.7 km from St Jean en Royans via the D54. Pilots should first go to the landing area to inform the aeroclub.
  • Take-off Access: The take-off is 500m SE of the aerodrome. Then take the D361 for about 3km. Turn left onto the D76 towards Col de Gaudissant.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Gradient at landing: At the end of the day, when the breeze decreases, landing can be challenging due to a strong gradient. A slight descending breeze can accentuate this phenomenon.
  • Panel on site: There is a panel on site with dangers to be aware of.
  • Airspace Restriction: There's an airspace restriction, R71, with a maximum altitude of FL75 (approximately 2250 meters) on weekdays.
  • Commercial Activities: Any commercial activity related to free flight (teaching, tandem flights, sales, rentals) requires prior authorization from the club managing the site.
search_recs: paragliding site St. Jean France official information paragliding St. Jean France St. Jean France paragliding terrain

html:
Overview

The Salève is an 18 km long mountain ridge situated near Geneva, Switzerland, and Annemasse, France. Offering stunning views of Geneva, Lake Geneva, the Jura, the Pre-Alps, the Mont Blanc massif, and Lake Annecy, the Salève is a popular site for soaring and cross-country (XC) flying.

Flying Conditions

  • General: Known for soaring and cross-country (XC) flying. Good thermals are common on the steep western side facing Geneva, especially during the summer months.
  • Wind Direction: Avoid flying when the wind is from the South and East.
  • Take-off Characteristics: Take-off sites can be short and relatively flat, leading to steep, wooded, or rocky terrain.
  • Altitude Restrictions: Strict adherence to maximum altitude limits is crucial due to the proximity to Geneva International Airport's approach path. Maximum altitude of 1700m ASL over the Salève and 1050m ASL in the plains after passing the highway.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Salève is considered a "hard" site and is not recommended for new or infrequent pilots due to challenging take-offs and landings. The area around the flying school landing site contains power lines and roads, requiring extra caution. The "Le Coin" landing is for experienced pilots due to steepness and potential thermal turbulence. The site is very popular and can be crowded, especially on weekends.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The Salève is accessible by car, public transport, or the Salève cable car from Veyrier.
  • Cable Car: The cable car offers free returns for paragliders if no take-off is possible. Regular return tickets are available for €18 for adults. Discounted options include "Happy Hour" tickets (€15) on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday evenings, as well as 10-trip cards.
  • Landing Shuttles: Some landing sites may offer shuttle services for a fee (e.g., the Swiss Paragliding Club charges approximately 10 CHF for a ride back up).

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace:
    • Geneva International Airport: The most significant restriction is the proximity to Geneva International Airport's airspace. Violations have led to site closures in the past.
    • TMA (Terminal Control Area): Maximum altitude of 1700m ASL over the Salève and 1050m ASL in the plains after passing the highway.
    • CTR (Control Zone): The CTR of Geneva airport is a prohibited zone for paragliding.
    • No Fly Zone: It is strictly forbidden to fly over the city of Geneva.
    • Annemasse Aerodrome and Parachute Drop Zone: Avoid the Annemasse aerodrome and the parachute drop zone.
  • Takeoff-Specific Risks:
    • Salève - Telepherique: The launch site is relatively flat and short, situated almost above a vertical wall. The cables of the cable car are directly to the left when leaving the take-off. The aerology is very delicate, with strong gradients and surprising thermals.
    • Salève - La Table d'Orientation: Careful with the side wind as the trees can produce rotors; also typical tail wind late in the evening.
    • Salève - Le Coin: Many obstacles, and overflying houses is strictly forbidden. A large gradient can occur during thermal days. There may be a fence around the landing area to keep cows and a bull within. Tailwind branch on the Salève side is turbulent with strong Southerly or Northerly winds.
  • General: Beware of collisions, reversing, and sudden descent to the ground. Aerology is very delicate: gradients and thermals can be surprising.
  • Pre-Flight Checklist: It is essential to read the panels about the airspace on take-off before flying and to check the landing configuration.
search_recs: Salève paragliding access and fees parapente Salève informations officielles Salève paragliding site information Salève paragliding official site Salève paragliding difficulty

html:
Overview

St. Vincent Les Forts is a well-known paragliding site nestled in the Ubaye Valley of the Alpes-de-Haute-Provence, France. With its stunning panoramic views of the Serre-Ponçon lake, the village, and the valley, it's a popular spot for experienced pilots seeking thermaling, ridge soaring, and potential cross-country (XC) flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Conditions: Ideal wind directions are West and Northwest. The site is particularly favorable due to its protection from the Mistral wind.
  • Thermal Activity: Known for thermaling and ridge soaring, with potential for cross-country (XC) flights. Afternoon conditions (June-August) can be strong.
  • Takeoff: The site is technical with a short take-off and a "cliff" departure over a road.
  • Landing: Landing can be technical with a slight counter-slope, gradient, and trees, though improvements are underway. Beach landing is possible from September to May (easy).

Who Should Fly Here?

This site is recommended for experienced pilots only. Novices are not recommended, especially at the village entry due to a strong breeze. The site requires an experienced launch technique.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access is by car, with a very short walk to the take-off.
  • Directions: To reach the site from Gap or Barcelonnette, take the D900 towards Digne, then the D407 towards St. Vincent les Forts.
  • Fees: No information about fees was found. Pilots must have air liability insurance.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Experienced Pilots Only: St. Vincent Les Forts is considered suitable for experienced pilots due to the "punchy air" and challenging conditions.
  • Strong Conditions: The site is known for strong conditions, especially in the afternoon during June, July, and August.
  • Top Landing: The site is described as a top landing site, which might be challenging and requires experience. "Do not fly downwind!".
  • Aerological configurations (wind, clouds) severely restrict practice, so pilots should ask the school for details.
  • Takeoff: Short takeoff, cliff launch above a road.
  • Landing Restrictions:
    • Landing on the beach is possible from September to May.
    • Landing on the beach is strictly prohibited from June 15th to August 31st.
    • Landing in the lake is permitted from June 1st to June 15th in the presence of cattle.
    • Landing in campsites is prohibited from June 15th to August 31st.
    • Landing in fields (private property) is prohibited, especially during cultivation or when animals are present.
search_recs: paragliding regulations St. Vincent Les Forts France St. Vincent Les Forts paragliding St. Vincent Les Forts paragliding site details St. Vincent Les Forts paragliding access St. Vincent Les Forts paragliding fees St. Vincent Les Forts site FFVL

html:
Overview

Val Louron, nestled in the heart of the French Pyrenees, stands out as one of the most picturesque paragliding locations in the region. Overlooking the stunning Louron valley and with landing near the tranquil Genos-Loudenvielle lake, this site provides a remarkable blend of scenic beauty and exhilarating flight opportunities. Though unofficially admitted, Val Louron is a favorite among pilots, offering conditions ideal for thermaling and cross-country (XC) adventures.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Best suited for ESE, SE, and SSE winds. Be extremely cautious with strong South winds.
  • Thermals: Known for smooth climbs, but be aware of potentially strong thermals, especially during summer afternoons.
  • Cross-Country (XC): Offers excellent potential, with a site record of 41.5 km.

Who Should Fly Here?

Val Louron welcomes pilots of varying skill levels. Beginners can benefit from introductory and tandem flights offered by local schools, while experienced pilots will appreciate the site's potential for extended XC flights. Note that the area around the "tour du bocal" flight path is reserved for certified pilots only.

Access & Facilities

  • Takeoff Access: A short walk (approximately 10 minutes) is often required to reach the take-off areas.
  • Landing Zone: A large landing area is conveniently located near Lake Genos-Loudenvielle.
  • Local Support: Two paragliding schools and independent instructors operate in the area, offering guidance and training.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Variability: Be prepared for strong thermal winds, particularly in the afternoons during summer. Southerly winds can be dangerous, exercise caution.
  • Mountain Weather: The Pyrenees are known for rapid weather changes. Stay vigilant, especially concerning northerly winds (Advection and EPM), westerly spillover, and the potential for summer storms.
  • Raptor Protection: Be mindful of local wildlife. Avoid certain sectors during nesting periods to protect vultures, eagles, and other raptors. Observe the no-fly cylinder indicated on the panel at the landing area (north of the parking lot) to protect nesting bearded vultures.
  • Altiport Awareness: Be aware of the Altiport (on the Peyragudes side of the valley) and follow all specific rules related to its operation. Check with local instructors for guidance.
  • Takeoff Caution: At the "Val Louron - 700 Décollage" takeoff, pilots should be aware of the potential for sudden thermals and avoid over-steering, which can lead to stalls.
  • Landing Zone Respect: Respect private land bordering the official landing area, especially the field south of the path connecting the parking lot to the swimming pool. Pay attention to the informative panel near the windsock north of the parking lot.
search_recs: Val Louron vol libre Val Louron official paragliding information paragliding Val Louron France Val Louron paragliding site guide Val Louron paragliding regulations Val Louron site landing zones paragliding

html:
Overview

The Puy de Dôme, located 10km west of Clermont-Ferrand in the Auvergne region of France, is a prominent volcano and part of the Chaîne des Puys, a UNESCO World Heritage site. Reaching an altitude of 1465m (4806 ft), it's the most emblematic paragliding site in Auvergne, attracting pilots from all over France.

Flying Conditions

  • Takeoff: Offers 360° take-off possibilities due to multiple launch points around the summit.
  • Flying Style: Known for thermal flying and cross-country (XC) potential. The site record is 252.14 km, set in July 2022.
  • Sunset Flights: Suitable for sunset flights, but flying is prohibited more than 30 minutes after local and legal sunset time.
  • Landing: The most used landing area is "la Taillerie", near the Panoramique des Dômes station. Landing can be technical in the middle of the day due to strong thermals.
  • Airspace: Airspace restrictions exist due to the proximity of Clermont-Ferrand airport. Summer ceiling is 3500m, and winter ceiling is 2590m.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Puy de Dôme is a very popular site. It is recommended that pilots without sufficient experience avoid taking off between 11 AM and 4 PM in the summer due to thermal activity. Tandem flights are readily available for beginner pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The access road to the summit has been closed to cars since 2010. Access is either by foot via the "muleteers' path" or the "goats' path," or via a cogwheel train ("Panoramique des Dômes").
  • Cogwheel Train: The cogwheel train takes less than 20 minutes to reach the summit. Season tickets are available.
  • Arrival Time: Pilots should arrive at the bottom of the Puy de Dôme (bottom station or Col de Ceyssat) at least 1 hour before the meeting time at the top in order to account for travel to the launch.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Thermal Activity: Strong thermal triggers can occur, particularly during approaches.
  • Turbulence at Landing: The Taillerie landing area can experience significant turbulence.
  • Thunderstorms: The area is prone to strong thunderstorms, which can rapidly change local aerology with rain, hail, and violent winds. Fly between April and October to avoid strong winds and storms.
  • Site Congestion: The site can be very busy on weekends and during the summer.
  • Power Cable: Be aware of the power cable for the train around the site.
  • Cable Car Catenary: Avoid flying over the catenary (support structure) of the "Panoramique des Dômes" train during your approach.
  • Airspace: The Puy de Dôme site is located within the TMA 5.1 of Clermont-Aulnat. The landing area is situated in TMA 2.3 of Clermont-Aulnat, and a CTR (Controlled Traffic Region) is close to Clermont-Ferrand.
  • Altitude Limits: The authorized altitude is 3500m in summer (March 15 to October 15) and 2590m in winter (October 16 to March 14).
  • Military Airspace: The site is within a military corridor (R368B) that can be activated by NOTAM (Notice to Airmen).
  • Proximity to Clermont-Ferrand Airport: Flight constraints exist to the east of Puy de Dôme due to the proximity of Clermont-Ferrand and the Aulnat airport.
  • No-fly zone: Flying is prohibited over the urban area of Clermont-Ferrand.
search_recs: Puy de Dôme paragliding regulations paragliding Puy de Dôme France Puy de Dôme paragliding site information Puy de Dôme paragliding club

html:
Overview

Drumont, located in the Vosges Mountains of Alsace, France, offers a unique paragliding experience. Situated near the Ferme Auberge du Drumont, this site is renowned for its excellent morning flying conditions and thermal opportunities. Its location opposite the Treh paragliding site on the other major crest of the Vosges adds to its appeal.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Conditions: Ideal for flying with an East wind, particularly in the morning.
  • Thermals: Drumont provides good thermal conditions suitable for cross-country (XC) flights.
  • Soaring: Dynamic soaring is possible with NE winds.
  • Venturi Effect: Be aware of a venturi effect in the valley of Urbès towards the Col de Bussang.
  • Gustiberg Rollers: With a south-easterly wind, rollers can form under the Gustiberg ridge.

Who Should Fly Here?

Drumont is best suited for experienced pilots. The challenging launch and potentially capricious conditions demand good technique and skill. While popular, the site's complexities require pilots to be confident in their abilities.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Via the N66, passing through Urbès after the Col de Bussang. Turn onto a forest road to the Ferme Auberge du Drumont.
  • Parking: Available along the road before the Auberge's parking area.
  • Take-off Access: A short 5-minute walk south of the Auberge, through a fence, to a small hill.
  • Facilities: The Ferme Auberge du Drumont provides a nearby point for refreshments.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Aerology: Unpredictable aerology due to a weak slope and plateau can be challenging.
  • Takeoff Area: Situated in a cow pasture, requiring passage through a fence.
  • Wind Restrictions: Avoid flying in winds over 20km/h from the East, North-East and South-West.
  • No-Landing Zones: Landing is prohibited in the valley east of the takeoff and the valley north of Gustiberg takeoff.
  • East/Northeast Wind Limitations: Reaching the Urbès landing with East or Northeast winds requires downwind flying, recommended for very experienced pilots only.
  • Aeromodelling Site: Be aware of the aeromodelling site located between the delta and paragliding launch areas.
search_recs: Drumont paragliding site official paragliding site Drumont France site de parapente Drumont France Drumont paragliding access fees FFVL Drumont

html:
Overview

Arbas is a popular paragliding site located in the Haute-Garonne department of the Occitanie region in the central Pyrenees, France. Easily accessible from Toulouse (approximately 1 to 1.5-hour drive), Arbas offers alpine thermal flying during the typical flying season from Spring through Fall (April to November).

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions:
    • Primary wind directions are North, Northeast, and East.
    • Westerly and Northwesterly winds are unfavorable.
  • Thermals: Known for strong thermals in certain areas, requiring pilot awareness.
  • Soaring: The site is not ideal for ridge soaring.

Who Should Fly Here?

Arbas is considered a site of medium difficulty. It is suitable for pilots with some experience in thermal flying. Beginner pilots should be cautious of strong thermals and be aware of wind gradients.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The take-off is accessible by car.
  • Fees: There may be a fee associated with using the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions:
    • It is not advisable to fly in westerly (O) or north-westerly (NO) winds, nor in strong southerly winds.
    • Strong gusts of wind can cause issues mid-flight.
    • Be aware of the potential for a marked gradient on the Arbas landing field when there are breezes.
    • Takeoff at the Arbas - Planot de Loubat Takeoff can be delicate in nil wind conditions. The takeoff area is bordered by tall trees, requiring caution.
  • Landing Zone Considerations:
    • The landing area is quite long and bordered by tall trees on one side.
    • Pilots should be aware of thermal triggers and wind gradients in the landing zone.
    • A PTU (Priority Turn to Upwind) with a left-hand turn is recommended in rising breeze conditions.
  • Hunting Season Restriction: Flying is prohibited before 13:30 from October 1st to November 8th due to wood pigeon hunting season.
  • Airspace: The airspace is unrestricted up to FL115 (approximately 3500 meters), then classified as E up to FL195 (approximately 5850 meters). North of the relay, the authorized airspace descends to 1950 meters.
  • Environmental Protection: From March 1st to September 15th, avoid flying within 300m of the highest point of the red zone to protect the Vautour Percnoptère (Egyptian Vulture) population.
search_recs: Arbas France flying conditions FFVL Arbas paragliding site Arbas paragliding site France Arbas paragliding take-off Arbas paragliding access fees Paragliding clubs Arbas France

html:
Overview

Saint-Omer is a well-regarded paragliding site located near the village of Saint-Omer in the Suisse Normande area of Normandy, France. Situated along the picturesque Crest Route (Route des Crêtes) and Rochers de la Houle, it offers panoramic views over the Clécy valley.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: Best suited for South to South-West winds. The site is leeward (sous le vent) with South-South-East winds.
  • Season: Open from April to October, depending on flying conditions.
  • Altitude: Take-off altitude ranges from 200 to 267 meters, with the landing area at 39 meters.
  • Windsock: Always observe the windsock. If it moves from left to right, be aware of significant turbulence.

Who Should Fly Here?

With a difficulty rating of 2/5, Saint-Omer caters to a range of skill levels. Paragliding schools use the site for instruction, making it suitable for beginners taking their first flights. More advanced pilots will also find the site enjoyable.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The take-off area is easily accessible by car. Follow signs for "Route des Crêtes."
  • Parking: Available in Saint-Omer.
  • Fees: Fees may be associated with site usage, especially when flying with a paragliding school. First flights start from €70 with operators like Plaine Altitude. Check with local operators or the FFVL for specific details.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Exercise caution with South-South-East winds as the site can be leeward. Monitor the windsock for turbulence indicators.
  • Takeoff: The Saint-Omer Sud takeoff involves a tremplin (ramp).
  • Site Congestion: Be aware that the site can get crowded. Respect local rules and other pilots.
  • Airspace: No specific airspace restrictions were found, but always verify current conditions and regulations.
  • Important Note: The FFVL does not have a formal agreement for this site, and pilots fly at their own risk.
search_recs: Saint-Omer paragliding access fees paragliding club Saint-Omer France paragliding Saint-Omer France Saint-Omer paragliding site official information Saint-Omer paragliding site difficulty

html:
Overview

Gréolières is an internationally recognized paragliding site located in the Alpes-Maritimes department of France, within the Préalpes d'Azur Regional Natural Park. Situated below the Cheiron mountain, near the village of Gréolières and close to the French Riviera, the site offers stunning views of the Mediterranean Sea and the snow-covered Alps in winter.

Flying Conditions

Gréolières is renowned for its thermic flying conditions, benefiting from a microclimate with over 300 days of sunshine annually. The south-facing slope of the Cheiron mountain provides year-round thermic opportunities suitable for all skill levels. Summer conditions can be dynamic, while spring and autumn offer gentler flying. Several take-off points at varying altitudes are available:

  • 300m Launch: Accessible for all skill levels.
  • 600m Launch: Offers a higher starting point with great views.
  • 700m Launch: Provides an even higher launch.
  • Summit (1778m): For experienced pilots seeking maximum altitude.

While cross-country flights are possible, other nearby sites may be better suited for long-distance flying.

Who Should Fly Here?

Gréolières is popular with pilots of all abilities and is considered accessible to novice pilots. Many paragliding schools operate in the area, making it an excellent location to learn and progress. Easy take-off and landing areas further enhance its appeal.

Access & Facilities

The "Au Gré de l'Air" club, a paragliding association of the French Riviera, manages the site. Official information is available on their website and at the launch and landing areas. Take-off points are accessible via hiking. A local paragliding school operates a shuttle service from the landing field to the 300 launch, and in summer to the 600/700 launches. Private users are prohibited from using these tracks.

Getting to Gréolières is possible by bus from Nice airport, though having a car is recommended.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Westerly Winds: Avoid flying in a westerly wind due to lee side conditions at the landing field. This could indicate a Mistral wind.
  • Strong Summer Thermals: Be aware of strong winds on top, especially during summer thermals. Consider flying early or late in the day.
  • Turbulence: The exit from the Gréolières - 300 takeoff can be turbulent with easterly winds.
  • Takeoff Specific Risks:
    • Gréolières - 700: Short takeoff with an abrupt drop. If conditions are too strong, use the 600 takeoff.
    • 1000 Cheiron: Wind can be very strong here.
    • S1-600 (auch Drachen): Be careful with westerly winds!
  • Airspace: Airspace exists above the Cheiron mountain. Check maps to avoid infringements. The Nice TMA (Terminal Control Area) is above 2100m.
  • Maximum Flight Altitude: The maximum flight altitude is FL65 (2000 meters) under Nice 13 (class D).
  • Landing Restrictions: No formal landing agreement is in place; landing is only tolerated. Landing is not authorized if the ground is snow-covered. Mini gliders are forbidden on the landing area.
  • 4x4 Access: The 4x4 tracks to the 600/700 takeoffs are forbidden for private users.
search_recs: Gréolières paragliding access fees Gréolières paragliding flying conditions Gréolières paragliding site France Gréolières paragliding official site information Gréolières paragliding club Gréolières paragliding difficulty

html:
Overview

Baigura is a popular paragliding site nestled in the inner French Basque Country, within the Pyrénées-Atlantiques department. This isolated pre-Pyrenean massif rises to 897 meters (2,943 ft), offering unique flying experiences. Its gentle north slope contrasts with the steep south side, adding to the site's distinct character.

Flying Conditions

  • Aerology: Known for its mild aerological conditions, Baigura is well-suited for introductory flights and shorter cross-country adventures.
  • Wind Directions:
    • Favorable wind directions include: W, NW, N, NE, E, and SE.
    • Flying is dangerous with south winds.
  • Take-off: The main take-off area is situated at 774 meters, providing ample altitude for enjoyable flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Baigura is considered an excellent site for beginner to intermediate pilots, offering a comfortable environment to hone skills. The south-east takeoff is specifically reserved for experienced paragliders.

Access & Facilities

  • Shuttle Access: Convenient access to the take-off area is provided via a shuttle (small train) from the leisure base, followed by a short walk.
  • Pastoral Road: Note that the road to the mountain's summit is reserved for pastoral activity.
  • Fees: The shuttle service costs 5.50€. Tandem flights are available for 95€.
  • Baigura Leisure Centre: Offers paragliding initiation courses, tandem flights, and various other outdoor activities.
    • Contact: baigura@communaute-paysbasque.fr
    • Phone: +33 5 59 37 69 05 or +33 6 84 78 65 09

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Hazards: Southerly winds pose the primary danger at Baigura. Be aware of sudden, violent gusts, especially from the west.
  • Turbulence: Northerly or Westerly winds can generate turbulence. Summer storms also require increased vigilance.
  • Unfavorable Wind Sectors: Flying is not recommended with South or South-West winds.
  • Takeoff Precautions: The south-east takeoff is reserved for experienced paragliders.
  • Emergency Landings: Be aware that emergency landing areas may be limited depending on the terrain.
  • French Regulations:
    • Flying is permitted in E (controlled) and G (uncontrolled) class airspaces.
    • Flights must maintain visibility; flying in clouds is prohibited.
    • Night flights are forbidden.
    • Flights above 3450m are restricted except in authorized areas in the Alps or Pyrenees.
  • Prior Permissions To paraglide in France, you must first have the agreement of the town hall, air liability insurance and the consent of the landowners.
  • Mandatory Equipment To fly a paraglider in France, the Ministry of Sport requires you to wear a helmet, whatever your level.
search_recs: Baigura paragliding access Baigura paragliding site information paragliding Baigura France Baigura paragliding official site Baigura paragliding fees Baigura France flying conditions

html:
Overview

Mieussy, located in the Haute-Savoie region of the French Alps, is renowned as the "Berceau du parapente" (birthplace of paragliding). With its mountainous terrain and launch sites on the Sommand Plateau, it offers a diverse range of flying experiences.

Flying Conditions

  • Flying Style: Known for both thermal and dynamic (ridge soaring) flying.
  • Cross-Country: Good XC opportunities are available from April through the end of summer, with routes via the Col de la Colombière to Mont Lachat.
  • Optimal Conditions: Summer offers calmer winds, Spring is suited for distance flights, and Autumn provides calmer overall flights.
  • Wind Considerations: Turbulent conditions can occur with north winds. South to South-East winds can cause the La Platière take-off (next to the parking) to be leeward. In this case, Pertuiset take-off is recommended.

Who Should Fly Here?

Mieussy is suitable for pilots of all experience levels, from beginner to expert. However, the site can be very busy in July and August.

Access & Facilities

  • Take-off Access: Access to the Pertuiset and La Platière take-off areas is from Mieussy, following the road to the Sommand ski station. Once on the plateau, take a right towards Roche Pallud, then the first track on the left.
  • Pertuiset Take-off: A 15-minute walk from the parking area.
  • La Platière Take-off: (West facing) is next to the parking area.
  • Landing Site: The Mieussy landing site is accessed from the village by heading towards the salle des fêtes, then taking the first left after the school, past the tennis courts.
  • Fees: There are no fees to access the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Flights can be turbulent, even very turbulent, with north winds.
  • Catex Cable: Be aware of the Catex cable on the Rovagne cliff, visible from the road to Sommand. It is not marked during operation (December - May).
  • Pertuiset Risks:
    • Do not scratch too close to the intermediate flat area.
    • South-westerly takeoffs are prohibited in winter.
    • With south to south-easterly winds, the takeoff next to the parking lot is downwind, favour Pertuiset instead.
  • La Platière Risks:
    • Turbulent flights are possible with north winds.
    • With south to south-easterly winds, the takeoff next to the parking lot is downwind, favour Pertuiset instead.
  • Ferme Landing: Main landing approach from the left with rising breeze return on the upwind leg above the Giffre (river). Be careful with strong North winds (rollers).
  • Airspace: TMA Geneva 7: FL105 (3200m) - FL195.
  • Regulations: In France, pilots must have the agreement of the town hall, air liability insurance, and the consent of landowners. Flying is authorized only in areas classified E and G. The Ministry of Sport requires helmet use.

html:
Overview

Mont Poupet, located in the scenic Jura Mountains near Salins-les-Bains and Saint-Thiébaud, France, offers a diverse paragliding experience. This prominent mountain provides a beautiful backdrop of rolling hills and forests for pilots of all skill levels. Maintained by the local flying school "Poupet Vol Libre" and the FFVL (Fédération Française de Vol Libre), Mont Poupet is a popular site known for both thermic and dynamic soaring opportunities.

Flying Conditions

Mont Poupet offers flying opportunities for various wind directions. Pilots should be mindful of wind conditions given the site's position as the first relief after the plains.

  • Wind Directions:
    • Suitable: South, West, Northwest, North, Southwest.
    • Technical Takeoffs: East, Southeast.
    • To Avoid: Moderate to strong winds from the North or South. East and Northeast winds are also unfavorable.
  • Soaring: Known for both thermic and dynamic soaring.

Who Should Fly Here?

Mont Poupet is suitable for pilots of all skill levels, from beginners (IPPI 3 / niveau vert) to cross-country (XC) pilots. The presence of a paragliding school on-site makes it an excellent location for learning and progression. Be aware that the site can experience moderate air traffic.

Access & Facilities

Access to the take-off points is possible either by foot or car.

  • By Foot: Approximately a 30-minute hike from Saint-Thiébaud.
  • By Car: Approximately a 25-minute drive from Saint-Thiébaud. Follow the D492, then the D273 to the left (direction Mont Poupet), then left again (Mont Poupet). Pass the antennas and picnic areas and continue to the end of the road to access all take-off points. Note that the road to the site is a passable track.
  • Fees: There is no information available regarding fees or permits required to fly at Mont Poupet.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

Pilots should be aware of the potential risks and restrictions at Mont Poupet:

  • Wind Conditions: Given that Mont Poupet is the first relief after the plain, avoid flying with moderate to strong winds.
  • Unfavorable Winds: Avoid flying with East (E) or North-East (NE) winds.

Per Takeoff Risks

  • Mont Poupet - South-East Takeoff: Located near a botanical reserve. Avoid straying onto the rocky spur west of the takeoff area.
  • Barbed Wire: A barbed wire fence has been installed at the entrance to the field and is marked with red and white ribbons.
  • Mont Poupet E: This is a technical site.
  • Landing at Café du Mont Poupet: This landing area is not FFVL (Fédération Française de Vol Libre) approved.

Flight Restrictions

  • Airspace: Mont Poupet is located under zones R 158 A and R 158 B. Zone R 45 passes 5 km to the East behind the site.

html:
Overview

Semnoz is a popular paragliding site situated in the Bauges Mountains, near Annecy in the French Alps. Offering panoramic views of the Alps and Lake Annecy from its summit at approximately 1,700 meters, Semnoz provides an excellent environment for ridge soaring and thermal flying.

Flying Conditions

  • Semnoz is well-suited for ridge soaring, particularly with north-westerly winds.
  • The site offers opportunities for cross-country (XC) flights towards Mont Revard and Nivolet, with the potential for routes up to 70 km out-and-return.
  • Optimal wind conditions are north-westerly. Be cautious in northerly winds.
  • Evening flights are particularly popular at this site.
  • The area benefits from valley breezes and the high altitude launch provides opportunities to fly around the lake under the right conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Semnoz is considered a site of medium difficulty, best suited for intermediate to advanced pilots. While both paragliding and hang gliding are common, including tandem flights, beginners are not recommended at the Semnoz take-off.

Access & Facilities

  • The Semnoz take-off is accessible by car.
  • Parking is available.
  • At Col de la Forclaz, there's a regulated and paying access for cars (except for people with reduced mobility). Contact the Talloires Town Hall for information on obtaining an access card. Access on foot is possible for pilots and spectators.
  • Note that it may be necessary to pay a fee to drive to the take-off point during peak season (May to September)

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Aeromodelling Zone: Avoid drifting too far east of the takeoff, as this area is reserved for aeromodelling. Respect the aeromodelling zone and their thermal activity.
  • Crêt de Châtillon Restriction: The take-off at Crêt de Châtillon is reserved for hang gliders (Deltas); paragliding is prohibited there.
  • Designated Takeoff: For paragliders, the only authorized take-off site in Semnoz is located behind the Chatillon restaurant. Taking off above Gruffy, behind the arrival of the "Panoramique" chairlift is prohibited.
  • Airspace Awareness: When crossing towards Semnoz, avoid flying too far over the city center of Annecy, as it lies within the CTR (Control Traffic Region). Be aware of airspace restrictions in force in the Bauges nature reserve and certain areas of the Aravis, Sixt and Bargy.
  • R185 SACCONGES Firing Range: Be aware of the R185 SACCONGES firing range. Incursions into this zone while firing is in progress have been noted. The military authority may take action if pilots enter this zone.
  • Seasonal Restrictions: From May 1st to October 30th of each year, an order applies to the summit of Semnoz.
  • Flying Restrictions: Paragliding take-off and landing are forbidden, except in the zone indicated by a blue circle on the map attached to the order.
search_recs: Semnoz paragliding access fees paragliding Semnoz France Semnoz paragliding official site Semnoz paragliding difficulty

html:
Overview

Revin, nestled in the Ardennes region of France near the Belgian border, offers a unique paragliding experience amidst wooded hills and the scenic Meuse River valley. With multiple launch sites like "Revin Fallieres" and "Revin Malgré-Tout," pilots can enjoy thermaling and ridge soaring in this green and tranquil environment.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Thermaling and ridge soaring are both possible, offering varied flight experiences.
  • Wind Directions:
    • Revin Fallieres: Suitable for Southeast, South, and Southwest winds.
    • Revin Malgré-Tout: Best flown with Southwest winds.
  • Seasonality: Flying is possible year-round, but be aware of potential limitations during hunting season (October to January).
  • Weather Considerations: The aerology can become turbulent during warm hours, making morning or late afternoon flights preferable.
  • Mandatory Site Familiarization: Trees and the river near the landing zones require careful assessment before flying.

Who Should Fly Here?

Revin Fallieres is rated as an intermediate site ("Parapente Moyen"). The upper launch is recommended for pilots with a P3 rating. Site briefings from local pilots are strongly advised, especially for those new to the area, to understand the nuances of the site.

Access & Facilities

  • Revin Fallieres: Accessible by car, followed by a short 5-minute walk to the launch. Parking is available on Rue de Fallières. Access to the landing area is via a path along the Meuse River, on foot. Note the forest road to the takeoff is closed to car traffic, carpooling is required.
  • Revin Malgré-Tout: Reachable via a steep path.
  • Fees: Contact local paragliding clubs to inquire about any membership or usage fees.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Turbulence: Be aware of potentially turbulent conditions, especially during warmer parts of the day.
  • Raptor Restrictions: From January 1st to July 31st, restrictions may be in place due to birds of prey. Always check for current local restrictions before flying, especially at Haybes-Fumay and Revin.
  • Revin Fallieres Takeoff Access: The forest road to the takeoff is closed to car traffic, with fines for violations. Access is restricted to members of the Pointe Ardennes Parapente club with properly identified vehicles. Carpooling from the Fallières and Argentine parkings is necessary.
  • Landing Zone Hazards (Revin Fallieres): Trees and the river border the landing zone. Mandatory site reconnaissance is essential. The site is also closed during hunting season (November 1st to February 28th).
  • Airspace: Revin is located north of the TMA (Terminal Control Area) of Florennes and Charleroi. Consult airspace regulations before flying towards the Northwest (NO) and Northeast (NE). It is strictly prohibited to fly in controlled airspace without prior authorization.
search_recs: Revin paragliding club Revin paragliding site details Paragliding Revin FR Sites de parapente Revin France Revin tourism

html:
Overview

Collet d'Allevard is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Belledonne mountain range, about 40 km southeast of Chambéry and 38 km northeast of Grenoble, in the Isère department of the Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes region of southeastern France. Part of the Le Collet d'Allevard ski resort, this site offers a variety of takeoff locations and excellent soaring and thermaling opportunities.

Flying Conditions

Collet d'Allevard offers multiple official take-off points, providing flexibility for different wind conditions:

  • Malatrait: Known for good thermal conditions, especially towards the end of the year, extending the flying season.
  • Les Plagnes: Suitable for soaring, offering a large slope for dynamic lift.
  • Pré Rond: A more technical launch, being both steep and narrow, and affected by being on the leeward side of thermals.
  • Super-Collet: Offers flying in winter, with landing only permitted when the ground is covered with snow.

Pilots should be aware of breeze conditions and potential venturi effects, especially when flying low in the valley in front of the Plagnes take-off with northerly winds. Southerly winds may be stronger in the valley and at the ski resort level than at the take-off; in such conditions, landing back at the take-off is advisable.

The best time to fly here is between April and November.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Malatrait take-off is very popular and frequently visited. The Super-Collet landing requires a confirmed skill level (IPPI 5) due to potentially tricky landing conditions, especially with wind. It's recommended that pilots flying at Super-Collet make themselves known to the "pisteurs" (ski patrol) beforehand.

Access & Facilities

Access to the take-off areas generally involves driving towards the Collet d'Allevard ski resort.

  • Malatrait: Park in the main ski resort parking lot. The take-off is located near the road at the parking lot entrance.
  • Pré Rond: From the resort, continue to the Pré Rond parking area towards Super Collet. The take-off is a short walk from the parking lot.
  • Super Collet: Continue to the end of the road and park at the Super Collet parking. The information panel is located at the Claran chairlift departure station. Access to the site is a 10-minute walk.
  • Les Plagnes: Drive to Super-Collet and take the chairlift (open in winter and July-August).

Access to the sites is generally free. However, using the chairlift to reach Les Plagnes will incur a fee when it is operational.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Lake Proximity (La Digue landing): It is forbidden to fly over the lake at low altitude due to the EDF (Électricité de France) reservoir. Never fly past the dike (digue) in breeze or northerly wind conditions.
  • Gusts: In summer, with a sustained breeze, very strong gusts are possible; launching is strongly discouraged in these conditions.
  • Venturi Effect: A venturi effect occurs at the top of the dike with northerly winds or a breeze. Be aware of significant venturi effect at Malatrait with strong North winds or strong breeze.
  • Obstacles at La Digue Landing: There are obstacles all around the landing area, including power lines, trees, houses, and the lake. Landing outside the designated area is impossible.
  • Turbulence at Super-Collet landing: The Super-Collet landing area can be very turbulent and dangerous, especially with southerly winds. Always land uphill. This landing is closed when there is no snow.
  • Landing Alternatives: In strong wind conditions, pilots should prefer landing at Saint Pierre d'Allevard (on the other side of the lake). When flying at Les Plagnes, With a marked southerly wind, it is better to land back at the takeoff (and go down on foot or by chairlift) than to land at Super-Collet.
  • Specific Takeoff Hazards: The Malatrait launch has a short takeoff area and a growing ravine on the right; avoid launching too close. Les Plagnes requires care not to descend too low into the valley facing the takeoff with breeze or sustained North winds due to venturi effect and to avoid leeward side of ridge with southerly wind. Pré Rond is considered technical because it is steep and narrow.
  • Flight Restrictions: The Super-Collet landing area is prohibited when there is no snow.
  • Airspace: The site is located under the LTA Alpes 3 airspace, class E, with a ceiling of FL145 (approximately 4420m).
