html:
Overview

Bergies is a popular paragliding site located near Laragne in the Hautes Alpes region of France. With its mountainous landscape and wide-open valleys, Bergies offers excellent flying conditions for both paragliding and hang gliding. The site is officially recognized by the FFVL (Fédération Française de Vol Libre) as a practice area, making it accessible to pilots of varying skill levels.

Flying Conditions

  • Take-off Options:
    • North Take-off: A gentle, grassy slope often used in the morning.
    • South Take-off: Suitable for longer XC flights when flown in a Southerly wind.
  • Wind Conditions: Generally flown in North West to North East winds. The site has a Balise on top that transmits wind direction and strength every 20 minutes.
  • Thermal Activity: Known for strong thermals, especially after midday on the South take-off, providing excellent cross-country (XC) potential.
  • XC Potential: The wide-open valley to the East offers numerous landing options, making Bergies an excellent site for first cross-country flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Bergies is suitable for a range of pilots, from those gaining experience to experienced XC pilots. Local schools frequently use it for training flights. While considered a medium difficulty site, pilots should be aware that thermals can become strong after midday, making it more appropriate for experienced pilots looking for XC opportunities.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The North take-off is accessible via a road, while the South take-off (Bergies - Sud) is accessible by car with a very short walk.
  • Parking: Specific parking regulations may be in place, so please check local information.
  • Location: Easily accessible from the town of Laragne.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Strong Thermals: Be prepared for strong thermals, particularly on the South take-off, especially during midday hours.
  • "Dusts": The North take-off area may experience "Dusts" (small whirlwinds) around 12:00.
  • Electric Lines: Beware of electrical lines near the landing zone.
  • Certification/Attestation: An attestation (site briefing confirmation) might be required to fly at Bergies. Check with the local "centre de vol libre" (free flight center).
  • French Regulations: Adhere to all French paragliding regulations. This includes obtaining agreement from the town hall, having air liability insurance, and obtaining consent from landowners.

Important Considerations

  • Weather Station: Stay updated with the latest weather information. Contact the weather station located at the summit of Bergiès (phone number 06 58 01 67 14 or 143.9875 mhz on your radio).
  • Winds: Strong breeze at the North landing zone.
search_recs: Bergies paragliding access and fees Bergies paragliding site details paragliding site Bergies France Bergies paragliding official information

html:
Overview

Couraduque is a popular paragliding site nestled in the scenic Val d'Azun within the Hautes-Pyrénées region of France. Renowned for its accessibility and favorable conditions, especially for beginners, Couraduque offers a delightful experience amidst mountainous landscapes and vast grassy slopes. The Col de Couraduque serves as the primary take-off point, providing stunning views and a gateway to memorable flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions:
    • Ideal wind directions are Northeast (NE), East (E), and Southeast (SE).
    • The Col de Couraduque take-off has orientations suited to southeast and south-west winds, making it adaptable to daily weather changes.
    • Flying in a southerly direction is not recommended due to the risk of turbulence.
  • Soaring and Thermaling:
    • The site is well-suited for ridge soaring and thermaling.
    • Ideal aerological conditions are present when the valley breeze is established.
    • Gentle thermals make it suitable for relaxed flights.
  • Flying Season:
    • The flying season extends from January to December, dependent on weather conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Couraduque caters to pilots of all skill levels, but is particularly well-suited to beginners. The Fédération Française de Vol Libre (FFVL) recommends a "niveau vert" (green level), which corresponds to IPPI 3 (Initiation Pilot Proficiency Identification) or beginner level.

Access & Facilities

  • Access:
    • The take-off point at Col de Couraduque is easily accessible.
    • Located near the Couraduque ski station. From Argeles-Gazost, take the direction of Col du Soulor, then turn towards the pass at Aucun.
    • Parking is available at the entrance to the village at the junction with the main road.
    • Walking access to the practice area from the parking is approximately 2 minutes.
  • Fees:
    • Access to the site is free, but pilots must hold a valid FFVL license-insurance.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • South Wind: Flying with a south wind is not recommended due to the risk of turbulent conditions. Be aware of "rentrée de sud" (turbulent return from the south).
  • Variable Weather: Mountain weather can change rapidly and unpredictably.
  • Overcrowding: Be aware of priority rules on crowded sites.
  • Licensing: The site is open to any free-flight pilot holding a FFVL (Fédération Française de Vol Libre) license and civil liability insurance.
  • National Park Regulations: Article 22 of the regulations for the Parc National des Pyrénées prohibits flying lower than 1000m above the ground without specific authorization from the park's administration.
  • Radio Required: Mandatory radio.
  • Altitude Restriction: The regulation is to fly higher than 300 meters above the ground on ski resorts and ski slopes.

html:
Overview

Mauroux is a popular paragliding site nestled in the French Pyrenees, near Targasonne. Takeoff is from Pic des Mauroux (2066m altitude), it offers stunning views and the potential for both thermalling and cross-country (XC) flights, taking advantage of the Cerdagne's sunny exposure. The main landing zone is located in Mauroux itself.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind: Be cautious of North wind conditions, listen to the weather beacon for updates. Strong breezes are common in July and August starting in the early afternoon.
  • Thermals: The takeoff area is prone to thermal triggers, so be cautious in the afternoon, especially during the summer. Aerology can be strong in the early afternoon.
  • Landing: The landing area is on a slope, which can present challenges. Crosswind landings are possible.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Pic des Mauroux site is reportedly very popular, catering to paragliders of all experience levels. All pilots should be aware of the sometimes strong conditions, and sloping landing area.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The takeoff at Mauroux is accessible via a shuttle from the landing zone. A 9-seater shuttle is authorized to use the track. Hiking to the take-off is also possible, with an elevation gain of 400 meters, taking approximately 45-60 minutes.
  • Meeting Point: The landing zone serves as a meeting point for pilots.
  • Exposure: The area is exposed to full sun.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Themis Solar Plant: Flying over the Themis solar power plant and within a 500-meter radius around the tower is strictly forbidden.
  • Airspace B31: Entry into the B31 airspace zone above the takeoff is prohibited. The lower limit of this airway is between 3307 meters and 3733 meters.
  • Sainte-Léocadie Aerodrome: It is forbidden to fly over the Sainte-Léocadie aerodrome below 1900 meters QNH.
  • Takeoff Orientation: The Pic des Mauroux takeoff (2070m) has orientations from South-East to South-West. Suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding.
  • Landing Area: The landing Area is East to West orientation. Altitude 1638m.
search_recs: Mauroux paragliding site details paragliding Mauroux (FR) FFVL Mauroux paragliding Mauroux paragliding site regulations

html:
Overview

Aiguebelette is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Avant-Pays Savoyard region of France, near the picturesque Lake Aiguebelette. This site, characterized by the wooded Montagne de l'Épine, offers stunning views and a variety of flying opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying:
    • Ridge soaring along the Épine range.
    • Thermal flying, especially in the afternoon.
    • Cross-country (XC) potential towards the Dent du Chat (north) or the Chartreuse and Vercors ranges (south).
    • Evening flights.
  • Flyable Days: Known for a high frequency of flyable days, typically from April to October.
  • Wind Conditions: Best conditions are with winds from the west. Not suitable with winds from the North, NE, E, or SE. Flights may be rough with any East component of wind.

Who Should Fly Here?

Aiguebelette caters to a range of pilot skill levels. Tandem flights are available for beginners through local operators like Aiguebelette Parapente. The main takeoff ("La Province") may require more experience.

The site is popular, although less crowded than Annecy, providing a more relaxed flying environment.

Access & Facilities

  • Landing Site Access:
    • From Chambéry, take the highway towards Lyon.
    • Exit at Novalaise/Lac d'Aiguebelette (exit n°12) after the 'L'Épine' tunnel.
    • At the first crossroad, turn left, and then immediately left again. The landing is just behind the trees.
  • Takeoff Access (La Province / L'Epine):
    • Go to the 'col de l'Épine' pass via the D916 road.
    • Just before the pass, turn left onto a road and follow it for 3 km. Look for 'décollage' (takeoff) signs.
  • Fees: Access to beaches around the lake may require payment. Verify any fees for using the paragliding site with local clubs or schools.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • General Risks:
    • Convict Effect: Risk of being caught in the descent of an inclined thermal, leading to tree landings.
    • Thermal Activity: Strong thermal activity in the mid-afternoon, potentially reinforced by North/Northeast winds.
    • Heat Restitution: On hot summer days, heat restitution over the lake and along the Chaîne de l'Épine.
    • Overcrowding: Respect rules of priority during busy periods.
  • Takeoff Risks (La Province / L'Epine):
    • Wind Conditions: Crosswind and leeward conditions possible with moderate to strong North/Northeast wind, alongside reinforced thermal activity.
    • Limited Launch Area: Launch area can only accommodate two wings being prepared at once. Use designated unfolding areas.
    • High-Voltage Line: A visible high-voltage line crosses the Montagne de l'Épine; avoid getting trapped behind it when flying low around the Col de l'Epine.
    • Rear Thermals: Pilots circling behind thermals above the takeoff risk being pushed back.
  • Flight Restrictions:
    • Airspace: Located within the Chambéry - Savoie Mont Blanc airport airspace. Strictly adhere to the TMA and CTR regulations.
    • CTR (Chambéry): Prohibited airspace from the ground up to 1060m altitude.
    • TMA (Chambéry): Classified as D airspace from December to April.
    • Highway Overflight: Cross the A43 highway at an altitude of more than 150 meters above ground level.
    • Landing Zone Restrictions: The "Les Marais" landing area is in a protected area. Landings are tolerated but leave the area quickly and pack equipment near the parking lot.
    • Nesting Zones: Eagles nesting zones on the right of takeoff in Le Chat site. Info on quiet zones by QR Code on the panel.
search_recs: Aiguebelette paragliding regulations paragliding Aiguebelette France Aiguebelette paragliding site official information Aiguebelette paragliding access fees

html:
Overview

Vérel, situated near Chambéry in the Savoie region of France, offers a thrilling paragliding experience amidst stunning mountainous terrain. Pilots can enjoy panoramic views of Chambéry, the Chartreuse mountain range, and the serene Bourget Lake from this cliffside launch.

Flying Conditions

  • Vérel is renowned for its excellent thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying opportunities, as well as acrobatics and evening flights.
  • The site thrives on a northerly breeze, enhanced by thermals rising from the cliff face.
  • Favorable Winds: West to North-West.
  • Unfavorable Winds: North-East to East, and South to South-East.
  • Takeoff can be technically demanding, particularly in the afternoon when strong breezes and thermals are present.
  • An ideal starting point for cross-country flights towards the north.

Who Should Fly Here?

  • Vérel is a popular site, attracting pilots looking for dynamic soaring conditions.
  • Experience Level: Not recommended for beginners, especially in the afternoon due to strong thermal activity.
  • The French Federation of Free Flight (FFVL) suggests a "blue level" pilot (IPPI 4, autonomous) is suitable for this site.

Access & Facilities

  • Takeoff: Located in Verel-Pragondran. From Chambéry, head to Verel, then Pragondran. Parking is available at the entrance to the village on the left. A 15-minute walk along a path between the houses and cliff leads to the takeoff.
  • Main Landing Area: Montagny, located on the D211 after the Sonnaz le bas landing; turn left towards the cliff.
  • Alternative Landing: Brocolis.
  • Restricted Area: Landing on the plateau of Verel-Pragondran is prohibited.
  • Hiking Trail: A trail connects the Montagny landing to the takeoff, with a 620m elevation gain and an average hiking time of 1h10m.
  • Fees: Access to the site is free.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Busy Site: The Planfait take-off, accessed via Vérel, can be crowded.
  • Cliff Takeoff: Vérel's cliff launch demands experience and caution.
  • Thermal Activity: High thermal activity, especially in the early afternoon, requires pilots to assess conditions carefully. Flying later in the afternoon may be preferable.
  • Wind Conditions: Northerly breezes are favorable; however, North-East to East winds (tailwind) and South to South-East winds (crosswind) are dangerous. Winds exceeding 20 km/h may impede return to the landing area.
  • Turbulence: North-easterly breezes can create turbulence at Planfait.
  • Takeoff Considerations: The Vérel takeoff is downwind of thermals and breezes, necessitating careful assessment. Rotors may form due to vegetation and terrain with North and South-West winds.
  • Airspace: Be mindful of the Chambery/Aix-les-Bains airport's TMA (Terminal Control Area) and CTR (Control Zone).
  • Landing approach: The landing area Montagny must only be approached with MAX 50m/ground.
search_recs: Vérel paragliding official site paragliding Vérel (FR) Vérel paragliding site information FFVL Vérel

html:
Overview

Rabou is a paragliding site nestled in the Hautes-Alpes department of France, in the Southern French Alps. Situated near the Dévoluy massif and the Drac valley, it offers breathtaking views of the Champsaur valley. Known for its thermal flying potential and easy access, Rabou attracts pilots looking to experience the beauty of the French Alps from above.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Flying: Rabou is renowned for its thermal activity, offering opportunities for cross-country (XC) flights towards Grenoble or Savines.
  • Wind Direction: The site reportedly works well with a weak north wind. The primary orientation is Southwest (SO), and the best conditions are typically found with a South wind.
  • Morning Flights: Take advantage of the first thermals with morning flights, when conditions are often optimal.

Who Should Fly Here?

Rabou offers something for a range of pilots. The grassy take-off is considered suitable for beginners, and the easy access allows for quick turnarounds. All pilots should be mindful of the conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Take-off Access: Take the D503 towards Rabou. 1500m before reaching Rabou, turn right onto a small road towards La Chau. Continue by car on a footpath for 500m to reach the landing zone.
  • Parking: Parking is available near the windsock.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Mountain Weather: Rapidly changing mountain weather conditions are a significant risk. Always check the forecast before flying and be prepared for strong gusts and turbulence. Spring conditions can be much stronger than those experienced in autumn.
  • Limited Emergency Landing Areas: The rocky or rough terrain surrounding the site may limit your options for emergency landings.
  • Airspace Awareness: Be vigilant and aware of any airspace restrictions in the area, as indicated by the National Federation (FFVL).
  • Respect the Site: As the FFVL status of the site may not be officially labelled, caution and respect for the environment are paramount.
  • Access Roads: Adapt your driving speed on access roads and respect fields, especially during cultivation periods.
search_recs: Rabou paragliding access and fees paragliding Rabou France site description Rabou paragliding site official information FFVL Rabou

html:
Overview

Accous is a renowned paragliding site nestled in the Aspe Valley within the Pyrénées-Atlantiques department of France. Situated in the heart of the Pyrenees National Park, this location offers stunning mountainous scenery and excellent thermaling opportunities. With the village of Accous at the mouth of the Iseye circus, pilots can enjoy memorable flights in a spectacular setting.

Flying Conditions

  • Season: Flying is generally possible from April to October, with June and September hosting national paragliding competitions.
  • Take-off Altitude: The main take-off (Delta) is at 1226m, offering a height difference of 750m or more.
  • Winds: The site is best suited for North, North-West, and West winds. East, South-East, South, and South-West winds are unfavorable.
  • Thermal Activity: Accous is known for its thermaling conditions, providing opportunities for cross-country (XC) flights.
  • Valley Breeze: Be aware that the valley breeze can become strong in the afternoon.
  • Weather Information: A weather beacon provides real-time wind information to aid in flight planning.

Who Should Fly Here?

Accous welcomes pilots of all skill levels. While suitable for beginners, experience in thermaling is beneficial. The FFVL (French Free Flight Association) recommends a minimum skill level of IPPI 3 (débutant/beginner). Its popularity makes it a great place to meet other paragliders and share flying experiences.

Access & Facilities

  • Take-off Access: The main take-off is accessible by car or a shuttle service managed by the local club, Accous d'Ailes.
  • Road Conditions: The road is mostly paved, with a final section on a drivable track.
  • Walk to Launch: Expect a 15-minute walk from the parking area to the take-off.
  • Shuttle Fees: Contact the local club (Accous d'Ailes) regarding shuttle fees and schedules.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Cyclonic Southerly Winds: Flying at Accous can be dangerous in cyclonic southerly winds.
  • Strong Valley Breeze: The valley breeze can become strong in the afternoon, potentially making landings at the "500" landing zone difficult.
  • Turbulence: Northerly winds (Advection and EPM) or westerly spillover can generate turbulence. Summer storms also require increased vigilance.
  • Downwind Conditions: The area to the left of the three mamelons (small hills) on an east/west axis (south-facing slopes) is often downwind under normal breeze conditions.
  • Proximity to power lines: Be aware of the presence of power lines during take-off and landing. Voltigeurs should be aware of the risk of electrocution from high-voltage lines.
  • Landing Zone Risk: There is a risk of a gradient wind at the "Accous - 500" landing zone.
  • ZRT (Restricted Zone): Be aware of the ZRT located to the north of the site, near the village of Bedous.
  • Pyrenees National Park Regulations: Note that the Pyrenees National Park is located to the south of the site. Paragliding is authorized to a height of less than 1000 meters above the ground in the heart of the National Park. The minimum height above the ground is 200 meters and at a distance of 200 meters from all walls, take-off from the heart is prohibited with the exception of the summits mentioned in Article 3 of the present decree, landing in the heart of the National Park is prohibited.
  • Gypaète barbu (Bearded Vulture): To ensure cohabitation with free flight activities and the preservation of the Gypaète barbu, it is important not to enter the Zones de Sensibilité Majeures (ZSM) when they are active. These zones are closed to free flight below 2200 meters altitude during the breeding season, which is typically between November 1st and August 15th. Updated information is usually posted on a panel at the chalet on site.

It is always recommended to contact local paragliding schools and clubs like Accous d'Ailes for the most up-to-date information on site conditions, regulations, and any temporary restrictions.
search_recs: parapente Accous France informations site officiel Accous paragliding site details paragliding Accous France site information Accous paragliding official site Accous paragliding club

html:
Overview

Poniente is a popular paragliding site located in Algodonales, Spain, within the Sierra de Lijar mountain range in the beautiful Grazalema Natural Park. Known for its thermaling and soaring opportunities, including potential cross-country (XC) flights, it's a fantastic site for experienced pilots looking for challenging conditions.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: The Poniente take-off is designed for South Westerly to Westerly winds.
  • Altitude: The take-off is located at 910m (3000ft).
  • Seasonal Flying:
    • March-May & September-October: Ideal for big XC flights.
    • November-February: Suitable for building hours in stable conditions.
    • July-August: Can be too thermic and potentially dangerous, best to avoid flying before 18:00 (6 PM).
  • Thermal Activity: Thermals can be strong, especially during the summer months. Pilots can achieve significant altitude gains, typically 500m-1,000m above launch, and up to 2,000m is possible.

Who Should Fly Here?

Poniente is recommended for experienced pilots only. It is not suitable for low airtime pilots or those fresh out of training. The launch ridge can get crowded, requiring confident launch and flying skills.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The take-off is accessible by road.
  • Shuttle Services: Shuttle services are available for a fee (approximately €10). CIVA offers accommodation and transfers.
  • Parking: Parking is available in the landing zone, potentially free for campers.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Strong Thermals (Summer): Be cautious of strong thermals during summer months, especially in July and August. Avoid flying before 18:00 (6 PM) during these months.
  • Power Lines: The landing area has power lines running parallel to it. Plan your approach carefully to avoid these lines, always passing after the lines during landing approach.
  • Landing Area Visibility: The landing field is not directly visible from the takeoff point.
  • Landing Options: Landing options can be limited due to the prevalence of olive trees.
  • Bird Protection Zones: Be aware of bird protection zones in the Algodonales area, especially from December 1 to July 31, and adhere to restrictions.
  • Local Briefing: It's essential to get a briefing from a local pilot or guide before flying this site.
  • Airspace and Nature Protection: Algodonales is subject to airspace and nature protection regulations.
search_recs: paragliding site Poniente description paragliding Poniente Spain Poniente paragliding official site Poniente paragliding access fees

html:
Overview

Cenes de la Vega is a popular paragliding site located south of Granada in Andalusia, Spain, near the Sierra Nevada mountains. This site offers a significant height difference and stunning views of the mountainous area, Monachil, and the Alhambra. Known as an "easy" site, it attracts beginners and tandem flights, making it a vibrant spot for both learning and enjoying the skies.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Suitable for SE, S, SW, W, and NW wind directions.
  • Thermals: The area is known for strong and turbulent thermals, particularly between 14:00 and 18:00 in the spring. Pilots should exercise caution during these times.
  • Altitude: Takeoff altitudes are either 747m or 1267m, depending on the specific launch location. The height difference is approximately 572m.
  • Wind Timing: In spring, the wind typically starts around 10:30-11:00.

Who Should Fly Here?

Cenes de la Vega is ideally suited for beginners due to its large takeoff area and multiple emergency landing options. However, pilots should be aware of the potentially strong and turbulent thermals, especially in the afternoon. Experienced pilots will also enjoy the site, particularly during calmer morning hours.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The site is accessible by car, followed by a short walk to the takeoff. One takeoff (Cenes de la Vega 1) involves a steep 15-minute walk.
  • Landing Area: The landing area is situated next to the main road, on a former landfill.
  • Permits: There is older information suggesting a permit might be needed to use the road to the launch site to avoid potential fines. It is strongly advised to verify current permit requirements locally before flying.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Landing Challenges: The landing area is located next to a main road on a former garbage dump and valley winds can make landings challenging.
  • Strong Winds & Thermals: Avoid flying between 14:00 and 17:00-18:00 (and sometimes later) due to strong winds and thermals.
  • Flying Over the City: It is prohibited to fly over the city below 150m AGL (Above Ground Level).
search_recs: Cenes paragliding regulations Cenes paragliding club paragliding Cenes Spain site guide Cenes de la Vega paragliding Cenes paragliding access

html:
Overview

Peña Negra, situated in Piedrahita, Ávila, Castile and León, Spain, offers a premier paragliding experience on the northern face of the Sierra de Gredos. Launching from 1,909 meters (6,204 feet) ASL with a generous 900-meter (2,925 feet) top-to-bottom height, this site boasts a stunning landscape where a mountain range rises dramatically from a vast, open plain. It's a well-established and popular flying location, attracting pilots from around the globe.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Peña Negra is renowned for excellent thermal flying and exceptional cross-country (XC) potential. Ridge soaring opportunities are also available.
  • Seasonality: Prime flying season spans from April to October, with July often considered optimal due to high cloud bases (exceeding 4,000m) and gentle westerly winds. August is also reliable, although inversions may delay the start of flying until later in the day.
  • Weather Considerations:
    • The launch faces NW, allowing thermals to develop from late morning thanks to the mountain's shallow slope.
    • Be mindful that the thermal breeze at launch can strengthen significantly by mid-afternoon (consider flying before 1:30 PM).
    • Easterly winds can become strong and turbulent further out.
    • Westerly winds tend to increase at the pass.
    • Strong southerly winds (over 20 km/hr) can prevent the anabatic wind from reaching the Peña Negra launch on unstable days.

Who Should Fly Here?

Peña Negra caters to pilots of varying skill levels. While experienced pilots will relish the cross-country opportunities and challenging thermals, beginners will find medium-to-easy flights within reach. The site's popularity is underscored by its history of hosting European Championships and other prestigious competitions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Reaching the Peña Negra launch is straightforward via a tarmac road (AV-932) connecting Piedrahita to the Peña Negra pass.
  • Parking: A large car park is conveniently located right next to the rigging area.
  • Fees: There are no known access fees for the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Exercise caution with strong winds, particularly those with an easterly component, which can complicate flights to the west. Be aware that strong southerly winds (over 20 km/hr) can prevent the anabatic wind from reaching the Peña Negra launch on unstable days. In strong easterly forecasts, the take off can appear fine due to shielding from the mountains, but strong and turbulent winds may exist out in the valley.
  • Thermic Activity: During summer, anticipate strong thermic conditions and restitutions.
  • Mountain Flying: While the Gredos mountains offer great potential for mountain flying, be aware that the area is isolated, and landing out can lead to lengthy retrieves.
  • Crossing Villatoro Pass: When flying cross country, pilots should have more than 2500m QNH to cross the Puerto de Villatoro with a safety margin.
  • Landing Fields: Official landing fields in the valley can change yearly, so it's essential to check with local pilots for the most up-to-date information. Not all landowners welcome landings; therefore, it's advisable to land and move to a road to pack up.
  • Main Launch Hazards:
    • A fence is situated to the rear of the top takeoff; if there is a possibility of being dragged back on a failed takeoff, it's best to prepare a little downslope.
    • With nil wind, it's generally better to take off below the road as it is steeper. If there is any danger of catabatic wind, it will affect the upper takeoff first.
  • Lastra del Cano Takeoff:
    • Only use if there is no prohibition due to bird and environmental protection.
    • Located 4km along a forestry track, accessed from in front of the bar of Lastra del Cano village. There is a gate after 400m that may be closed.
    • This site is often used when the wind is too strong from the South for the anabatic wind to come up the Peña Negra launch (on unstable days, southerly winds of more than 20km/hr can be stopped by the valley breeze at Peña Negra) or when the wind is over the back early in the day at Peña Negra.
    • Unless you get away early, the conditions can become too strong to take off.
  • Airspace: Be aware of important airspace restrictions approximately 64 km to the east, and airspace beyond Avila. Classic flights to the west towards Ávila are possible until you encounter restricted airspace. Northwest of Ávila, there is a NOTAM area where flying is permitted but only below 3000 meters. Always check current regulations before flying.
search_recs: Peña Negra paragliding access Peña Negra paragliding Peña Negra paragliding official site Peña Negra vuelo libre Peña Negra Peña Negra paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Pegalajar, located in Jaén, Andalusia, southern Spain, is a renowned paragliding site offering a mix of flatland and mountain flying. With a history spanning over 30 years and operated by the "Club Vuelo Pegalajar," this site is known for excellent cross-country (XC) potential and has hosted numerous prestigious competitions.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Flyable in various wind directions, including West (W), Northwest (NW), North (N), and Northeast (NE).
  • Season: Flying is typically possible from March to November.
  • Thermals: Well-defined thermals with cloud base reaching above 3000m.
  • Valley Winds & Conversion Lines: Offers a combination of flatland and mountain flying conditions.
  • Venturi Effect: The mountain can create a venturi effect, potentially leading to very strong winds at takeoff.

Who Should Fly Here?

Pegalajar attracts a wide range of pilots, and it's popularity is reflected in the many competitions that it has hosted. The site is sometimes described as "easy". However, the mixed terrain and conditions suggest that sufficient knowledge of meteorology and flying experience is required.

Access & Facilities

  • Takeoff Access: Easily accessible, located just 2 km from Pegalajar via a road with ample parking.
  • Shuttles: Daily shuttles from the HQ to the takeoff may be available.
  • Accommodation: Camping may be available for a fee.
  • Transportation: To reach Pegalajar, take a train to Jaén Capital followed by a bus.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Be aware of potentially strong winds at takeoff due to the mountain's venturi effect.
  • Landing Difficulties: The surrounding area is covered in olive trees, which can make landing tricky.
  • Strong Thermals: Thermals can be very strong, with cloud base exceeding 3000m.
  • Cables: Be aware of cables to the right of the Siete Pilillas launch site.
  • Airspace Restrictions: The Estación de Vuelo Libre de Siete Pilillas flying site has regulated airspace that requires authorization from the Spanish Aviation Safety Agency before flying.
  • General Restrictions: Flying in controlled airspace, restricted (R), prohibited (P), and dangerous (D) zones is prohibited, as is flying over crowds of people or buildings.
search_recs: Pegalajar paragliding club Pegalajar paragliding site information Pegalajar paragliding official site Pegalajar paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Castejón de Sos, nestled in the heart of the Pyrenees within the Benasque Valley, is a renowned paragliding destination. The landscape boasts high mountains and a verdant valley, with the primary launch site, Liri, offering stunning views across the Aragonese Pyrenees. As a central location for paragliding in the area, Castejón de Sos is home to several paragliding schools and businesses.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermalling and Cross-Country (XC): Known for its excellent thermalling and XC flying opportunities.
  • Launch Direction: The main take-off, Liri, faces southeast and is ideal for morning XC flights.
  • Thermal Strength: Strong thermal conditions are common in spring and summer, with cloud bases frequently reaching 3,000m to 3,500m, and sometimes exceeding 4,000m. Expect thermals of 6-7m/s.
  • Prevailing Winds: Westerly winds are favorable for eastward XC flights.
  • Flying Season: Possible year-round, with thermalling opportunities from mid-February to October. Autumn offers mellower flying, while winter is suitable for flying and speed riding, weather permitting.
  • Landing Zone Winds: Pilots should be aware that wind patterns in the landing zone typically shift from north-westerly in the morning to south-easterly during the day, south-westerly in the evening, before turning northerly again late at night.

Who Should Fly Here?

Castejón de Sos caters to a wide range of experience levels. Beginners can enroll in paragliding courses offered by local schools, while experienced pilots can take advantage of the excellent XC flying opportunities.

Access & Facilities

  • Liri Launch: Access to the Liri launch site (2,300m) is typically provided via a shuttle service, costing around €10. The ride uphill takes approximately 45 minutes.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Hazards: As a high mountain zone, weather conditions can develop very quickly. It's essential to monitor the weather and cloud development closely.
  • Unpredictable Winds: Be cautious of unpredictable northerly winds, which can increase suddenly and become dangerous (foehn effect).
  • Strong Thermals: Exercise caution during strong thermal conditions around midday, especially in summer.
  • Rapidly Changing Conditions: Be prepared for conditions to change quickly, particularly in spring and summer.
  • Liri Takeoff Hazards: The wind can be unpredictable, particularly from the north, which can increase suddenly and become dangerous.
  • Castejón de Sos Intermediate Takeoff: Requires a very specific wind direction. A long takeoff run is not possible due to the gentle slope, which could hinder the takeoff. Access outside of March to December can be difficult due to snow.
  • Piedras Blancas Takeoff: Often used in the morning when it's cross at Liri.
  • Airspace at El Raso Landing: Shared airspace with ultralight aircraft requires strict adherence to rules at the "El Raso" landing area.
  • El Raso Landing Area Rules:
    • Do not fold your glider in the middle of the runway; use the sides.
    • Avoid abrupt maneuvers during landing to remain predictable to other aircraft.
    • Do not land in the middle of the runway; if you do, clear the glider to the sides immediately.
    • Always look before crossing the runway, as ultralight aircraft can be quiet.
  • Radio Communication: It is advisable to keep your radio tuned to the frequency used by local schools for condition updates.
search_recs: Castejón de Sos paragliding skill level Castejón de Sos paragliding official site paragliding Castejón de Sos site description Castejón de Sos paragliding access fees

html:
Overview

El Bosque, nestled in the province of Cádiz, Andalusia, Southern Spain, offers pilots a fantastic flying experience on the edge of the Sierra de Grazalema Natural Park. With forest-covered ridges, exposed cliff faces, and stunning mountain views, this site provides a memorable backdrop for paragliding and hang gliding adventures. It's known as a great alternative to Algodonales when the winds are too strong there.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions:
    • Ideal for West and Northwest winds.
  • Thermals and Soaring:
    • Known for good thermals and soaring conditions.
    • Enjoy evening flights with valley lift extending until sunset.
  • Best Time to Fly:
    • Optimal conditions in autumn, winter, and spring, though flying is possible year-round.

Who Should Fly Here?

El Bosque caters to pilots of all skill levels, making it a popular choice. Several paragliding schools operate in the area, providing instruction and guidance. The landing is considered easy.

Access & Facilities

  • Access:
    • Drive to the site and then hike for 10-15 minutes to the takeoff.
    • There is no designated parking area.
  • Fees:
    • The status of any site fees is unclear; check with local operators for the most up-to-date information.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Rocky Terrain:
    • The takeoff area can be rocky, requiring extra caution during launch.
  • Vultures:
    • Be aware of vultures in the area. Fly safely to avoid collisions and disturbances to the birds.
  • Mountainous Terrain & Natural Park Proximity:
    • El Bosque is situated on the edge of the Grazalema Natural Park. The only zones of the Natural Park intended for paragliding practice is Cerro Albarracín, where the takeoffs are located.
    • Pilots should respect any regulations affecting the practice in this area.
  • El Bosque 2 Takeoff:
    • If the wind is crossed from the North, pilots need to be prepared, as the glider may go to the other side of the takeoff area.
    • The takeoff is a bit small.
  • Airspace & Flight Restrictions:
    • Flights should be performed in accordance with diurnal Visual Flight Rules (VFR).
    • Avoid flying over controlled airspace, restricted, prohibited, or activated danger areas, congested areas, and groups of people.
    • Maximum pressure altitude of 10,000 feet, but can operate between 10,000 and 13,000 feet for less than 30 minutes during the entire flight.
search_recs: El Bosque paragliding site information paragliding El Bosque Spain Club de parapente El Bosque paragliding regulations El Bosque Spain

html:
Overview

Loja, situated in Andalusia, Southern Spain, offers a diverse paragliding experience within the Sierra de Loja mountain range. This area, characterized by a high plateau transitioning into mountainous terrain, provides an altitude difference of approximately 600m, making it suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding. The town of Loja itself is split by the Genil River, adding to the scenic beauty of the location.

Flying Conditions

  • Takeoff Directions: West, Northwest, East, and Southeast.
  • Type of Flying: Known for thermal flying and cross-country (XC) potential.
  • Wind: Wind conditions are often present, as evidenced by the presence of wind turbines in the area.
  • Best Time to Fly: Spring and summer are generally recommended.

Who Should Fly Here?

With a medium difficulty rating, Loja is suited for both single and tandem flights. While the takeoff can be narrow and better suited to intermediate pilots with takeoff experience, the site's versatility ensures it can be enjoyed by a range of skill levels.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Both take-off spots are accessible via a natural/dirt road.
  • Fees: There is no readily available information about specific fees or permits required to fly the site. Check with local authorities or clubs for the most up-to-date information.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Conditions: Flights are often cancelled or postponed if conditions are deemed unsafe. Spring conditions can be strong. It is essential to check the weather forecast and assess wind strength and direction before flying.
  • Turbulence: Flying in conditions of turbulence is prohibited.
  • Site Conditions: Emergency landing areas may be limited due to rocky or rough terrain.
  • Crowded Sites: Be cautious on crowded sites and respect priority rules.
  • Takeoff Conditions: The takeoff can be narrow. The takeoff is suited to intermediate pilots with takeoff experience.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Flights are prohibited over controlled airspace, restricted, prohibited, or activated danger areas, and over congested areas.
  • Altitude Restrictions: Maximum flight altitude is 3,000 meters (10,000 feet), with a possible allowance to fly between 3,000 and 4,000 meters (10,000-13,000 feet) for no more than 30 minutes during the entire flight. Consult NOTAM before flying.
  • General Regulations: Paragliding in Spain is overseen by the Spanish Aviation Safety Agency (AESA) and is subject to the air regulations.
  • VFR Conditions: Flights must be performed under diurnal Visual Flight Rules (VFR).
  • Documentation: It is recommended to have both insurance and a pilot qualification from your own country. Some autonomous regions or sports federations may require specific documentation.
  • Equipment: Harness or seatbelts and helmets are mandatory.
  • Prior Authorisation: Paragliding is prohibited within airport approach and takeoff zones without prior authorization. Any aerial activity in controlled airspace requires coordination with air traffic control authorities.
  • Minimum Altitudes:
    • Over congested areas of cities, towns or settlements or over an open-air assembly of persons: at a height less than 300 m (1 000 ft) above the highest obstacle within a radius of 600 m from the aircraft.
    • Elsewhere: at a height less than 150 m (500 ft) above the ground or water, or 150 m (500 ft) above the highest obstacle within a radius of 150 m (500 ft) from the aircraft.
    Spanish airspace authority (ENAIRE) establishes the following specifications: Elsewhere: at a height less than 50m (150 ft) above the ground or water.
search_recs: Loja Spain flying conditions paragliding paragliding site Loja Spain Paragliding Loja Spain Loja Spain paragliding club Access to paragliding site Loja Spain

html:
Overview

Pedro Bernardo, often called the "Balcony of Tiétar," is a renowned paragliding site nestled in the province of Ávila, Castile and León, in central Spain. Situated on the southern slopes of the Sierra de Gredos, overlooking the Tietar Valley, this site offers stunning panoramic views and excellent conditions for thermal flying and cross-country adventures.

Flying Conditions

  • Take-off Points: Pedro Bernardo features three main take-off points, each catering to different wind conditions:
    • South Take-off: Altitude of approximately 950m ASL.
    • East Take-off: The highest and most popular, at around 1000m ASL.
    • West Take-off (Risco de la Sierpe): Reaching approximately 1200m ASL.
  • Wind Conditions: The predominant wind direction is from the Southwest. The site is known for strong thermals, particularly during the summer months.
  • Thermal Flying: Pedro Bernardo is a high-mountain flying site with exceptional thermal activity, providing opportunities for long-duration flights. Distances over 200km have been achieved from this location.
  • Flyable Season: The site is generally flyable throughout the year, thanks to its favorable thermal conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Pedro Bernardo is a popular site that welcomes pilots of varying skill levels. While the take-offs are considered easy and suitable for pilots with a basic license, the strong thermal activity in summer requires experience in handling such conditions. The site also hosts national and international competitions, attracting seasoned pilots looking to push their limits.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Take-off areas are generally accessible by car, followed by a short walk. The roads leading to the take-offs are typically suitable for most vehicles.
  • Transportation: The local flying club, "Club de Vuelo y Montaña de Pedro Bernardo," may offer transportation to the take-off locations. Check with them for availability.
  • Fees: Entry fees may apply for participation in competitions.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Power Lines: Be aware of a power line located within the flying area. Maintain a safe distance at all times.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Pedro Bernardo is situated within an area affected by the Madrid-Barajas airspace. Be aware of altitude restrictions.
  • NOTAMs: Check for current NOTAMs (Notices to Airmen) before flying, as temporary altitude adjustments may be in effect.
  • Restricted Zone LER 71: The site is located within the LER 71 restricted zone. Familiarize yourself with the restrictions and regulations applicable to this zone before flying.
  • Per-Takeoff Risks: Be aware that risks may vary depending on the chosen take-off point and prevailing wind conditions.
search_recs: paragliding Spain Pedro Bernardo access fees Club de parapente Pedro Bernardo paragliding Pedro Bernardo Spain site information Pedro Bernardo paragliding official site Pedro Bernardo paragliding difficulty

html:
Overview

Villar del Arzobispo, located approximately 60 km from Valencia in the Valencian Community, Spain, is a popular paragliding destination known for its stable conditions and vibrant flying community. Nestled within the rugged terrain of the Serranía Valenciana, this site offers excellent opportunities for both paragliding and hang gliding.

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable Winds: Best with SE winds, but ENE and S winds can also be suitable.
  • Thermal Activity: Ideal thermal conditions for extended flights.
  • Airspace Restriction: Flights must remain below 1200m (4000ft) due to commercial aircraft approaches to Valencia airport.

Who Should Fly Here?

Villar del Arzobispo attracts pilots of all experience levels. It's a busy site, especially in the summer, offering rewarding flying for both novice and experienced pilots alike. It's even considered the easiest place to fly in the province of Valencia.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Easily accessible by car followed by a short walk to the takeoff.
  • Fees: No information available regarding site fees.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Awareness: Commercial aircraft use the airspace for approaches to Valencia airport, so pilots must be mindful of the 1200m (4000ft) altitude limit.
  • Hunting Season Restrictions: From the beginning of November to the end of February, flying is PROHIBITED on Thursdays, weekends, and holidays due to hunting season.
  • Respect Local Rules: Adherence to the hunting season restrictions is crucial. Consider flying in nearby areas like Higueruelas, Chulilla, or Titagüas on restricted days.
  • Local Knowledge: Always check with local pilots for updated information, especially regarding hunting season restrictions.
  • AIP Publication: Villar de Arzobispo is now published as a flight zone in the AIP (Aeronautical Information Publication), increasing awareness and safety by marking the area on air navigation charts.
search_recs: Club de parapente Villar de Arzobispo villar de arzobispo paragliding site information paragliding Villar de Arzobispo paragliding site guide Villar de Arzobispo Villar de Arzobispo paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Figueroles is a popular paragliding site located in the Valencian Community, in the province of Castellón, Spain. Offering a unique blend of rocky landscapes and sea views, it presents a great environment for thermaling and cross-country (XC) flights.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: The take-off faces south, with the best wind directions being Southeast, South, and Southwest.
  • Thermals: Figueroles is known for its thermal activity, providing good opportunities for soaring and XC flights.
  • Altitude: The take-off point is at a maximum altitude of 700m, offering a height difference of 270m.

Who Should Fly Here?

Figueroles is considered a site of medium difficulty. It is suitable for intermediate to advanced pilots comfortable with thermaling conditions. First-time visitors are strongly advised to seek local advice before flying.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access is primarily by car, followed by a walk to the take-off. From Figueroles, head towards Mas de la Parra, following the "L'APIPA" signs from in front of Bar La Juventud. Park at the highest point of the slope and walk along the path to the take-off.
  • Fees: Information regarding fees is limited. However, some sites in the region have regulated and paying access for cars, but it is not confirmed for Figueroles.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Restrictions: Figueroles is located within the Valencia airport TMA (Terminal Control Area). Pilots must respect airspace regulations and be vigilant about commercial air traffic to Castellón Airport.
  • Commercial Flight Path: The site is on the direct route of commercial flights to Castellón Airport.
  • Takeoff Difficulty: The takeoffs are considered to be of medium difficulty.
  • VFR Rules: General VFR (Visual Flight Rules) apply. Minimum altitudes must be respected, as specified in SERA 5005, section f, December 2018 document.
    • Over congested areas, maintain a height of at least 300 m (1,000 ft) above the highest obstacle within a 600 m radius.
    • Elsewhere, maintain a height of at least 150 m (500 ft) above the ground or water, or 150 m (500 ft) above the highest obstacle within a 150 m radius.
    • Spanish airspace authority (ENAIRE) establishes a minimum height of 50m (150 ft) above ground or water for certain VFR operations.
  • Contact: The website http://alasdef.org is listed as a site contact, which may provide additional information and local guidance.
search_recs: Figueroles paragliding Spain Figueroles paragliding access Figueroles paragliding site guide Figueroles paragliding official information parapente Figueroles España Figueroles paragliding skill level

html:
Overview

Montellano is a popular paragliding site nestled in Andalusia, Southern Spain, near the historic city of Seville. Characterized by a well-inclined ridge and a maximum height difference of 162m (300-341m ASL), the site provides a brilliant location for ridge soaring amidst the picturesque Mediterranean forests and olive groves of the region.

Flying Conditions

Montellano is particularly renowned for its ridge soaring opportunities, especially when the wind blows from the North-East. The site also offers the potential for exciting cross-country (XC) flights. It's worth noting that Montellano tends to experience stronger wind conditions compared to nearby Algodonales. When the NE winds prevail, Montellano becomes a hotspot, drawing many pilots due to its unique suitability for this wind direction.

Who Should Fly Here?

While Montellano welcomes pilots of all skill levels, some sources recommend it for pilots with some experience. This is due to the relatively stronger wind conditions and the specific designated landing area. The site is also described as brilliant for pilots with low airtime.

Access & Facilities

The site is easily accessible by car, followed by a short walk to the takeoff area. A new, designated landing area is available, which is on rented land.

Guest pilots are allowed, however respect for signaling at takeoff and landing is expected. Check with local pilots and Montellano flight club.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Infringement: Pilots have been known to inadvertently fly through Class D airspace and NOTAM'd danger zones. Always be mindful of airspace restrictions to avoid potential hazards.
  • Overcrowding: The launch area at Montellano can become quite crowded, especially during peak thermal activity.
  • Landing Area: Landing is restricted to the designated rented landing area. Landing elsewhere is strictly prohibited. Be especially careful to avoid landing in planted fields ("fincas sembradas").
  • Guest Pilot Restrictions: The Montellano site is not open to guest pilots on weekends.
  • Respect Signaling: Pilots must respect signaling at takeoff and landing.

It is strongly advised to connect with local pilots and the Montellano Flight Club for the most up-to-date information on site conditions, regulations, and any potential hazards.
search_recs: Montellano paragliding club paragliding Montellano Spain site information Montellano paragliding official site

html:
Overview

Palomaret is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Valencian Community of southeastern Spain, near Agost, Alicante. Located on the El Palomaret ridge between El Cid and Maigmó peaks, this site offers stunning views over the arid, mountainous Alicante landscape.

Flying Conditions

Palomaret is renowned for its thermal flying conditions, making it an easily accessible and rewarding site. It is suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including tandem flights. The site supports East, Southeast, South, and Southwest wind directions, offering stable and prolonged flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Palomaret welcomes pilots of all skill levels, including beginners. Its popularity stems from the ease of access and consistent conditions, making it a great spot for training and tandem flights. However, pilots should be mindful of potential overcrowding, especially on weekends.

Access & Facilities

The site is easily accessible by car, followed by a short walk to the takeoff. A rural lane leads up to a wide clearing on the El Palomaret ridge. The drive from Alicante takes approximately 20 minutes. Carpooling with local clubs is encouraged to minimize disturbance. While specific fees are not mentioned, it is essential to have civil liability insurance as required by Spanish law.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace Restrictions: The most significant risk at Palomaret is the proximity to Alicante Airport's controlled airspace (Class D), which starts at 300m above the terrain. Pilots must avoid entering this airspace to prevent conflicts with air traffic. Consult insigniavfr.enaire.es for airspace information.
  • Wind Conditions: Be cautious of rotor conditions in the landing area south of the launch when the wind is from the east ("Levante"). In these conditions, use the east landing area.
  • Spanish Regulations:
    • Pilots are required to have civil liability insurance.
    • Although a specific paragliding license is not required in Spain, a pilot qualification from your home country and adequate insurance are highly recommended by the Spanish Free Flying Association (AVLE).
    • Adhere to minimum altitudes: 300 m (1000 ft) above congested areas and 150 m (500 ft) elsewhere, or 50m (150 ft) above ground or water.
  • General Flight Rules:
    • Flights must be conducted under Visual Flight Rules (VFR) during daylight hours and in Visual Meteorological Conditions (VMC). Avoid flying in turbulent or marginal conditions.
    • Flying in controlled airspace, restricted (R), prohibited (P), and dangerous areas (D) that are active is not allowed.
    • Flying over crowds of people or buildings is not permitted.
search_recs: Palomaret paragliding access Palomaret paragliding site Palomaret paragliding official information Palomaret paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Santa Marina de Orozco is a popular paragliding site nestled in the mountainous Basque Country of Spain, near the Gorbea Natural Park. Known for its excellent thermaling conditions, it's a favourite among local pilots seeking to experience the region's dynamic skies. The launch site is a grassy field, accessible by car.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Primarily flyable with northerly winds, with a preference for North to Northeast winds. Santa Marina de Arrola-Orozco is used as an alternative take-off when winds are too strong at nearby Orduña.
  • Seasonal Considerations: The prime flying season extends from March to September.
  • Thermal Activity: Renowned as one of the best thermaling sites in Bizkaia, benefitting from a sea breeze that sustains thermal activity throughout the day. Expect typical cloudbase heights around 1250-1500m.
  • Cross-Country Potential: Excellent potential for XC flights, with achievable distances of around 150 km and good triangles of 80 km possible. Local flights frequently involve flying to the Oderiaga peak and returning to the village (approximately 25km).
  • Late Day Soaring: Flying is generally best after 17:00.

Who Should Fly Here?

This site is suitable for pilots of various experience levels, as indicated by parapentegorobel.eus. However, experience with thermal flying is definitely beneficial. Keep in mind that strong thermals can be challenging for less experienced pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Take-off Access: The take-off area is easily accessible by car. The take-off is wide and suitable for kiting practice.
  • Parking: Pilots are requested to park responsibly, avoiding blocking the road end to ensure emergency services have access.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Be mindful of wind strength at take-off, as conditions can change rapidly.
  • Thermal Strength: Strong thermals can pose a challenge to less experienced pilots.
  • Turbulence: The official landing zone may experience turbulence due to the confluence of two local valley breezes.
  • Landing Zone Distance: Be aware that the official landing zone may be too far to reach if there is no wind or thermal lift. Consider your altitude and glide path carefully.
  • Alternative Landing Zones: Fields are available for landing, but be aware that they may be inclined and have cables to avoid.
  • Landing Permission: Confirm landing permission before flying, as the landing field is borrowed.
search_recs: Santa Marina de Orozco access paragliding Club parapente Santa Marina de Orozco Santa Marina de Orozco paragliding parapente Santa Marina de Orozco

html:
Overview

El Yelmo, nestled in the Sierra de Segura within the Sierras de Cazorla, Segura y las Villas Natural Park in Andalusia, Spain, is a renowned paragliding site. Known as the "acro mecca" of Spain, it attracts pilots for its excellent thermal soaring, cross-country (XC) potential, and vibrant paragliding community. With its stunning mountainous landscape dotted with olive groves and historic castles, El Yelmo offers a unique and rewarding flying experience.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions:
    • Main (West) Take-off: Suitable for West, Northwest, and Southwest winds.
    • South Take-off: A secondary take-off for South winds.
    • East Take-off: A less frequently used take-off for East winds (Levante).
  • Prevailing Winds: Westerly winds are common due to the Guadalquivir valley.
  • Thermals: Excellent thermal soaring conditions. Late afternoon restitution thermals are frequent from May to August. Summer can bring strong thermal activity in the middle of the day.
  • Cross-Country (XC): High potential for XC flights, with distances exceeding 200km achieved. Best days for distance flights are in spring and autumn.

Who Should Fly Here?

El Yelmo caters to a wide range of pilot skill levels. However, due to the technical nature of some take-offs and potentially challenging landing conditions, it is recommended that novice pilots gain experience before flying here. Advanced pilots will appreciate the opportunity for long-distance flights and acro training.

Access & Facilities

  • Meeting Point: The main meeting point for pilots is the bar 'Los Pinos' at the roundabout in Cortijos Nuevos.
  • Access to Take-off: Driving to the summit is possible.
  • Shuttle Service: There is no organized shuttle service. Drivers are needed to retrieve pilots from the landing zone, a 25-minute drive away.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Power Lines:
    • A high-tension power line runs through the middle of the valley. If low, aim for landing areas near Ojuelo village.
    • An electrical line is also present on the slope, specifically near the Poniente Takeoff.
  • Landing Challenges:
    • The "official" landing area is in Orcera. Ensure sufficient altitude to reach it.
    • Alternative landings in olive groves are possible but can be uneven.
  • Takeoff Precautions: Takeoff and landing are statistically the riskiest phases of paragliding.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Avoid flying in controlled airspaces, near airports, in air traffic control zones, or in air corridors without authorization. During competitions, entering restricted zones invalidates the flight.
  • Height Restrictions: During competitions, exceeding NOTAM-imposed height restrictions results in penalties.
  • Hunting Season: Be aware of potential flight restrictions during the red partridge hunting season (February to March).
  • Cables: Be aware of cables while flying in the area.
search_recs: El Yelmo paragliding access fees El Yelmo paragliding official site El Yelmo paragliding site information Paragliding El Yelmo description El Yelmo paragliding regulations Club parapente El Yelmo

html:
Overview

Alcúdia, nestled on the northeast coast of Mallorca, Spain, in the Balearic Islands, offers a unique paragliding experience. With its blend of coastal terrain and the imposing Serra de Tramuntana mountains, pilots can enjoy stunning views and a mix of coastal soaring and thermaling opportunities. While site certification for "Alcudia Strand" is uncertain, Puig de Sant Marti provides an excellent launch point for those seeking to experience the thrill of flight over this beautiful landscape.

Flying Conditions

Alcúdia benefits from the convergence of sea winds, which often strengthens thermals, especially on the flanks of Puig de Sant Marti. This makes it an ideal location for both coastal soaring and thermaling. Popular flying times are typically between 12:00 and 17:00, dictated by weather conditions. The parasailing season in Alcúdia runs from May to October, offering a broad window for enjoying the skies.

Who Should Fly Here?

Alcúdia caters to a broad range of pilots. Tandem flights are readily available for beginners with no prior experience, providing a safe and exhilarating introduction to paragliding. However, solo pilots should possess the appropriate skills and experience to handle the coastal conditions and thermal activity.

Access & Facilities

Access to launch sites such as Puig de Sant Marti may involve a walk of approximately 50 minutes. It's advisable to confirm access details and any associated fees or permits with local operators or clubs before flying. Some operators offer convenient transportation to and from the take-off and landing points.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Conditions: Be prepared for shifting and potentially strong wind conditions, requiring careful pre-flight weather assessment.
  • Pilot Error: Human error is a significant risk. Ensure you're properly trained and capable of assessing weather conditions and following safety protocols.
  • Inexperience: Only fly within your skill level. Proper training and certification from a qualified instructor and joining a registered club are crucial for safety.
  • Landing Zone Hazards: Carefully scout and choose landing zones that are flat, clear of obstacles, and offer favorable wind conditions.

Flight Restrictions:

  • Age Limit: The minimum age authorized is 14 years old.
  • Weight Limit: Weight is important at the time of booking, depending on your weight you will assigned times of more or less wind for each person.
  • Areas to Avoid:
    • Controlled Airspaces: Strictly regulated to avoid interference with commercial and military air traffic.
    • Airports and Surroundings: The areas around airports are restricted, including air traffic control zones (ATZ) and terminal control zones (CTR).
    • Air Corridors: Designated routes for commercial and military aircraft—avoid flying in these corridors without authorization.
    • Protected Natural Areas: Many protected areas have restrictions on paragliding to preserve local flora and fauna.
    • Urban Areas: Flying over urban and densely populated areas is generally prohibited.

Important Notes: Equipment should be properly maintained and inspected regularly. It is crucial to comply with local regulations and respect flying rules at all times.
search_recs: paragliding Alcúdia official site paragliding Alcúdia Spain site information Alcúdia paragliding club paragliding Alcúdia requirements

html:
Overview

Arangoiti is a popular paragliding site located in Lumbier, Navarra, Spain. Situated on a large ridge offering stunning views of the Yesa Reservoir, it's known for its thermaling and cross-country flying potential and has a history of hosting paragliding competitions. The site offers a significant height difference of around 723-800 meters and caters to a range of pilots.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals and Cross-Country: Arangoiti is renowned for its thermal activity and opportunities for long cross-country flights.
  • Ridge Soaring: The large ridge at Arangoiti generates excellent lift for soaring.
  • Wind Considerations:
    • North Winds: Be particularly cautious of strong north winds, especially during the summer months.
    • Foehn Winds: Watch for potential Foehn wind effects from the mountains to the north, which can significantly impact flying conditions.
  • Multiple Takeoff Orientations: Arangoiti features various takeoff orientations (N, NE, SE, S, SO, NO), allowing pilots to adapt to different wind conditions. Always assess the specific conditions for each launch area before taking off.

Who Should Fly Here?

Arangoiti is a versatile site suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including tandem flights. While specific skill level recommendations are not explicitly stated, its history of hosting competitions and potential for cross-country flying suggests it is best suited for intermediate to advanced pilots. All pilots should be aware of the potential for strong winds and dynamic conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Access by Car: The site is accessible by car via the north side. From Lumbier, drive to Bigüezal, then follow the road, turning right at junctions.
  • Driving License Requirement: Be aware that a driving license may be required to access the site by road during the summer months. However, an exception is made for pilots who possess a valid flight license.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • North Wind Hazard: The primary risk at Arangoiti is the potential for strong north winds, particularly in summer. These can make flying dangerous and unpredictable.
  • Foehn Wind Influence: Be vigilant for signs of Foehn winds developing from the northern mountains, which can create significant turbulence and downdrafts.
  • Documentation: Ensure you have the appropriate driving or flight license to access the site, especially during the summer.
search_recs: Arangoiti paragliding access Arangoiti paragliding site Spain information Arangoiti paragliding official site Arangoiti paragliding fees

html:
Overview

Arrona is a paragliding site located in Spain, offering coastal flying opportunities. With take-off points at 128m ASL and 406m ASL, it presents a unique flying experience. However, the site is not officially certified, so seeking local advice before flying is essential.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Arrona is best suited for North, Northeast, and Northwest wind directions.
  • Coastal Flying: Pilots can enjoy the beautiful coastal scenery during their flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Given the site's rating of 1 star and uncertified status, Arrona might be better suited for more experienced pilots who are comfortable assessing conditions and making informed decisions. Always seek local advice before flying, especially if you are unfamiliar with the area.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The site is accessible by car, followed by a walk uphill from Zestoa.
  • Facilities: Limited information is available regarding on-site facilities, highlighting the importance of self-sufficiency.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Uncertified Site: As the site is "No" certified, pilots should exercise extra caution and seek local advice before flying.
  • Weather Conditions: Sudden changes in weather can affect flight safety. Check the weather forecast and use an anemometer to estimate wind strength and direction before flying. Be aware that spring conditions can be stronger than autumn.
  • Site Environment: Rocky or rough terrain can limit emergency landing areas. Be prepared for challenging landing conditions.
  • Technical Expertise: Pilots should have the necessary technical expertise for maneuvers and be willing to start flying on easy sites or safe areas that require very simple techniques.
  • Flight Restrictions:
    • Flights should be performed in accordance with diurnal Visual Flight Rules (VFR).
    • Flights over controlled airspace, restricted, prohibited, or activated danger areas, and over congested areas are prohibited.
    • Maximum altitude should not be above 3,000 meters (10,000 ft), although flights between 3,000 and 4,000 meters (10,000-13,000 ft) are permitted for a period not longer than 30 minutes.
    • Minimum altitudes for free flying are:
      • Over congested areas: a height less than 300 m (1000 ft) above the highest obstacle within a radius of 600 m from the aircraft.
      • Elsewhere: at a height less than 150 m (500 ft) above the ground or water, or 150 m (500 ft) above the highest obstacle within a radius of 150 m (500 ft) from the aircraft, or 50m (150 ft) above the ground or water.
  • Licensing & Insurance: While not mandatory, it's strongly recommended to have both insurance and a pilot qualification from your home country. Qualifications are needed to practice paragliding as a business activity (teaching, tandem flights, etc.).
  • Local Regulations: Contact the regional federation for detailed information on specific regional requirements.
  • Airspace Awareness: Be aware of airspace restrictions, especially near airports. Coordinate with air traffic control authorities for aerial activity in controlled airspace.
  • General Safety: Wear adequate protection (helmet, back protector), maintain equipment in good condition through regular checks, and assess weather conditions before flying.
search_recs: Arrona paragliding official site info paragliding Arrona Spain site review Arrona paragliding flying conditions Arrona paragliding access fees

html:
Overview

Vale de Amoreira is a paragliding site nestled in the Serra da Estrela, mainland Portugal's highest mountain range. This picturesque valley location offers stunning views of Torre, the highest peak in mainland Portugal, and the Zêzere River. Located near the traditional mountain village of Manteigas, Vale de Amoreira offers a unique blend of flying adventure and serene natural beauty.

Flying Conditions

Known for its thermaling potential and opportunities for XC (cross-country) flights, Vale de Amoreira boasts a resident thermal in front of the take-off. The east-facing site is aligned with the River Zêzere, providing protection from strong winds originating outside the Serra da Estrela. The flying season extends from February to November, with June to September offering the best conditions, including cloud bases reaching 3000m and the chance for 100km+ XC flights. The site is suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, including 1- and 2-seater flights. The takeoff is suitable for East, North and Northwest winds.

Who Should Fly Here?

Vale de Amoreira is a popular site considered "easy" by local pilots, making it accessible to a range of skill levels. Locals often describe it as one of the most underestimated take-offs in Portugal.

Access & Facilities

The site is developed by "Club Vertical" in 2003. Access is via an 8km tarmac road from Head Quarters (4km from the official landing site), followed by 1.5km of dirt road (approximately a 10-minute drive). The launch site is accessible by car and a short walk. The local club (Clube Vertical) may operate a shuttle to take-off. The landing area is a large field in the valley near the river.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Conditions: Be aware of sudden weather changes. Check the forecast before flying and monitor wind conditions. Spring can bring stronger conditions than autumn. Watch out for strong gusts.
  • Cables: Pay close attention to the electric cables that cross the valley near the landing field.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Respect all airspace regulations to avoid conflicts with other aircraft.
  • Serra da Estrela Protected Area Restrictions: Flights may be restricted due to a very high or maximum risk of forest fires or the activation of airspace for military purposes.
  • Limited Emergency Landing Areas: Emergency landing areas may be limited due to rocky or rough terrain, choose takeoff locations carefully.
search_recs: official paragliding sites Portugal Vale de Amoreira paragliding site guide paragliding Vale de Amoreira Portugal Associação Parapente Vale de Amoreira

html:
Overview

Óbuda is a unique paragliding site in Hungary, located at Hármashatár-hegy in Budapest. Its proximity to the capital city makes it one of Hungary's most special locations for paragliding. Situated on the eastern slope of Hármashatár-hegy, it features a sizable hill with a steep slope and a clearing at the top edge ideal for launching.

Flying Conditions

Óbuda is known as a four-season paragliding location, weather permitting, and is suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding. The difference between the take off and landing is about 300 meters.

Who Should Fly Here?

While the site itself is appealing, be aware that detailed information should be sought at the takeoff site. Experience levels are not specified, but pilots should be aware of the changing landscape.

Access & Facilities

Access to the Óbuda launch area is possible by car and then by foot. There are no fees associated with the site itself.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Changing Landing Zones: Available landing areas are decreasing due to construction, potentially impacting safety, particularly for beginners.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Flights are limited by the TMA (Terminal Control Area) with a maximum altitude of 750 meters AMSL.
  • Újlaki Takeoff (Nearby): Be aware that Újlaki is a difficult launch site, being small and stony.
search_recs: paragliding rules Hungary Obuda paragliding official site Óbuda paragliding site information Óbuda siklóernyőzés

html:
Overview

Csolnok is a charming village in Komárom-Esztergom county, Hungary, nestled in a valley surrounded by picturesque mountains and hills. The area is known for its natural beauty and vineyards adorning many slopes. Csolnok offers pilots the opportunity for thermal soaring and even some cross-country adventures.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Direction: The best wind direction for flying at Csolnok is between 120° and 220°.
  • Thermal Soaring: Csolnok is known for its favorable thermal soaring conditions.
  • Walk & Fly: The site is popular for walk & fly activities.
  • Cross-Country Potential: While not exclusively a cross-country site, Csolnok has seen some successful XC flights, with a site record of 49.1 km.
  • Top Landing: Top landing is a viable option at this site.

Who Should Fly Here?

Csolnok is accessible to pilots flying both single and two-seater paragliders. It is suitable for both 1- and 2-seater gliders.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The site is accessible by car and by foot.
  • Fees: There are currently no known fees for using the Csolnok paragliding site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Agricultural Landings: Landing on agricultural areas is strictly prohibited.
  • Weather Conditions: Be prepared for sudden changes in weather. Strong gusts can lead to altitude loss or canopy collapse. Spring conditions are typically stronger than autumn conditions.
  • Overcrowding: Especially on weekends, the site can become crowded. Be mindful of other pilots and respect priority rules.
  • Wind Indicators: Ensure the site has functioning wind indicators before launching.
  • Thunderstorms: Avoid flying near thunderstorm cells, as they pose significant risks.
  • "Day of the Dead": Respect local customs and refrain from flying during the "Day of the Dead" public holidays.
  • Airspace: Paragliding is only permitted in Class G airspace.
  • Altitude Limits: The general altitude limit for paragliding in the north-west part of Hungary is 760 meters / 2,500 ft AGL (above ground level) and 2900 meters / 9,500 ft AMSL (above mean sea level).
  • Aerodromes: If flying near aerodromes, remain alert and coordinate with the aerodrome manager before entering their traffic zone.
  • Takeoff: The takeoff area is large and wide, featuring several clearings.
search_recs: Csolnok paragliding Csolnok paragliding site Hungary Csolnok landscape Csolnok paragliding club paragliding Hungary site information Csolnok paragliding regulations

html:
Overview

Csobánc is a distinctive 376-meter high "witness hill" in the Tapolca Basin, near Lake Balaton, Hungary. Renowned as one of the most beautiful paragliding locations in the country, it features vineyards at its base and the ruins of a 13th-century castle on its summit. Situated within the Balaton Uplands National Park and the Bakony-Balaton Geopark, Csobánc offers a unique blend of natural beauty and flying adventure.

Flying Conditions

  • Versatile Launch Options: Due to its volcanic shape, launches are possible in almost all directions, offering flexibility based on wind conditions.
  • Suitable Wind Directions: The best wind directions for flying at Csobánc are North (N), Southeast (SE), South (S), Southwest (SW), West (W), and Northwest (NW).
  • Soaring and Thermaling: Csobánc is known for both soaring and thermaling opportunities.

Who Should Fly Here?

Csobánc is suitable for pilots with a medium skill level. While the take-off is also suitable for beginners, the lift zone can become crowded, which may be stressful for less experienced pilots. Both paragliding and tandem flights are permitted.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The site is accessed from the west side via a 15-20 minute walk from the parking area to the take-off. The trail can be accessed from either Diszel or Gyulakeszi. Access to the takeoff area is only by foot, using designated tourist routes.
  • Registration: Flying is permitted only after registration with the Balaton-felvidéki National Park (BfNPI). Only 30 pilots are allowed per day, and registration is mandatory.
  • Fees: There is no admission fee to visit the castle ruins.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • National Park Restrictions: Csobánc is located within a National Park, and strict regulations apply.
  • Seasonal Closure: Flying is strictly prohibited between March 1st and May 31st to protect local wildlife.
