  • Pilot Limit: Be aware that only 30 pilots are allowed to fly per day due to park regulations.
  • Height Restriction: Maximum permitted altitude is 1050 meters at Csobánkai road.
  • Required Documentation: Ensure you possess all valid documents required for paragliding, including club membership.
  • Takeoff Choice: Carefully assess wind and thermal conditions to select the appropriate takeoff location. There are four takeoff locations: near the castle for Southerly winds, a grassy clearing north of the castle for Northwesterly winds, and takeoffs for Southeasterly and Northeasterly winds.
search_recs: Csobánc paragliding official site Csobánc paragliding site information Csobánc siklóernyőzés Csobánc paragliding fees Csobánc paragliding access

html:
Overview

Vértesszőlős is a paragliding site located in Hungary, offering pilots the opportunity to fly in the Vértes Hills. The takeoff point, Öregkovács-hegy, sits at an altitude of 423m, providing a maximum height difference of 203m. Although "Not Certified", the site is listed on paragliding maps, such as Paragliding Map, DHV (Deutscher Hängegleiterverband) and Paragliding Earth.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Suitable for North (N), West (W), and Northwest (NW) winds.
  • Glider Type: Appears suitable for both single and two-seater paragliders.
  • Thermal Forecasts: Detailed thermal forecasts are available on meteoblue, including surface conditions, stability indices, lapse rate, humidity, clouds, and winds.

Who Should Fly Here?

Although popularity is unknown, the site is rated 4 stars on Paragliding Map. Given the relatively low height difference, it is likely suitable for intermediate pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the takeoff point involves a walk.
  • Fees: There are no specific fees mentioned for using the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • General Risks: Be aware of thunderstorms and dense power lines in the area.
  • Thunderstorms: Thunderstorm clouds can be dangerous; avoid storm cells.
  • Power Lines: Dense power lines can be extremely dangerous.
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • Height Limit of 200m AGL (Above Ground Level) and 450m.
    • Local TMA restrictions may apply.
  • General Aviation Rules: Paragliding is subject to general aviation and airspace usage rules.
  • VFR Rules: Pilots must adhere to Visual Flight Rules (VFR).
  • Right-of-way rules: Pilots must adhere to rules about yielding to other aircraft, including the "right-hand rule," slope rule, and thermal rule.
  • Weather Conditions: Strong winds, rain, and thunderstorms can significantly impact safety.
search_recs: Vértesszőlős paragliding access Vértesszőlős paragliding flying conditions Vértesszőlős paragliding site information Vértesszőlős paragliding official site Vértesszőlős sárkányrepülés

html:
Overview

Eged, also known as Nagy-Eged-hegy (Great Eged Hill), is one of the most popular paragliding sites in Hungary, located near Eger. This hill, with its Eocene and Triassic limestone formations, offers a variety of flying experiences from thermal soaring to cross-country flights. The Eged Eagles Siklóernyős Sportegyesület (Paragliding Sports Association) has been associated with the site since 1994, further solidifying its status as a key location for Hungarian paragliding.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: Known for its thermal flying opportunities and cross-country (XC) potential. Ridge soaring is also possible, especially with southerly, southeasterly, and southwesterly winds.
  • Wind Direction: Best conditions are generally found with winds from the Northwest to West (NW-W). Other launch options cater to winds from the South (S) and Southwest (SW) .
  • Thermal Activity: Moderate to medium strength thermals, averaging 2-5 m/s.
  • Cloud Base: Typical cloud bases reach around 2000 meters.

Who Should Fly Here?

Given the potential for thermaling and cross-country flying, Eged is best suited for intermediate to experienced pilots. While the site has hosted competitions and is popular among seasoned flyers, pilots of all skill levels are welcome as long as they are aware of the conditions and their own capabilities.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Good road connections to the landing areas, with dirt roads (suitable for off-road vehicles) leading to the top of the hill from both landing zones.
  • Takeoff Points: Three distinct takeoff points cater to different wind directions: NW-W, SW-S, and S-SE. The SE and SW takeoffs can accommodate approximately 10 gliders simultaneously. The NW takeoff is smaller, allowing only 3-4 gliders at a time.
  • Fees: It's recommended to contact the local club (Eged Eagles) to confirm any fees or requirements associated with site usage or club membership.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather Dependence: Flying is highly dependent on suitable weather conditions, with unpredictable changes possible. Stay updated on forecasts and be prepared for quick shifts.
  • Airspace Restrictions: While some sources indicate no airspace restrictions, other sources list Eged, Eger as within a TRA (Temporary Reserved Airspace). It is vital to confirm current airspace restrictions before flying. The airspace is usually G classification, but a special NOTAM is required for competitions. Always verify airspace regulations before launch.
  • General Aviation Rules: Paragliders are considered aircraft in Hungary, necessitating valid pilot licenses, paraglider technical inspection, and liability insurance.
  • Site Permissions: Flying is only permitted from officially approved launch sites.
  • Nature Conservation: Some start places are located within the Bükk National Park. Check which locations need permission before flying.
search_recs: paragliding sites in Hungary Eged Eged paragliding official site Eged paragliding Hungary Eged paragliding site information Eged hill Hungary paragliding Eged hegy siklóernyőzés

html:
Overview

Csákberény is a popular paragliding site located in Fejér county, Hungary, specifically on Kopasz-domb (Bald Hill) in the Vértes Hills. This site offers thermal soaring opportunities and a chance to enjoy the landscape characterized by rolling hills and the nearby Mór wine region.

Flying Conditions

  • Winds: Known for thermal soaring, especially with southerly winds (South, South-West, and South-East). Flying is permitted only with these wind directions.
  • Thermals: Considered a good thermalling site due to its location on the southern ridge of the Vértes mountains.
  • Launch: Mountain launch site is available.
  • Suitability: Suitable for both paragliding and tandem paragliding flights.
  • Winch Launch: A winch launch site exists near the base of the hill, although its current availability may vary.

Who Should Fly Here?

Csákberény is a popular site, used for training, and suitable for walk & fly activities. While it's accessible to beginners, the presence of thermal activity may make it more suitable for CP rated pilots and above, or those with guidance. All pilots using the site must be registered.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the hilltop launch requires walking.
  • Permissions: To fly from the mountain, you need permission from Asztalos Zoltan Peternel (+36 303854875) because of the private landing area. Approaching the area requires traversing private property, so respect for the landowners is crucial.
  • Pilot Limit: A limit of 10 people at the launch site per day is in place, as per Duna-Ipoly National Park regulations.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Direction: Taking off or landing with other wind directions than South, South-West and South-East is not allowed.
  • Nature Conservation: The launch site is within the Vértes Landscape Protection Area. Non-compliance with park regulations may result in legal action.
  • Altitude Restrictions: Flying below 50 meters over local properties and restaurants (e.g. Catherine's Cottage) is prohibited.
  • Respect for Residents: Pilots are asked to leave the airspace over enclosed gardens quickly.
  • Land Access: The launch site is accessed through private property; respect for these properties is essential. Parking and landing areas are also privately owned.
  • Required Documents: Pilots must have necessary documents, including a start log, medical certificate, and aircraft airworthiness certificate. When using the mountain launch site, a permit for paragliding activities in the area is required.
  • Regulations: Pilots are obligated to comply with nature conservation and aviation regulations, as well as local rules.
search_recs: Csákberény paragliding club Csákberény paragliding site information Csákberény siklóernyőzés

html:
Overview

Nyikom is a paragliding site located near Pásztó in Nógrád County, Hungary. While not featuring high mountains, the hills provide sufficient elevation for enjoyable paragliding and hang gliding experiences. This site is recognized within the Hungarian free flying community and offers opportunities for both thermaling and competition flying.

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable for: Paragliding and Hang Gliding, including tandem flights.
  • Wind Directions: Southwest, West, and Northwest.
  • Thermals: Known to offer thermaling opportunities.

Who Should Fly Here?

Nyikom is suitable for intermediate pilots and above, with evidence of its use in competitions indicating it can cater to more experienced flyers. A skilled pilot even learned to fly at Nyikom.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Hike to takeoff.
  • Fees: No fees associated with the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Natura 2000 Area: Nyikom is located within a Natura 2000 protected area. Technical sports activities require permission from the regional Government Office.
  • Landowner Permission: Entry to the area requires permission from the landowner.
  • Emergency Landing Areas: Limited options for emergency landings due to rocky or rough ground.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Check terkep.legter.hu for airspace limitations on a map.
  • Registration: The site may be subject to restrictions, with flying permitted only after registration.
  • National Park Restrictions: Some sources mention flying is restricted with permits on the site, but other sources say the site is outside of national park area.

Important Note: Pilots should always seek the most current information from local clubs, instructors, and the authorities before flying at Nyikom. Flying is permitted only after registration.
search_recs: paragliding clubs Nyikom Hungary Nyikom paragliding site information paragliding Nyikom Hungary Nyikom paragliding official site Nyikom flying conditions

html:
Overview

Sárhegy is a popular paragliding site located near Gyöngyös, Hungary, in the Mátra mountain range. Offering a launch altitude of 474m and a height difference of approximately 220m, Sárhegy is known for its thermaling and ridge soaring opportunities.

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Directions: Sárhegy is best flown with Southeast (SE) winds, but also accommodates East (E), SouthEast (SE), and South (S) wind directions.
  • Soaring Characteristics: The site is well-suited for both thermaling and ridge soaring.
  • Takeoff Area: The takeoff area features a large, grassy field, providing ample space for preparation and launch.
  • Landing Area: In the event of an unsuccessful flight, pilots can land near the road to Abasár. Always assess potential landing zones before launch.

Who Should Fly Here?

Sárhegy is suitable for both single and tandem paragliders. While not explicitly stated, the site's characteristics suggest it is best suited for intermediate pilots and above who are comfortable with thermaling and ridge soaring techniques. Be aware of other pilots and respect priority rules, especially if the site is busy.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The site is accessible by car, followed by a short walk to the takeoff area.
  • Parking: Parking is available, but pilots are advised to follow specific rules to avoid inconveniencing local residents and landowners. Avoid blocking access roads to farms and respect marked parking areas.
  • For more information, contact the Gyöngyösi Siklóernyős Sport Klub.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Limited Emergency Landing Areas: Be aware that emergency landing areas might be limited, especially if flying from rocky or rough terrain. Always assess potential landing zones before launch.
  • Airspace Regulations: All paragliding activities must comply with Air Traffic Regulations. Paragliding is prohibited within airport approach and takeoff zones without authorization, and activity in controlled airspace requires coordination with air traffic control.
  • Visual Meteorological Conditions: Paragliding activities should only be conducted during daylight hours and in visual meteorological conditions. Pilots must remain clear of clouds and in sight of the ground.

html:
Overview

Tardos is a paragliding site located in Hungary, offering pilots a unique flying experience amidst a gorge nestled between mountains reaching approximately 500 meters in height. The landscape features forests, hiking trails, and interesting rock formations, providing a scenic backdrop for your flight.

Flying Conditions

The takeoff point, Gorbatető / Tardosbánya, sits at 448m altitude and faces East and Southeast, making it suitable for paragliding. While the site is operational year-round, as evidenced by winter paragliding videos, pilots should always check current weather conditions before flying.

Who Should Fly Here?

Tardos is frequently used and likely suitable for intermediate pilots. Pilots should possess the skills and experience to manage the specific challenges posed by the local terrain.

Access & Facilities

The Gorbatető / Tardosbánya takeoff point is accessible by foot, allowing you to enjoy the natural beauty of the area during your ascent.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Pilot Skill: As with any paragliding site, pilot error is a significant risk. Ensure you are flying within your skill level and are prepared for changing conditions.
  • Altitude Limit: Be aware of the local height limit of 450m AGL (Above Ground Level) at Tardos.
  • Airspace Restrictions: Pilots must adhere to VFR (Visual Flight Rules). While specific details are limited, airspace restrictions, possibly including TMA (Terminal Control Area) zones, may be present. Pilots should conduct thorough pre-flight planning to understand any relevant airspace limitations.

html:
Overview

The Elfer, located in Neustift in the Stubaital valley, Tyrol, Austria, is a very popular and well-known paragliding site. Situated in the heart of the Stubai Alps, this classic site offers stunning mountain views and reliable flying conditions. Accessible via the Elferbahnen gondola, it attracts pilots of all skill levels, from beginners to experienced cross-country enthusiasts.

Flying Conditions

  • Soaring and Thermaling: The Elfer is known for excellent soaring conditions, especially in valley winds. It is suitable for ridge soaring and thermaling, offering the potential for cross-country (XC) flights.
  • Year-Round Flying: Flying is possible almost year-round. Summer and late winter/spring offer good thermals, while winter flying is also popular.
  • Valley Winds: Be aware of valley winds, especially in summer. Avoid flying too far into Neustift village, as it may become difficult to reach the landing site.

Who Should Fly Here?

The Elfer is suitable for pilots of all experience levels. It is particularly well-suited for beginners due to its easy takeoffs and predictable winds. The site is also used for various training courses, including basic, intermediate, advanced, and thermal flying. More experienced pilots can enjoy exploring XC options.

Access & Facilities

  • Gondola Access: Access to the primary launch is via the Elferbahnen gondola. A lift ticket is required (approximately 10 euros for a one-way trip).
  • Designated Landing Zone: The landing site is located northeast of the valley station. Landing outside the marked landing zone may lead to legal action for trespassing.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Valley Winds & Jet Effect: Strengthening valley winds can create a strong jet effect in the adjacent Pinnistal valley, making it impossible to exit.
  • Turbulence: Be aware of the risk of turbulence, especially in spring conditions.
  • Designated Areas: Pilots must use only the marked takeoff and landing areas and the designated flight routes.
  • Flight Bans: Adhere to flight regulations and landing area assignments. Flight bans may be announced via the cable car's loudspeaker system (e.g., due to weather conditions, helicopter operations, etc.).
  • No Aerobatics/Speed Flying: Aerobatics and flights with speed flyers or mini-wings are strictly prohibited.
  • Pinnistal Avoidance: Do not fly over the Hennenbichl into the Pinnistal valley (to the right from the takeoff direction).
  • Neustift Village: Avoid flying too far into the village of Neustift, as valley winds may prevent a safe approach to the landing site.
  • Landing Pattern: A left-hand landing pattern with downwind, base, and final approach is required.
  • License & Insurance: A valid Austrian civil pilot's license (or a recognized foreign equivalent) and owner liability insurance with a minimum coverage of EUR 1.5 million are required.
  • Student Pilot Restrictions: Student pilots must be supervised by a certified flight instructor.
  • Minimum Distance: Maintain a minimum distance of 50 meters from various facilities including the launch site, cable car facilities, ski lifts, power lines, ski slopes, and hiking trails.
  • Takeoff Airspace Avoidance: After launch, the airspace in front of and above the launch site must be widely avoided.
search_recs: Elfer paragliding fees Elfer paragliding site guide paragliding Elfer Austria Elfer paragliding requirements

html:
Overview

Verbier, nestled in the heart of the Swiss Alps in Val de Bagnes, Valais, is a renowned paragliding destination. Characterized by its stunning high mountains, glaciers, and alpine valleys, Verbier offers diverse flying experiences, from tandem flights to challenging cross-country adventures.

Flying Conditions

  • Year-Round Flying: Thanks to favorable weather conditions, Verbier allows paragliding throughout the year.
  • Thermal Activity: Les Ruinettes provides thermal columns that enable pilots to gain altitude, even during winter months.
  • Multiple Takeoff Points:
    • Les Ruinettes: Easily accessible via ski lifts from Verbier or Le Châble.
    • Savoleyres: Reached by gondola lift, ideal for soaring.
    • La Tournelle: Offers stunning views of the Combins massif, Mont Blanc, and the Dents du Midi.
  • XC Potential: The site allows for longer XC flights towards the German-speaking part of Valais or the Mont Blanc massif.
  • Winter Flying: Opportunities for speed riding and speed flying during the winter season.

Who Should Fly Here?

Verbier caters to a wide range of pilots:

  • Beginners: Tandem flights are available and require no specific fitness level.
  • Experienced Pilots: Opportunity for cross-country flying, but seeking advice from local pilots is recommended to understand site-specific conditions.

Access & Facilities

  • Les Ruinettes Access: Easily accessible from Verbier or Le Châble using ski lifts.
  • "Paragliding" Pass: A special pass is available for lift access from Le Châble to Les Ruinettes, costing CHF 22.00 for adults. VIP Pass holders may have free access.
  • Travel Time: Approximately 30 minutes by cable car from Le Châble to "Les Ruinettes / Takeoff".
  • Parking: Free parking lot available at Le Châble train station.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Weather: Be prepared for sudden changes in weather conditions. Monitoring forecasts and carrying an anemometer is highly recommended.
  • Avalanche Risk (Winter): The traverse above the reservoir (lake) can be avalanche-prone in February. Pay attention to avalanche warnings.
  • Technical Skills: Avoid taking risks beyond your current skill level. Gain experience gradually.
  • Swiss Licensing: Strict rules apply to paragliding licenses in Switzerland. If you lack a Swiss license, flying with a qualified guide or instructor may be necessary.
  • Airspace Restrictions: XC potential is limited due to surrounding mountains and the Sion airspace.
  • Notice Boards: Check notice boards at launch and landing areas for information on launch directions, landing approaches, flying restrictions, and potentially dangerous areas.
  • Right-of-Way: Be aware of right-of-way rules for paragliders to avoid collisions.
search_recs: Verbier paragliding flying conditions Verbier paragliding site information paragliding Verbier Switzerland Verbier paragliding official site Verbier paragliding access Verbier paragliding fees

html:
Overview

Brändlen is a popular paragliding site located above the village of Wolfenschiessen in the Engelberg valley, canton of Nidwalden, Switzerland. Nestled in the Swiss Alps, this site offers opportunities for both thermaling and ridge soaring, making it a favorite among local pilots and flying schools.

Flying Conditions

  • Take-off Points:
    • North Take-off: Steeper, and best suited for thermic flights in the summer afternoons. Altitude approximately 1219m.
    • South Take-off: Often used in the mornings and winter. Altitude approximately 1247m. Available only from October to March, or when the windsock is mounted.
  • Wind Conditions: The site is well-protected from winds, but pilots should be aware of a strong valley wind (Talwind) that typically develops from 3 PM onwards, offering excellent soaring conditions towards sunset. Be prepared for potentially strong winds, especially at the NW launch.

Who Should Fly Here?

Brändlen is suitable for both single and two-seater paragliders and caters to a range of experience levels. While the nearby Büelen site can be crowded, Brändlen is often less busy.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the take-off is via the Luftseilbahn Brändlen (Brändlen cable car).
  • Cable Car Fees:
    • Single ride: 10.00 CHF
    • 5-ride pass: 45.00 CHF
    • 10-ride pass: 90.00 CHF
    • Annual pass: 330.00 CHF
  • Tickets: Can be purchased at the Kasse/Talstation (ticket office/valley station) with card or TWINT or at the Bergstation (bring small change).
  • Parking: Available at the valley station.
  • Landing Area: Located near the forest edge, northeast of Wolfenschiessen, and a 10-minute walk from the valley station.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Power Lines/Cables: The Engelberg valley is known for having many cables, including the cable car line near the landing area. Exercise extreme caution, especially when flying below the tree line.
  • Strong Valley Wind (Talwind): The valley wind can become very strong in spring and summer.
  • Brändlen NW Launch: Small, moderately steep to steep meadow that can experience crosswinds when the valley wind is strong.
  • CTR Buochs Airspace: Be aware of the CTR (Control Zone) of Buochs, which begins north of a line connecting Buochserhorn and Stanserhorn, particularly for cross-country flights. Carry radio equipment and obtain clearance if entering the CTR.
  • Landing Pattern: When landing at Wolfenschiessen, fly a left-hand pattern with north wind (Talwind) or no wind, and a right-hand pattern with south wind (Bergwind).
  • Landing Zone: Landing is only permitted between the two fences in the area near the creek. Landing near the road or the cable car is strictly prohibited.
  • Winter Landing Area: Only available from November 1st to February 28th, regardless of snow conditions.
  • Footpath: When leaving the landing site, pilots are only allowed to use the forest path to the train station. Walking towards the road or the flight shop is strictly forbidden.
  • Training: Ground handling practice is prohibited at the landing field year-round.

html:
Overview

The Wispile is a popular paragliding site situated south of Gstaad in the picturesque Saanenland region of Switzerland. Characterized by its stunning alpine landscape with mountains, wide fields, valleys, and charming farms, Wispile offers diverse flying opportunities for pilots of varying skill levels.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermals: Wispile is renowned for its reliable thermals, making it an excellent location for thermal beginners to hone their skills.
  • Take-Off Sites: Three distinct take-off sites cater to different wind directions – East, West, and North – ensuring optimal launch conditions.
  • Flight Directions: Flying is possible in a variety of directions, including Southeast to Northeast, Southwest to Northwest, Northwest to Northeast to Southeast, and West to Northwest.
  • Microclimate: The Saanenland region is known for its unique microclimate, which can produce surprisingly favorable flying weather, even when forecasts are less promising. Pilots should remain vigilant for sudden changes in conditions.
  • Valley Winds: Valley winds are generally light, seldom exceeding 20-25 km/h. However, the landing site in Rougemont may experience stronger winds in the afternoon.
  • Soaring: Excellent soaring opportunities can be found at Rodomont and Horneggli in westerly wind conditions. Glacier 3000 offers high alpine flight potential under ideal conditions.
  • Wind Indicators: It is advisable to check the windsocks located on Wispile and at official landing sites to assess current wind conditions.

Who Should Fly Here?

Wispile's accessibility and consistent thermals make it a favorite among pilots of various experience levels. It is particularly well-suited for thermal beginners. However, other sites in the vicinity offer varying levels of difficulty, with Videmanette recommended only for experienced pilots.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the Wispile take-off sites is conveniently provided by the Wispile gondola from Gstaad. Gstaad is accessible by train to Zweisimmen then a change to Gstaad, or via the MOB train from Montreux.
  • Take-Off Sites: A short walk (2-10 minutes) from the mountain station leads to the various launch sites.
  • Landing Sites: Designated landing areas are located at the Wispilebahn valley station in Gstaad, next to the church in Rougemont, and at the Rellerli cable car valley station in Schönried.
  • Ticketing: A discounted mountain ascent is available with the Swiss Travel Pass/GA travelcard. Tickets can be purchased upon arrival at the station.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Microclimate: The Saanenland microclimate, while often advantageous, can result in rapid and unexpected changes in weather conditions.
  • Cables & Electric Lines: While generally not an issue when adhering to official take-off and landing procedures, pilots must maintain a safe distance from cables and electric lines.
  • Wispile EAST: Be cautious of potential sinking conditions in the afternoons when launching from Wispile East. Good Thermals in the morning.
  • Landing Sites: Always use the official landing sites. If possible, land on mowed meadows, and avoid packing your glider in high grass.
  • Airspace: Paragliders are permitted to fly in airspaces G and E, adhering to VFR rules as per SERA 5001.

html:
Overview

Rütiberg, also known as Bisehoger, is a paragliding site in the lower Emmental region near Hasle bei Burgdorf, Switzerland. Characterized by rolling hills and farmland, this site offers opportunities for ridge soaring and regional thermaling during "Bise" conditions (a north-easterly wind).

Flying Conditions

  • Wind Conditions: Best flown during moderate "Bise" conditions with wind from the north-east (from the direction of Rüegsau). Avoid flying when the wind is from the east (Lützelflüh).
  • Turbulence: Increased wind speeds at higher altitudes (measured at Bantiger) can lead to turbulent conditions.
  • Soaring and Thermaling: Primarily suited for ridge soaring and regional thermaling flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Rütiberg is not suitable for student pilots or beginners. Pilots must be proficient in strong wind launches and reverse inflation techniques. Expect company in good conditions, as up to sixty paragliders can be in the air simultaneously.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: A 30-minute walk from the parking area near the shooting range (Schützenhaus).
  • Car Access: In exceptional cases, car access is possible via a signposted route. Check with the Gleitschirmclub Emmental.
  • One-Way Traffic: Voluntary "Einbahnverkehr" (one-way traffic) on the last steep section to the launch site.
  • Official Site: Maintained by the Gleitschirmclub Emmental (GCE). Official information, including airspace regulations and landing information, can be found on the GCE website.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Airspace: Located in uncontrolled airspace G/E. Marked with a danger symbol (Delta) on the ICAO map.
  • Reporting Point "Echo": The reporting point "Echo," used by aircraft approaching Bern Airport is located immediately east of the Rütiberg launch site. Motorized aircraft must fly over this point at a minimum altitude of 1100 meters above sea level (340 meters above the launch site). Observe airspace carefully.
  • Firing Range: Significant airspace restriction when the Hasle b. Burgdorf shooting range is in operation. An absolute flight ban is in place north of the launch site when the red and white flag is displayed at the shooting range.

html:
Overview

Le Cernil is a paragliding site nestled in the rolling hills and meadows of the Jura region in Switzerland. Known for its evening flying opportunities, it offers pilots a chance to experience the Swiss landscape from above.

Flying Conditions

  • This site is popular for evening flights.
  • A glide ratio of at least 6 is required to safely fly over the forest.

Access & Facilities

  • Access Route 1: From Corgemont, take the tarred road that passes by the shooting range in the direction of the Anabaptists' bridge (Pont des Anabaptistes).
  • Access Route 2: Alternatively, access the site from Orvin, then proceed through Pres-d'Orvin, Métairie de Prales, Métairie de Gleresse, and finally to Pont des Anabaptistes.
  • Parking: Parking spaces are available along the roadside before exiting the forest. Please refrain from parking in the pastures.
  • Takeoff Access: After parking, pass the turnstile and walk along the wall for approximately 150 meters to reach the takeoff area.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Aerodrome of Courtelary: Be aware of the nearby aerodrome of Courtelary.
  • Airspace Restrictions:
    • In Switzerland, airspace above 3950 meters AMSL (Above Mean Sea Level) on weekdays and 4450 meters AMSL on weekends and after 17:05 is off-limits to paragliders.
    • Only airspace classified as E and G are authorized for free flights.
  • Visual Flight Rules (VFR): Flying must adhere to Visual Flight Rules. Cloud flying and night flying are strictly forbidden.
  • Swiss Airspace: In Switzerland, uncontrolled airspace G extends from the ground to 600m AGL (Above Ground Level), except for control zones (CTR). Controlled airspace E does not require clearance but pilots must observe visual flight rules.

html:
Overview

Monte Lema, situated in Ticino, Switzerland, near Lugano, stands at 1,624 meters (5,328 feet) and is renowned as one of Switzerland's most stunning paragliding locations. This grassy mountain offers panoramic views of the Ticino lakes (Lugano and Maggiore), the snow-capped Alps of Canton Bern, and the Valais peaks with their glaciers.

Flying Conditions

  • Thermal Hotspot: Monte Lema is famous for its exceptional thermal conditions, enabling experienced pilots to achieve altitudes exceeding 3,000 meters.
  • Versatile Flying Options: Enjoy diverse flying experiences, including gliding, ridge soaring towards Monte Tamaro, and cross-country flights over 200 km towards Valtellina or Engadina.
  • Take-off Area: The large, grassy take-off area is suitable for launches in almost all directions, typically SE or SW (for evening flights).
  • Best Time to Fly: Year-round flights are possible, with optimal conditions from spring to autumn, typically between 9 AM and 5 PM.
  • Landing Zones: Choose between the official landing zones in Sessa (ideal for less experienced pilots) and Miglieglia (closer to the cable car, but potentially challenging due to thermal activity, especially in spring).

Who Should Fly Here?

Monte Lema welcomes pilots of all skill levels. Less experienced pilots can enjoy safe landings in Sessa, while experienced pilots can take advantage of the outstanding thermal and cross-country opportunities. Tandem flights are available for those without prior paragliding experience.

Access & Facilities

  • Cable Car Access: Reach the take-off site via a scenic 10-minute cable car ride from Miglieglia, covering an altitude difference of 849m, followed by a short 10-minute walk.
  • Cable Car Fees: Note that cable car fees apply. Ticino Ticket holders enjoy free travel to Miglieglia (cable car fare separate), while the Swiss Travel Pass offers free travel to Miglieglia and a reduced cable car fare.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Foehn Wind: Beware of the dangerous Foehn wind from the north, and refrain from taking off under such conditions.
  • Thermal Turbulence: Landing in Miglieglia can be challenging during midday, especially in spring, due to strong thermal activity.
  • Model Aircraft: Be considerate of model airplanes operating in the area.
  • Flight Regulations: Respect all relevant legislation in the countries affected by your flight.
  • Airspace Declaration: Flights crossing non-active airspace (HX, Tower OFF...) or authorized crossings must be indicated on XContest.
  • GPS Requirement: The use of GPS is mandatory during competitions.

html:
Overview

Loarre is a popular paragliding site located in the province of Huesca, Aragon, in northeastern Spain. Situated near the impressive Castillo de Loarre, a Romanesque castle dating back to the 11th century, the takeoff point sits at an altitude of 1,071 meters above sea level, offering stunning views of the castle and the surrounding plains as you fly.

Flying Conditions

  • Type of Flying: The site is well-suited for thermaling and ridge soaring, offering scenic flights over the castle and surrounding landscapes.
  • Wind Directions: Optimal wind directions are S, SW, and SE. Valley wind typically crosses from South to Southeast. Northwest winds above can also create favorable conditions.
  • Seasonality: Flying is possible throughout the year, weather permitting. March and Spring are often considered good times to visit, but mid-summer can bring strong conditions.
  • Weather Considerations: Caution is advised when strong north winds from the high mountains or west winds from the Atlantic are present. Checking the weather forecast is essential.
  • Thermic Conditions: The site is known to become very thermic, especially around midday. Pilots should be prepared for strong thermal activity and potential turbulence. Expect lift of 300-600m above take-off, but it can reach up to 1000m in good conditions.
  • Wind Considerations: The takeoff area often experiences crosswinds from the left. Pilots should be experienced in dealing with crosswind launches.

Who Should Fly Here?

Loarre is generally considered an easy site, suitable for paragliding at all experience levels. Tandem flights are available for beginners with no prior experience. However, novice pilots should be aware of the potential for strong thermic activity and turbulence during peak hours and be prepared to handle crosswind launches.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the takeoff is by car, following a forest trail/broken road leading from Loarre towards the Castillo de Loarre. A relatively long drive along the paved forest road is required. You then turn onto a dirt road towards a large meadow; the launch site is at the end of the road. Some operators provide transport to the takeoff point.
  • Fees: Tandem paragliding flights are offered commercially, with prices starting around €75 for a 20-minute flight, often including transportation and photo/video packages. There doesn't appear to be a fee to use the site if you are not flying commercially.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Thermic Conditions: The site is known to become very thermic, especially around midday. Novice pilots should be aware of this risk and potentially avoid flying during peak thermic hours.
  • Wind Conditions: The takeoff area often experiences crosswinds from the left. Pilots should be experienced in dealing with crosswind launches.
  • Airspace: Be aware of and avoid flying in controlled airspace without authorization. Paragliding is generally permitted in Class E, F, and G airspaces.
  • Minimum Altitudes: In Spain, adhere to general minimum altitude regulations:
    • Over congested areas: 300m (1000 ft) above the highest obstacle within a 600m radius.
    • Elsewhere: 150m (500 ft) above the ground or water, or 150m (500 ft) above the highest obstacle within a 150m radius.
  • Regulations: Comply with all Spanish paragliding rules and regulations.
  • Insurance: Civil liability insurance is essential to cover potential damages to third parties during flights.

Recommendations: It is highly recommended to seek local knowledge and guidance before flying at Loarre. Always check the weather forecast, ensure you have appropriate insurance, and respect the environment and local regulations.

html:
Overview

Serra do Larouco is a popular paragliding site located in Montalegre, northern Portugal, near the Spanish border. Boasting the third-highest elevation in Continental Portugal at 1535 meters, it offers a mountainous landscape with a mix of low hills, flatlands, and higher ridges, making it a prime location for cross-country flying and thermaling.

Flying Conditions

  • Best Time to Fly: While flying is possible year-round, the best conditions for thermal flights are typically from May to August.
  • Thermals: Expect strong thermals and high cloudbases during the summer months.
  • Sea Breezes: Afternoon sea breezes often create excellent "glass-off" conditions, ideal for smooth soaring.
  • Wind Conditions: Mornings can be windy, with conditions generally improving in the afternoon. Be prepared for potentially gusty conditions.
  • Multiple Take-off Points: Several take-off points accommodate different wind directions.
  • Convergence: Known for safe flying with convergence conditions allowing for long flights.

Who Should Fly Here?

Larouco is considered suitable for all pilot skill levels, from beginner to advanced. Its popularity has led to hosting several top-level events, including Paragliding World Cups and European Championships. However, pilots should be aware that mornings can be windy, requiring appropriate skill and judgment.

Access & Facilities

  • Easy Access: Access is straightforward, with an asphalt road leading directly to the take-off areas.
  • Fees: There is no mention of fees associated with using the site.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Wind Conditions: Strong and gusty wind conditions can occur, particularly in the morning. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather. Task cancellation due to strong winds is possible.
  • Launch Site Awareness: Multiple launch sites exist, including a main launch, a north launch (described as tiny), and a south launch. Consider each site's specific wind direction suitability and size constraints.
  • Airspace Regulations: It's crucial to be aware of and adhere to Portuguese airspace regulations. Paragliding near airports is strictly prohibited without prior authorization, and any aerial activity in controlled airspace requires coordination with air traffic control.
  • Licensing and Insurance: Ensure you have the necessary licenses and insurance. Non-FPVL (Federação Portuguesa de Voo Livre) pilots may need proof of insurance with specific coverage amounts.
  • General Air Navigation Order: Pilots must not recklessly or negligently endanger any person or property. Flights are only allowed within designated flying areas.

html:
Overview

Linhares da Beira, a medieval village nestled in the heart of Portugal near the Serra da Estrela, is home to one of the country's most renowned paragliding sites. Known as the "Cathedral of Portuguese Paragliding," Linhares offers a unique flying experience with its stunning granite mountain landscape and reliable thermaling conditions.

Flying Conditions

Linhares is suitable for both paragliding and hang gliding, accommodating single and tandem flights. The site is celebrated for its thermaling opportunities and cross-country (XC) potential. In fact, the 200 km XC mark was first broken in Europe here!

  • Best Time to Fly: May to the end of August.
  • Prevailing Winds: Southwest, West, Northwest, and North.
  • Takeoff: The sloped takeoff area ensures safe launches in various wind directions.
  • Thermals: Resident thermals near the viewpoint allow pilots to climb and stay on the ridge.
  • Altitude: Takeoff is at 1152m AMSL, with an altitude above the valley of 450m.

Who Should Fly Here?

Linhares is considered an accessible site, attracting both seasoned professionals and beginners alike. Its forgiving conditions make it an excellent location for pilots of all experience levels.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: The takeoff is 6.5km from the official landing, including 5km on paved road and 1.5km on a dirt road. This translates to a 15-minute drive.
  • Climbing Card: To fly independently, pilots need to acquire a climbing card at the Operations Center or with the landing official.
  • Landing Area: A large, official landing field is located near the village entrance.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

Safety is paramount. Be aware of the following potential risks and restrictions:

  • Fire Risk: Flying may be restricted during periods of very high fire risk, as determined by IPMA. Check the Fire Risk Index before flying, especially in protected areas.
  • Weather: Watch out for strong gusts or sudden weather changes. Use an anemometer to assess wind strength and direction. Spring conditions can be stronger than autumn conditions.
  • Airspace: Be aware of local airspace restrictions, especially near airports. Normal maximum altitude allowed for events in the area is about 3000m ASL.
  • General Restrictions: Paragliding activities should only be conducted during daylight hours and in visual meteorological conditions. Pilots must remain clear of clouds and in sight of the ground at all times.
  • Power Lines & Trees: Be mindful of power lines crossing the valley and trees at the top of the landing field.
search_recs: Clube vuelo libre Linhares Portugal Linhares Portugal paragliding site guide paragliding Linhares Portugal paragliding Portugal site regulations

html:
Overview

Col de la Forclaz is a world-renowned paragliding site located in Haute-Savoie, France. Situated at an altitude of 1250-1280 meters above sea level, this mountain pass offers breathtaking panoramic views of Lake Annecy and the surrounding Aravis and Bornes massifs. Known for its excellent thermaling and cross-country (XC) flying opportunities, it attracts pilots from around the globe.

Flying Conditions

  • Suitable for: Paragliding, hang gliding, mini gliding, acrobatics, hike-and-fly, SIV training, and tandem flights.
  • Thermals: The site benefits from generous thermals and a significant valley breeze, making it ideal for soaring and XC flights.
  • Wind Direction:
    • West and Northwest facing slopes: Generally favored due to the breeze.
    • Southeast faces: Can be more turbulent.
    • South winds: The site is sensitive to south winds due to the north-western orientation of the take-off. Can create very turbulent flights in the Montmin and Rocher du Roux area

Who Should Fly Here?

Col de la Forclaz is popular with pilots of all skill levels. However, due to its popularity, especially during the summer months (June-August), the site can experience high traffic. Pilots should be aware of potentially crowded conditions and adhere to flight rules. A regulator is often present at take-off during the summer to ensure safety.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: Access to the take-off is regulated by the Talloires-Montmin town council. Options include:
    • Walking up (about 20 minutes).
    • Taking a taxi-bus from Doussard to the landing area.
    • Using an access card: A rechargeable access card can be purchased at the Talloires Town Hall.
  • Parking: Parking fees apply from May to November. The upper parking lot is reserved for shuttles, schools, tandem pilots, and the disabled.
  • Landing: Common landing area is at Doussard, a large field designed for landing.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • High Traffic: Especially in summer, increasing the risk of collisions. Respect flight rules!
  • Turbulence: Especially on Southeast faces and in specific wind conditions.
  • SIV Area: A designated area above the lake for SIV training. Pilots not participating in SIV courses should avoid this area. Landing on the SIV beach if you are not part of the SIV course is forbidden.
  • Cable on La Tournette: A hard-to-see cable runs on the Montagne de la Tournette from the Tournette refuge towards the Pré Verel refuge on the west face.
  • Takeoff Risks:
    • Col de la Forclaz - Montmin - Coche Cabanne Takeoff: Can be delicate in northerly winds due to strong rotors. Landing with tailwind regarding the lake and HT-Line.
    • Montmin: Southerly winds can place pilots in the lee, potentially causing very turbulent flights. Strong south winds make take-off impossible or very dangerous (tailwind).
  • Restricted Airspace: It is forbidden to fly over the natural reserve at the end of the lake below 200m above ground level (AGL).
  • Doussard Landing: When landing facing the lake, be careful not to fly downwind of the gymnasium.
  • Landing Zones: The landing area in Doussard is divided: the left side is reserved for hang gliders/ULMs, and the right side for paragliders.
  • Takeoff Regulations: Access to the Col de la Forclaz takeoff by vehicle is restricted and requires a paid access badge.
search_recs: Col de la Forclaz paragliding official website Col de la Forclaz paragliding site guide Col de la Forclaz paragliding regulations Col de la Forclaz paragliding access and fees paragliding Col de la Forclaz site description

html:
Overview

Montlambert is a popular paragliding site nestled in the Savoie region of France, within the town of Saint-Jean-de-la-Porte. Located in the heart of the Parc Naturel Régional du Massif des Bauges, a UNESCO Global Geopark, it offers stunning views of wooded valleys, alpine pastures, and rocky summit ridges. Known for its reliable northerly conditions, Montlambert provides opportunities for ridge soaring, thermaling, and cross-country (XC) flying.

Flying Conditions

  • Best Conditions: Northerly winds, even strong ones, are ideal. The south orientation allows for early starts.
  • Morning Site: Montlambert is best enjoyed in the morning.
  • Thermal Activity: From 11:00 AM, thermal activity and valley breezes can become sustained.
  • Wind Caution: Moderate southwest to west winds require caution.
  • Turbulence: Be aware of potential turbulence, especially near the Dent d'Arclusaz, which can cause strong flaps and reduced horizontal speed.

Who Should Fly Here?

Montlambert attracts a wide range of pilots, including local paragliding schools. The site is considered of medium difficulty, making it suitable for intermediate to advanced pilots. All pilots are expected to drive slowly and respect local residents due to the site's fragility.

Access & Facilities

  • Access: From Montmélian, take the D201 towards Saint-Pierre d'Albigny. Before Saint-Jean-de-la-Porte, take the road on the left towards Montlambert and drive to the right.
  • Parking: Mandatory parking in the designated parking lot before the hamlet.
  • Hike & Launch: A 5-10 minute walk from the parking lot to the take-off.
  • Road Restrictions: Speed limit of 40 km/h, or even 30 km/h maximum, both uphill and downhill on the access road. Stopping is not authorized on the Montlambert U-turn.

Risks & Airspace Considerations

  • Valley Breeze: The valley breeze can become strong by the end of the morning.
  • Thermal Activity: Strong thermal activity from 11:00 AM can create challenging conditions.
  • Power Lines and Railway: High-tension power lines and a railway line are located upstream of the landing area.
  • Takeoff Area: The left part of the takeoff has a slight flat area, requiring attention during launch.
  • Downwind Takeoff: Avoid taking off downwind with moderate South West to West winds.
  • "Getting Out of the Jar": With northerly winds, remain vigilant and avoid "getting out of the jar" (further clarification needed).
  • PTU (Autorisation de Transport Unitaire): A mandatory PTU is required due to the site's popularity and location (further research needed).
  • Railway, Power Line, and Orchards: Avoid flying over the railway line, power line, and quince orchards at medium altitude.
  • Landing Approach: Avoid arriving too low on approach to landing due to a railway line and trees at the edge of the field. Use a proper downwind-to-base-to-final approach (PTU).
  • Airspace: Consult local airspace regulations at https://hehol.fr/gliding?points=6.10480_45.55290&radius=10.
search_recs: Montlambert paragliding site official information paragliding Montlambert France Montlambert paragliding access fees
